DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Reverse logistics center unnecessary

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo recently proposed that a reverse logistics center be set up in Kaohsiung Harbor to enhance the port's competitiveness. The feasibility and importance of this proposal requires in-depth study and discussion.
If the minister has hired professionals to assess the proposal's feasibility, the first thing they will look at is Taiwan's comparative advantages, including its maintenance and logistics costs.

Maintenance relies mainly on the labor force. With Taiwan's relatively high wages, most maintenance will probably incur higher costs in Taiwan than in other developing countries in the region. Taiwan is competitive only in maintenance work that requires complex skills or expensive equipment.

Taiwan does not enjoy an obvious competitive edge in terms of logistics costs, either. Many people, including President Ma Ying-jeou, have often claimed that Taiwan is positioned in the center of East Asia, with the sailing time between Kaohsiung and other major ports in the region averaging only 53 hours. However, this comparison does not take into account the South Korean port of Busan and the Chinese ports of Shenzhen, Qingdao, Ningbo, Guangzhou and Tianjin, all of which can also be considered centrally located in terms of sailing times.

We must recognize the fact that Kaohsiung does not have a particularly advantageous geographical position, and biased figures should not be allowed to mislead our future policy direction. (May 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA likely to be inked in June: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 15:09:00 (By He Meng-kuei, Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will likely be signed in mid-June if all goes smoothly, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou said at a legislative session Monday.

Huang was responding to media reports that said the fifth round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, is scheduled to be held June 15-20 in Shanghai.

According to the United Daily News, Taiwan and China had planned to defer the fifth Chiang-Chen meeting to July, but decided to hold the negotiations as scheduled after most significant details were ironed out.
The proposed trade pact will be the main focus of the fifth round of cross- strait talks and is therefore expected to be signed during the meeting, Huang said.
Huang said talks on the pact's "early harvest lists" have entered the final stage, but the content of the lists cannot be made public because negotiations are still underway.
Asked whether the trade pact will be signed by June 15, Huang said: "That is our goal, and we will work toward achieving it."

Meanwhile, Huang Chih-peng, director general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, a major negotiator on the ECFA issues during the previous rounds of unofficial talks with China, said that the planning of the fifth Chiang-Chen meeting has being handled by the SEF and ARATS and that he knows nothing about the details.
Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang also said that he has not received any information about the matter and refused to comment on what progress has been made on the "early harvest lists."

However, he said during a business forum that China has become the major manufacturing center and the biggest consumption market in the world, and that Taiwanese businesses with alliances to Chinese firms will see their value boosted if the pact is signed.

Noting that Taiwanese businesses in China have collaborated with their Chinese counterparts for about 20 years, Shih said they can take advantage of their standing in China to explore the vast Chinese market.
Taiwan will be the ideal partner for multi-national enterprises eager to venture into the Chinese market, because of a shared culture and language, Shih added.

The minister also said that the government plans to invest NT$24 billion (US$750 million) over the next five years to develop the cloud computing industry and would spend NT$12.7 billion in research and development with the aim of creating 50,000 jobs and NT$1 trillion in turnover for the industry.
Meanwhile, the administration has tried to help the manufacturing industry generate NT$100 billion in production value, Shih said.

He added that about half of information technology (IT) spare parts worldwide are made in Asia, with the production value of the IT parts sector of Taiwan, Hong Kong and China accounting for two-thirds of the total in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 1.07 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 15:30:48 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 1.07 percent Monday on active bargain hunting as investors shrugged off a Wall Street fall at the end of last week, dealers said.

Gains in other major regional markets, including Japan and South Korea, also prompted investors in Taiwan to take advantage of recent heavy losses, leaving behind worries about tensions on the Korean Peninsula, they said.
The weighted index closed up 78.66 points at the day's high of 7,373.98, off an earlier low of 7,292.54, with turnover at NT$67.93 billion (US$2.12 billion).

The cement sector posted the biggest gains, up 1.33 percent, followed by the paper sector's 1.18 percent, the construction sector's 1.17 percent, the plastics and chemicals sector's 1.11 percent and the financial sector's 1.05 percent.
The food sector closed up 1.01 percent, the machinery and electronics sector rose 0.97 percent and the textile sector was 0.2 percent higher.
A total of 1,489 stocks closed up and 1,168 down, with 363 unchanged.
"After last week's heavy losses, investors tended to pick up stocks with attractive valuations, in particular small and medium shares," President Securities analyst Vickie Hsieh said.
Hsieh said old-economy stocks remained the favorites of bargain hunters.
She said investors rushed to buy cement and construction stocks after the government announced a three-stage plan to expand Taipei's Songshan Airport to accommodate more passenger and cargo flights.
"The airport expansion plan could boost demand in the cement and construction sectors, as well as dress up their bottom lines, " Hsieh said.
Universal Cement gained 1.80 percent to NT$14.15 and Taiwan Cement added 1.30 percent to NT$27.35.
Dacin Construction gained 6.76 percent to NT$18.15 and Hung Poo Real Estate rose 2.69 percent to NT$41.95.
China Airlines closed up 4.23 percent at NT$14.80 on hopes that growing demand for cross-strait air links will boost its earnings, dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President advocates restraint in exercising power
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 16:09:49 (By Garfie Li and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The late U.S. President Thomas Jefferson, who advocated soft power, would have nodded in his tomb if he heard President Ma Ying-jeou saying Monday that those with power should know restraint when exercising it.

Paraphrasing Jefferson's quote of 1815 that "the less we use our power, the greater it will be, " Ma made the comments during a meeting with the representatives of the Judges Association of the Republic of China (Taiwan) at the Presidential Office.
He told them he has in the past expressed reservations about appeals from several civic groups to preside over judicial reforms by setting up a committee under his office.
"I don't want to make the Office of the President a supreme executive organization," the president said.
Under the Constitution, the president is chief of state, while the premier heads the government.

Judicial reform such as the protection of human rights does not always require legislation or promulgation by the president. It can sometimes simply be a case of setting precedent, said the president, who holds a doctorate in law from Harvard.
However, the president complained that his reluctance to interfere with the judiciary is often held up by critics as evidence that he is "spineless."
"My efforts to keep the judiciary free from interference have sometimes not gone down well with those who do not see eye to eye with me on the meaning of justice," Ma observed.
The president touted his administration's efforts to end investigators' illegal eavesdropping, adding that eavesdropping should only be conducted when absolutely necessary and legal.
Ever since investigators have had to seek court approval to carry out eavesdropping, the numbers of eavesdropping applications have fallen significantly, he said.
The president also promised to support the association's bid to host the 2011 annual conference of the International Association of Judges (IAJ).

Noting that the IAJ is one of only a few international non-government organizations to which the country has been admitted under its official name of Republic of China, the president said Taiwan can use the occasion to enhance its international profile and showcase the independence of its judiciary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Almost third of job seekers encounter fraud: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 16:25:58 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: More than 30 percent of job seekers said they had encountered fraud, with young females the most common victims, according to the results of a recent survey.

Of 1,085 job seekers who responded to a poll by 1111 job bank, 32.58 percent said they had encountered dishonest employers, and of those who reported the experience, the average person had run into the problem twice.
Two surveys were conducted by the job bank from May 13-28, with one focusing on dangers that job seekers face and the other on what companies value during recruitment.
The most problems were reported in the service sector and the information technology industry, with people seeking sales, trade and management positions the most likely targets.

The biggest problem job seekers face is that their actual work does not fit the description advertised or what was discussed in interviews. If they discovered the fraud, 55.45 percent said they would decline the offer right away. Some 54.46 percent of those who had the experience said it had affected their confidence in applying for other jobs.
More than 60 percent said they would take measures to prevent the problem, such as looking for information about the companies before an interview or declining an interview in an odd location.

According to the other survey of 384 companies, 97.6 percent said punctuality is important in their hiring decisions, and 79.64 percent said they expect applicants to provide detailed cover letters describing themselves along with their resumes. Some 53 percent said the resume should include a photo of the applicant.
Top reasons companies gave for rejecting applicants included supplying a false resume, being late for an interview and knowing nothing about the job.

The survey also showed 33.63 percent of the companies have experience with applicants who don't show up for interviews. Some 36.53 percent of companies said they would not give a second chance to candidates who don't show up for an interview without an excuse or those hired who fail to report to work.

DOC.HEADLINE: French, Taiwanese photographers record Taiwan's contrasts

TEXT.P: What are the differences in the photos taken by a French and a local photographer?

One such French photographer is Eric Rechsteiner, a freelancer based in Tokyo who has spent more than seven years collecting the faces of Taiwanese people with his camera and who has recently been searching for a Taiwanese publisher to publish a series of photos as part of a project titled "Facing Taipei."

Asked why he chose to come to Taiwan, the photographer could not explain the exact reason. "Probably because I am from Japan, I feel Taipei is a place with a combination of new and old, a relaxing and serious atmosphere, which is what caught my eye the first time I came here about 12 years ago," he said.
"Since then, I have come to Taiwan almost every year, and it is like a second home to me now," he told CNA in an interview.
Since he cannot speak Mandarin, Rechsteiner communicates with people here using his cameras. Asked how many photos he has taken, he replied simply: "Too many to count."

Looking at his pictures, there is one of a little boy praying in the temple, while others show a grandmother bathing a baby in a basin on the street, a couple having their wedding photos taken by the Tamsui River and many others, all of which reflect the contrasts of a city that is modern but still has a great deal of older areas, as well as the contrasts in the relaxed yet sometimes rather serious expressions on his subjects' faces.

Shooting Taipei for so many years, Rechsteiner worries that the old Taipei is gradually disappearing, just as with other Asian cities. "The past is important, but those old brick houses in Taipei have been gradually vanishing in recent years," he said.

Compared with Rechsteiner's work, a Taiwanese photographer shows another side of Taiwan, in that most of her photos over the last seven years have been taken in the southern and western parts of Taiwan or on the outlying islands such as Kinmen and Matsu.

"I have taken over 200,000 photos in almost seven years, " said 20-year-old Shen Hsin-ling, a sophomore at National Tsing Hua University who has already held exhibitions in Taipei and Beijing in 2008.
She records the lives of farmers and poor people, most of whom live in southwestern Taiwan, and her purpose is to reveal their difficulties and their needs to the public.
Growing up in Yunlin County, in the central part of Taiwan, Shen has been involved in charity work since she was 12.
She has helped her hometown to promote agricultural products using the Internet and has also established a free website to teach children, work that has brought her many awards and honors.
"The reason I record people's lives in remote areas of Taiwan is because I am planning to set up a database for people here in the future," she told CNA.

Asked why, Shen said it is because she has witnessed many of the senior generation passing away and wonders what the situation will be 10 years from now, "so I felt I could not hesitate any more and that I had to do something."
During her shooting trips, she said, she prefers chatting with local people, trying to understand their lives and telling their stories with her photos.

Among her photos is one titled "Red Envelope." She said she will never forget that story. "It was an old woman in the countryside many years ago. I saw her and greeted her, whereupon the woman smiled at me and told me she received `a red envelope' today, " Shen said.

I thought at first that she had probably won the lottery or received a gift that day, but instead, her answer was that one of her thumbs was bleeding, " she said, adding that the woman, an oyster farmer, had cut her thumb while working.
The old grandmother told that it was nothing and that she was happy just to have the ability to work and earn money to support her family.

"I have many stories about things that have happened on my journeys and I will keep taking photos to illustrate those stories, " Shen said, adding that she will publish her photos next year in an effort to speak out for those vulnerable groups in society. Photo Nos. 43, 44 (By Sunnie Chen, CNA staff reporter)/J .

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes up on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 16:52:55 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, rising NT$0.05 to close at the day's high of NT$32.225.
Turnover totaled US$647 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$32.175 and then moved to a low of 31.957 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to hold anti-ECFA events in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 17:38:47 (By Sophia Yeh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will kick off a series of rallies in Kaohsiung on June 5 to promote a national referendum on a proposed trade pact with China, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said Monday.
A "made in Taiwan" market fair featuring locally made products and craftwork will be held at Glory Pier in the afternoon before the rally, Tsai said.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, elected DPP officials, academics and experts will review the current administration's performance as well as address the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in the evening, Tsai added.
The events are expected to attract 10,000 participants, the spokesman said.

The Executive Yuan's Referendum Review Committee is slated to meet on June 3 to decide whether a referendum proposal initiated by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) conforms to legal requirements.
Tsai Chi-chang expressed hope that members of the committee will ensure people's rights to express their will through a referendum and not to use political maneuvering or bureaucracy to hinder them.

He added that because the ECFA is crucial and will lead to a large redistribution of wealth in Taiwan, the government should allow the public to participate in discussions and the decision-making process.

In a protest against the government's plan to complete the signing of the proposed ECFA with China in June, the TSU, pro-independence groups and former Premier Frank Hsieh held anti-ECFA sit-ins and speeches around the country earlier in the month.

The government says the proposed ECFA will boost economic growth in Taiwan and prevent the island from being marginalized, but critics have said it will lead to job losses and could make Taiwan too economically dependent on and politically vulnerable to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mediated solution not an option for Taiwan in Lafayette case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 17:51:08 (By Lee Ming-tsung, Hsieh Chia-chen, Su Lung-chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan did not renege on a tacit agreement to solve the Lafayette frigate case dispute with France as has been reported and will not opt for a mediated solution in the future, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday.
The ministry said in a statement that it has not made contact with French defense contractor Thales over a possible out-of-court settlement and that it would resolve the case based on the law.
"We insist that the dispute be solved in accordance with the verdict of the International Court of Arbitration under the International Chamber of Commerce," the MND said.

The ICC court on May 3 ordered contractor Thales and the French government to pay a penalty of more than US$591 million to Taiwan for paying commissions on the sale of six Lafayettte-class frigates to the country's Navy in 1991, in violation of the contract on the deal.

The Liberty Times reported Monday that because Taiwan reneged on a consensus that the commission dispute would be solved out of court, France is closing down its military liaison office under its de facto embassy in Taiwan, the French Institute in Taipei.

The Chinese-language newspaper also said that as part of an out-of-court settlement, France had agreed to sell new weapons to Taiwan, help raise the technical levels of the Lafayette frigates and French-made Mirage jet fighters, and offer more technical services to Taiwan's military.

The MND denied the report, saying it was completely off base. It said that logistics, technical maintenance and personnel training related to the Lafayette frigates and Mirage fighters have proceeded smoothly and normally according to existing contracts.
If the contracts were violated, Taiwan's military could sue the French suppliers, the MND statement said.

The court case was launched in 2001 by Taiwan's Navy to investigate claims that much of the US$2.8 billion paid for the warships were for commissions to middlemen, politicians and military officers in Taiwan, China and France, in violation of Article 18 of the procurement contract.
The court gave its ruling only this year.

Thales and the French government, which would be liable for nearly 75 percent of the overall penalty because of its critical role in the contract, were expected to have to pay a total of up to US$861 million when interest, litigation fees and other expenses were added in, according to a Navy attorney.
Thales issued a statement on May 3 saying that the company will fight the ruling, including requesting the Paris Court of Appeals to revoke it.

Meanwhile, Ko Kuang-yueh, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, said at a legislative meeting Monday that although France is closing down its military liaison office in Taiwan in July, the French government will come up with a better substitute plan.
"Existing exchange programs, including military and technical support and services will not be affected, " Ko said at a hearing of the Legislature's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee.

Also speaking on the issue at the meeting, Foreign Minister Timothy Yang said the Lafayette arbitration was a business issue and would not have any adverse impact on bilateral relations between Taiwan and France.
Yang said it remains to be verified whether the French government will indeed close its military liaison office in Taiwan in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei nixes Tokyo's plan to redraw air defense identification zone
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 18:01:44 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy C.T. Yang said Monday that a Japanese plan to redraw its air defense identification zone (ADIZ) west of its Yonaguni Island is "unacceptable."
The decision to refuse to approve the Japanese plan was made jointly by his ministry and the Ministry of National Defense, Yang told the Legislative Yuan.
"Although Japan can redraw the zone unilaterally according to its own laws, as Japan's next door neighbor to the west, we have to make our stance clear to Japan," Yang said.
Yonaguni, Japan's westernmost territory and the last of the Ryukyu chain of islands, lies just 108 km off Taiwan's east coast.
Yang said Taiwan's Association of East Asian Relations, which is in charge of dealing with Japan in the absence of diplomatic ties, relayed Tokyo's plan to Taipei May 21.
Under the plan, the ADIZ 12 nautical miles west of Yonaguni will be moved a further two nautical miles west toward Taiwan in June, following a request by residents of the island.
"Japan should consult with Taiwan about the move, which will affect Taiwan's air defenses. We have made known to Japan that its plan is unacceptable," Yang said.
Turning to the tension on the Korean Peninsula triggered by the March 26 sinking of a South Korean warship by North Korea, the minister accused North Korea of damaging stability in Northeast Asia.
He said the ministry has issued a grey travel alert for South Korea and a orange alert for North Korea, and is working on plans to evacuate Taiwanese there.

Under the Foreign Ministry's four-level alert system, grey represents no perceived danger, while an orange alert suggests that people should avoid traveling to the region in question and to be on high alert if travel is unavoidable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Men's grooming market in Taiwan grows
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 18:47:41 ( By Angela Tsai and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The largest Online shopping site in Taiwan officially launched a men's care section to satisfy growing demand in the men's grooming market in Taiwan, an official from Yahoo!Shopping Mall said in a press conference Monday.

Men's cosmetics sales in Taiwan grew 73 percent in the first quarter of 2010 compared to the same period of last year, according to sales performance statistics released by the online shopping company.

Sales of facial mask products showed fast growth, while other ranges, such as skin care and anti-acne creams, have also seen sales increase significantly in the first quarter of 2010, said Hsu Chen-fei, the company's product director.

Hsu compared the booming market in men's cosmetics to Taipei's tallest building 101, saying that Taipei 101 is 508 meters high, and if an average height of one care product is 20 centimeters, the total height of men's products sold in 2009 would be equal to nine Taipei 101 buildings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government finances tight but stable: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 18:58:23 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Monday that the government's finances are tight but remain stable and that the debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio remains at an acceptable level.
Lee said the current debt to GDP ratio is still within the acceptable 40 percent level, adding that rising debt means the government finances are tight, but not intolerable.
Outstanding government debt totals NT$4.2 trillion (US$131 billion), or about 32 percent of GDP, and the figure is expected to rise to NT$4.5 trillion next year or 35 percent of GDP, Lee said.

Lee said that as the government spends the next couple years repaying part of its debt for several special budgets, including NT$120 billion for reconstruction after the Typhoon Morakot battered the island in August 2009, the debt level is expected to fall accordingly.
He did not elaborate on how much debt the government will repay over the next two years.
Lee made the comments as he answered questions in a legislative session that reviewed a proposed amendment to the Value-Added and Non-Value Added Business Tax Act.
He said raising debt for government operations is similar to the strategies many companies adopt to meet their day-to-day financial needs.

The Alliance for Fair Tax Reform has accused the administration of cutting taxes by more than NT$700 billion since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008, imposing a heavy burden on the government.
Lee said the government had only cut around NT$70 billion and that the alliance's accusation was groundless.

Meanwhile, Lee said that negotiations on a cross-strait taxation agreement are still under way, but that it could take several years for Taiwan and China to reach a consensus before signing a taxation agreement.
He added although both sides failed to sign any taxation agreement in the fourth round of cross strait talks at the end of last year, it did not mean the negotiations had broken down.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH planning a surcharge on alcohol
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 19:49:30 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has begun drafting a law to control the harmful use of alcohol that would authorize "health" surcharges on alcohol and require bottles of liquor to carry warning labels, DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Monday.
Yaung said he would support the legislation but expected it would be tougher to prevent alcohol abuse than the hazards from smoking cigarettes.
"Drinking mildly may not harm one's health but alcoholism or abusive drinking is a big problem, " he said during a hearing at the Legislature's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee.
The bill, he said, would only be proposed after a series of public hearings are held nationwide and society reaches a consensus on the drive to combat alcohol abuse.

The health minister also suggested that the DOH cooperate with the John Tung Foundation -- a nonprofit organization dedicated to public welfare in Taiwan that spearheaded the no-smoking campaign -- to use its clout in promoting the anti-alcohol campaign.

Meanwhile, Chiou Shu-ti, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, said that according to practices abroad, imposing alcohol taxes or surcharges is an effective way of reducing alcohol-related abuse.
Chiou said measures aimed at lowering alcohol hazards abroad vary but include the imposition of alcohol taxes according to the liquor's proof and minimum price schemes.

Nothing similar has been finalized yet in Taiwan, and Chiou said some experts have even suggested that alcohol surcharges can be levied in accordance with the Health Promotion Act, making an alcohol hazards prevention bill redundant.
During a meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva on May 21, Chiou extended Taiwan's support for a WHA strategy to reduce the harmful use of alcohol.

The WHA passed a resolution to reduce the harmful use of alcohol by, among other things, regulating advertising, encouraging abstinence, imposing limits on the availability of alcohol and offering treatment for heavy drinkers.

She also said Taiwan will follow World Health Organization guidance to enact a law to help achieve those goals, including levying "health" charges and adding health warnings to alcohol-related containers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Warning labels not the solution to reduce choking in children: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 20:05:00 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Monday that mandatory cautionary labeling on food items is not the solution to lowering the incidence of choking among children in Taiwan, but agreed that more education is needed to raise awareness of the issue.

Last month, an eight-month-old girl died, allegedly after choking on a konjac jelly candy -- a popular children's snack in Taiwan that can be easily sucked out whole from a plastic cup the size of a coffee creamer and can lodge intact in a child's windpipe.
In April, a six year-old died after a small fish ball became stuck in his airway, and at around the same time, a 78 year-old man lost his life when he choked on a piece of unchewed lychee.
Although the government does not maintain figures on food choking-related deaths, the media reports similar cases almost every year.
Since 2005, the DOH has required all mini konjac jelly cup makers to put labels on the packaging warning that the sweets should not be given to children under 5.
However, other items that are easy to choke on, such as hot dogs, popcorn, raw carrots and nougat are not subject to the mandatory labeling.

In the United States, the American Academy of Pediatrics is now urging the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to require warning labels on foods that are known as choking hazards and calling on manufacturers to redesign some of their most dangerous food products.
According to the U.S.-based group, in 2000, 160 children there died from obstruction of the respiratory tract.

However, Taiwan's FDA Deputy Director Feng Jun-lan pointed out that all food, if not consumed properly, can be a potential choking hazard and that it therefore would be impracticable to require warning labels to be placed on every single food item.

"What really matters is the size and the design of the food item itself and not the type of food. We are still doing research on the issue but the most important thing is not mandatory labeling but increasing public awareness of potential choking hazards," she said.
Taiwan Pediatric Association Executive Director Lee Ping-ing said that although warning labels can be useful, some parents are just not vigilant enough on what their children put in their mouths.

A comprehensive nationwide effort from the DOH, the Ministry of Education, and the Bureau of National Health, even down to the media, is needed in order to raise public awareness of the danger of food that is easily choked upon.

However, Kuo Yun-ting, chief of the pediatric department of Taipei Medical University Shuang-ho Hospital, advocated mandatory labeling, saying that more should be done to warn parents about items that are potential choking hazards.
"I cannot predict how effective such labels would be, but the more warnings we give to parents, hopefully, the lower the chance of their children choking on food," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex expects no big rise in overseas visitor numbers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 20:10:14 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei, the world's second-largest computer trade show, will not see a big increase in the number of international visitors this year, despite the recovering global economy, the organizer predicted Monday.

"We don't expect a huge increase in the number of international visitors this year for two reasons, " said Moses Yen, executive director of the exhibition department of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
TAITRA is the semi-official trade promotion body that, along with the Taipei Computer Association, co-organizes Computex, now in its 30th year.
He said that flight tickets are very expensive at present, as well as being the beginning of the peak vacation season.
He made the remarks at a press briefing the day before the opening of Computex Taipei for a five-day run.
Yen's deputy, Jeremy Horng, said fear of another repeat of the volcanic eruption in Iceland that threw European air travel into chaos several weeks ago is another reason.
"Unexpected volcanic eruptions make people reluctant to plan their trips early," he told reporters at the press briefing.
Horng, however, said he does expect a rise in the number of pre- registration international buyers this year, as that number for this year has already surpassed 11,000.
"Last year, we had fewer than 10,000 pre-registration international buyers, while 34,000 foreign buyers turned out at the event," he noted.

Asked if the European debt crisis and the tension on the Korean Peninsula have caused an impact on participating companies, Horng said that on the contrary, more than 100 companies are still on the waiting list to take part in the event.
"Our problem is that we do not have enough space at the venue, " he said.
Horng noted that a new hall will open in 2013 in Taipei, which will provide space for at least an additional 2,500 booths.

Consumers cannot buy products at Computex as companies use the event to showcase their products that are to be launched in the near future, but overseas buyers can use the event to place orders for these products, he said.
Consumers will have to wait until early August to buy the products at the Taipei Computer Applications Show, Horng noted.
Computex this year has a record 1,715 manufacturers presenting their products and technologies in 4,861 booths. The booth number is up 8 percent from last year's figure.
This year, the products highlighted will include e-reader devices, cloud- computing technologies, 3D displays and various computer peripherals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese company to publish third World Expo guidebook
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 20:42:33 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A best-selling book detailing tourist routes for the Shanghai World Expo will be published in Taiwan using traditional Chinese characters on June 10, an official from the Taipei-based Chinese Creation Publishing Co. Ltd said Monday.

"Six Golden Routes to the World Expo, " the company's third book on the fair, describes itineraries that allow tourists with limited time to see the highlights of the show, said Wang Cheng-hui, the company's general manager.

Following two successful deals to exclusively publish the Shanghai World Expo 2010 Official Guide and Official Tour, Wang told the Central News Agency that the latest book had sold more than 200,000 volumes in just one month in its simplified Chinese version. Chinese Creation cooperated with the Shanghai Century Publishing Group to distribute the book in Taiwan.
The guidebook also provides detailed tour information, including the best places for taking photos, an event calendar and a map, Wang said.
The World Expo began on May 1 and runs through Oct. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dentists give free treatment to jailed compatriots in Thailand
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 20:52:15 (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese inmates at a high-security prison in Bangkok do not have it easy, suffering from malnutrition and isolation, but once a year their spirits are lifted by visits of volunteer dentists from back home.
Dentists Huang Chun-fung and Yang Chung-ho recently returned from this year's mission to Bangkok, in which they provided free dental treatment to Taiwanese jailed at the Klong Prem Central Prison.
Many Taiwanese inmates suffer from dental problems, Huang said, primarily because of long-term malnutrition and the lack of access to proper medical care.
According to Huang, he and Yang had plenty of work on their recent trip, cleaning and extracting teeth, performing root canal procedures, and teaching their patients about oral hygiene.
But what they did and said may have had less of an impact than simply showing up.
"When they heard me speaking Taiwanese, they all felt homesick, " Huang said. "Sometimes, giving them mental comfort was more significant than the dental treatment."

Yu Ting-chen, chairperson of a Taipei County-based association of family members of Taiwanese inmates in Thai prisons, said most inmates who returned home after completing their sentences in Thailand suffered from serious dental problems.
Some had even loss many of their teeth, Yu said, attributing the problem to "different water, diet and language."
"If Taiwanese are affected with dental problems in Thai prisons, they usually have to endure the pain for three to six months before having a chance to get treated," Yu noted.

She expressed gratitude to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Thailand -- Taiwan's de facto embassy in the country -- for sending physicians to Thai prisons every year to provide free services to Taiwanese inmates.
It was the second time since 2008 that Huang, who runs a dental clinic in Taipei County's Banciao, and Yang, from Makong in Penghu County, volunteered to make the journey.
There are approximately 200 Taiwanese imprisoned in Thailand, mostly for drug trafficking and financial fraud.
The TECO has offered free medical treatment to the Taiwanese inmates every year since 1998 as part of the services it provides to overseas compatriots.

DOC.HEADLINE: e-dictionary preserves dying indigenous languages, cultures
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 21:47:54 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An e-dictionary of the languages and cultures of Taiwan's indigenous people has been compiled to help preserve indigenous mother tongues and collective memories that are quickly dying out, the Ministry of Education said Monday.

The ministry said the reference work would help users reinforce, learn or revive these dying languages and cultures before it is too late. It covers the mother tongues of 14 indigenous mountain tribes and the Pingpu plains (low-lying areas) aborigines.

The e-dictionary also has sections on 16 cultural subjects, including religions and worship, myths and legends, social organizations and functions, languages and philology, archeological sites and relics, and history.

The need for the e-dictionary on indigenous cultures was highlighted by the eye-opening visit to Taipei of a member of the Tao (Yami) tribe on Orchid Island, located about 49 nautical miles off Taiwan's southeastern coast.
The Tao man, known as Chou Lung-fa in Chinese, was in Taipei to collect his prize money after winning a contest to quit smoking. But what shocked people had nothing to do with giving up cigarettes.

Instead, in accepting the award, Chou spoke in the Tao language because he "didn't know how to speak Mandarin Chinese, " a rare phenomenon at a time when most indigenous people in Taiwan, particularly younger generations, don't speak their mother tongues.

Even on Orchid Island, where the Tao have lived in relative isolation from ethnic Chinese for over 800 years after migrating from Batan, the Philippines, the tribe's language has only been well preserved in two of the six villages on the island.
In other villages, the language is dying out, with only elders speaking it.

By linguistic or philological classification, both the Tao dialect and the Batan dialect belong to the Batanic language group, a subgroup of the Malayo- Polynesian group of Austronesian languages, the MOE said.

According to Robert Blust, a prominent linguist with the University of Hawaii's Department of Linguistics, the Formosan languages form nine of the 10 primary branches of the Austronesian language family, making them a vital resource.
Taiwan's indigenous languages, however, are dying out because of cultural assimilation, according to National Dong Hwa University in Hualien, which was one of the compilers of the e-dictionary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma welcomes overseas students from ally countries
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 21:58:07 (By Garfie Li and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou praised a Burkinabe student for his fluent Mandarin and said he welcomed more young people from Taiwan's allies to take advantage of the country's scholarship program.

Ma, speaking at a meeting with visiting Burkina Faso Minister of Defense Yero Boly at the Presidential Office on Monday, was referring to a student he met when attending a May 25 Africa Day celebration at Huashan Creative Park in Taipei,
The student was a recipient of a Taiwan Scholarship and has been studying at Shih Chien University in Taipei for two years, Ma told Boly.
"The fluency of the student amazes everyone," Ma said, adding that a lot of his usages are similar to that used by local people.
Ma said he hopes more people can be part of the scholarship program.

He also mentioned another cooperation program between Taiwan and Burkina Faso, the "Lamp for Africa" project, which provides schoolchildren with rechargeable LED lighting kits they can charge at school and take home to use as a light source.
Ma expressed his appreciation to Burkinabe President Blaise Compaore for attending his inauguration in 2008 and for supporting Taiwan by speaking up at several international events.
He said the recent visit by the country's Prime Minister Tertius Zongo in early May proves the strong ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan building projects win top international prize
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 22:00:54 (By Lin Hui-chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A commercial building project in Taichung City and a public works project in Taipei County have recently won top prizes of the Paris-based International Real Estate Federation (FIABCI), a local real estate assocation said Monday.

Parklane by CMP in Taichung took the top prize in the Retail Category and the Northern Taiwan Solar City in Taipei County won in the Sustainable Development Category for their environmentally friendly and high-technology designs.

The Prix d'Excellence Awards were presented during FIABCI's 61st World Congress held in Bali May 24-28, according to the Real Estate Association of the Republic of China, which is also registered as FIABCI-Taiwan.
This was the second time that Taiwanese properties have won top prize of the FIABCI, the world's leading property organization.

A bridge system in the southern port city of Kaohsiung -- the Heart of Love River, won the FIABCI Prix d'Excellence Award at the federation's 60th world congress, which took place in Beijing in May 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese firms unveil tablet PCs before Computex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 22:10:49 (By Alex Jiang and James Lee)

TEXT.P: Ready to join the global digital trend created by Apple's iPad, Taiwanese computer makers unveiled their new tablet PCs and other digital devices Monday a day before the opening of Asia's largest computer trade show.

ASUSTeK Computer Inc. (Asus), a leading Taiwanese computer maker, unveiled its answer to the iPad called the "Eee Pad, " which it said was expected to hit the market in the first quarter of next year.

Coming with either a 10-inch or 12-inch screen, the Eee Pad has an embedded virtual keyboard and can also be fit into the socket of a specially designed keyboard, turning the product into a quasi-desktop, the company said.
Asus also showcased a tablet with a 10-hour battery life, called the "Eee Tablet, " that combines the functions of a notepad and e-reader.

The Eee Tablet has a 2450 dpi resolution touch screen, a built-in two megapixel camera, and an assortment of notepad templates, and it also serves as an e-reader, with text file page turns taking only a tenth of a second -- nine times faster than normal, the company said.
Another new Asus innovation presented Monday -- an Android-powered smartphone -- was created in association with Garmin Corp., the global leader in satellite navigation Garmin Corp.
The smartphone integrates Google mobile services, including Google Maps, YouTube, Gmail and Android Market, enabling users to choose from more than 30,000 applications to personalize their phones.
Separately, Micro-Star International Co. (MSI) , a Taiwan-based maker of computers and related parts, unveiled its tablet PC called "Wind Pad."
The 10-inch touch screen product runs on Microsoft Corp.'s Windows 7 operating system with built-in Wi-Fi and 3G wireless technology.
MSI will ship Wind Pad to the United States and Europe in the upcoming quarter, MSI President Joseph Hsu said recently.
MSI also unveiled what it called "Sketch Book, " a concept notebook computer that allows users to draw or write on a pad on the back of traditional keyboards.
The company said Monday it will see how buyers and consumers react to the concept notebook at Computex Taipei before it decides on a timetable for the commercialization of the product.
Computex Taipei, which will be held in both the Taipei World Trade Center and the Nangang Exhibition Hall, runs from June 1 to June 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proposed ECFA referendum cannot be valid proposal: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/10 23:19:33 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The government's stance on a proposed referendum on a trade pact currently being negotiated with China is that it should not be a question put to a referendum, a ranking official said Monday.

The official, who asked for anonymity, made the point three days before the Referendum Screening Committee under the Executive Yuan is due to decide on whether a referendum proposal initiated by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) can be a valid one.
The TSU has proposed a referendum asking "do you agree that the government should sign an economic cooperation framework (ECFA) with China?"

The official noted that during a public hearing on the proposed referendum May 27, representatives from both the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said that the pact will involve mainly the issues of "taxes" and "investment," and therefore, cannot be made into a referendum proposal.
Moreover, the pact, which the government hopes to sign in June, will be subject to the monitoring of the legislature and therefore has no need for a referendum.
The representatives from the MAC and the MOEA urged the screening committee to reject the proposed referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 1, or the 19th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
2001: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issues a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 09:41:22 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Tuesday than its previous close, moving down 46.97 points at 7,327.01 on a turnover of NT$1.57 billion (US$49.06 million).
The weighted price index gained 78.66 points, or 1.07 percent, to close at 7,373.98 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
TTL has big medal haul in international competition
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, May 31 (CNA) 06/01/10 10:58:05 (By Lin Yu-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: State-owned Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTL) was showered with honors at the prestigious Monde Selection awards this past weekend, winning dozens of medals and five special trophies for its beer, spirits, cigarettes, and cosmetics.
TTL received a total of 43 medals, including 10 grand gold medals -- the highest possible honor -- and 17 gold medals. The other 16 were silver and bronze medals.

TTL Chairman Wei Po-tao and Vice President Lin Tzann-feng were at the award ceremony in Wiesbaden, Germany Sunday to collect the awards on behalf of the company -- Taiwan's biggest maker and distributor of alcohol and cigarettes.
"The awards are expected to help TTL further open markets in the United States, Japan, Southeast Asia and mainland China, " Lin said.

The Monde Selection awards represent a seal of quality for TTL products because the quality screening standards in Europe, known for prioritizing environmental protection and food hygiene, are regarded as stricter than those in the U.S., Lin said.

Aside from its haul of medals, TTL also received "International High Quality Trophies" for its canned Gold Medal Taiwan Beer, Yulu Burdock Wine, Vinata Essence Intense Hydration Anti-Wrinkle cream, Vinata Night Cream Revival Anti- Wrinkle cream, and Long Life Classic cigarettes.
The trophy is given to products that have received grand gold or gold medals for three consecutive years.

Monde Selection, founded in Belgium in 1961, is considered one of the most important food and beverage certification institutions in the world. It screens the quality of more than 2,000 different products from over 80 countries every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Elections are not springboards

TEXT.P: For those politicians in power or ready to come to power, the year-end mayoral elections in five special municipalities represent just five more political opportunities to gain power, or five more springboards to future national-level elections.
To the residents of these five metropolitan areas, however, what matters is whose leadership will be the most favorable to their well-being.

As the formula to distribute revenue among localities has not been revised, the problem of funding shortages is expected to continue despite these districts' upgraded status as special municipalities. If roads cannot be repaired properly, schools cannot turn on their lights, and administrative efficiency cannot be enhanced despite the upgrade, what difference does it make if all the political superstars get elected?

If the mayoral elections are the precursor of the 2012 presidential race, then the two major political camps must not overlook the other localities besides the five holding elections. Nobody would want to be treated as a second-class citizen. We hope the blues and greens, besides seeking victory, will present a vision to contribute to Taiwan's overall development. (June 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Need for reflection on tax reforms

TEXT.P: "Increasing taxes" was a consensus shared by Japan, Australia and New Zealand when they recently unveiled plans for fiscal reforms. This idea, however, is a political taboo in Taiwan.

Over the past 18 months since a tax reform committee was set up by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, a number of tax cuts have been announced, including lowering the gift and estate tax rates to 10 percent, and dropping the corporate income tax rate to 17 percent.

On the other hand, many items that would contribute to the fairness and soundness of the tax system were put aside, such as plans to abolish income tax exemptions for military personnel and public school teachers and to impose an energy tax and luxury housing tax.

Such reforms can simply be described as "cuts only, no hikes." It is predicted that tax revenue as a percentage of Taiwan's gross domestic product will hit a record low of 11.3 percent in 2011. The figure will probably be the world's lowest as well.

Despite such a major fiscal crisis, the administration has been engaging in some under-the-table dealings, such as seeking to evade the government debt ceiling and using unprofessional bookkeeping tricks to try to cover up its budget deficits.

From the examples of Japan, Australia and New Zealand, we can see that tax reforms must be considered as a comprehensive package. In Taiwan, what is lacking is the determination and fortitude of our policy-makers, rather than professional know-how. (June 1, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- SWAT team posted in Taichung to fight crime

TEXT.P: A string of daytime gunfights among gangsters in Taichung City streets recently prompted the National Police Agency to order the deployment of 40 SWAT team members in the central city Monday.
It was the fourth time in the past 11 years that special service police members have been stationed in Taichung to help with maintaining law and order in the central city.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

With public order out of control in Taichung City, the National Police Agency (NPA) decided Monday to have 40 SWAT team members stationed in the central city to deter criminal rings from engaging in street gunfights again.

Hu Mu-yuan, director of the Taichung City Police Bureau, said the SWAT team will conduct spot checks of major streets around the city day and night in a high- intensity campaign to deter organized crime and improve public order.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu admitted that the recent spate of street shootings in broad daylight were ominous signs that the city's public order was getting out of control.
Hu said he hopes the deployment of SWAT team will help deter the recurrence of similar incidents.

The mayor said that since assuming office nine years ago, he has spared no effort to clamp down on illegal businesses in the city. To date, he added, the number of illegal businesses in eight controversial lines of business has dropped from 399 to eight.
In fact, Hu said, the city's public order has improved steadily, and he is not sure where exactly the problem lies. (June 1, 2010).
Liberty Times:

There have been a series of shooting incidents in Taichung in recent months. During a question and answer session at the Taichung City Council, several city councilors grilled Mayor Hu on what has gone wrong with the city's public order.
Over the past nearly nine years, the councilors said the city's police budget has increased from NT$3 billion to NT$5 billion and the number of police officers has expanded from 2,500 to 4,052.

But many city dwellers are still haunted by daylight gunfights on the city's streets, the councilors said. Every time, shooting incidents happen, they said, the mayor tends to declare a war on gangsters or organized crime, but those declarations have not shown satisfactory results.

The city councilors, including Chen Shu-hua, Chang Liao Wang-chien and Ho Ming-chen, said the mayor should consider stepping down and let somebody else deal with the issue. (June 1, 2010). United Daily News:
On city councilors' demand that he resign to take the blame for Taichung's poor public order, Hu rejected the idea, saying his resignation would amount to surrendering to criminal rings.
"We will work to the best of our ability to prevent a recurrence of similar shooting incidents, " Hu said, adding that to him, every bullet fired by gangsters was like a shot at him.

Taichung City Police Bureau chief Hu Mu-yuan said the city's criminal incidence rate used to double the national average six years ago, but the ratio already dropped to the national average last year. Since progress has been made, he said, the city police force will redouble efforts to make further improvements. (June 1, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Transition to free economy

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan gained access to the international market using the "export processing zone" strategy as early as five decades ago, it is still not a highly liberalized economy today.

The widespread apprehension held by the public toward the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China demonstrates that many people in Taiwan refuse to face up to the fact that Taiwan's economy will gradually move toward full liberalization.

To prepare Taiwan for the advent of the new era, we need a trailblazer similar to the export processing zones to allow the Taiwanese people to experience and cope with the scenario in an enclosed area.

The proposal to set up special economic and trade zones in selected harbors and airports will play such a role. Through the simulation, which is expected to take no more than 10 years, Taiwan will bravely enter a free economy era.
Meanwhile, we want to remind Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang to speed up the project to keep pace with the rapidly changing world. (June 1, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: French decision to close military office in Taiwan not finalized
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 12:24:38 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Discounting a Liberty Times report, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said late Monday that the French government has not yet finalized a decision to close down its military liaison office in Taiwan.

In a statement issued Monday evening, the MOFA said the French government has told Taiwan that based on budgetary and personnel considerations, it is downsizing its overseas representation, including the military liaison office under its de facto embassy in Taiwan, the French Institute in Taipei.
But the ministry said France has not finalized the plan.
"It is a French internal matter, and the MOFA will not comment on when the military liaison office in Taiwan will be closed down, " the statement said.

The Liberty Times reported Monday that because Taiwan reneged on a consensus that the commission dispute involving the sale of six Lafayette-class frigates would be solved out of court, the French government has ordered that the military liaison office in Taiwan be closed down in July.

The Chinese-language newspaper also said that as part of an out-of-court settlement, France had agreed to sell new weapons to Taiwan, help raise the technical levels of the Lafayette frigates and French-made Mirage jet fighters, and offer more technical services to Taiwan's military.

The Ministry of National Defense denied the report the same day, saying it was completely off base. It said that logistics, technical maintenance and personnel training related to the Lafayette frigates and Mirage fighters have proceeded smoothly and normally according to existing contracts.

The International Court of Arbitration under the International Chamber of Commerce on May 3 ordered French defense contractor Thales and the French government to pay a penalty of more than US$591 million to Taiwan for paying commissions on the Lafayette frigate sale to Taiwan's Navy in 1991, in violation of the contract on the deal.
Foreign Minister Timothy Yang also said Monday that the Lafayette arbitration was a business issue and would not have any adverse impact on bilateral relations between Taiwan and France.
Yang said it remains to be verified whether the French government will indeed close its military liaison office in Taiwan in July.

Contrary to Yang's remarks, Ko Kuang-yueh, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, said at a legislative meeting Monday that although France is closing down its military liaison office in Taiwan in July, "the French government will come up with a better substitute plan."
"Existing exchange programs, including military and technical support and services will not be affected," Ko said.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run enterprise workers to stage protest in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 13:12:39 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Some 6,000 employees of enterprises run by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) are expected to join a planned demonstration in Taipei Wednesday to demand that a law that fails to clearly define their status be amended.

Pan Hsin-chung, the spokesman for the Taiwan Electric Power Labor Union (TPLU), said Tuesday that more than 4,000 TPLU members will be present in the parade to appeal for the revision of the "Administrative Law of State-Run Enterprise."
"All we want is that our status is clearly classified because right now we are neither public servants nor corporate employees, "Pan said.
Over 13,000 people at state-run utility Taipei Power Company (Taipower) are so- called "fake public servants" who are "public servants with the status of employees," according to Pan.

They are not eligible for pensions paid in monthly installments or savings accounts with a preferred interest rate of 18 percent, as is the case for most civil servants, and they are not covered under the new labor insurance pension plan that took effect Jan. 1, 2009, Pan said.

Under the Labor Standards Act passed in 1984 to protect workers' rights and benefits, state-run company employees are offered the choice to preserve their public servant insurance or to transfer to the labor insurance program.

Those who choose to be covered under the public servant insurance program are considered to be "public servants with the status of employees." Currently there are over 40,000 workers at state-run enterprises who hold this status.
TPLU executive member Chiu Wen-chang, a worker at the Taipower Dalin Thermal Power Plant in Kaohsiung City, said the union has issued a call for all its members to join the parade.
The protesters will set off from the Legislative Yuan, walking to the Control Yuan on Zhongshan South Road to deliver their petition, Chiu said.
They will then head to Qingdao East Road, Linsen South Road and Jinan Road before returning to the legislature.
Most TPLU members, from managers and department directors to grassroots workers, have expressed support for the parade, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister denies cross-strait tax agreement aborted
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 13:36:43 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lee Sush-der denied Tuesday a media report that the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait double taxation avoidance agreement has been aborted.
Lee told reporters that the government is still negotiating the agreement with China and will also seek to reconcile the different views on the issue in various quarters.
"The deal has not been finalized, but it has not broken down," he said.
The agreement was originally scheduled to be concluded in December 2009 during the fourth meeting between the chief negotiators of the two sides but it was shelved at the last minute.

Citing ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, the Commercial Times reported Tuesday that the agreement has been aborted, as evidenced by the failure of the two sides to resume negotiations on the issue in the last six months.

According to the paper, Lee "did not deny" Lai's comment, and the minister said that the two sides had not held any formal discussions on the issue since the end of last year mainly because of differences between large businesses and small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) on whether the agreement should be signed.
The fifth round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China is seen likely to take place later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan diplomat narrowly escapes being taken hostage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 14:14:52 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An official with Taiwan's embassy in Guatemala was taken hostage at gunpoint Monday in the country's capital but managed to escape after drawing out the situation and getting help from local police, multiple sources said Tuesday.
Lin Shyo-shiun, deputy director of Taiwan's Technical Liaison Office in Guatemala, was abducted by a group of armed youths while he was driving to work.
But he was later freed after police chased the kidnappers to an area just outside Guatemala City, according to an AFP report.
An embassy spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, told the Central News Agency by phone that Lin helped his cause by not upsetting the armed men.
According to the spokesman and details released by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the two kidnappers sat in the front seat and ordered Lin to sit in the back, setting off the car's alarm.
Fearing that the noise would irritate the gunmen and make them trigger-happy, Lin offered to move behind the wheel so he could silence the alarm.

Just as the men were changing positions in the car, a police car passed by. The officers were alerted by the strange movement in Lin's car and ordered it to pull over, according to the spokesman, who did not specify if there was a chase as reported.
Fearing that if the police discovered they had interrupted a kidnapping, a gunfight would be unavoidable, Lin told the police that the two men were his friends, according to the spokesman.
The police remained suspicious, however, and asked the three men to step out of the car.

The police searched them and found that all was clear -- the gunmen having left their guns in the car -- but Lin whispered to the police that he was kidnapped, leading them to arrest the kidnappers and allow him to escape.
Sun Ta-cheng, Taiwan's ambassador to Guatemala, expressed admiration for Lin's poise in dealing with the situation, which could have ended up in disaster, the embassy spokesman said.
According to the AFP report, the two men arrested were aged 27 and 24, and two pistols were confiscated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer aims greater China expansion through bond sale: analysts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 14:29:19 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Acer Inc., the world's largest notebook computer vendor, is expected to expand its reach in the Greater China area through a newly announced bond issuance plan, analysts said Tuesday.

"Acer is expected to take advantage of its global strength to penetrate the emerging Greater China market, with a focus on the mainland, " said Edward Chen, vice president of the Research Department at First Capital Management.
Acer announced Monday it has decided to issue up to US$550 million (NT$17.6 billion) in overseas convertible bonds this year to meet the company's need for funds.
The company said the bond issuance will be divided into two parts, one to raise up to US$300 million and the other to raise up to US$250 million.
The company said its board of directors has approved the bond sale proposal.
Local media have speculated that Acer was raising funds in a bid to acquire China's Founder Group, one of that country's biggest computer vendors, and boost its market share there.
Acer was not immediately available for comment on the Founder acquisition reports, but Chen said the scenario was plausible.
"As the world's largest notebook computer vendor, Acer's market share in China is not significant at all. I do not rule out the possibility," he said.
Chen said Acer now has about NT$33 billion (US$1.03 billion) in cash on hand, and the bond issues are expected to further boost the company's capacity for future development.

"Regardless of whether Acer buys Founder or not, the cash to be raised is expected to create about NT$100 billion in production value for the company. I am very positive about the bond sale," he said.

In the first quarter, Acer accounted for seven percent of China's notebook computer sales, making it the fifth largest notebook computer vendor in that market. Founder trailed with a four percent market share.
Acer and Founder signed a memorandum of understanding last week that will give the Taiwan-based company access to Founder's comprehensive distribution network to sell its products.

Acer had previously said it will introduce a new notebook computer exclusively tailored to Chinese consumers by the end of this year, after the company listed China's market as its top marketing priority.

Henry King, an analyst at Goldman Sachs (Asia) said earlier that the cooperation with Founder is expected to help Acer reach its goal of boosting its market share in China to 10 percent by the end of 2010.
Mars Hsu, an analyst with Grand Cathay Securities, agreed that the funds Acer is raising will be used to strengthen its presence in China but said an acquisition of Founder may not be Acer's purpose.
"Acer wants to go deeply into China's tier four to six cities, which have populations of no more than 20,000, and it is a huge task that requires a lot of money," he said.
Hsu said Acer is also likely to acquire smartphone production capacity with the new funds as the company has been eager to diversify into that business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes China's further opening to tourist exchanges: KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 15:11:06 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan, regardless of their party affiliation, should welcome China's further opening to tourist exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Su Jun-pin said Tuesday.

The Taipei office of the Beijing-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association (CSTA) announced the previous day that China will allow residents of six remote areas -- Gansu and Qinghai provinces and the autonomous regions of Inner Mongolia, Tibet, Ningxia Hui and Xinjiang Uyghur -- to visit Taiwan for pleasure, with effect from July 18.

They are the last batch of Chinese administrative districts to lift restrictions on travel to Taiwan by their residents. In July 2008, the China government formally began allowing citizens in 13 provinces and large metropolises to visit Taiwan for vacation purposes.

Responding to the CSTA announcement, Su said he believes Taiwan's two major political camps -- the KMT-led "pan-blue" camp that favors closer ties with China and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led "pan-green" camp that advocates Taiwan's separate statehood -- should welcome China's decision to fully open its doors for its citizens to visit Taiwan.

Meanwhile, CSTA Taipei office Director Fan Guishan said in a recent interview with the Chinese-language United Daily News that with the lifting of the travel restrictions in China, the annual number of Chinese tourist arrivals in Taiwan will break the 1 million mark soon.
In the period July 2008 to April 20 this year, the total number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan had exceeded 1 million, according to the latest CSTA tallies.

The CSTA is a quasi-official organization authorized to handle tourist exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties, and its Taipei office is the first office of any kind to be established by China in Taiwan.
To get a better understanding of Taiwan's travel environment, Fan said, he plans to lead CSTA staff on an islandwide tour soon, focusing on the attractions of southern Taiwan.
Southern Taiwan is known as a traditional pan-green camp stronghold.
On the appeal by some Taiwanese tour operators for China to allow its citizens to make "individual visits" to Taiwan, Fan said Chinese authorities are studying the feasibility of the proposal.
"The issues being studied include mode of travel, issuance of documents, experimental procedures, and problems that may arise during individual travel," Fan said.
However, there is no timetable for concluding such an arrangement, Fan said. If individual visits are allowed, they will start with residents of major cities, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 1.14 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 15:22:48 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 1.14 percent Tuesday on profit taking after the market moved closer to the nearest technical resistance level of around 7,400 points, dealers said.
The weighted index closed down 84.65 points at 7,289.33, off a low of 7,276.52 and a high of 7,348.56 on turnover of NT$69.54 billion (US$2.17 billion).
A total of 1,176 stocks closed lower and 949 higher, while 300 were unchanged.

The market opened 0.64 percent lower as investors pocketed the gains posted in the previous trading sessions, and the downtrend continued until the end of the session on lingering concerns over the debt problems in Europe, dealers said.
The plastics/chemical sector suffered the heaviest losses, dropping 2.0 percent, followed by the financial sector, which fell 1.9 percent, and the textile sector, which lost 1.7 percent.
The construction and food sectors each closed 0.9 percent lower, while the machinery/electronics and paper sectors each lost 0.8 percent and the cement sector 0.7 percent.
In the plastics sector, Nan Ya Plastics shares fell 2.46 percent to NT$51.60 and Formosa Plastics dropped 2.17 percent to NT$63.20 on concerns over falling product prices, dealers said.
Among financial stocks, Cathay Financial dropped 2.74 percent to NT$46.15 and Fubon Financial decreased 1.50 percent to NT$36.15.

The touch panel sector bucked the downside on introduction of new tablet computer models at Computex Taipei, the world's second largest computer exhibition which opened Tuesday, with Young Fast Optoelectronics finishing up 6.68 percent at NT$244.00.
"The market moved in thin trade on a lack of new leads. After the bourse posted gains for four sessions in a row, it was time for profit taking," MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
Tang noted that while the market had risen in the previous sessions, trading volume failed to expand. This indicated that not many investors were willing to chase prices, he said.
"Amid uncertainty over the European debt crisis, keeping cash on hand could be a smart strategy at the moment," he said.
Tang said the market was basically in consolidation mode and can be expected to move in a narrow range over the next few sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: France denies military liaison office exists in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/10 15:35:31 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: France's Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied the existence of a military liaison office in Taiwan in a press briefing Monday after Taiwanese media reported that the office has been closed over the handling of a warship sale dispute.

According to the Web site of the French Foreign Ministry, its spokesman denied the existence of a military liaison office under the French Institute in Taipei, which represents French interests in Taiwan in the absence of bilateral diplomatic ties.

"We do not have a military liaison office in Taipei. There are no changes foreseen in the French Institute in Taipei, " the French Foreign Ministry spokesman said in response to a reporter's question.

The Chinese-language Liberty Times newspaper reported Monday that the French government ordered that the military liaison office in Taiwan be closed down in July because Taiwan reneged on a pledge to settle a dispute over commissions paid on the sale of six Lafayette-class frigates in 1991 out of court.
The French Institute in Taipei told the Central News Agency Monday that it had no comment on the matter.

Taiwan's Navy brought the case to the International Court of Arbitration under the International Chamber of Commerce in 2001, and on May 3, the court ruled against French defense contractor Thales, which was Thomson-CSF, when the sale was made.
