DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 2, or the 20th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
2001: The Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Mongolian Olympic Committee sign a sports cooperation and exchange agreement in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 09:31:38 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday than its previous close, moving down 36.54 points at 7,252.79 on a turnover of NT$1.67 billion (US$52.19 million).
The weighted price index lost 84.65 points, or 1.14 percent, to close at 7,289.33 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Songshan Airport renaissance

TEXT.P: Taipei's Songshan Airport will launch direct flights to Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport June 14 and to Tokyo's Haneda Airport Oct. 31, and is planning to further provide direct flights to Seoul's Kimpo Airport.

We very much look forward to the economic development opportunities brought by the close links between Taipei and the three major Northeast Asian cities. The air services will be very helpful to promoting bilateral exchanges and attracting international business and leisure travelers.

Songshan Airport, Hongqiao Airport and Haneda Airport are all located downtown, which means that travel time can be significantly shortened with the help of MRT systems. In order words, a "one-day living circle" can be realized between Taipei, Shanghai and Tokyo.

Before Songshan Airport sees a sharp traffic increase, however, we need to make full preparations in advance and seek to improve the airport's infrastructure. The space, design and facilities of Songshan Airport have long been insufficient to meet the needs of an international airport. For example, Boeing 747s cannot land or take off at the airport because its runways are too short.
The support of many quarters will be needed for the airport to display a fresh look. (June 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students win top prize in U.S. website design contest
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/10 10:22:05 (By Zep Hu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A website developed by a group of Taiwanese high school students to showcase the global food crisis has won the top prize in an international website page design competition sponsored by the United States Department of State.

The Taiwanese team, made up of students from Mingdao High School and Dazhi High School, was named on Tuesday as one of two winners of the Platinum Prize in the 2010 Door to Diplomacy contest organized by the Global SchoolNet Foundation.

Their website project, called "The Silent Tsunami -- Global Food Crisis, " highlights in English how the world is affected by food shortages, what their impact is, and how to resolve the problem. The website is http://www.mingdao.edu.tw/diplomacy/en/.
A team from Clinton High School in Clinton, New York won the other Platinum Prize with a project called "Diplomacy Through Communication."
The website, http: //www.wix.com/dt/Doors-To-Diplomacy, shows that the only way to make diplomacy work is to gain knowledge of other cultures and their differences.

"Doors to Diplomacy" is an educational challenge formed to encourage middle school and high school students around the world to produce websites that teach others about the importance of international affairs and diplomacy.
Each member of the Door to Diplomacy Award winning team will received a US$2,000 scholarship, and the winning coaches' schools will each receive a US$500 cash award.
A total of 263 students from 29 countries, all aged between 11 and 18 years, participated in the competition.
Global SchoolNet, http: //www.globalschoolnet.org, is a nonprofit, Internet-based education program funded by the U.S. government.
The Doors to Diplomacy Award was specially created for CyberFair, a contest that encourages students and educators to join together to build high-quality, educational websites on a variety of topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Don't breach the debt ceiling

TEXT.P: The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou is currently seeking to amend the Public Debt Act to relax or adjust the debt limits of various levels of government. If the amendment is passed, the government's combined allowable debt burden will rise from 48 percent to 51 percent of the country's gross domestic product.
We urge the administration to rein in the move before it is too late, because it would bring disaster upon Taiwan.

The outstanding amount of debt owed by the government is the accumulated sum of deficits incurred by the government over the years. The reason why debt has continued to accumulate is because revenues have fallen short of expenditures. Raising the debt ceiling will cover up the truth that the government is "failing to make ends meet, " which will in turn allow the problem to continue to worsen.
The imbalance between revenues and expenditures should be tackled by reforming the tax system and cutting down on spending in order to truly resolve the problem.

Five or 10 years from now, when the incumbent president and premier are no longer in office, the problem will have been passed on to their successors. Future generations will suffer from the disaster. Is this something a responsible government should be doing?

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 10:37:08 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.282 at 9:45 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.136 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Gang leader shot dead in presence of police

TEXT.P: Four police officers were at the crime scene when gang leader Weng Chi-nan died in a shower of bullets in central Taiwan's Taichung City May 28.

Two higher-ranking officers -- Lin Chi-you, a traffic police squad leader, and Lin Wen-wu, a detective police squad leader -- have been removed from their leadership posts and slapped with a demerit as punishment.

The two lower-ranking officers -- Shih Chang-hsing and Tai Chih-hung -- were given a warning as they were reportedly just carrying out their duty by driving their superiors to the gang leader's office. Shih sustained an injury to one of his toes in the shooting.
The incident has again raised concerns over the police force's integrity and work ethic as well as the shady ties between police and criminal rings.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:
The gunman in last Friday's shooting that claimed two lives remains at large, while an equally shocking fact came to light Tuesday -- four police officers witnessed the execution-like killing.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu was kept in the dark for five days about the presence of police officers at the crime scene. When he found out about the embarrassing event, he said with frustration that it seemed like he had taken another bullet, after already being shot once.
It was truly "heart-wrenching" to know that ranking police officers maintain ties with gang members, Hu said while attending a city council session.

Taichung prosecutors summoned the four police officers for questioning and tentatively concluded that the police officers had nothing to do with the shooting incident and did not break any law. Their presence at the gang leader's office was an inappropriate act rather than a legal infraction, the prosecutors said. (June 2, 2010).
United Daily Daily News:
According to a police investigation, the two ranking police officers were invited to the gang leader's office by their retired colleague Chen Wu-hsiung for a chat.

When the gang leader, Weng Chi-nan, arrived at the scene, a gunman who had been waiting for him for some time fired a volley of bullets at him. Surveillance cameras showed that the four police officers hid behind couches as the assailant fired his gun.

The police officers regretted showing up at the scene at the most inappropriate time. Lin Chi-you, a traffic police squad head, said he did not know "the place was so complex." He further said they could not help at the time because they were not on duty and therefore unarmed.

Taichung Police Bureau chief Hu Mu-yuan said he had heard that police officers were present at the crime scene on the day the shooting happened but did not inform the mayor until obtaining solid evidence.
Hu promised to step down from his post if the fugitive gunman is not brought to justice by the end of this year. (June 2, 2010). Liberty Times:

Mayor Hu said the previous day that he was not sure where exactly the city's public order problems lie. Some people familiar with police circles said the problems lie in the shady dealings between police officers and underworld ring members.

Police officers sometimes have to engage with gang members to obtain tips to facilitate investigations into criminal dealings. Some police officers fail to observe the fine line and eventually are co-opted by ring leaders while failing to get any useful information.

A retired police detective who once worked in central Taiwan said in some cases, targeted gangsters were tipped off and fled before police began to probe their suspected criminal acts. (June 2, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry denies report about missile testing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 12:10:42 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A magazine report about a medium-range missile test-firing plan is not accurate, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said in a statement Wednesday, without elaborating.
Next magazine reported in its latest issue that the military will test-fire its newly developed surface-to-surface missiles, with a range of 2,000 kilometers, on Thursday and Friday.
The test-firing will be part of an overall tactical assessment, the weekly tabloid magazine said.

The MND said in the statement that its various weapons research and test-firing plans have been proceeding smoothly in accordance with their original schedules, but that, in line with its customary practice, it would not comment on R&D details.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A review of low exchange and interest rates

TEXT.P: Responding to the pressure for appreciation of the Taiwan dollar in the wake of the fall of the euro, the central bank intervened in the foreign exchange market in mid-May to prevent an excessive increase in the value of Taiwan's currency.

Economists Chen Shiu-sheng and Wu Tsong-min, however, have recently written articles to discuss Taiwan's currency policy. They found that there was no clear evidence showing that the policy to prevent currency appreciation contributed to economic growth, and also concluded that the central bank's intervention is ineffective in stabilizing currency fluctuations.

The central bank's effort to stop currency appreciation is bound to lead to an increase in the money supply. At the same time, certificates of deposit are being issued to try to prevent a capital glut.

As the rise in money supply is not supported by an increase in domestic investment, the yields of the certificates of deposits auctioned out by the central bank have fallen, standing at just 1.89 percent in the first quarter of 2010.

In the first four months of this year, the average increase in the consumer price index was 1.3 percent, higher than the average savings interest rate of 0.64 percent. If the inflation rate further rises, the people will suffer from a negative real interest rate.

We need to ponder if it is necessary for Taiwan to adopt a long-term policy against currency appreciation. If the government does not prepare properly for the future scenarios of an inflation and capital flow reverse, it will be unfavorable to Taiwan's long-term development. (June 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen plans to purchase 100 new cargo ships amid recovery
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 12:24:54 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Evergreen Group, a Taiwan-based shipping conglomerate, has confirmed that its maritime shipping unit will order 100 new ships to modernize its fleet amid the global economic recovery.

"It will take at least 10 years to have the 100 boats built, but the first will be delivered in 2013, " said Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa in an interview with the Chinese-language United Daily News published Wednesday.
Chang said Evergreen Marine Corp., Asia's second largest container line, hopes to order 32 container ships this year with a capacity of 8,000 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) each.

The company is thinking of purchasing 10 of the vessels from South Korea and another 12 from Taiwan's CSBC Corp., Chang said, but their prices have yet to be finalized. The remaining ships may be ordered from either Korean or Japanese shipyards.
The report said that at Chang's insistence, the new ships will be environmentally friendly and not cost more than US$10,000 per TEU.
The plan, regarded as the world's largest order for new boats, has drawn the attention of all major shipbuilders, test centers and equipment suppliers around the world, the report said.
Bloomberg News reported last month, when Chang first announced the new order plan, that Evergreen Marine is the only shipping line among the world's 20 biggest without any new ships on order.

Meanwhile, EVA Air, one of the Evergreen Group's eight subsidiaries, also disclosed that three new Boeing 777-300 passenger aircraft that it purchased will be delivered in the second half of the year.
They will be used on flights between Taiwan and Europe, the United States, and Japan, the report said.
In the interview, Chang also predicted that Evergreen Marine and EVA Air will both be profitable this year.

Thank to its cross-Taiwan Strait, European and U.S. flight services, EVA Air generated profits of NT$1.2 billion (US$37.2 million) in the first quarter, Chang said, and he was optimistic about the company's prospects for the rest of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai Precision retains top enterprise title in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 14:19:36 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. kept its title as Taiwan's top enterprise in terms of sales for 2009, even though its revenue figure fell 3.56 percent from a year earlier, indicating an impact from the global economic meltdown, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

According to the survey results released by China Credit Information Service, Hon Hai, the world's largest electronic component contract maker, posted NT$1.42 trillion (US$43.96 billion) in sales for 2009 to take the top position for the fifth consecutive year.
It was the first decline the company had experienced since 1990, according to the survey results.

Cathay Financial Holding took the No. 2 title, posting NT$930 billion in sales, followed by Quanta Computer's NT$750 billion, CPC Taiwan Corp.'s NT$735 billion and Formosa Petrochemical's NT$643 billion.
All four firms also suffered year-on-year declines in sales.

The survey, which covered a total of 5,000 enterprises operating in Taiwan from old economy companies to the high tech and service sectors, showed that the total sales of the 5,000 firms fell 6.11 percent from a year earlier to a combined NT$28.96 trillion, the lowest level in three years.
Among the top 500 enterprises, 219 enjoyed revenue growth and the number of firms was the lowest since 1990.

"Although 2009 was a year of economic recovery at home and abroad, the survey demonstrates that the recovery was not as strong as had been previously expected, " CCIS editor in chief Liu Jen told CNA.

Meanwhile, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the world's largest contract chipmaker, posted the highest net profit of NT$89.22 billion, followed by Hon Hai's NT$75.69 billion, Chunghwa Telecom's NT$43.76 billion, Formosa Petrochemical's NT$39.19 and CPC Taiwan's NT$37.65 billion.

The survey results show that while net profits of the top 500 firms rose to NT$894.7 billion in 2009 from NT$184.7 billion a year earlier, the total reached just 57 percent of the NT$1.58 trillion recorded in the boom year of 2007.
Among the top 500 firms, 71 suffered losses in 2009, down from 115 that recorded losses in 2008 but still higher than the 47 registered in 2007 and the 62 recorded in 2006.

"This is also evidence that the economic recovery has not been significant enough. The higher profits came largely from their efforts in cost control, falling raw material prices and foreign exchange gains," Liu said.
Looking ahead, Liu said, the debt problems in Europe could compromise global consumption, while China's monetary tightening measures are also likely to impact demand.
"We remain cautious about the second half of 2010," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan free to sign trade pacts with other countries: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 14:33:59 (By H.C. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is entitled to ink any trade pacts that it wishes to with other countries under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.
His remarks echoed a press release issued the previous day by the Mainland Affairs Council that emphasized Taiwan's right to sign FTAs with other countries.

Both Taiwan and China are WTO members, so are entitled to ink free trade agreements (FTAs) with other WTO members to enhance their economic interests, the MAC said. "China should not disrupt Taiwan's efforts to ink FTAs with its trade partners," it added.

"Under the directive of President Ma Ying-jeou, the government will do its very best to create welfare and benefits for the Taiwanese people through globalization, by first making Taiwan a strong economic power and reaching out to other Asian countries, " Wu said.

"Trade and commerce is the lifeline of Taiwan, and this country, as a WTO member, is eligible to clinch trade deals, pacts or agreements of any kind with other countries to bolster its trade development and boost the welfare and benefits for its people, regardless of any outside influence," he said.
"The government will definitely move toward this ultimate goal despite China's opinion."
China routinely objects to other countries agreeing to enter FTAs with Taiwan, making it very difficult for such deals to be signed.
Ma has reiterated that Taiwan will seek to forge free trade agreements with its major trade partners when negotiating a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The premier's remarks came after China's Foreign Ministry said a day earlier that while Beijing is not opposed to Taiwan conducting private sector trade exchanges with China's diplomatic partners, it "firmly objects" to Taiwan's inking of official agreements with them.
Commenting on a referendum being promoted by the opposition as a means of foiling the ECFA, Wu said the government will not oppose any kind of such a public vote, as long as it is legitimate.

In response to a question from reporters on whether Taiwan should list its demand for a role in the international arena in an ECFA formal statement, Wu said the two sides must put aside their political disputes to arrive at the trade-concession trade deal for the sake of mutual benefit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibit opens at stronghold of Taiwanese art in Berlin
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/10 15:01:57 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Tamtam 8, the only art gallery in Berlin dedicated to contemporary Taiwanese art, has opened an exhibition of the works of eight Taiwanese female artists that it hopes will give them greater exposure and advance their careers.

The exhibition, the biggest since the gallery's founding in April 2009, features the works of Taiwanese artists based in London, Paris, Beijing and other cities around the world and covers themes such as lesbian love, the female body, identity and the nomadic state of mind.

Taiwan's National Culture and Arts Foundation has offered financial support for the ongoing exhibition at the gallery, which was founded by a group of Taiwanese students studying in Germany to give Taiwanese artists more exposure.
Fu Ya-wen, one of the founders who is now studying at a visual arts college in Leipzig, said Taiwanese artists have few chances to showcase their works abroad.
"We hope the establishment of Tamtam 8 will offer them a platform to display their creations," Fu explained.

Acknowledging that operating an art gallery in Europe is no easy task, Fu said she hopes Taiwan's government can offer subsidies to help keep Tamtam alive so that Taiwanese artists will have more opportunities to exhibit abroad.
"We are convinced that we can carve out our own niche in Berlin's flourishing art market," Fu said confidently.

Since its inauguration in the trendy Friedrichshain district, Tamtam 8 has sponsored a series of art exhibitions, concerts and cultural seminars, Fu said, in the hope of inspiring cross-border and cross-culture exchanges of creative ideas.

With a liberal artistic atmosphere and incorporation of eastern and western European cultural characteristics, Berlin has emerged as Europe's new arts capital and has attracted artists from around the world to work and reside in the city, Fu said.
She said she believes that Tamtam 8 will offer Taiwanese artists a good platform from which to draw creative inspiration and connect with art lovers.

After the current exhibition closes June 20, Fu said, Tamtam 8 plans to collaborate artists from around Europe in sponsoring a series of activities, including movie screenings as well as theatrical performances and concerts featuring modern music.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government must clarify death penalty policy: activists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 15:18:01 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Disappointed anti-death penalty activists said Wednesday that they will stop pursuing a constitutional interpretation on capital punishment after the Justices of Constitutional Court rejected a petition last week on halting the death penalty.
However, they urged President Ma Ying-jeou to live up to his pledge to end the practice in the future.

Accusing Ma of duplicity, the Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty (TAEDP) , along with over 50 supporters from the medical, environmental, religious and legal sectors, complained that while the president has vowed to abolish the death penalty, he continues to allow the Ministry of Justice to execute people.
In April, Taiwan ended a four-year de facto moratorium on capital punishment by executing four of its 44 death row inmates.

Justice Minister Tseng Yong-fu, who was appointed after his predecessor resigned for refusing to sign off on executions, has been vague on the eventual plight of the remaining 40, saying only that he will respect the decision of the Constitutional Court.

According to the court, the government's adherence to its death penalty policy does not go against the two U.N. covenants -- the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights -- signed by the president in late March.

Human rights lawyer Wellington Koo lamented the court's decision, saying the rejection means the group has exhausted all legal means of swaying the government and that "all we can do now is to plead with the government to hear us out."
According to the TAEDP, Taiwan is one of 18 countries, including the United States and China, that continue to enforce capital punishment.

"The president and the justice minister have publicly vowed to end the death penalty but yet they continue to sign off on death warrants. Their actions make us highly dubious of their true intentions, " said TAEDP Chairwoman Chiu Hei- yuan, urging Ma to clarify his stance.
Another of the activists, Catholic Archbishop John Hung, said that "it has been proven over and over again that the death penalty is not an antidote for reducing violence in society."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 1.28 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 15:21:02 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 1.28 percent Wednesday after heavy selling triggered by the resignation of Japanese Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama and concern that the political situation in the world's second-largest economy will impact the global recovery, according to dealers.
The weighted index closed down 93.62 at 7,195.71 after fluctuating between 7,159.75 and 7,304.13 on turnover of NT$79.69 billion (US$2.46 billion).

The market opened down 0.50 percent as investors witnessed a Wall Street fall overnight and the downside accelerated, in particular in late trading, due to Hatoyama's decision and a weakening Japanese yen, the dealers said.
A total of 2,148 stocks closed down and 665 were up, with 259 remaining unchanged.

The machinery and electronics sector faced the largest decline, down 1.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals, which dropped 1.3 percent, the paper and pulp with a 1.2 percent fall and textiles, down 1.1 percent.
Cement and construction sectors each closed down 1.0 percent, while the financial sector fell 0.8 percent and foodstuffs lost 0.6 percent.
"Hatoyama's resignation has added uncertainty to the global economy. With fingers crossed, investors were wondering how big the impact will be," said Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang.
"Such uncertainty is the last thing investors wanted, " Huang said.
Huang said the concerns were amplified by the fact that the debt problems in Europe have not yet been resolved.
He said he did not rule out the possibility that the local bourse will test the key 7,000 point support soon.
Selling pressure focused on large-cap high tech stocks as investors were afraid of possible weakness in global consumption, the dealers said.
Personal computer maker Acer shed 4.45 percent to NT$75.20, while smartphone firm HTC lost 3.97 percent to close at NT$411.50.
United Microelectronics Corp. fell 2.70 percent to NT$14.40, while Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. closed unchanged at NT$59.80.
Nan Ya Plastics fell 1.74 percent to NT$50.70 and China Petrochemical Development lost 1.33 percent to end the day at NT$14.80.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'FTA-like' deals possible for Taiwan: US expert
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/10 16:16:27 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Despite China's opposition to any form of "official" engagement between Taiwan and other countries, it remains possible for Taiwan to seal free trade deals that do not take the form of a "government-to-government" agreement, a U.S. expert said Tuesday.

"One presumes that other countries would realize that a 'government-to- government' agreement would not pass muster with the PRC (People's Republic of China) , so they would plan to fashion any agreement to avoid that problem, " Alan Romberg, distinguished fellow and director of the East Asia Program at the Henry L. Stimson Center, told the Central News Agency.

Romberg was commenting on recent remarks by Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Ma Zhaoxu, who said Beijing has no objection to unofficial economic and trade relations between Taiwan and other countries, but opposes their signing any official agreements.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has interpreted Ma's statement as meaning that Beijing will continue to block Taiwan's efforts to establish free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, even after it signs an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Taiwan's government, which plans to seal the deal with China soon, has said the agreement will help clear the way for Taiwan's bids to negotiate FTAs with its trade partners.

Romberg, who formerly served as a spokesman for the U.S. Department of State, said that Ma's statement does not make clear whether Beijing would oppose an agreement that "substantively is the equivalent of an FTA but does not take the form of a 'government-to-government' agreement."

If China were to disappoint Taiwan's expectations by opposing such "FTA-like" agreements altogether, it would destroy much of the goodwill that has been built up between the two sides over the past two years, Romberg said.
As the ECFA has not been signed, he said, it is premature to try to pin down Beijing's position regarding a future situation.

"But it is hard to believe that Beijing would not understand the importance of this issue and would not be cooperative as long as any such agreements take into account the need to finesse the issue of 'one China, one Taiwan' or 'two Chinas,'" he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes down on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 16:34:53 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, falling NT$0.103 to close at NT$32.315.
Trading volume totaled US$782 million during the day's session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.418 and then dropped to a low of NT32.246 and rebounded slightly before the close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai shares plunge on Foxconn pay hike
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 18:10:57 (By Chang Chun-mao, Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry shares closed sharply lower in heavy trading Wednesday amid concerns over the company's bottom line after Foxconn Technology Group announced a 30 percent wage increase for the group's workers in China, dealers said that day.
Hon Hai is the parent company of Foxconn, which has been accused of mistreating its Chinese workers in the wake of a string of suicides by workers at its Shenzhen complex.
The pay hike, announced the previous evening, was an attempt to overcome public criticism and assuage its Chinese employees after the 10 deaths, according to the dealers.
Hon Hai closed down 4.02 percent at NT$119.50 (US$3.69) , the lowest level since last Sept. 1, with some 67 million shares changing hands.
"The 30 percent pay increase was much higher than the 20 percent rise the market had been expecting, " said Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang.
"The pay hike is likely to add more than NT$10 billion per year to Hon Hai's operating costs, which will definitely hurt the company's bottom line," Chiang said.
The trading volume was high, indicating that selling pressure on the stock was heavy, he said.

At present, Foxconn, which assembles mobile phones, laptop computers and other products for companies such as Apple, Dell and Hewlett-Packard, has more than 800,000 employees in China, about 400,000 of whom work in the Shenzhen complex.

Chiang said foreign institutional investors have largely been selling in the past 10 trading days and added that the higher-than-expected pay hike is expected to prompt them to continue to dump their stock.
Amid cautious sentiment toward Hon Hai, Chiang said, the stock might fall further to around the NT$110 mark before bargain-hunting kicks in to cause a rebound.
Daiwa-Cathay Capital Markets analyst Calvin Huang said the pay increase will erode Hon Hai's already low gross margin, which at present stands at 4 percent.
Huang added that Hon Hai's pay hike might trigger a chain reaction in which other Taiwanese investors in Shenzhen could follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex offers more than hot products

TEXT.P: While buyers and reporters from home and abroad were focusing heavily on tablet PCs, e-readers, 3D gadgets and gaming products at Computex, the world's second- largest computer trade show taking place in Taipei, other products, including interactive whiteboards and a keyboard PC, also captured visitors' attention.

A number of exhibitors at Computex, now in its 30th year, were showcasing interactive whiteboards on which teachers or students can write or draw on an electronic board that shows the image projected from an overhead projector.

"You can see weathermen on TV use a similar technology. Businessmen can also use the interactive whiteboard to highlight their points during their presentations, " Patrick Hung of Hitachi Sales Corp., Taiwan told CNA Wednesday at the Nangkang Exhibition Hall, the Computex venue.

Some of these whiteboards are actually multi-touch screens, allowing users to quickly and directly switch between different functions or move graphics from one place to another using their fingers on the screen.

"These interactive whiteboards have existed for at least 10 years, but they have only begun getting popular in the last two years," said Jason Liao, a sales representative of China-based Fuzhou Returnstar Technology Co., which produces the devices.
He attributed the popularity of the products to the increasing use of projectors.
Liao said his company saw a 40 percent to 50 percent growth in sales of interactive whiteboards last year from a year earlier, with Europe and the Middle East regarded as the most lucrative markets.
"This kind of whiteboard is eco-friendly and does not harm the health, as teachers no longer have to breathe in chalk powder, " he said.
While a majority of exhibitors were displaying flat-screen TVs, one Taiwanese exhibitor was showcasing two traditional TV sets connected to keyboards in the most eye-catching spot of his booth.

"These are keyboard PCs. A keyboard PC combines a keyboard and a hard drive. You can simply connect it to a traditional TV set at home and use the TV set as a computer screen, " said Jonathan Chang, sales manager of DMP Electronics Inc.
This kind of product is obviously not aiming to compete with iPad or any other tablet PCs, but is targeting emerging markets and developing countries, according to Chang.
"We are eyeing Africa, as well as Central and South America. They have a big demand for this kind of product because of the huge digital divides in their countries," he noted.
"We also spoke to Taipei-based envoys of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, who say they find it very interesting and will help us promote it in their own countries, " he said.
The majority of the countries that recognize Taiwan diplomatically are in Central America.
Another booth that made visitors stop and take photos featured a small pond in which computer screen products were being sprayed by water fountains.
"We want to show that our products are waterproof because our products are designed for use by restaurants and factories, " said Sandy Huang, a marketing specialist of Taiwan's Sensor Tech Co.
"Users don't need to worry that dust or powder will get inside the computer, as it is completely sealed and if it gets dirty, it can simply be washed," she added.
Some of the exhibitors attracted visitors' attention not with their products but with their booth designs.

In strong contrast to a booth fronted by a large devil statute standing with a spear in its hand in an apparent effort to appeal to gamers, In Win Development Inc. created a relaxing atmosphere in its "yacht" booth.

"By designing our booth as a yacht, we want to send the message that we are sailing toward a bright future, as our high tech products are designed to be more user-friendly and eco-friendly, " said Winner Tsao, the Taiwanese company's marketing supervisor.

With this wealth of picture-drawing whiteboards and specially designed booths, along with dragons, pandas and giant cartoon characters walking around the exhibition hall to provide photo-ops, you could be forgiven that the show is largely for kids. Children under 12, however, are not permitted to enter the trade show, which runs through June 5. By Alex Jiang CNA staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Flora expo to display Taiwan's charm as 'Orchid Kingdom': mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 18:50:54 (By Johnson Sun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Flora Expo , scheduled to open in November, will again display Taiwan's charm as the "Orchid Kingdom," a distinction that was enhanced during a recent U.K. flower event, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Wednesday.
Hau said more than 3,300 plants representing more than 1,600 species will be exhibited at the show, slated to run from Nov. 6, 2010 to April 25, 2011, including up to 800 orchid species.
"We will show the world Taiwan's soft power, " Hau said when receiving Taiwan Orchid Growers Association Secretary-General Lin Feng-pei.

Lin was the leader of the Taiwan delegation to the 2010 Chelsea Flower Show held May 25-29 in London. Taiwan's booth, which was designed under the theme of "Orchids in the Art World, " seized a silver medal in the show.

Queen Elizabeth praised the delicacy of Taiwanese orchids during a stop at the Taiwan booth. Princess Alexandra, a cousin of the queen, and Stephen Bennett, manager of the event, also lauded Taiwan's orchids when they visited the stand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tibetan treasures to be exhibited in Taiwan from July
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 18:52:24 (By Cheng Ching-wen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of Tibetan art treasures, including rarely shown objects from the Dalai Lama and Panchen Lama palaces in Tibet, will open July 1 at Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM),

The "Sacred Land Tibet -- Treasures from the Roof of the World" exhibition will showcase a total of 130 artifacts from different historical periods spanning the 5th to the 20th century, said NPM Deputy Director Feng Ming-chu.
The treasures, which will include 36 first-class exhibits from China, will "display the superiority of Tibetan art in every dimension," she said.

One such example is a 77-centimeter tall gold-plated statute of Bodhisattva with 11 faces and 1,000 arms, which was created during the Qing Dynasty, according to one of the exhibition's co-organizers, the Gold Media Group.
The statue has been kept at Norbulingka palace, the traditional summer residence of successive Dalai Lamas, the Gold Media Group said.
All 130 exhibits will be shipped from Beijing to Taiwan at the end of June and will carry an insurance value of NT$300 million (US$9.3 million), according to the group.
Tickets for the exhibition are available at all 7-11 stores around Taiwan and at Books.com at a price of NT$220 each or NT$320 per pair.
The exhibition will run through Sept. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prize-winning works in Taiwan-sponsored contest shown in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 18:57:31 (By Tang Pei-chun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of prize-winning works in a Taiwan-sponsored international children's painting contest opened in Singapore Tuesday as part of Taiwan's efforts to boost cultural exchanges and art education.

Taiwan's Association for Education Through Art and the Association for Formative Art Education have jointly organized the annual contest for 40 consecutive years and decided for the first time this year to showcase the winning works abroad.
Vanessa Shih, Taiwan's representative in Singapore, as well as various other dignitaries, attended the opening ceremony of the 40th World School Children's Art Exhibition.
Shih described the exhibition, which includes artworks from over 50 countries, as a "meaningful cross-cultural art event."
School children in Singapore will be invited to the exhibition to participate in storytelling contests and discussions of the paintings, she added.

Wu Long-rong, chairman of the Association for Education Through Art, said his association hopes relations and cooperation in art education between Singapore and Taiwan will improve as a result of the exhibition.
After the Singapore exhibition, the artworks will also go on show in Malaysia, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hundreds of state firm employees protest vague status
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:03:35 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of employees of state-run firms staged a protest Wednesday, calling for the government to clarify their status and ensure that they are provided with benefits to which they are entitled.

Demonstrating in front of the Legislative Yuan, the protesters -- union members from several state-owned enterprises, including Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) , Taiwan Sugar Corp., CPC Corp., Taiwan, and Taiwan Water Corp. -- accused the government of failing to enshrine their rights and clear status under the law.
They urged the government to clarify whether they are classed as government civil servants or laborers.

Pan Hsin-chung, secretary-general of the Taipower union, said that due to the vagueness of their status, employees of state-owned companies are not entitled to labor pensions under the Labor Standards Act.

At the same time, Pan said, they are also not entitled to the monthly pension civil servants receive after retirement or the preferential 18 percent bank deposit interest rate that civil servants get.
Worse still, he went on, employees of state-owned companies are nevertheless subject to punishments designed for civil servants should they misbehave.
Pan said that as a state-run company employee, he feels like an orphan, sacrificed on the one hand to a twisted legal structure, while being misunderstood by the public on the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidates launch joint campaign for mayoral races
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:08:25 (By S.F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) candidates in November's mayoral elections in Xinbei City and Kaohsiung City, jointly launched their campaigns Wednesday and vowed to win the races through a show of unity.

Eric Liluan Chu and Huang Chao-shun unveiled their joint campaign theme of "building both Xinbei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south into trade and commerce hubs" at a ceremony presided over by Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wang at the council headquarters.
Chu and Huang pledged to achieve the goal of boosting regional development through joint efforts and described the two areas as complementary.
Chu said he is capable of creating a sound investment environment to lure back the many foreign-based Taiwan businessmen who have left the areas.
"I am poised to create a win-win situation for both southern and northern Taiwan," he said.

Huang for her part promised to make Kaohsiung into a trade and commerce hub for air and sea transport in the Asia-Pacific region, helping the city regain the vigor and prosperity it enjoyed 10 years ago.

The mayoral elections will take place Nov. 27 in five special municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- whose populations together account for 70 percent of the country's total.
The races are widely viewed as a bellwether for the 2012 presidential election at a time when President Ma Ying-jeou's approval ratings have sunk to a low ebb.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. scholar to receive NTNU outstanding alumni award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:26:54 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Stanford University emeritus professor Albert Dien, one of the first foreign students to study Mandarin at National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) , has returned to Taiwan after more than half a century to accept an outstanding alumni award from the university on June 4.
"Before I came to Taiwan in 1956, I had studied classic Chinese for 10 years in the United States, but I could not speak a word of Mandarin," Dien said at a welcome reception at NTNU Wednesday.

The 82-year-old scholar recalled that during his first week in Taipei, he could not speak enough Mandarin to order food at a restaurant so he ate moon cakes from street stands for a whole week, as it was around the time of moon festival.

After Dien's return to the U.S., he became a major figure in Chinese and Asian academic disciplines, serving as chairman of the East Asia Sectional Committee and American Oriental Society, and director of the Stanford East Asia National Resource Center, among other posts.
"Definitely, the training I received in Taiwan during the two years I spent here was important to my whole life," he said.
The first group of foreign students -- Dien and four others -- to study Mandarin at NTNU helped promote the establishment of the university's Mandarin Training Center (MTC) in 1956.

Dien and his wife Ding Shu-fang, a graduate of NTNU's English Department, expressed appreciation to the school for providing them with what they said was a good education and the chance to meet each other.

NTU's Mandarin Training Center, which teaches Chinese as a second language, is the largest of its kind in Taiwan, with an enrollment of 1,500 students from more than 60 countries each academic quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 40% of parents want their kids to attend summer camps: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:40:22 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: With the approach of the long summer vacation, nearly 40 percent of the parents of 4th to 6th grade children surveyed recently said they want their kids to sign up for local summer camps, according to the survey results released Wednesday by the Taipei-based King Car Educational Foundation.

The results of the survey on summer activities also show that more than 40 percent of the parents who answered the poll revealed that they have decided to enroll their children in various courses during the two-month summer break.

According to the survey of 10 to 12-year-old children and their parents, travel camps are the most popular kind of summer camp among children, with 55.7 percent of the children surveyed saying they want to attend that kind of camp this summer.

Sport-oriented summer camps are the second-most popular, attracting 54.88 percent of the respondent kids, followed by art camps (31.53 percent) , science camps (27.91 percent) and ecology camps (22.92 percent).
Parents, however, listed their order of preference as ecology camps (56.36 percent), travel camps (34.48 percent), sports camps (33 percent), and science camps (27.88 percent).

Art camps for activities such as painting, music and drama were not even on the list of parent preferences, suggesting that despite government efforts to promote aesthetic education in recent years, most parents are uninterested, the King Car Foundation concluded.
A total of 1,496 valid student samples and 1,495 parent samples were collected for the survey, which was conducted May 1-12. The margin of error reached plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan corrects Cabinet over poor IPR investment return
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:42:53 (By Sophie Yeh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan passed a motion Wednesday to correct the Executive Yuan over low return on the government's investment in intellectual property rights (IPR) research.

Citing findings of its study, the Control Yuan -- the top monitor of government integrity -- said the executive branch budgets nearly NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion) for science and technology research annually, but combined IPR revenues of agencies under the Executive Yuan only total slightly more than NT$700 million.
The disparity indicates the government has failed to work out an overall strategy and efficient measures to cope with IPR issues, the Control Yuan said in its statement of censure.

Chao Jung-yao, one of two Control Yuan members who initiated the motion to study IPR investment, said that South Korea -- Taiwan's major trade competitor -- has over the past decades narrowed the gap between its IPR investment and earnings and almost achieved a balance.
Chao said Taiwan has made little progress in this regard.
Over the past five years, Chao said, the government's annual IPR investment accounted for 2.7 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP).
Chao added that Taiwan spends over NT$100 billion in royalty and trademark fees annually, but its royalty revenues total only about NT$7 billion or NT$8 billion.
Huang Huang-hsiung, Chao's colleague, said that although Taiwan produces many academic papers annually, their value is questionable.
Huang quoted former National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen as having said that 90 percent of those papers were of little to no commercial value.

In the process of investigating the case, Huang said he and Chao had visited a number of private enterprises, many of which mentioned problems involving "patent trolls, " people or companies that enforce patents in an overly aggressive or opportunistic manner, usually without any intention of actually manufacturing or marketing the patented invention.

As small- and medium-size enterprises form the backbone of Taiwan's economy, Huang said, the government should follow South Korea's example by setting up a fund to procure patents owned by its universities or research institutes, or to support technological research projects to prevent them from flowing out of the country or being obtained by "patent trolls."

The government should also encourage or help local industries to establish integrated platforms for IPR exchanges, Huang said, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs should reinforce the manpower and professional capability of its Intellectual Property Office to speed up patent screening and quality to better protect locally developed intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Philippines might sign free trade agreement
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:04:17 (By Emerson Lin and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Trade ministers from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum are scheduled to meet this weekend in the Japanese city of Sapporo, and Taiwan and the Philippines are expected to discuss the possibility of signing a free trade agreement (FTA) on the sidelines of the meeting.

Taiwan's representative office in the Philippines told CNA that Taiwanese officials have promised to push for the agreement and expressed hope that bilateral trade relations will make significant progress in the short term.

Philippines Trade and Industry Secretary Jesli Lapus said he is interested in any deals that would increase foreign investment and that a bilateral trade agreement could further strengthen trade links between Taiwan and the Philippines.

The Philippines and Taiwan signed a memorandum of understanding for the creation of an economic corridor between the Subic Bay Freeport Zone in the Philippines and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan in 2005, and it is now time to upgrade this to a national level, he said.

However, the issue requires a certain degree of diplomatic sensitivity that will need to be handled delicately, Lapus said, adding that the Philippines follows a one-China policy that recognizes the Beijing's government as the sole legitimate government of China.
According to statistics released by the Manila Economic and Cultural Office, the amount of Taiwanese capital invested in Philippines in 2009 was over US$113 million.

Another report conducted by the Philippines' National Economic and Development Authority also suggested that once Taiwan signs a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, Taiwanese capital will leave the Philippines and flow into China, which could cause thousands of Philippines workers to lose their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister urges speedy amendment of allocation act
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:26:45 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah called for the quick passage of amendments to the Act Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures to facilitate the upgrade and merger of several cities and counties into special municipalities.

Jiang issued the call Wednesday during a meeting with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, Lai Ching-te, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate for the Tainan municipality mayoral election, and several local government officials and DPP representatives.

Jiang said that after the Cabinet approved a plan to re-map Taiwan's administrative zones, his ministry created a task force that has met every two months since last September to handle related affairs. After elections later this year, Taipei County will be upgraded to "Xinbei City, " Taichung City and county will be merged, Kaohsiung City and county will merge, and Tainan City and county will merge to form special municipalities.

The task force has created a data bank and information systems, Jiang said, but added that some issues such as financial policies and the municipal governments' rights and obligations have yet to be settled.

The minister said issues concerning labor inspections, traffic supervision and transfers of business operations at public senior high schools and medical institutions are expected to be addressed before October.
The budget and staff of cities and counties will also be handed over as part of the transfers of business operations to the newly formed municipalities, Jiang said.

He said that amendments to the act were crucial to whether the transfer of business operations from the existing local governments to the new municipalities and municipal budget allocations can be completed by 2011.
Jiang was responding to complaints of a potential financial shortfall in the future Kaohsiung and Tainan municipalities.

Hao Chien-sheng, secretary-general of the Kaohsiung City government, said that despite an increase to NT$14.3 billion (US$443 million) in revenue allocation for the new Kaohsiung municipality, it would still see a financial shortfall. Hao said that based on the current allocation act, expenditures would be at least NT$26.2 billion.

Transfer of business operations after the merger will require a lot of money, and an exact division of powers and functions between the central and local governments has not been established, he said.
Hao also suggested the central government retain temporary workers hired by the local governments' township offices.
Chen said she hoped the merger could help narrow the gap between urban and rural areas.
Lai expressed concern that the future Tainan municipality would have to spend about NT$20 billion, but would only be allocated NT$8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swiss bank releases US$1.52 m. from former first family's account
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:32:59 (By Lin Chung-sen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A Swiss bank on Wednesday remitted to Taiwan US$1.52 million from accounts held in the names of former President Chen Shui-bian's family members, according to Taiwan's Special Investigation Division (SID).

The Swiss bank wired two sums of US$529,617 and US$1 million into an SID designated account from the family's accounts in Switzerland which hold a total of US$21 million and had been frozen since 2007.

It was second time in two weeks that funds had been released from the accounts, as the Swiss bank wired US$2 million two weeks ago into the SID-designated account. This means that so far, close to US$3.53 million has been returned to Taiwan from the family's accounts in Switzerland, the SID said.

In addition to the US$21 billion that was frozen in Merrill Lynch Bank (Suisse) S.A. and the Royal Bank of Scotland, the former first family in June 2007 had also transferred to a Swiss bank NT$570 million (US$17.67 million) of the NT$740 million it had in a Cathay United Bank vault, according to the SID.
The SID had asked the Swiss bank to freeze the NT$570 million because it was considered a bribe that had been paid to the family by Taiwan's financial holding companies.

The ex-president's son Chen Chih-chung said earlier this month that his family will cooperate with the SID by returning to Taiwan the US$21 million it holds in Swiss bank accounts, but he did not say whether the NT$570 million will be returned.
Prosecutors believe that all of the funds held in Swiss banks in the family's name were illegally acquired and should be confiscated.
The former president, who has been in detention since Nov. 12, 2008 on charges of corruption, has been sentenced to life imprisonment.
The Taiwan High Court judge who presided over Chen's appeal of his life sentence, had suggested that the former president return the money to Taiwan if he wishes to be released on bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to learn from Dutch 'cycling paradise'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:35:44 (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should learn from the bicycle-friendly Netherlands to improve both the island's environment and the public's well-being, the president of the world's largest bicycle manufacturer said Wednesday.

Announcing plans to embark on a cycling trip in the Netherlands later this month, Giant Global Group President King Liu said at a press conference that 27 percent of all Dutch travel is done by bicycle. In other words, he said, Dutch ride bicycles not just for fun but also for practical, utilitarian purposes -- unlike Taiwan.
"It would be a dream come true if I could help bring Taiwan up to that level," he said.
Starting on June 14, Liu will spend six days on a 500 kilometer ride through the nation he described as a "cycling paradise."

Liu said Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials will also participate on the trip, dubbed "Green World on Wheels, " and study the cycling infrastructure of the Netherlands to find ways Taiwan can improve its cycling environment.

Describing himself as "born on a bicycle, " Menno Goedhart, the representative of the Netherlands Trade & Investment Office in Taipei, said that even though he has seen tremendous improvement in Taiwan's cycling culture, there is still a long way to go.

MOTC statistics show the total length of bike lanes in Taiwan was 2,170 km by the end of 2009, while a review published by Rutgers University last year said the Netherlands already had about 20,000 km of bike paths and lanes by the end of 1996.
During a survey conducted by the ministry this March, 40.1 percent of 9,236 participants said they would be more willing to ride a bike if the country was safer and more friendly for cyclists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition by Mexican photographer opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:36:19 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of 40 photos by Mexican photographer Pedro Vazqueznieto opened at the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Wednesday, the Mexican Trade Services Documentation and Cultural Office in Taiwan said.
The show, which features photos of the city of Guanajuato, is the first leg of an Asian tour of the exhibition in celebration of the 200th anniversary of Mexico's independence.
"We organized the exhibition to promote Mexican culture and tourism, " said Martin Munoz Ledo Villegas, head of the Mexican office.
Munoz Ledo said he hopes to let Taiwanese people know more about the beauty of the city of Guanajuato through the event, which was listed as a world cultural heritage site by UNESCO in 1988.
The city was founded by the Spanish in the early 16th century and was the world's leading silver-extraction center in the 18th century.
Munoz Ledo said the works of the internationally renowned photographer show the multi-faceted beauty of the city and include photos of the University of Guanajuato, his alma mater.
The event will run through July 3 in Taipei and will later move to Taichung before going to Vietnam, the city of Guangzhou in China, New Zealand, Singapore, Japan, Australia and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 10% of jobs demand engineering degrees: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:56:10 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Almost 10 percent of employers in the job market seek graduates with engineering majors, an online job bank survey showed Wednesday.
Yes123 website said that when employers list requirements for education background in their job advertisements, the most common request is for people with science or engineering degrees.

The survey found 9.74 percent of offered jobs require engineering degrees, which is the most common requirement, followed by industrial and mechanics (8.91 percent) and business management (7.35 percent).
Yes123 also said that employers were paying less attention to diplomas, preferring to focus on work experience or certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget for biomedical park project in Hsinchu unfrozen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 21:26:58 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee unfroze the budget for a biomedical science park in Hsinchu County Wednesday after the administration reverted to the original plan for the park, according to the head of the National Science Council (NSC).
In a report to the committee, NSC Minister Lee Lou-chuang said the park will be used for translational research and to provide care to acutely and critically ill patients, as was previously planned.

The committee decided to unfreeze the NT$120 million budget after it was given the assurance that the Department of Health's (DOH's) plan to set up a medical center in the park to attract international medical tourism had been suspended.
Legislators were worried that the DOH's proposal to recruit businesses to develop medical tourism would have put profit before medical research.
According to a DOH official Huang Kun-chang, translational research can broadly include research on genetic protein and stem cells, and the development of new drugs, medical equipment and reagents.
The focus will depend on which biomedical or pharmaceutical companies are participating in the work at the park, he said.
The NSC will establish a research and development center in the park, while the Ministry of Economic Affairs will build an industry incubator center, and the DOH plans to set up a hospital, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan entitled to sign official pacts with other countries: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:11:42 (By Garfie Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that as an independent and sovereign country, the Republic of China has signed many official pacts and agreements with other countries in the past, and will endeavor to continue to do so.
Ma, was responding to a statement by a spokesman for China's foreign ministry the previous day that Beijing is opposed to Taiwan signing any free trade agreements (FTAs) with foreign countries.

"Trade has been the lifeline of Taiwan, and Taiwan cannot survive if there is no trade, " Ma said at a weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang, of which he is chairman.
He said that Taiwan as a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) "is entitled to sign any trade deals with other WTO members and this right cannot be interfered with for any reason."
In an interview with the BBC Wednesday morning, Ma again urged Beijing "not to stand in Taiwan's way of clinching FTAs with foreign countries."

Ma made a similar statement on April 25 during a televised debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on whether Taiwan should ink an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Ma's administration is hoping the cross-strait trade pact could be signed in June to help boost Taiwan's competitiveness in the global arena.
Ma told the BBC that the June schedule remains unchanged, but the details of some issues related to the pact have yet to be worked out.
Taiwan government officials have reiterated that the ECFA would help pave the way for Taiwan to ink FTAs with other major economies.

In related news, DPP Chairwoman Tsai said that the latest statement by the Chinese spokesman highlighted the fact that Beijing will continue to hobble Taiwan's FTA efforts even after the ECFA is signed, and proved that her party "is right to oppose the ECFA."
She said that one of the government's touted advantages of the ECFA -- that it will serve as springboard to other FTAs -- will not come to fruition.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will increase Taiwan's competitiveness: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:25:25 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will benefit Taiwan by boosting the country's competitiveness and attraction for foreign investors.

In an interview with the BBC conducted in Chinese at the Presidential Office, Ma said there has been a boom of free trade agreements (FTA) in the Asia region over the past decade -- from three to the current 58 -- and that unless Taiwan takes action quickly, it will face further isolation.

The purpose of the ECFA, he said, is to normalize the existing robust cross- strait trade relationship. By doing so, it will maximize profit margins, encouraging Taiwanese businesses to stay in Taiwan and luring more foreign investment.
Taipei and Beijing have tentatively agreed to sign the agreement in June, he said, but a specific date has yet to be announced.

The president also stressed that by forging a trade pact with Beijing, it is hoped that other countries will be encouraged to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) or similar deals with Taiwan -- an idea that has been long been opposed by Beijing.
The Chinese foreign ministry reaffirmed its stance the previous day that Beijing strongly objects to Taiwan signing FTAs with other countries.
"We hope and ask China not to impede our efforts in signing FTAs with other countries because the agreements are vital to Taiwan's livelihood," he told the BBC.

As members of the World Trade Organization (WTO), both China and Taiwan have the right to establish free trade relationships with other WTO members and Beijing should not stand in Taiwan's way, he said.

While the administration has repeatedly touted the EFCA, many in Taiwan, especially the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, have warned that the pact will make Taiwan further dependent on China's economy and compromise Taiwan's sovereignty.

The president acknowledged the fear and said the government is aware of potential setbacks, which is why the administration has been working very carefully to ensure Taiwan's rights will not be compromised in the process, he said.

"I have said before in open debates that if there is any possibility that Taiwan's rights will be harmed by the trade pact, then I would rather see the negotiations collapse than have the deal go through, " he said. "This is why we are taking each step very carefully."

In answering a question from a BBC viewer who inquired about Ma's view on "eventual unification, " the president emphasized his "no unification, no independence, no war" stance on cross-strait ties. He said that during his tenure he will not push for unification with China, and that because the Republic of China has been independent since 1912, he will also not support Taiwan's de jure independence.

Last month marked Ma's second anniversary in office. Looking back on the last two years, the president said the country has faced many trials, including the worldwide economic contraction and the most devastating and costly flooding the country has ever seen.

"Although we had many difficulties, we have also gained confidence in ourselves and we have been making good progress, " he said, adding that Taiwan's growth, overall competitiveness and government efficiency have all received excellent international ratings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shenzhen wage increase threatens Taiwanese firms
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:33:31 (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A planned wage increase for factory workers in Shenzhen, China could create a heavy burden on Taiwanese companies and squeeze some of them out of the market, a Taiwanese business representative said Wednesday.

Shenzhen authorities are likely to announce a 20 percent wage hike in the minimum wage that would take effect from July, said Hung Jia-sheng, vice chairman of the Shenzhen Taiwan Business Association.
Hung told the Central News Agency that the measure will deal another heavy blow to Shenzhen-based Taiwanese enterprises, which only recently begun to recover from the global financial tsunami.

"Although many said they had no choice but to accept the wage raise ordered by the Shenzhen City government, some could be eliminated by a fresh wave of operating difficulties, " Hung said by telephone.

At present, there are two levels of minimum wages for workers in Shenzhen. The minimum at factories near the city center is 1,000 yuan (NT$4,740) a month, while those on the city's outskirts must pay at least 900 yuan a month. Minimum wage in Taiwan is NT$17,280.

Hung said Tuesday's decision by Taiwanese high-tech giant Foxconn to adopt a 30 percent increase in monthly wages starting June 11 will affect other companies operating in the area. Foxconn's decision came after a spate of suicides at its factory in Shenzhen's Longhua area.
However, other Taiwan businesspeople were reserved about such a development.

Yeh Chung-jung, chairman of the Dongguan Taiwan Business Association, said Foxconn's hike would not have a large effect on other Taiwanese firms, as what happened to Foxconn was simply an isolated case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister declares war on organized crime
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:39:29 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Police forces will be fully mobilized to crack down on the illegal possession of firearms and to bring to justice fugitive suspects involved shooting cases in an all-out effort to improve public order, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday.

Speaking at a special session of the Legislative Yuan's Internal Administration Committee on public order in central Taiwan's Taichung City following a string of shocking daytime shootouts there, Jiang said his ministry is working on a blueprint to clamp down on criminal ringleaders.
On a May 28 shooting incident that claimed two lives, Jiang said that four Taichung City Police Bureau staff who were present at the crime scene have been punished.

Citing the police bureau's initial investigations, Jiang said the four police officers were invited by a retired colleague to a biotech company for a chat. None of them knew that the company was run by Weng Chi-nan, an underworld gang leader who died in a shower of bullets in the shooting incident.

Two higher-ranking officers -- Lin Chi-you, a traffic police squad leader, and Lin Wen-wu, a detective police squad leader -- have been removed from their leadership posts and slapped with demerits, Jiang said.

The two lower-ranking officers -- Shih Chang-hsing and Tai Chih-hung -- were given a serious warning as they were reportedly just carrying out their duty by driving their superiors to the gang leader's office. Shih sustained an injury to one of his toes in the shooting.

On Taichung's public order, Jiang said that compared with the same period last year, the number of criminal cases reported in the city showed a downward trend and the ratio of cases solved had also declined slightly.
Nevertheless, he added, all major criminal cases listed by the Interior Ministry's National Police Agency (NPA) for special monitoring have been resolved with the exception of the latest shooting.

Jiang said the ministry has ordered the Taichung City Police Bureau and the NPA's Criminal Investigation Bureau to set up a special task force to track down the fugitive gunman and other suspects involved in the case.

At the city police bureau's request, the NPA has assigned 40 SWAT team members to serve in Taichung to help maintain public order. The SWAT team members started conducting spot checks Wednesday at major streets around the city day and night in a high-intensity campaign to deter organized crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3D gesture-based controller to be new rehab device: institute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:50:09 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: A combination of 3D and gesture-based remote control technologies are poised to be commercialized for physical rehabilitation applications, a research institute said Wednesday.

At Computex Taipei, Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) displayed an interactive glass-free 3D digital signage that uses two household webcams to immediately recognize hand gestures.

"You can set the functions by using different gestures, " said Peter Chew, promotion director of ITRI's 3D System and Application Division. "For example, you can make a fist to zoom in on an image and wave your hand to turn the page."
This application can be used in the fields of advertising, gaming, or even medical treatment, he said.
"The technology will be applied in physical rehabilitation by using hand gestures to change the 3D images, " said Chew, adding that patients will have more fun with such interaction.
Asked which manufacturer is interested and when the product will hit the market, Chew said it is too early to say.
Wii, a Japanese home video game console that was released a few years ago, is now being used in settings like hospitals, nursing homes and clinics for all types of rehab devices.
Chew said that 3D digital signage is just the beginning and he is optimistic about the future of its applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's FTA goals achievable: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 23:07:05 (By Jorge Liu, Alex Jiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be able to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries as long as it does not seek to forge such pacts for political purposes, said a U.S. expert on cross-strait affairs Wednesday.

Bonnie Glaser, a senior research fellow with the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, told the Central News Agency that she does not think " Beijing is adamantly opposed to Taiwan signing economic agreements with other countries, but it does have some concerns, and perhaps even prcondictions."

A spokesman for China's foreign ministry said the previous day that "Beijing is opposed to Taiwan signing any agreements 'of an official nature' with foreign countries, but it maintains a hands-off policy with regard to Taiwan developing unofficial trade and economic relations with them."

Glaser said that, first of all, Beijing might insist that Taiwan use a moniker in such agreements that is consistent with past practice. Taiwan was admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO) under the name "the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."
Secondly, she said, China could insist that Taiwan give priority to negotiating a cross-strait economic agreement and that there be no linkage between the ECFA and other FTAs.
Finally, Beijing could stipulate that other counties sign FTAs with China first, before considering Taiwan, she said.
However, Glaser said, none of those concerns or preconditions would be "insurmountable barriers" to Taiwan signing trade pacts with other countries.

Glaser said that she believes that Beijing will not stand in the way of Taiwan's inclusion in the regional economic process, in light of China President Hu Jintao's statement last December that China will give due consideration to Taiwan in this regard.
Besides, under the framework of the WTO, economic agreements among members are permitted, Glaser said, adding that China does not have reasonable grounds on which to oppose such agreements.

"As long as Taiwan does not seek to use the signing of economic agreements with other countries for political purposes, as was done in the past when Chen Shui- bian was president, this (signing of FTAs) is a goal that is achievable under President Ma Ying-jeou's leadership," she said.
Meanwhile, a visiting European Commission official declined to comment on China's latest remark on the possibility of Taiwan signing FTAs with other countries.
