Mauro Petriccione, head of the commission's Directorate General of Trade (B) , said before a European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) luncheon that he was not sure exactly how China had voiced its opposition and therefore he could not comment.
Addressing the luncheon, Petriccione said that "we will continue to work with Taiwan and watch what happens with the ECFA and its possible implications."
Upon arrival in Taiwan on May 28, Petriccione told Taiwanese officials that there should be further assessment of the possibility of a free trade agreement between Taiwan and European Union.

During a meeting the same day on Taiwan-EU trade, Petriccione also asked Taiwanese officials about the progress of the trade pact talks between Taiwan and China, according to a Taiwanese official who was at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: China should adopt new approach on Tiananmen: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 23:28:45 (By Garfie Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on China Wednesday to address issues related to the Tiananmen Incident with a new approach.
Ma issued the call in an interview with the BBC in Chinese two days ahead of the 21st anniversary of the incident, which occurred on June 4, 1989.
Ma said that every year since the crackdown he has either participated in activities commemorating the incident or has issued a statement.

He told the BBC that he has always been concerned about the incident as it was a historic event connected to human rights. The Chinese government has to face it squarely and take steps to heal wounds, sort out the feelings of injustice and ease the pain of victims and their families, Ma said.
He pointed out that similar events have taken place in other countries, including the 228 Incident and the White Terror Era in Taiwan.

The 228 Incident refers to the anti-government uprising that began in February 1947 and subsequently led to a brutal crackdown by the then Kuomintang-led government that is widely believed to have resulted in thousands of deaths.
The White Terror Era refers to a crackdown on advocates of communism, Taiwan independence and democratic reforms by the KMT in the 1950s and 1960s.
The crackdown measures adopted during the martial law era from 1949-1987 are now considered a main source of the problem.
Taking Taiwan's experience in handling the aftermath of the incidents as an example, Ma said the government opted to face the facts and take measures to heal wounds caused by the incidents.
It is inevitable that the government has to assume full responsibility when armed conflict breaks out, the president said.
Noting that the circumstances in China now are totally different than when the Tiananmen Incident occurred, Ma said that it is time to do something about it.
On cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Ma said he did not see an immediate need for leaders of Taiwan and China to meet, and that it is more important to lay a solid foundation for future development.
For example, Ma said that though leaders of South Korea and North Korea have met, there has been little progress made in other areas.
The president said he has no plan to invite Chinese leaders to visit Taiwan and did not expect leaders in the other side to invite him to China.
He also said he is glad to see improvements in cross-strait relations and will work to allow the two sides to engage in closer interactions under a peaceful atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prize-winning works in Taiwan-sponsored contest shown in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 18:57:31 (By Tang Pei-chun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of prize-winning works in a Taiwan-sponsored international children's painting contest opened in Singapore Tuesday as part of Taiwan's efforts to boost cultural exchanges and art education.

Taiwan's Association for Education Through Art and the Association for Formative Art Education have jointly organized the annual contest for 40 consecutive years and decided for the first time this year to showcase the winning works abroad.
Vanessa Shih, Taiwan's representative in Singapore, as well as various other dignitaries, attended the opening ceremony of the 40th World School Children's Art Exhibition.
Shih described the exhibition, which includes artworks from over 50 countries, as a "meaningful cross-cultural art event."
School children in Singapore will be invited to the exhibition to participate in storytelling contests and discussions of the paintings, she added.

Wu Long-rong, chairman of the Association for Education Through Art, said his association hopes relations and cooperation in art education between Singapore and Taiwan will improve as a result of the exhibition.
After the Singapore exhibition, the artworks will also go on show in Malaysia, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hundreds of state firm employees protest vague status
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:03:35 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of employees of state-run firms staged a protest Wednesday, calling for the government to clarify their status and ensure that they are provided with benefits to which they are entitled.

Demonstrating in front of the Legislative Yuan, the protesters -- union members from several state-owned enterprises, including Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) , Taiwan Sugar Corp., CPC Corp., Taiwan, and Taiwan Water Corp. -- accused the government of failing to enshrine their rights and clear status under the law.
They urged the government to clarify whether they are classed as government civil servants or laborers.

Pan Hsin-chung, secretary-general of the Taipower union, said that due to the vagueness of their status, employees of state-owned companies are not entitled to labor pensions under the Labor Standards Act.

At the same time, Pan said, they are also not entitled to the monthly pension civil servants receive after retirement or the preferential 18 percent bank deposit interest rate that civil servants get.
Worse still, he went on, employees of state-owned companies are nevertheless subject to punishments designed for civil servants should they misbehave.
Pan said that as a state-run company employee, he feels like an orphan, sacrificed on the one hand to a twisted legal structure, while being misunderstood by the public on the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidates launch joint campaign for mayoral races
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:08:25 (By S.F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) candidates in November's mayoral elections in Xinbei City and Kaohsiung City, jointly launched their campaigns Wednesday and vowed to win the races through a show of unity.

Eric Liluan Chu and Huang Chao-shun unveiled their joint campaign theme of "building both Xinbei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south into trade and commerce hubs" at a ceremony presided over by Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wang at the council headquarters.
Chu and Huang pledged to achieve the goal of boosting regional development through joint efforts and described the two areas as complementary.
Chu said he is capable of creating a sound investment environment to lure back the many foreign-based Taiwan businessmen who have left the areas.
"I am poised to create a win-win situation for both southern and northern Taiwan," he said.

Huang for her part promised to make Kaohsiung into a trade and commerce hub for air and sea transport in the Asia-Pacific region, helping the city regain the vigor and prosperity it enjoyed 10 years ago.

The mayoral elections will take place Nov. 27 in five special municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- whose populations together account for 70 percent of the country's total.
The races are widely viewed as a bellwether for the 2012 presidential election at a time when President Ma Ying-jeou's approval ratings have sunk to a low ebb.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. scholar to receive NTNU outstanding alumni award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:26:54 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Stanford University emeritus professor Albert Dien, one of the first foreign students to study Mandarin at National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) , has returned to Taiwan after more than half a century to accept an outstanding alumni award from the university on June 4.
"Before I came to Taiwan in 1956, I had studied classic Chinese for 10 years in the United States, but I could not speak a word of Mandarin," Dien said at a welcome reception at NTNU Wednesday.

The 82-year-old scholar recalled that during his first week in Taipei, he could not speak enough Mandarin to order food at a restaurant so he ate moon cakes from street stands for a whole week, as it was around the time of moon festival.

After Dien's return to the U.S., he became a major figure in Chinese and Asian academic disciplines, serving as chairman of the East Asia Sectional Committee and American Oriental Society, and director of the Stanford East Asia National Resource Center, among other posts.
"Definitely, the training I received in Taiwan during the two years I spent here was important to my whole life," he said.
The first group of foreign students -- Dien and four others -- to study Mandarin at NTNU helped promote the establishment of the university's Mandarin Training Center (MTC) in 1956.

Dien and his wife Ding Shu-fang, a graduate of NTNU's English Department, expressed appreciation to the school for providing them with what they said was a good education and the chance to meet each other.

NTU's Mandarin Training Center, which teaches Chinese as a second language, is the largest of its kind in Taiwan, with an enrollment of 1,500 students from more than 60 countries each academic quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 40% of parents want their kids to attend summer camps: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:40:22 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: With the approach of the long summer vacation, nearly 40 percent of the parents of 4th to 6th grade children surveyed recently said they want their kids to sign up for local summer camps, according to the survey results released Wednesday by the Taipei-based King Car Educational Foundation.

The results of the survey on summer activities also show that more than 40 percent of the parents who answered the poll revealed that they have decided to enroll their children in various courses during the two-month summer break.

According to the survey of 10 to 12-year-old children and their parents, travel camps are the most popular kind of summer camp among children, with 55.7 percent of the children surveyed saying they want to attend that kind of camp this summer.

Sport-oriented summer camps are the second-most popular, attracting 54.88 percent of the respondent kids, followed by art camps (31.53 percent) , science camps (27.91 percent) and ecology camps (22.92 percent).
Parents, however, listed their order of preference as ecology camps (56.36 percent), travel camps (34.48 percent), sports camps (33 percent), and science camps (27.88 percent).

Art camps for activities such as painting, music and drama were not even on the list of parent preferences, suggesting that despite government efforts to promote aesthetic education in recent years, most parents are uninterested, the King Car Foundation concluded.
A total of 1,496 valid student samples and 1,495 parent samples were collected for the survey, which was conducted May 1-12. The margin of error reached plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan corrects Cabinet over poor IPR investment return
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 19:42:53 (By Sophie Yeh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan passed a motion Wednesday to correct the Executive Yuan over low return on the government's investment in intellectual property rights (IPR) research.

Citing findings of its study, the Control Yuan -- the top monitor of government integrity -- said the executive branch budgets nearly NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion) for science and technology research annually, but combined IPR revenues of agencies under the Executive Yuan only total slightly more than NT$700 million.
The disparity indicates the government has failed to work out an overall strategy and efficient measures to cope with IPR issues, the Control Yuan said in its statement of censure.

Chao Jung-yao, one of two Control Yuan members who initiated the motion to study IPR investment, said that South Korea -- Taiwan's major trade competitor -- has over the past decades narrowed the gap between its IPR investment and earnings and almost achieved a balance.
Chao said Taiwan has made little progress in this regard.
Over the past five years, Chao said, the government's annual IPR investment accounted for 2.7 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP).
Chao added that Taiwan spends over NT$100 billion in royalty and trademark fees annually, but its royalty revenues total only about NT$7 billion or NT$8 billion.
Huang Huang-hsiung, Chao's colleague, said that although Taiwan produces many academic papers annually, their value is questionable.
Huang quoted former National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen as having said that 90 percent of those papers were of little to no commercial value.

In the process of investigating the case, Huang said he and Chao had visited a number of private enterprises, many of which mentioned problems involving "patent trolls, " people or companies that enforce patents in an overly aggressive or opportunistic manner, usually without any intention of actually manufacturing or marketing the patented invention.

As small- and medium-size enterprises form the backbone of Taiwan's economy, Huang said, the government should follow South Korea's example by setting up a fund to procure patents owned by its universities or research institutes, or to support technological research projects to prevent them from flowing out of the country or being obtained by "patent trolls."

The government should also encourage or help local industries to establish integrated platforms for IPR exchanges, Huang said, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs should reinforce the manpower and professional capability of its Intellectual Property Office to speed up patent screening and quality to better protect locally developed intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Philippines might sign free trade agreement
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:04:17 (By Emerson Lin and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Trade ministers from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum are scheduled to meet this weekend in the Japanese city of Sapporo, and Taiwan and the Philippines are expected to discuss the possibility of signing a free trade agreement (FTA) on the sidelines of the meeting.

Taiwan's representative office in the Philippines told CNA that Taiwanese officials have promised to push for the agreement and expressed hope that bilateral trade relations will make significant progress in the short term.

Philippines Trade and Industry Secretary Jesli Lapus said he is interested in any deals that would increase foreign investment and that a bilateral trade agreement could further strengthen trade links between Taiwan and the Philippines.

The Philippines and Taiwan signed a memorandum of understanding for the creation of an economic corridor between the Subic Bay Freeport Zone in the Philippines and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan in 2005, and it is now time to upgrade this to a national level, he said.

However, the issue requires a certain degree of diplomatic sensitivity that will need to be handled delicately, Lapus said, adding that the Philippines follows a one-China policy that recognizes the Beijing's government as the sole legitimate government of China.
According to statistics released by the Manila Economic and Cultural Office, the amount of Taiwanese capital invested in Philippines in 2009 was over US$113 million.

Another report conducted by the Philippines' National Economic and Development Authority also suggested that once Taiwan signs a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, Taiwanese capital will leave the Philippines and flow into China, which could cause thousands of Philippines workers to lose their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister urges speedy amendment of allocation act
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:26:45 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah called for the quick passage of amendments to the Act Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures to facilitate the upgrade and merger of several cities and counties into special municipalities.

Jiang issued the call Wednesday during a meeting with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, Lai Ching-te, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate for the Tainan municipality mayoral election, and several local government officials and DPP representatives.

Jiang said that after the Cabinet approved a plan to re-map Taiwan's administrative zones, his ministry created a task force that has met every two months since last September to handle related affairs. After elections later this year, Taipei County will be upgraded to "Xinbei City, " Taichung City and county will be merged, Kaohsiung City and county will merge, and Tainan City and county will merge to form special municipalities.

The task force has created a data bank and information systems, Jiang said, but added that some issues such as financial policies and the municipal governments' rights and obligations have yet to be settled.

The minister said issues concerning labor inspections, traffic supervision and transfers of business operations at public senior high schools and medical institutions are expected to be addressed before October.
The budget and staff of cities and counties will also be handed over as part of the transfers of business operations to the newly formed municipalities, Jiang said.

He said that amendments to the act were crucial to whether the transfer of business operations from the existing local governments to the new municipalities and municipal budget allocations can be completed by 2011.
Jiang was responding to complaints of a potential financial shortfall in the future Kaohsiung and Tainan municipalities.

Hao Chien-sheng, secretary-general of the Kaohsiung City government, said that despite an increase to NT$14.3 billion (US$443 million) in revenue allocation for the new Kaohsiung municipality, it would still see a financial shortfall. Hao said that based on the current allocation act, expenditures would be at least NT$26.2 billion.

Transfer of business operations after the merger will require a lot of money, and an exact division of powers and functions between the central and local governments has not been established, he said.
Hao also suggested the central government retain temporary workers hired by the local governments' township offices.
Chen said she hoped the merger could help narrow the gap between urban and rural areas.
Lai expressed concern that the future Tainan municipality would have to spend about NT$20 billion, but would only be allocated NT$8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swiss bank releases US$1.52 m. from former first family's account
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:32:59 (By Lin Chung-sen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A Swiss bank on Wednesday remitted to Taiwan US$1.52 million from accounts held in the names of former President Chen Shui-bian's family members, according to Taiwan's Special Investigation Division (SID).

The Swiss bank wired two sums of US$529,617 and US$1 million into an SID designated account from the family's accounts in Switzerland which hold a total of US$21 million and had been frozen since 2007.

It was second time in two weeks that funds had been released from the accounts, as the Swiss bank wired US$2 million two weeks ago into the SID-designated account. This means that so far, close to US$3.53 million has been returned to Taiwan from the family's accounts in Switzerland, the SID said.

In addition to the US$21 billion that was frozen in Merrill Lynch Bank (Suisse) S.A. and the Royal Bank of Scotland, the former first family in June 2007 had also transferred to a Swiss bank NT$570 million (US$17.67 million) of the NT$740 million it had in a Cathay United Bank vault, according to the SID.
The SID had asked the Swiss bank to freeze the NT$570 million because it was considered a bribe that had been paid to the family by Taiwan's financial holding companies.

The ex-president's son Chen Chih-chung said earlier this month that his family will cooperate with the SID by returning to Taiwan the US$21 million it holds in Swiss bank accounts, but he did not say whether the NT$570 million will be returned.
Prosecutors believe that all of the funds held in Swiss banks in the family's name were illegally acquired and should be confiscated.
The former president, who has been in detention since Nov. 12, 2008 on charges of corruption, has been sentenced to life imprisonment.
The Taiwan High Court judge who presided over Chen's appeal of his life sentence, had suggested that the former president return the money to Taiwan if he wishes to be released on bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to learn from Dutch 'cycling paradise'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:35:44 (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should learn from the bicycle-friendly Netherlands to improve both the island's environment and the public's well-being, the president of the world's largest bicycle manufacturer said Wednesday.

Announcing plans to embark on a cycling trip in the Netherlands later this month, Giant Global Group President King Liu said at a press conference that 27 percent of all Dutch travel is done by bicycle. In other words, he said, Dutch ride bicycles not just for fun but also for practical, utilitarian purposes -- unlike Taiwan.
"It would be a dream come true if I could help bring Taiwan up to that level," he said.
Starting on June 14, Liu will spend six days on a 500 kilometer ride through the nation he described as a "cycling paradise."

Liu said Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials will also participate on the trip, dubbed "Green World on Wheels, " and study the cycling infrastructure of the Netherlands to find ways Taiwan can improve its cycling environment.

Describing himself as "born on a bicycle, " Menno Goedhart, the representative of the Netherlands Trade & Investment Office in Taipei, said that even though he has seen tremendous improvement in Taiwan's cycling culture, there is still a long way to go.

MOTC statistics show the total length of bike lanes in Taiwan was 2,170 km by the end of 2009, while a review published by Rutgers University last year said the Netherlands already had about 20,000 km of bike paths and lanes by the end of 1996.
During a survey conducted by the ministry this March, 40.1 percent of 9,236 participants said they would be more willing to ride a bike if the country was safer and more friendly for cyclists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition by Mexican photographer opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:36:19 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of 40 photos by Mexican photographer Pedro Vazqueznieto opened at the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Wednesday, the Mexican Trade Services Documentation and Cultural Office in Taiwan said.
The show, which features photos of the city of Guanajuato, is the first leg of an Asian tour of the exhibition in celebration of the 200th anniversary of Mexico's independence.
"We organized the exhibition to promote Mexican culture and tourism, " said Martin Munoz Ledo Villegas, head of the Mexican office.
Munoz Ledo said he hopes to let Taiwanese people know more about the beauty of the city of Guanajuato through the event, which was listed as a world cultural heritage site by UNESCO in 1988.
The city was founded by the Spanish in the early 16th century and was the world's leading silver-extraction center in the 18th century.
Munoz Ledo said the works of the internationally renowned photographer show the multi-faceted beauty of the city and include photos of the University of Guanajuato, his alma mater.
The event will run through July 3 in Taipei and will later move to Taichung before going to Vietnam, the city of Guangzhou in China, New Zealand, Singapore, Japan, Australia and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 10% of jobs demand engineering degrees: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 20:56:10 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Almost 10 percent of employers in the job market seek graduates with engineering majors, an online job bank survey showed Wednesday.
Yes123 website said that when employers list requirements for education background in their job advertisements, the most common request is for people with science or engineering degrees.

The survey found 9.74 percent of offered jobs require engineering degrees, which is the most common requirement, followed by industrial and mechanics (8.91 percent) and business management (7.35 percent).
Yes123 also said that employers were paying less attention to diplomas, preferring to focus on work experience or certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget for biomedical park project in Hsinchu unfrozen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 21:26:58 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee unfroze the budget for a biomedical science park in Hsinchu County Wednesday after the administration reverted to the original plan for the park, according to the head of the National Science Council (NSC).
In a report to the committee, NSC Minister Lee Lou-chuang said the park will be used for translational research and to provide care to acutely and critically ill patients, as was previously planned.

The committee decided to unfreeze the NT$120 million budget after it was given the assurance that the Department of Health's (DOH's) plan to set up a medical center in the park to attract international medical tourism had been suspended.
Legislators were worried that the DOH's proposal to recruit businesses to develop medical tourism would have put profit before medical research.
According to a DOH official Huang Kun-chang, translational research can broadly include research on genetic protein and stem cells, and the development of new drugs, medical equipment and reagents.
The focus will depend on which biomedical or pharmaceutical companies are participating in the work at the park, he said.
The NSC will establish a research and development center in the park, while the Ministry of Economic Affairs will build an industry incubator center, and the DOH plans to set up a hospital, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan entitled to sign official pacts with other countries: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:11:42 (By Garfie Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that as an independent and sovereign country, the Republic of China has signed many official pacts and agreements with other countries in the past, and will endeavor to continue to do so.
Ma, was responding to a statement by a spokesman for China's foreign ministry the previous day that Beijing is opposed to Taiwan signing any free trade agreements (FTAs) with foreign countries.

"Trade has been the lifeline of Taiwan, and Taiwan cannot survive if there is no trade, " Ma said at a weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang, of which he is chairman.
He said that Taiwan as a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) "is entitled to sign any trade deals with other WTO members and this right cannot be interfered with for any reason."
In an interview with the BBC Wednesday morning, Ma again urged Beijing "not to stand in Taiwan's way of clinching FTAs with foreign countries."

Ma made a similar statement on April 25 during a televised debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on whether Taiwan should ink an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Ma's administration is hoping the cross-strait trade pact could be signed in June to help boost Taiwan's competitiveness in the global arena.
Ma told the BBC that the June schedule remains unchanged, but the details of some issues related to the pact have yet to be worked out.
Taiwan government officials have reiterated that the ECFA would help pave the way for Taiwan to ink FTAs with other major economies.

In related news, DPP Chairwoman Tsai said that the latest statement by the Chinese spokesman highlighted the fact that Beijing will continue to hobble Taiwan's FTA efforts even after the ECFA is signed, and proved that her party "is right to oppose the ECFA."
She said that one of the government's touted advantages of the ECFA -- that it will serve as springboard to other FTAs -- will not come to fruition.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will increase Taiwan's competitiveness: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:25:25 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will benefit Taiwan by boosting the country's competitiveness and attraction for foreign investors.

In an interview with the BBC conducted in Chinese at the Presidential Office, Ma said there has been a boom of free trade agreements (FTA) in the Asia region over the past decade -- from three to the current 58 -- and that unless Taiwan takes action quickly, it will face further isolation.

The purpose of the ECFA, he said, is to normalize the existing robust cross- strait trade relationship. By doing so, it will maximize profit margins, encouraging Taiwanese businesses to stay in Taiwan and luring more foreign investment.
Taipei and Beijing have tentatively agreed to sign the agreement in June, he said, but a specific date has yet to be announced.

The president also stressed that by forging a trade pact with Beijing, it is hoped that other countries will be encouraged to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) or similar deals with Taiwan -- an idea that has been long been opposed by Beijing.
The Chinese foreign ministry reaffirmed its stance the previous day that Beijing strongly objects to Taiwan signing FTAs with other countries.
"We hope and ask China not to impede our efforts in signing FTAs with other countries because the agreements are vital to Taiwan's livelihood," he told the BBC.

As members of the World Trade Organization (WTO), both China and Taiwan have the right to establish free trade relationships with other WTO members and Beijing should not stand in Taiwan's way, he said.

While the administration has repeatedly touted the EFCA, many in Taiwan, especially the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, have warned that the pact will make Taiwan further dependent on China's economy and compromise Taiwan's sovereignty.

The president acknowledged the fear and said the government is aware of potential setbacks, which is why the administration has been working very carefully to ensure Taiwan's rights will not be compromised in the process, he said.

"I have said before in open debates that if there is any possibility that Taiwan's rights will be harmed by the trade pact, then I would rather see the negotiations collapse than have the deal go through, " he said. "This is why we are taking each step very carefully."

In answering a question from a BBC viewer who inquired about Ma's view on "eventual unification, " the president emphasized his "no unification, no independence, no war" stance on cross-strait ties. He said that during his tenure he will not push for unification with China, and that because the Republic of China has been independent since 1912, he will also not support Taiwan's de jure independence.

Last month marked Ma's second anniversary in office. Looking back on the last two years, the president said the country has faced many trials, including the worldwide economic contraction and the most devastating and costly flooding the country has ever seen.

"Although we had many difficulties, we have also gained confidence in ourselves and we have been making good progress, " he said, adding that Taiwan's growth, overall competitiveness and government efficiency have all received excellent international ratings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shenzhen wage increase threatens Taiwanese firms
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:33:31 (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A planned wage increase for factory workers in Shenzhen, China could create a heavy burden on Taiwanese companies and squeeze some of them out of the market, a Taiwanese business representative said Wednesday.

Shenzhen authorities are likely to announce a 20 percent wage hike in the minimum wage that would take effect from July, said Hung Jia-sheng, vice chairman of the Shenzhen Taiwan Business Association.
Hung told the Central News Agency that the measure will deal another heavy blow to Shenzhen-based Taiwanese enterprises, which only recently begun to recover from the global financial tsunami.

"Although many said they had no choice but to accept the wage raise ordered by the Shenzhen City government, some could be eliminated by a fresh wave of operating difficulties, " Hung said by telephone.

At present, there are two levels of minimum wages for workers in Shenzhen. The minimum at factories near the city center is 1,000 yuan (NT$4,740) a month, while those on the city's outskirts must pay at least 900 yuan a month. Minimum wage in Taiwan is NT$17,280.

Hung said Tuesday's decision by Taiwanese high-tech giant Foxconn to adopt a 30 percent increase in monthly wages starting June 11 will affect other companies operating in the area. Foxconn's decision came after a spate of suicides at its factory in Shenzhen's Longhua area.
However, other Taiwan businesspeople were reserved about such a development.

Yeh Chung-jung, chairman of the Dongguan Taiwan Business Association, said Foxconn's hike would not have a large effect on other Taiwanese firms, as what happened to Foxconn was simply an isolated case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister declares war on organized crime
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:39:29 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Police forces will be fully mobilized to crack down on the illegal possession of firearms and to bring to justice fugitive suspects involved shooting cases in an all-out effort to improve public order, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday.

Speaking at a special session of the Legislative Yuan's Internal Administration Committee on public order in central Taiwan's Taichung City following a string of shocking daytime shootouts there, Jiang said his ministry is working on a blueprint to clamp down on criminal ringleaders.
On a May 28 shooting incident that claimed two lives, Jiang said that four Taichung City Police Bureau staff who were present at the crime scene have been punished.

Citing the police bureau's initial investigations, Jiang said the four police officers were invited by a retired colleague to a biotech company for a chat. None of them knew that the company was run by Weng Chi-nan, an underworld gang leader who died in a shower of bullets in the shooting incident.

Two higher-ranking officers -- Lin Chi-you, a traffic police squad leader, and Lin Wen-wu, a detective police squad leader -- have been removed from their leadership posts and slapped with demerits, Jiang said.

The two lower-ranking officers -- Shih Chang-hsing and Tai Chih-hung -- were given a serious warning as they were reportedly just carrying out their duty by driving their superiors to the gang leader's office. Shih sustained an injury to one of his toes in the shooting.

On Taichung's public order, Jiang said that compared with the same period last year, the number of criminal cases reported in the city showed a downward trend and the ratio of cases solved had also declined slightly.
Nevertheless, he added, all major criminal cases listed by the Interior Ministry's National Police Agency (NPA) for special monitoring have been resolved with the exception of the latest shooting.

Jiang said the ministry has ordered the Taichung City Police Bureau and the NPA's Criminal Investigation Bureau to set up a special task force to track down the fugitive gunman and other suspects involved in the case.

At the city police bureau's request, the NPA has assigned 40 SWAT team members to serve in Taichung to help maintain public order. The SWAT team members started conducting spot checks Wednesday at major streets around the city day and night in a high-intensity campaign to deter organized crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3D gesture-based controller to be new rehab device: institute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 22:50:09 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: A combination of 3D and gesture-based remote control technologies are poised to be commercialized for physical rehabilitation applications, a research institute said Wednesday.

At Computex Taipei, Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) displayed an interactive glass-free 3D digital signage that uses two household webcams to immediately recognize hand gestures.

"You can set the functions by using different gestures, " said Peter Chew, promotion director of ITRI's 3D System and Application Division. "For example, you can make a fist to zoom in on an image and wave your hand to turn the page."
This application can be used in the fields of advertising, gaming, or even medical treatment, he said.
"The technology will be applied in physical rehabilitation by using hand gestures to change the 3D images, " said Chew, adding that patients will have more fun with such interaction.
Asked which manufacturer is interested and when the product will hit the market, Chew said it is too early to say.
Wii, a Japanese home video game console that was released a few years ago, is now being used in settings like hospitals, nursing homes and clinics for all types of rehab devices.
Chew said that 3D digital signage is just the beginning and he is optimistic about the future of its applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's FTA goals achievable: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 23:07:05 (By Jorge Liu, Alex Jiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be able to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries as long as it does not seek to forge such pacts for political purposes, said a U.S. expert on cross-strait affairs Wednesday.

Bonnie Glaser, a senior research fellow with the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, told the Central News Agency that she does not think " Beijing is adamantly opposed to Taiwan signing economic agreements with other countries, but it does have some concerns, and perhaps even prcondictions."

A spokesman for China's foreign ministry said the previous day that "Beijing is opposed to Taiwan signing any agreements 'of an official nature' with foreign countries, but it maintains a hands-off policy with regard to Taiwan developing unofficial trade and economic relations with them."

Glaser said that, first of all, Beijing might insist that Taiwan use a moniker in such agreements that is consistent with past practice. Taiwan was admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO) under the name "the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."
Secondly, she said, China could insist that Taiwan give priority to negotiating a cross-strait economic agreement and that there be no linkage between the ECFA and other FTAs.
Finally, Beijing could stipulate that other counties sign FTAs with China first, before considering Taiwan, she said.
However, Glaser said, none of those concerns or preconditions would be "insurmountable barriers" to Taiwan signing trade pacts with other countries.

Glaser said that she believes that Beijing will not stand in the way of Taiwan's inclusion in the regional economic process, in light of China President Hu Jintao's statement last December that China will give due consideration to Taiwan in this regard.
Besides, under the framework of the WTO, economic agreements among members are permitted, Glaser said, adding that China does not have reasonable grounds on which to oppose such agreements.

"As long as Taiwan does not seek to use the signing of economic agreements with other countries for political purposes, as was done in the past when Chen Shui- bian was president, this (signing of FTAs) is a goal that is achievable under President Ma Ying-jeou's leadership," she said.
Meanwhile, a visiting European Commission official declined to comment on China's latest remark on the possibility of Taiwan signing FTAs with other countries.

Mauro Petriccione, head of the commission's Directorate General of Trade (B) , said before a European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) luncheon that he was not sure exactly how China had voiced its opposition and therefore he could not comment.
Addressing the luncheon, Petriccione said that "we will continue to work with Taiwan and watch what happens with the ECFA and its possible implications."
Upon arrival in Taiwan on May 28, Petriccione told Taiwanese officials that there should be further assessment of the possibility of a free trade agreement between Taiwan and European Union.

During a meeting the same day on Taiwan-EU trade, Petriccione also asked Taiwanese officials about the progress of the trade pact talks between Taiwan and China, according to a Taiwanese official who was at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: China should adopt new approach on Tiananmen: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 2 (CNA) 06/02/10 23:28:45 (By Garfie Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on China Wednesday to address issues related to the Tiananmen Incident with a new approach.
Ma issued the call in an interview with the BBC in Chinese two days ahead of the 21st anniversary of the incident, which occurred on June 4, 1989.
Ma said that every year since the crackdown he has either participated in activities commemorating the incident or has issued a statement.

He told the BBC that he has always been concerned about the incident as it was a historic event connected to human rights. The Chinese government has to face it squarely and take steps to heal wounds, sort out the feelings of injustice and ease the pain of victims and their families, Ma said.
He pointed out that similar events have taken place in other countries, including the 228 Incident and the White Terror Era in Taiwan.

The 228 Incident refers to the anti-government uprising that began in February 1947 and subsequently led to a brutal crackdown by the then Kuomintang-led government that is widely believed to have resulted in thousands of deaths.
The White Terror Era refers to a crackdown on advocates of communism, Taiwan independence and democratic reforms by the KMT in the 1950s and 1960s.
The crackdown measures adopted during the martial law era from 1949-1987 are now considered a main source of the problem.
Taking Taiwan's experience in handling the aftermath of the incidents as an example, Ma said the government opted to face the facts and take measures to heal wounds caused by the incidents.
It is inevitable that the government has to assume full responsibility when armed conflict breaks out, the president said.
Noting that the circumstances in China now are totally different than when the Tiananmen Incident occurred, Ma said that it is time to do something about it.
On cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Ma said he did not see an immediate need for leaders of Taiwan and China to meet, and that it is more important to lay a solid foundation for future development.
For example, Ma said that though leaders of South Korea and North Korea have met, there has been little progress made in other areas.
The president said he has no plan to invite Chinese leaders to visit Taiwan and did not expect leaders in the other side to invite him to China.
He also said he is glad to see improvements in cross-strait relations and will work to allow the two sides to engage in closer interactions under a peaceful atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 3, 2010, or the 21st day of the fourth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King" and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium in Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories include "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus" and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American sweetheart, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The U.S. Navy launches an attack against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treason. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution, with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for U.S. Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of the state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: An earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: A train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen visits the offshore islands of Tungyin and Matsu, his first visit to the frontline islands since he assumed the post on May 20.
2001: Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, says that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square is a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being forward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 09:58:34 (By Y.F. Low)

The weighted price index lost 93.62 points, or 1.28 percent, to close at 7,195.71 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Content to be China's concubine?

TEXT.P: China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs Spokesman Ma Zhaoxu on Tuesday expressed Beijing's opposition to the establishment of official agreements between Taiwan and other countries when asked about Taiwan's plan to negotiate free trade agreements (FTAs) with its trade partners after concluding an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

This statement means that signing the ECFA is not equal to gaining an international pass to FTAs, as the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou expected. What Beijing was trying to say was that the "Republic of China" was not a country and that the Ma administration was only a "humble concubine" who had no right to ask for an equal footing with China.

The Referendum Screening Committee under the Executive Yuan will issue its ruling Thursday night on whether a referendum initiative on the ECFA will be permitted. This will be the best opportunity for the Ma administration to answer the question of whether it is a "humble concubine."
The Ma administration must not overlook the seriousness of this matter and should allow the referendum to become the last democratic mechanism to protect the Taiwanese people. (June 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares continue momentum in mid-morning trade
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 11:01:21 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices extended momentum in mid-morning trade Thursday after investors took cues from a jump on Wall Street overnight, dealers said.
A rebound on the high-tech-rich NASDAQ also boosted buying in local counterparts, in particular large cap electronic stocks on a rebound from recent heavy losses, they added.
At 10:30 a.m., the weighted index had risen 135.88 points or 1.89 percent to 7,331.59 on turnover of NT$34.41 billion (US$1.07) after opening 1.76 percent higher than Wednesday's close.
"The current buying largely came from foreign institutional investors who had served as the major sellers in the past few sessions," Tom MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
"They are buying into electronic heavyweights," Tang said.
However, Tang said it remains to be seen whether the local bourse has returned to an upward trend after recent declines.
"The market remains choppy. Once Wall Street falls again, the local bourse is expected to face volatility, " Tang said.
Personal computer maker Acer had risen 4.78 percent to NT$78.80 and integrated circuit designer MediaTek had gained 2.71 percent to NT$530.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Will China make dramatic concession on ECFA?

TEXT.P: On the eve of Taiwan's announcement on whether to approve an initiative to hold a referendum on a planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, a Beijing official revealed that the number of Taiwanese industries or services to benefit from the accord's "early harvest" program could reach 500.

The number was far higher than Taiwan earlier expected. In a recent interview with Reuters, Premier Wu Den-yih said Taiwan wants at least 300 items included in the "early harvest" list for tariff concessions or easier market access terms.
Also on Wednesday, President Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed in an interview with BBC his administration's plan to sign an ECFA with China in June, but he added that a specific date has yet to be decided.

Ma acknowledged in the interview that Taiwan hopes its ECFA deal with China will facilitate its bid to sign similar pacts or free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries and asked China not to stand in Taiwan's way to realize its ultimate goal.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

A Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs mentioned for the first time Wednesday that the number of Taiwanese goods and services to be subject to tariff waivers or preferential market access terms under the ECFA's "early harvest" program may reach as high as 500.

The disclosure of the possibility of China making a dramatic concession to Taiwan over the "early harvest" list came after a Chinese foreign ministry official's recent reaffirmation of Beijing's objection to Taiwan signing FTAs with other countries drew broadsides from Taiwan's opposition camp.

Noting that concluding negotiations on the "early harvest" list marks the first step to signing the ECFA, the Chinese official said China will refrain from asking Taiwan to offer the same preferential treatment to its industries and services as it offers Taiwan.
Asked about his view on the Chinese official's remarks, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung said that as ECFA negotiations are still ongoing, he cannot make any comments.
Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang is scheduled to head for Japan Thursday to attend a ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) .

Industry sources said Shih will meet with Chinese Minister of Commerce Chen Deming on the sidelines of the APEC meeting, with ECFA issues high on their talk agenda. The Shih-Chen meeting may lead to a final settlement of the "early harvest" list, the sources said. (June 3, 2010).
United Daily News:

President Ma said in the interview with BBC that Taiwan hopes China will refrain from impeding its efforts to sign FTAs with other countries because such accords are vital to Taiwan's sustainable growth.

"As WTO full members, both Taiwan and China have the right to forge free trade relationships with other WTO members, " Ma said, adding that China should not interfere with Taiwan's FTA negotiations with other WTO members.

On the planned ECFA deal with China, Ma said the main purpose is to normalize the existing flourishing cross-Taiwan Strait relationship. He also stressed that if there is any possibility that Taiwan's rights will be harmed by the pact, he would rather see ECFA negotiations collapse than have the deal go through. (June 3, 2010).
Liberty Times:
The Referendum Screening Committee under the Executive Yuan will meet Thursday evening to decide whether an opposition party-proposed referendum initiative on the ECFA will be permitted.

The meeting is expected to begin at 6 p.m. and last less than three hours. It remains uncertain whether all of the committee's 21 members will be present at the session. As of Wednesday evening, several members had yet to confirm whether they would attend.

On Wednesday, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei urged the committee members to respect people's right to have a say on the critical trade pact with China by approving the referendum initiative.
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party also said it will consider whether to mount a large-scale street protest if the referendum initiative is rejected. (June 3, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: DPP's position toward Songshan Airport
DOC.DATELINE: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 06/03/10 11:40:10 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: used to have a proposal to relocate Taipei's Songshan Airport to make way for a park there. Su Tseng-chang, the DPP's candidate for the year-end Taipei mayoral election, is reportedly struggling whether to follow his party's "anti-Songshan Airport" policy.

With Songshan Airport set to launch direct flights to Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport, Tokyo's Haneda Airport and Seoul's Gimpo Airport, Su's hesitance demonstrates that he is aware that the trend cannot be blocked by himself or the DPP.

The revival of Songshan Airport is partly thanks to a change in airport managing concepts that has been taking place internationally in recent years. Hongqiao Airport, for example, redefined its status from a domestic airport to a "regional airport" after completing a runway and terminal expansion project in March.

Another example is Haneda Airport, which was reopened to international flights after Japan felt the threat from South Korea. Maintaining direct links with 28 Japanese cities, Korea's Incheon International Airport was replacing Japan's Narita International Airport as the favorite transit venue for Japanese citizens traveling abroad. In other words, Incheon Airport's openness and close-knit international network have greatly enhanced its competitiveness.

The direct link between Songshan and Hongqiao symbolizes not only closer ties between Taipei and Shanghai, but also rosier prospects for Taipei in the East Asian aviation network. We want to remind Su to find a proper position for Songshan Airport in his policy platform. (June 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan music ensemble touches England's heart
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 2 (CNA) 06/03/10 12:32:38 (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A music ensemble from Taiwan called Sheng Dong, or as it translates in English, A Moving Sound, touched the heart of England Tuesday with a poetic musical performance.

Lead singer Mia Hsieh, her husband -- ensemble director Scott Prairie -- and four other musicians put on their Taiwan Show at RichMix art center in eastern London, attracting a capacity crowd, including leading music critics.
The group's unique musical expression fuses Taiwanese, Chinese and neighboring Asian musical influences in modern song compositions, fusing traditional and modern art.

Hsieh's vocals and dance were performed with music from Chinese instruments such as the vertically held and bowed erhu and the Chinese zhongruan, or "moon guitar, " as well as Western guitar and hand drums.
They performed 11 pieces created or adopted between 2004-2010, including "Wedding, ""Dombra, " "Fire, " "Ganesh, " and the energetic "Marketplace."
Mo Hua-wei, Taiwan's deputy representative in London, was among the audience. "The show was indeed impressive," he said.
"Despite its small size, the ensemble makes itself a great citizen diplomacy front," Mo told the Central News Agency.
Helena Lopez, another member of the audience who is a University of London student from Portugal, said A Moving Sound's artful expression of human feelings and condition is interesting and great fun.
Lopez, who was in Taiwan for a two-week holiday in the summer of 2009, said she loves the island and would like to visit again.
A Moving Sound's third CD/DVD, titled Starshine and issued earlier this year, was nominated for a Golden Melody Award -- Taiwan's version of a Grammy -- in the crossover music category.
Hsieh and Prairie, who met in New York, jointly established the band in Taipei in 2002.
