DOC.HEADLINE: Some notebook firms won't follow Foxconn pay hike
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 13:20:03 (By Chi Chin-lin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Major Taiwanese notebook computer producers that run production facilities in China said Thursday they will not raise wages at their Chinese plants after Foxconn Technology Group announced a 30 percent pay hike for its Chinese workers.

Foxconn, which has been accused of mistreating its Chinese workers, announced the pay raise in an attempt to overcome public criticism and assuage its employees after a string of suicides at its Shenzhen complex left 10 dead and two injured.

Shares of Foxconn's parent company Hon Hai Precision Industry suffered heavy selling on Taiwan's stock exchange Wednesday -- a day after the pay hike announcement -- on fears the pay increase would hurt the company's bottom line.
Daiwa-Cathay Capital Markets analyst Calvin Huang said Wednesday that Foxconn's move is expected to trigger a chain effect, prompting other Taiwanese investors on the mainland to follow suit.
Compal Electronics President Chen Jui-tsung, however, said that his company issued a pay raise last year and that its pay scale meets the demand set by authorities.
Chen said Compal, which operates plants in Kunshan of eastern Jiangsu Province, has no plans for another raise but will give extra rewards to employees who achieve the company's production target.
Quanta Computer Vice Chairman Liang Tzu-chen said his company also follows the requirements of the Chinese government in employee compensation, adding that Quanta's wages are above the minimum.

Liang said Quanta, which runs production facilities in Jiangsu Province, has tried hard to improve the working environment and hopes its employees can take advantage of the company's efforts and get along well with each other.
Wistron Corp. officials said their company has been very competitive in employee compensation, so it sees no need to consider a pay hike for the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA head speaks at Haiti aid summit about aid
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 14:17:02 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung talked about Taiwan's assistance to Haiti and other plans to help the recovery of the quake-ravaged Caribbean country, at a Haiti aid summit Wednesday in the Dominican Republic.

At the summit that was opened by Dominican President Leonel Fernandez, Chen said the Taiwan government will deliver on its promise to help with the post-quake reconstruction in Haiti, according to a press release by the Embassy of the Republic of China in the Dominican Republic.

Chen also told Haitian Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive that he and the Taiwan delegation will visit Haiti after the summit to get a first-hand look at the reconstruction work there and to see what is needed.

Since Haiti was struck by a 7.0-magnitude earthquake Jan. 12, the Taiwan government has been working with private charities and non-governmental organizations to send medical and reconstruction teams and emergency supplies to the Caribbean ally.
Taiwan has also offered some debt relief to Haiti in the form of about US$12 to US$13 million in loan interest payments and a five-year suspension of principal payments.
In addition, Taiwan has promised to provide Haiti with about US$10 million in aid annually over the next decade through bilateral cooperation projects.
Taiwan's total aid package to Haiti over the next decade is estimated at around US$121.37 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dates set for Jones Cup basketball tournament
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 14:26:35 (Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The R. William Jones Cup International Invitational Tournament, Taiwan's top international hoop event, will be held from July 13-21, a Taiwan basketball official said Thursday.

Seven men's teams and five women's teams will participate in the annual tournament in Taipei County's Sinjhuang Stadium, said Lee Yi-chung, deputy secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Basketball Association (CTBA), Taiwan's top basketball governing body.

Host Taiwan will field its national teams and university all-star teams in both the men's and women's competitions, Lee said. Several of Taiwan's national players have injuries, however, and have said they will sit out in order to be in better shape to prepare for the Asian Games, which will be held in Guangzhou, China in November.
Among the men's participating teams are Japan's national team, Lebanon's national team, Iran's national second team, a club team from western Australia and the Philippines' national team.

Lee said he expected the Philippine team to be the top box office draw as usual because there are many overseas Filipino workers in Taiwan and because Filipinos are known for their passion for basketball.
"Moreover, this Philippine team was selected to compete for a berth in the Asian zone for the 2012 London Olympics. I think the team will be highly competitive, " Lee said.
In the women's competition, Japan, Kazakhstan and Lebanon will send their national teams to compete with the two home teams.

The Jones Cup started in 1977 as an invitational tourney with national teams, club teams and university teams mainly from the Asian region. It was named after Renato William Jones, one of the founders and former secretary-general of the International Basketball Federation (FIBA).

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Strategy against Northeast Asian triangle

TEXT.P: Ahead of a China-Japan-South Korea leadership summit in late May, South Korean President Lee Myung-bak proposed launching negotiations with China in the second half of 2010 or the first half of 2011 on the establishment of a Korea-China free trade area.

Seoul is eager to open free trade talks with Beijing partly because Taiwan will soon sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China. With 70 percent of Taiwan's exports to China overlapping with those of South Korea, Seoul is afraid that it might lose its edge in the Chinese market.

This tells us that when working hard toward the goal of forging the ECFA with China, Taiwan should also realize that it is racing against time. Any foul-up by Taiwan could throw it into an unfavorable situation.

The proposed China-Japan-South Korea free trade area was on the agenda of the summit. Regrettably, Taiwan is again being excluded from the golden economic and trade triangle in Northeast Asia, after having been shut out from the Southeast Asian free trade area.
How to break through the impasse is an issue that the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou cannot evade. The opposition Democratic Progressive Party must also present a viable strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE reports record high number of foreign students in Taiwan in 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 15:03:26 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The number of foreign students at Taiwan universities and colleges reached a record high in 2009, according to the Ministry of Education (MOE) Thursday.
The total number of students from abroad studying for degrees, learning Mandarin, or engaged in exchange programs was 22,300 last year, the latest MOE figures showed.
"The majority of the foreign students in Taiwan in 2009 were from Southeast Asia and India, " said CJ Liu, Director General of the MOE's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations.

A breakdown of the 2009 figures shows that Asian students accounted for 72.7 percent of the total; students from North, South and Central America 17 percent; European students 5.4 percent, African students 3.2 percent, and South Pacific Islanders 1.64 percent, he said.

"One of the goals we are focusing on is increasing the number of degree students studying in Taiwan, " said Lu, noting that the number foreign degree students in Taiwan last October was 7,764, an increase of more than 30 percent from the previous year.

In order to attract more degree students from abroad, the MOE plans to promote a better quality of teaching and an improved learning environment, rather than increase the number of scholarships offered, he said.

The government will push for internationalization of the language of instruction and the learning environment at Taiwan universities, will try to forge links with schools in other countries, and make the application process more convenient for foreign students, he added.
"We already have a high quality of teaching, an open learning environment and lower fees, which make schools in Taiwan more competitive than those in other countries," according to Liu.
Most of the degree students in Taiwan in 2009 were from Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea and the United States, in that order, Lu said.

Those studying Mandarin were mostly from the U.S., Japan, South Korea, Vietnam and Indonesia, while the majority of exchange students were from Japan, the U.S., South Korea, France and Germany, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy rain warning issued for some areas in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 15:06:40 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau issued heavy rain warnings for some areas in Taiwan Thursday, in light of the movement of a stationary front to northern Taiwan and the influence of strong northeasterly winds.
The front has increased the possibility of heavy rainfall or torrential rains in the areas of central, northern, northeastern and southern Taiwan, the bureau said.

Strong north-easterly winds will keep temperatures in northen Taiwan between 22-25 degrees Celsius during the day Thursday, dropping to around 20 degrees Celsius in the evening and early morning Friday, according to the bureau.
Compared to the torrential rain that hit southern Taiwan in May, the intensity of the rainfall this time is expected to be lower, but residents still need to be prepared, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should monitor human rights situation in China: lawyers

TEXT.P: Taiwan should take a tougher stance against the deteriorating human rights situation in China before Taiwanese nationals become victims of China's obscure legal system, a group of lawyers said Thursday on the eve of the 21st anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

Human rights lawyers from Hong Kong and Taiwan warned that if Taiwan continues to turn a blind eye to China's human rights violations, "sooner or later, China- based Taiwanese nationals will suffer," said Lin Feng-jen, executive director of the Judicial Reform Foundation.

The activists say China continues to detain, kidnap and torture human rights lawyers who speak up against the government. Several lawyers have gone missing while others had their license revoked for bucking the system, they said.
Activists said that by being under the constant threats of the government, lawyers have lost their vital role as protectors of citizens' rights.
The group called on President Ma Ying-jeou, a Harvard-trained legal scholar, to be mindful of China's human rights situation as he tries to forge closer trade relations with Beijing.

Taiwan and China are expected to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) next month. Since Ma took office in 2008, his administration has been heavily accused by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party of being too China-leaning.

In an interview with the BBC on Wednesday, the president affirmed his plan to issue a statement on the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre Friday as he has done since the bloody crackdown in 1989.
Over the last 21 years, the president said during the interview, China has made dramatic changes and improvement.

"I believe the Beijing government will undertake new measures on the issue and by doing so, it will narrow the gap between people on both side of the [Taiwan Strait] because the Taiwanese people are watching," he said. "We have always been highly concerned about the issue, especially me." (By Jenny W. Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: China should not foil Taiwan's FTA efforts: President Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 15:34:30 (By S. H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that Beijing should not disrupt Taiwan's efforts to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, stressing that Taiwan must take this path because its economy is its lifeline.
Ma made the statement, the third of its kind in two days, in a meeting at the Presidential Office with a group of representatives of Taiwan business associations in China.

China's Foreign Ministry said Monday that Beijing is not opposed to Taiwan conducting private trade and commerce exchanges with other countries, but that it objects to Taiwan clinching official agreements with any country.
"As a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Taiwan is eligible to sign FTAs with other countries, " Ma noted. "This is clearly stipulated in the WTO regulations."

Although Taiwan has inked four FTAs with its central American allies, which has helped boost Taiwan's exports to those countries, Taiwan still needs to establish FTAs with its major trading partner in order to achieve a similar goal, Ma said.

"Our main trading partner is China and that is why we have been seeking to clinch a cross-strait trade agreement, " the president said, adding that Taiwan cannot afford to ignore the vast China market.

"We will first conclude the pact with China before approaching other countries, " Ma said. "Taiwan must take that path for its own development and survival and China should not foil Taiwan's efforts."
According to Ma, Taiwan is aiming to clinch a cross-strait ECFA to lower tariffs on exports to China, protect intellectual property rights and guarantee the interests of Taiwan businesses there.

"Taiwan companies are also welcome to return and invest at home," he said, adding that the government has been assessing the feasibility of building an exclusive zone for foreign-based Taiwan businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-tech sector lifts Taiwan shares
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 16:05:16 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 2.28 percent Thursday as buying focused on the high-tech sector after investors witnessed a strong showing on Wall Street overnight, dealers said.
The weighted index closed up 164.57 points at 7,360.28, off a low of 7,309.46 and a high of 7,361.70, with turnover of NT$79.02 billion (US$2.45 billion).

The market opened 1.76 percent higher across the board on a 2.3 jump on the Dow Jones average index overnight, and the momentum accelerated with growing interest in electronics after a significant rebound on the tech-heavy NASDAQ index, dealers said.
A total of 2,319 stocks closed up and 622 down, with 245 unchanged.

The textile sector posted the largest gains, up 4.1 percent, while the machinery and electronics sector closed up 2.5 percent, the financial sector rose 2.4 percent, the plastics and chemical sector was up 2.0 percent and the foodstuff sector ended 1.6 percent higher.
The paper and pulp, and construction sectors added 1.3 percent each, followed by the cement sector's 1.2 percent rise.

"Today's gains gave the market a breather as investors left behind concerns over the pace of the global economic recovery, which had caused sell-off in the past few sessions, " Concord Securities analyst Allan Lin said.
"Judging from the buying, I think many investors have regained confidence to some extent. After the gains, the local bourse has turned technically healthy," Lin said.
Lin said he suspected foreign institutional investors served as the major buyers, rushing to pick up high-tech stocks and taking advantage of their low valuations after recent heavy selling.
He said the electronics sector accounted for about 70 percent of the total turnover as a driver of the gains on the broader market.

Integrated circuit designer MediaTek closed at the day's high of NT$535.00, up 3.68 percent, with 5.60 million shares changing hands after Merrill Lynch upgraded the company's earnings forecast, dealers said.
Personal computer vendor Acer gained 5.19 percent to NT$79.10, and Hon Hai Precision Industry added 4.60 percent to NT$125.00.
Lin said, however, that investors should watch out for technical resistance if the market rises to about 7,450 points.
"Turnover remained moderate today despite the gains. Unless it grows to NT$90 billion or above, it is not easy for the market to jump over the technical hurdles," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese airlines to lower fuel surcharges from June 10
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 16:06:15 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday it has approved a request by Taiwanese airlines to reduce their fuel surcharges on international flights, in light of a recent drop in aviation fuel prices.

When the lower surcharge rates take effect on June 10, passengers on long-haul flights will see a drop in ticket prices from US$52 to US$45.5, while those on short flights see a decrease from US$20 to US$17.5, the CAA said.
The cuts are in line with a decision on June 1 by the state-run oil company CPC Corp., Taiwan to lower its aviation fuel price from US$103.18 per barrel to US$96.49 per barrel, the CAA said.
The last time the country's air carriers lowered their fuel surcharges was in January 2009. Since then, surcharge rates have been raised four times.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tennis greats Agassi, Safin coming to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 16:35:13 (By Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Andre Agassi and Marat Safin, two of the biggest names -- and personalities -- in men's tennis in the past 15 years, will play a series of exhibition matches in Taiwan early next year, the promoter of the event confirmed Thursday.
Agassi and Safin will play in best-of-three matches (with the third set a first- to-10-points super-tiebreaker) at the Taipei Arena on Jan. 6, 2011 and at the Kaohsiung Arena on Jan. 8, 2011.
Jeff Hsu, the CEO of the event promoter Integration Sports Inc., said the two stars have plenty to offer to Taiwan's tennis scene.
"We know that Agassi and Safin are really well-known in Taiwan, so we did our best to invite them to play. They'll bring character, experience, and a passion for tennis.
Both matches will be preceded by a single set match between Taiwan's top pros Lu Yen-hsun and Jimmy Wang and followed by a set of doubles.
Hsu would not reveal the appearance fees being paid to the two stars, but he said staging the event will cost a total of NT$75 million.

A first round of advanced ticket sales will take place in mid-June, and tickets will also be available online beginning in early August. Hsu said ticket prices will range between NT$800 and NT$10,000, with the average about NT$3,700 for the roughly 12,000 seats available in Taipei and 14,000 in Kaohsiung.
Dedicated Web site and Facebook pages for the event should be ready by mid-June to keep fans informed of the latest developments, he said.

Though both players have retired from the men's ATP Tour, they continue to play exhibitions around the world and should raise the game's profile in Taiwan, which has long been starved of top-flight sports events.
Tennis, especially, has suffered because of a lack of a tennis center that would meet the ATP's tough requirements.
"Most countries around Asia have held major tennis events that market their cities. Only Taiwan's fans haven't been able to enjoy such an event," because of the facility problem, Hsu said.
"So to get world-class players to come to Taiwan without having to comply with the ATP's many strict regulations, we felt holding an 'invitational' event was more feasible."
Negotiations began with CAA, the agency for both Agassi and Safin, in early March, and the contract was finalized Thursday. Hsu felt both players can still perform at a very high level.
"They are still very, very good if they just play two out of three in one day. They may not be able to win a real grand slam, but their experience and skill are still there," he said.
Safin and Agassi split six ATP and Davis Cup matches during their lengthy careers, with Safin winning both of their grand slam encounters in five sets.

Getting Agassi and Safin for the event is a fairly low-risk proposition because of their high name recognition and limited schedule, which means they are less likely to pull out with injuries or save themselves for the year's first grand slam, the Australian Open, to be played roughly two weeks later.
Even Safin's reputation for being unpredictable should not be an issue, Hsu indicated.
"Since we've signed the contract, CAA will do their best to secure this. I did talk to them about this, and they said I don't need to worry," Hsu said.

If nothing else, Agassi and Safin should put on quite a show. Agassi, who retired after the US Open in 2006, won eight grand slam titles and 60 singles titles during a topsy-turvy 21 years on the men's tour, ranking No. 1 in the world in 1995, 1999, 2000 and 2003 but also dropping to No. 140 in 1997.

When he won the French Open in 1999, he became only the fifth player in men's tennis history to have won a career grand slam (winning the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon and the US Open), and he also won a men's singles Olympic gold medal in Atlanta in 1996.
Safin, who retired last year, won two grand slams, the 2000 US Open and 2005 Australian Open, but was often derailed by injuries and a mercurial temperament.

"I am not perfect and neither was my career. In the end tennis is like life, messy, " is how Safin summed up his body of work. But he told retired player Justin Gimelstob that part of his frustration was not that he didn't work hard enough, but that he was a perfectionist.

"I always wanted to master the sport, but tennis is a sport that you can't be perfect at. You learn more from your mistakes, and as a result you become stronger. Sometimes it was my mind, other times injuries and my body, but at the end I accept I am what I am," Safin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MECO welcomes report of Taiwan-Philippines free trade talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 16:44:12 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Philippines' representative office in Taiwan said it welcomed the reported plans for Taiwan and the Philippines to hold talks on a free trade agreement (FTA).
However, Taiwan officials have been cautious in their responses to the report on the sensitive issue.

A Philippines newspaper, the Business Mirror, on Monday quoted Philippines Trade Secretary Jesli A. Lapus as saying that officials from Manila and Taipei will start talks on a "mini-FTA" on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting in Sapporo, Japan this week.

"This is of course a welcome development from MECO's perspective, if it is correct, but as the (trade) secretary said, it is still at an exploratory stage," said Antonio Basilio, resident representative and managing director of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei.

Meanwhile, Shih Yen-hsiang, who is leading the Taiwan delegation to the June 5-6 APEC Meeting of Ministers Responsible for Trade, declined to comment directly on the report prior to his departure, saying only that the APEC meeting focuses on multilateral trade discussions rather than bilateral talks.

According to the newspaper report, Lapus said he will seek a meeting with his Chinese counterpart to ask about the contents of a prospective economic agreement between China and Taiwan and to seek Beijing's opinion on whether a full-blown trade deal would conflict with its "one-China policy."
He said that Taiwan and the Philippines are working on a mini-FTA under the so-called Subic-Clark-Kaoshiung Economic Corridor Agreement.

Taiwan is hoping that the conclusion of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will help boost its competitiveness in the global market and help pave the way for FTAs with other countries, without China's interference.
Taiwan is reportedly hoping to sign FTAs with Singapore and the Philippines after the ECFA is completed.

However, China's foreign ministry said Wednesday that Beijing is opposed to Taiwan signing free trade agreements (FTAs) with any country. In response, President Ma Ying-jeou said that Taiwan "is entitled to sign any trade deals with other WTO (World Trade Organization) members and this right cannot be interfered with for any reason."

Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) deputy spokesman James Chang said Thursday that the ministry "had not received information about Taiwan negotiating (trade deals) with any specific country or countries, but we believe that the easing of cross-strait tensions will help create an atmosphere in which Taiwan can secure FTAs with other countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/03/10 16:57:26 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground Thursday, falling NT$0.04 against the New Taiwan dollar to close at NT$32.275.
Turnover totaled US$732 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.315 and then moved to a low of NT$32.081 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to spend big to promote Taiwanese food internationally
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:02:51 (Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs said in a Cabinet meeting Thursday that it plans to spend NT$1.1 billion (US$34.2 million) between 2010 and 2013 to promote Taiwanese food overseas.

The program will be aimed at helping to establish 3,500 new stores in Taiwan and abroad, generate 10,000 jobs in Taiwan, add 50 new international food brands, train 1,000 workers "with global vision " and create 500 business cooperation opportunities, as well as spur NT$2 billion- worth of private investment, the ministry said.

To push for the globalization of Taiwanese food in local terms, the ministry will set up a think tank to promote Taiwanese delicacies through experience- sharing among food stores and food service establishments and will designate a street in Taipei dedicated to local fine food that will hold international food fairs to attract tourists from Taiwan and overseas.
It also plans to organize training courses for chefs and send them to compete in international culinary competitions.
To allow renowned Taiwanese chefs to demonstrate their skills, the ministry will arrange events and seek to hold international culinary contests for them to show their skills.

Meanwhile, to give Taiwanese delicacies a presence in other countries, the ministry will devise an incentive mechanism to encourage Taiwanese restaurants to set up overseas stores and will try to persuade overseas shopping centers to stock a variety of Taiwanese fine food brands.
In addition, it will make efforts to establish a unified translation system for menu terms and dishes and produce promotional brochures that will be distributed overseas.
After being briefed on the issue, Premier Wu Den-yih said that more needs to be done to integrate the resources of various central and local government agencies and private enterprises and groups.

He said the program should also include Hakka food and added that an overseas credit guarantee fund managed by the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission should relax its rules for loans to overseas Taiwanese food store operators to help promote Taiwanese fine food abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time not right for closer relations with Iran: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:06:16 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The time is not right for Taiwan and Iran to develop closer relations, despite a strong desire by both sides to do so, a Taiwan foreign ministry official said Thursday.

Taiwan and Iran both intend to boost their already strong trade relationship but "the time is not right" to take the bilateral relations to the next level, said Lin Jinn-jong, director-general of the Department of West Asian Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), at a press briefing.

As the international community has been contemplating sanctions against Iran because of its nuclear energy policies, "it's not appropriate at this moment to step up exchanges (with Iran) , " Lin said.

On May 21, the Associated Press reported that Taiwan had turned down a request by Iran to open a "diplomatic mission" in Taiwan. Taiwan's Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang rebutted the report May 25, saying that his ministry has not received any request from Iran to open a trade office in Taiwan.
According to Lin, Iran is Taiwan's third largest oil supplier after Saudi Arabia and Kuwait and the annual two-way trade volume is valued at a peak of US$5.6 billion.
"However, the real trade volume could exceed that figure because some deals were done via the Dubai Free Zone," Lin said.
The Taiwan External Trade Development Council established an office in Tehran in 1992.

According to Bureau of Foreign Trade statistics, the total trade volume between Taiwan and Iran, Taiwan's 25th-largest trading partner, was US$2.5 billion in 2009. Most of Taiwan's imports, valued at US$1.98 billion, were petroleum products.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges Chinese cooperation in anti-drug war
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:37:05 (By T.H. An and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called Thursday for China's cooperation in clamping down on the cross-Taiwan Strait trafficking of illegal narcotics, under the framework of a Taiwan-China judicial assistance accord.

"International and Chinese cooperation should help the government more effectively fight the trafficking of drugs from China to Taiwan by cutting the supply chain, " the president told a national anti-drug meeting, held every year since 1993, when Ma served as minister of justice.
During Ma's tenure as justice minister, law enforcement authorities seized the country's largest-ever haul of illegal drugs -- 336 kg -- in Chiayi County.

Although the rate of inmates convicted of drug trafficking or abuse has dropped from 60 percent to 42 percent -- about 24,000 prisoners -- Ma said their recidivism rate remains as high as 90 percent and that the government's top task now is to lower this rate by reducing consumption and breaking the supply chain.
The government has set up a program comprising a series of measures to raid drug rings, educate the public and help addicts to get clean, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM expects enhanced Taiwan-Hong Kong ties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:40:24 (by Lee Ming-tsung & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that he foresees enhanced relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong after the establishment of a cooperative platform between the two sides.

Wu was referring to the Taipei-based Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Co- operation Council and its Hong Kong counterpart -- the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Co-operation and Promotion Council -- that were set up by the governments of the two sides recently to handle mutual exchanges.

Wu, after hearing a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) report on the Taiwan-Hong Kong platform at a Cabinet meeting, said that Hong Kong was Taiwan's fourth- largest trading partner last year, with bilateral trade totaling US$30.6 billion and 2.86 million travelers between the two.
He asked government agencies to make good use of the platform to further exchanges with Hong Kong in the fields of finance, transportation, investment, education and culture.

In a ceremony marking the opening of the Taiwan council May 26, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that the council and its Hong Kong counterpart will deal not only with issues related to civilian exchanges, but also with issues involving "official matters" on the two sides.

Former Finance Minister Lin Chen-kuo serves as the chairman of the council, while MAC Vice Chairman Kao Charng is the vice chairman and MAC's Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department Director Chu Hsi is the secretary-general.

Hong Kong's role as a major transit hub for trade and tourism between Taiwan and China has been greatly weakened as a result of warmer cross-strait relations since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 mortality rate down: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:41:47 (By Karen Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's mortality rate was down in 2009, at 616.3 deaths per every 100,000 people, marking the first year-on-year decline in the past 12 years, according to Department of Health (DOH) tallies released Thursday.
The DOH suggested that the decline could be related to a decline in the number of deaths caused by chronic disease.
Meanwhile, the average lifespan of Taiwanese women was 6.6 years longer than that of their male counterparts in 2009, according to the tallies.
Life expectancy among Taiwanese women was an average of 82.5 years in 2009, compared to 75.9 years for men, said Chao Kun-yu, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion.
During the 1940s, Taiwanese women's lifespans were about three years longer than men, gradually increasing to 4.5 years in the 1950s and 6.5 years by 2008.
In 2009, 142,240 people died in Taiwan, representing a slight decrease from the 2008 level and the first decline of its kind in 12 years, according to the tallies.
Cancer remained the top killer for the 28th consecutive year, claiming 39,917 lives or 28.1 percent of the total figure of the 2009 mortalities, according to the DOH.
Cancer caused a death every 13 minutes and 10 seconds in 2009, 20 seconds faster than the previous year, according to the figures.

A total of 217.4 per 100,000 male cancer patients died in 2009, compared to 127.8 females, meaning that the male cancer mortality rate was 1.7 times higher than that of the female rate, according to the tallies.

Rounding out the top 10 killers list were heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, pneumonia, diabetes, accidents, lower respiratory tract disease, chronic liver disease, suicide, and nephritis, in that order, according to the DOH figures.

Of the 10 categories, only the number of deaths from accidents increased in 2009, up by 2.6 percent year on year. Chao attributed the increase mainly to Typhoon Morakot, which claimed 614 lives and left 75 others unaccounted for.
According to the DOH figures, the overall death rate of suicides in Taiwan dropped by 1.9 percent in 2009. However, the suicide mortality rates of people in the 15-24 and 45-64 age groups increased.
The suicide mortality rate among males was 2.2 times higher than that among females, according to the figures.

Chang Chia-ming, a psychiatrist with the Department of Psychiatry of the Chang Gung Medical Center, attributed the higher suicide mortality rate among males to the facts that they tend to choose more effective ways to end their lives and that most men decline to seek consultation before committing suicide.
Meanwhile, Chu Kai-yu, chief secretary of the Lifeline Association, Taipei, said more suicidal people had called a helpline since the hotline's inception in 2008.

The suicide counselling service hotline, jointly run by the DOH and the association, served some 40,000 people in 2008, a number that increased to over 60,000 in 2009, according to Chu, who added that the hotline intervention stopped 143 people from committing suicide in two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fifteen young scholars win Junior Research Investigators Awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:45:15 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Fifteen young Taiwanese scholars were granted Junior Research Investigator Awards Thursday by Taiwan's top research institute, Academia Sinica, for their achievement in publishing academic papers that had significant effect in their fields of research.

The awards were given in three main categories, with each of the winners receiving a certificate and a cash prize of NT$200,000. They were also granted NT$300,000 each for research work, with the stipulation that the sum be used within two years.

The winners were chosen from a field of 149 applicants, 69 of whom work in Mathematics and Physical Sciences, 38 in Life Sciences, and 42 in Humanities and Social Sciences, according to Academia Sinica.
At the awards ceremony, Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-Huey said the award is pursued by many young academics in Taiwan and is perceived as a great honor.
"Some 170 outstanding scholars have been chosen over the past 15 years," Wong said. "Many of them have gone on to win other awards and honors from local and international institutions."
Academia Sinica said it has been honoring young scholars with the Junior Research Investigators Award since 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan passes draft human research act
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 17:58:44 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed a draft act on human research Thursday that requires the researchers to get the informed consent of their study subjects.
The bill, drafted by the Department of Health, is aimed at promoting scientific study while protecting the rights of the individual.

Under the bill, researchers should come up with plans and seek approval from the ethics committees of their institutions, or in case there is no such committee under their institutions, the approval of the ethics committee of a similar institution.
For organizers who sidestep the requirement, the institutions in which they work will be subject to fines of between NT$100,000 (US$3,103) and NT$1 million.
Research institutions should monitor and check all research they approve and must suspend or drop it if irregularities are found.
The research should be limited to subjects with compos mentis and should obtain their prior consent, while in the case of infants and cadavers, consent of next of kin is required.
However, the compos mentis requirement may be waived in research that will benefit "special" groups of people or people with "special" diseases.
No jail inmates should be research subjects unless there are no alternatives to their use.

Researchers should inform their study subjects, or their next of kin, legal agents, guardians or assistants, in layman's terms, of the purpose and methods of the research, the name of the research institute involved, the providers of the funds and the rights of the research subjects.
Neither the organizers nor the members of the research team should divulge information about subjects that they learn about through their research.
The draft bill must still go to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA steps up monitoring of mining districts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 18:03:32 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Mines has stepped up efforts and computerized facilities to monitor mining districts around Taiwan in a bid to prevent misuse of land and accidents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.
Under the monitoring plan, underground mining data are being collected via a computerized geographic information system (GIS) and incorporated into a database.

Satellite images of mines taken at different times were examined and compared under the plan, and locations where physical changes or accidents had occurred or had a potential to occur are also examined and identified on a regular basis, the bureau said.
Backed by the database, bureau investigators then make field trips to mine sites to conduct on-the-spot investigations, the bureau noted.
The efforts will also help the government make better land-use and water- and soil-conservation decisions, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged not to block ECFA plebiscite
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 18:03:58 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the government Thursday not to use administrative intervention to hinder a referendum on a planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The DPP criticized President Ma Ying-jeou for only verbally calling on China not to obstruct Taiwan from signing free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries after Chinese officials publicly said Taiwan is not a sovereign independent country and warned other countries against signing FTAs with Taiwan to avoid interfering in "China's internal affairs."
DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang accused Ma of being weak and irresponsible in dealing with the matter.

The DPP's criticism came after China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Ma Zhaoxu on Tuesday expressed Beijing's opposition to the establishment of official agreements between Taiwan and other countries after being asked about Taiwan's plan to negotiate FTAs with its trade partners after concluding the ECFA.
Lin asked what the president will do if China blocks Taiwan's FTA talks with other countries after Taiwan signs the trade pact with China.
The DPP suggested that Ma should ask China to promise not to do so in the trade pact.

The Executive Yuan's Referendum Review Committee was slated to meet Thursday to decide whether a referendum proposal initiated by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) conforms to legal requirements.

The government should ensure people's right to hold a popular referendum as it is an essential safeguard for democracy, Lin said, while urging the administration not to use political maneuvering or bureaucracy to hinder it.
"This evening is the best time to show whether the Ma administration allows referendums and protects Taiwan's democracy, " Lin said.
To promote the referendum, the DPP will hold a rally in Kaohsiung on June 5.

Ahead of the rally, the party will hold a "made in Taiwan" market fair featuring locally made products and craftwork at Glory Pier that is expected to include 120 booths to help the party raise funds for the year-end special municipality mayor elections.

As a warm up to the rally, the DPP held a promotional event in Taipei Thursday during which Lin Yu-kuo, a fruit farmer from Dashu Township in Kaohsiung County, called on the government to come up with measures to protect Taiwan's disadvantaged industries before signing the trade deal with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boost traditional manufacturer production
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 18:12:22 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The government will spend about NT$75 million (US$2.33 million) to help traditional manufacturing companies integrate information and communication, with the aim of increasing their combined production value by at least NT$1.8 billion by the end of this year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

According to the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the MOEA, the information and communications technology (ICT) project -- launched for traditional manufacturing industries for the first time -- is also expected to increase the country's private investment by more than NT$100 million by year- end.
A total of 30 projects applying ICT applications were selected from nearly 100 applications in April, with subsidies of between NT$2 million and NT$5 million granted, an IDB official said.
"Most traditional manufacturers have slow response to new technologies, so the government's move has made them aware of the importance of ICT applications," he said.

One of the chosen companies, Tex-Ray International, plans to integrate its smart clothes products -- which can monitor heartbeat and provide electrocardiograms (ECGs) -- with security system and medical service providers to develop an individual health care service module that is expected to be sold to hospitals and health centers and achieve around NT$80 million in production value in two to three years, the official said.

Sanitary wares supplier Hocheng Corp. (HCG) was selected for its planned project to transform its business operation model from a pure sanitary wares supplier to a solution provider for all home facilities.
Hocheng's project is expected to increase the company's sales by 5 percent and sharply lower its after-sales costs by 30 percent by the end of this year, the official said.

Meanwhile, a service team was also set up to provide consultation and evaluation services to traditional manufacturers to enhance their understanding about ICT applications and help develop new business opportunities, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More bananas, mangoes to be exported to China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 18:16:53 (By Justin Su and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Several Taiwanese merchants associations in China have decided to buy 600 metric tons of bananas to help local banana farmers cope with a fall in the price of the fruit, a leader of one of the associations said Thursday.

The decision came after an announcement by the Council of Agriculture (COA) May 29 that 800 tons of bananas will be shipped to Beijing and Shanghai by the end of June -- the first time the fruit will have been sold in China since 2006.
Lin Rong-de, honorary chairman of the Taiwan Merchants Association in China's Kunshan, said at a press conference that if banana prices keep falling, they will bring even more bananas into China.
A COA official said the bananas will be shipped to Xiamen City in southeastern China.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chao-shun, who helped coordinate the sales to Taiwanese businessmen in China, said she hopes the sales will help reduce pressure on local banana farmers.
Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih also announced a day earlier that he is scheduled to visit Beijing and Shanghai June 15 to promote mango sales.

Su said that top quality mangoes from his county have successfully opened up the Japanese market and he expressed hope that his first trip to China to promote the summer fruit can lead to more sales channels for local farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft opens software center in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 18:23:09 (By Chou Pin-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Microsoft Corp. opened a Software and Services Excellence Center (SSEC) in Taipei Thursday for the development of cloud computing-based technology in collaboration with its Taiwan partners.

Steven Guggenheimer, corporate vice president of Microsoft's original equipment manufacturing division, announced the opening of the center on the sidelines of Computex Taipei, the world's second largest computer fair that will run through June 5.

"The opening of the SSEC is a significant milestone for Microsoft and its hardware partners in our collaboration for the development of additional business opportunities in the area of cloud computing," he said.

Microsoft said it will combine its research and development (R&D) expertise and technology leadership in software, services and cloud computing data center technology with Taiwan's strength in hardware innovation.

"Over the past two decades, hardware manufacturers in Taiwan have established their global leadership in PCs, netbooks, cell phones, LCDs, and other IT technologies, which is important for the global ICT (information communication technology) industry," Guggenheimer said.
The center is expected to create new business opportunities for Microsoft and its Taiwanese partners, the company said.

Cloud computing is a Web-enabled software solution based on the use of computer technology to allow users who have no knowledge of or expertise in technology infrastructure to carry out common business applications online.

Through the center, Microsoft said, it also plans to license patents and share its software development expertise with academic and R&D institutes in Taiwan to help the country develop its ICT industry.
Representatives of Microsoft's partners in Taiwan, including Quanta Computer Chairman Barry Lam and Inventec Corp Chairman Lee Shih-chin, attended the opening ceremony.
The center was established on the basis of a memorandum of understanding signed between Microsoft and the Ministry of Economic Affairs in November 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan contributes to global effort on wild tiger conservation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 19:13:37 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's wild tiger conservation efforts in recent years have proven successful, but more can be done to protect the endangered animals, a Council of Agricultural (COA) official said Thursday at a screening of a National Geographic documentary about the seedy underworld of tiger trade and poaching in Asia.

According to Kuan Li-hao, director of the Forestry Bureau's Conservation Division, during the 1970's, Taiwan had a problem with live tigers or tiger- related products being imported into the island because there was no law sanctioning such practices.

However, with growing awareness and increased global efforts to save endangered species, Taiwan enacted the Wildlife Conservation Act in June 1989, which outlawed all imports and exports of wildlife, including live tigers and tiger- related products, except for the purpose of scientific research or exhibition, such as in zoos.
Violators face a maximum fine of NT$1.5 million and five years imprisonment, according to Taiwan's law.

"The Taiwan authority takes the matter of smuggling of tiger and tiger parts very seriously. It has been years since our last case, Kuan said, attributing public vigilance as a major policing force in the effort.
But he added that more can be done.

Some Taiwanese people would bring back medicine made with tiger parts from China, which is also illegal, Kuan said. Further increasing public awareness is the best way to deal with this problem, he said.
Tiger body parts have been long considered as potent natural elixirs in traditional Chinese medicine as well as symbols of luck and prominence in various Asian cultures.
It is believed that alcoholic tonic made from tiger penis is a powerful aphrodisiac and can improve virility in men and that tiger bones, when grounded into power, can treat rheumatism and headaches.

The government does not have a figure of the black market on tiger parts in Taiwan, but officials said almost all of the so-called tiger penises sold in traditional medicine shops are fakes, such as cow or dog penis.

Each year, the COA provides funding to Taiwanese conservation groups, such as the Society of Wildlife and Nature and other international organizations, totalling around NT$10 million to NT$20 million to help with the worldwide conservation work.
According to National Geographic, there are approximately 3,500 tigers left in the world X a significant drop from the 100,000 at the beginning of the 20th century.
In Taiwan, there are 54 tigers spread out in three zoos as well as in the government-sponsored tiger haven run by the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, Kuan said.

The documentary will premier on Sunday June 6 at 9 a.m. on the National Geographic Channel in Taiwan. The film will show agents from the Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA) going under cover across China to investigate the tiger smuggling operations and the illegal traders involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA English news budget for June 3 (II)

TEXT.P: enrollment 36. 1st Japanese encephalities fatality in Taiwan this year 37. AIT chairman calls on legislative speaker 38. Real estate launches online applications to sell houses

DOC.HEADLINE: New graduates in Taiwan afraid to tackle challenges: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 19:20:14 (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: New graduates in Taiwan tend to have difficulty making the transition from school to the workplace and the wider world, the results of a survey by the 1111 Job Bank and Discovery Channel indicated Thursday.
According to some 42 percent of the respondents, what they dread most is trying new unfamiliar tasks, with 34.2 percent saying they would rather quit than attempt to tackle the unknown.

The poll suggests that fresh graduates in Taiwan are not ready to strike out on their own, which could narrow their chances of building a career, said Charlene Chang, spokeswoman for the 1111 Job Bank.
The survey also found that new university graduates in Taiwan are unadventurous in other areas, as 82 percent said they are afraid to travel alone.
However, when asked if they would visit a cannibal village if they were given a free trip there, 16 percent said yes.

Commenting on the trend in Taiwan, Olly Steeds, host of Discovery Channel's new adventure series "Solving History with Olly Steeds, " said he is looking forward to sharing with Taiwan's college students his experience in facing challenges on the job.
Hailed by the international media as a "real-life Indiana Jones," Steeds said his motto is "Adventures are a mark of incompetence."
"I encourage young people around the world to go out there and make mistakes and don't be afraid," he said.
The survey was carried out among 1,177 respondents and had a margin of error of 2.9 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature brought to halt by opposition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 19:44:57 (By Kelven Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan ground to a halt Thursday when the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took issue with all the bills on the agenda in an attempt to disrupt the last sitting of the session.

Displeased with the Internal Administration Committee's confirmation the previous day of a May 10 decision to approve a revision of the Act Governing the Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area to allow Chinese students to enroll in local colleges, the opposition decided to go all out to stonewall the sitting.

Legislator Lee Chun-yi, secretary of the DPP Legislative Caucus, said the party would not tolerate what it described as the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) contempt for both legislative procedures and the opposition.

"Unless the KMT declares null and void the Internal Administration Committee's confirmation the previous day, the DPP will suspend negotiations with the KMT, and the ruling party should be held responsible for the disruption of the legislature," said Lee.

However, Lin Hung-chih, secretary of the KMT's Legislative Caucus, and Legislator Wu Yu-sheng, who presided over the Thursday meeting of the Internal Administration Committee, said the confirmation of the May 10 decision made jointly by the Internal Administration Committee and the Education and Culture Committee followed procedure to the letter.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng agreed to look into the dispute by examining a video tape of the meeting of the Internal Administration Committee to see whether procedure was in fact followed properly.
Noting that the present legislative session will last for two more days before the session adjourns next Monday, the speaker said this is enough time to sort out the differences.
The DPP, which opposes closer ties with China, has pulled out all the stops to sink the ruling party's policy of opening local colleges to Chinese students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parents to be fined if children play with fireworks alone
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 19:51:08 (By Lin Shen-hsu and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Parents who let children under the age of 12 play with fireworks unsupervised are now punishable under a recently revised law, the National Fire Agency said Thursday.
The revised Firework and Firecracker Management Act was implemented a day earlier, the agency said, and includes changing the categories of fireworks and increasing punishments for violations.

The agency said parents or guardians will face fines of between NT$3,000 and NT$15,000 if their children are caught playing with fireworks with no supervision. Previously, the law only required them to accompany their children while playing, and there was no punishment if they failed to do so.
Selling fireworks to children remains illegal and violators can still be fined between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000 under the revised act.
A new addition to the act is a prohibition on sales methods in which the age of purchasers cannot be checked, such as vending machines and mail order.

The agency said fireworks and firecrackers are now categorized by their usage in the act, which includes those for general use and those for professional use. Previous categories were high altitude fireworks and general fireworks.
Professional fireworks include those used in films, on television and in public pyrotechnic displays, and can only be set off by certified technicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor draws battle lines in crackdown on crime
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 20:04:37 (By S. C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu drew the battle lines Thursday to fight crime in his city, saying that he is determined to deal with the so-called "eight categories of special business," which are regarded as covers for criminal activities.

"As mayor of this city, I will not back down from a war against gangsters even if my life is threatened, " he told reporters. "I do not expect to gain the votes of those who work in those eight lines of business."
Hu said some elements from those circles have threatened to have him removed as mayor, as the Nov.27 mayoral elections approach.

The eight categories of "special business" in Taiwan refer to entertainment- related enterprises such as KTV clubs, saunas, night clubs, barber and massage shops, dance halls, discotheques, and tea houses, many of which are said to be run by organized gangs.
Hu has come under strong pressure amid criticism of public order in Taichung City after an alleged gang leader was shot dead by an unknown assailant at his own company on May 28.
In response to the incident that was the latest in a spate of high-profile killings in the central Taiwan city, Hu pledged to crack down on gangs in the city.
It was later revealed that four police officers on the crime scene were chatting and drinking tea when the shooting took place, which gave rise to rumors of links between the local police and gangs.
Two ranking police officers have been given a demerit by the National Police Agency for what was deemed to be misconduct, while the other two were given a strong warning.
Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah vowed Thursday to get to the bottom of the killing regardless of who was involved.
"We will not cover up any corruption among officials if firm evidence in this regard is discovered," Jiang said.
Meanwhile, Nantou police said Thursday that the gunman remained at large and his whereabouts were unknown.
The day after the shooting, the police found a vehicle near Sun Moon Lake, which they later confirmed was the car used by the assailant to flee the crime scene.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP unveils fund-raising plan for municipality elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 20:09:12 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is devising a fund-raising mechanism for the year-end special municipality elections that will involve only small amounts, a DPP official said Thursday.

The party plans to set up an association of DPP friends in July with the aim of recruiting 10,000 members, each of whom will be required to make a monthly donation ranging from NT$500-NT$1,000 via credit card, according to Hung Yao-fu, DPP acting secretary-general.
The mechanism is designed to become a fixed revenue stream for the party, Hung said after a party meeting to discuss the DPP's campaign strategy for the year- end elections.

Wu Nai-jen, the DPP's election campaign manager, said that with the high popularity of the five DPP candidates in the year-end elections, the party's campaign spending for the elections might be less than the NT$70 million spent on the 2009 three-in-one elections that included the elections for city mayors, county magistrates, city and county councilmen and township chiefs.

Wu said the DPP will do its utmost to win all five seats up for grab in the five municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City (a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County), Tainan City (a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County) and Kaohsiung City (a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County).
When DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen took office in May 2008, the party was NT$200 million in debt, which has been reduced to NT$30 million, according to Hung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Real estate agents launch mobile, online sales promotion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 20:13:20 (By Lin Ye-fong and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's real estate agents have launched various marketing campaigns, including a promising new house-hunting service on a mobile platform, in a bid to gain the edge in fiercely competitive business, a broker said Thursday.
According to Yung-ching Real Estate, since its mobile application was launched in March, it has recorded a 20 percent increase in the number of prospective buyers.
The service allows registered online clients to view, rent or even buy properties listed in the company's database of 150,000 entries, via their cell phones.
HB Housing and Sinyi Realty have also introduced various games on Facebook and Plurk to attract buyers, with Sinyi Realty drawing 160,000 Facebook users in five weeks, according to a media report.

Another real estate agent TWHouse, which registered on Facebook in March, said that it hopes to increase the number of its Facebook fans to 100,000 by the end of September from the current 53,000, the report said.

The competition in the real estate business has become quite fierce in the last two to three years, as the number of realtors has been growing at a faster rate than the number of deals, an executive of HB Housing said.
In 2009, the number of real estate agents increased 84 percent to 4,165 from 2,262 in 2004, the company said.
The company also announced Wednesday that it will launch a two-month sales campaign to coincide with the Taiwan release this month of the 3D animated U.S. film Toy Story 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidates pledge 'co-prosperity' in two municipalities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 20:27:30 (By Lin Hui-chun and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) candidates for the year-end mayoral elections in two northern Taiwan municipalities pledged Thursday to make concerted efforts to promote co-prosperity for their respective cities.

Hau Lung-bin and Eric Liluan Chu, who will run for the KMT in the mayoral elections in Taipei City and Xinbei City -- an upgrade of Taipei County -- made "Golden Decade and Co-prosperous Twin Cities" their joint campaign slogan at a press conference that day.

Hau, the incumbent Taipei mayor, said that with a combined population of 6.5 million -- over 25 percent of Taiwan's total -- the two cities should play a leading role in sharpening Taiwan's competitive edge.
"Close and well-concerted cooperation between the two cities will produce a 'one plus one is greater than two' effect, " Hau said.
"The locomotive with twin engines (Taipei and Xinbei cities) will surely lead Taiwan to a 'golden decade' economically, " Hau added.

Hau noted that seven of Taipei City's 10 additional mass rapid transit lines that are either under construction or on the drawing board will run deep into surrounding Xinbei City, making them a " two-in one" community.

Chu, who resigned last month as vice premier to prepare for his election campaign, advocated the creation of a " golden Taipei technology corridor" by connecting existing and planned science parks in the two municipalities -- including the Neihu Technology Park, the Nankang Software Park, the Keelung Valley Science Park and the Liudu Industrial Park.

He also called for the establishment of an " innovative industry and green energy industrial zone" by including the Keelung Valley Science Park in a free trade zone of the Taipei Port, setting up an intellectual science park in Linkou Township and linking it with the planned Taoyuan Aerotropolis.

With this empowered technology corridor, Hau said, the two cities will in the next decade turn into a "global research and development hub and an Asia-Pacific operational center, in addition to becoming the headquarters for Taiwanese enterprises worldwide."
The elections -- scheduled for Nov. 27 in five municipalities -- are widely regarded as a crucial indicator for the 2012 presidential election.
The three other municipalities are Taichung City (a merger of Taichung city and county) , Tainan City (a merger of Tainan city and county) and Kaohsiung City (a merger of Kaohsiung city and county).

DOC.HEADLINE: Women with breast cancer to race dragon boat
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 20:47:15 (By Johnson Sun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A dragon boat team made up of women with breast cancer is set to race in Taipei's Dragon Boat Festival on June 12 to raise awareness of the sports' benefits to post-surgery rehabilitation, a spokesman from the Taipei City Hospital said Thursday.
The team composed of 22 members aged between 34 to 64 is the first team formed by cancer patients in Taiwan, Chen Huo-mu, a director of General Surgery in Taipei City Hospital said.
The Dragon Boat Race is a part of patients' rehabilitation exercises that could improve their health conditions, Chen said.

According to a research study conducted by a Canadian sports medicine physician Dr. Don McKenzie in the 1990s, dragon boat racing can help patients gain physical strength, and reduce the formation of post-operation adhesions and Lymphedema - localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system.
In terms of the impact on recovering cancer patients' mindset, the sport helps patients rediscover the rhythm of life and gives them a chance to share their emotions with their teammates.
With the support from family members and friends, the patients are able to walk out of their home and receive training with others, which produces the effect of group therapy, Chen added.

The number of breast cancer patients in Taiwan is increasing by more than 7,000 a year. The Taiwan Breast Cancer Alliance will host an international breast cancer conference in November 2011, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International human rights groups appeal to Taiwan on death penalty
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 20:56:14 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: International human rights organizations repeated their appeals to the Taiwan government Thursday to restore an unofficial moratorium on executions to spare the lives of 40 death row inmates.

Amnesty International and the Anti-Death Penalty Asia Network (ADPAN) issued separate statements to express their regret over a decision reached May 28 by the Justices of Constitutioal Court to reject a petition filed by the Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty (TAEDP) on behalf of the prisoners.
ADPAN urged Taiwan to halt further executions following the April 30 execution of four prisoners and to either consider alternatives to capital punishment or re-introduce an unofficial moratorium.

Amnesty International argued that Taiwan's application of the death penalty is unconstitutional and violates the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights that was signed by President Ma Ying-jeou in May last year and incorporated into the domestic laws of Taiwan.

Provisions for legal representation, particularly in the final stages of trials, and opportunities to debate appropriate sentencing during trials are inadequate, the organization said in the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. official stays clear of Taiwan's trade talks with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 22:24:26 (By Kelven Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt shrugged off questions about Taiwan's ongoing trade pact talks with China during a visit Thursday, saying that "it is up to Taiwan to decide."

Burghardt, who arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for a one-week visit, is reportedly on a mission to learn about the details of Taipei's talks with Beijing on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that are entering their final phase.
He gave his brief reply in response to journalists' questions before a meeting with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.
Wang later confirmed that during their talks, Burghardt asked him about the legislative procedures for handling the proposed pact after it is concluded.
Wang said he told Burghardt that the pact and other cross-strait agreements are not international treaties according to a ruling by the Constitutional Court.
However, according to the ruling, Wang said, the legislature can recommend to the executive branch that the pact should be "revised."
"I am not certain what kind of binding force our recommendation would carry or how far we can go in requesting revisions, " the speaker said.
There is simply no mechanism the legislature can use to deal with an agreement other than an international treaty, Wang said.
Wang also said Burghardt told him that he hoped talks between Taiwan and the United States on a trade investment framework agreement can be resumed later this year.

Those talks, which began in 1994, are the most important trade negotiations between Washington and Taipei and are considered a step toward a free trade agreement. However, they have been suspended since July 2007 because of a dispute over imports of U.S. beef.

Wang said that when he broached the possibility of Taiwan and the United States having a free trade pact, Burghardt said the prospects are dim, as there is little support in Washington for such an agreement.

Turning to Taiwan's request to buy F-16 C/D jet fighters from the United States, Wang said he got the feeling from his talks with Burghardt that Washington is very likely to give a green light to such a sale, although Burghardt said only that Washington is "considering it carefully."
Taiwan requested in 2006 to buy 66 F-16 C/Ds to replace its aging IDF jet fighters and French-made Mirage 2000s, but there has been no official response from Washington to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA referendum review decision should be followed: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 22:28:36 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: An official in charge of China affairs urged all government agencies Thursday to observe the decision to be made by the Referendum Review Committee over a referendum proposal on a planned trade pact with China.

Mainland Affairs Council Deputy Minister Liu Te-shun issued the call hours before the committee under the Executive Yuan makes a final decision on whether the referendum initiative is in conformity with the law.

Liu said at a routine press conference that the fact that the review committee approved a Consumers Foundation request for a referendum on U.S. beef imports in January proves that the screening committee is impartial. He added, therefore, that all government agencies should abide by its decisions.

Meanwhile, in response to a statement issued Tuesday by China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Beijing's opposition to the establishment of official agreements between Taiwan and other countries, Liu said that trade is Taiwan's lifeline and that seeking to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other major trade partners is the government's consistent policy.

As a member of the World Trade Organization, Taiwan is eligible to clinch trade agreements with other countries, Liu went on, adding that the government will work toward this goal and that China should not hinder it from doing so.

Although it is well-known that Taiwan is under great pressure, mainly from China, when seeking to sign FTAs with other countries, the government nevertheless has the responsibility to overcome all difficulties to reach the goal, he said.

While noting that the MAC does not agree with the Chinese government's rhetoric, Liu expressed hope that China will understand Taiwan's stance and that both sides will allow each other to seek more international space and the best platforms for economic development.
The government's determination to ink FTAs with other countries will not be affected by negative factors, according to Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung police head resigns over police presence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 22:33:33 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The resignation of Taichung police chief Hu Mu-yuan was approved late Thursday following public outrage over the presence of four police officers at a crime scene in which a gang leader was shot in the central city.
His post was filled by Chiu Feng-kuang, deputy head of the National Police Agency's Criminal Investigation Bureau.

Hu, chief of the Taichung City Police Department, resigned after attempting to cover up the presence of the four officers when alleged gang boss Weng Chi-nan was shot dead in his office May 28. It was not until June 1 that the matter came to light.
The four police officers were reportedly playing mahjong there and hid under a table when Weng was shot.

The case came to light after investigators looked at surveillance tape and discovered that when the killer entered the office, there were four police officers on the scene. At first, the police force did not release details about the tape and officers were later disciplined.
Hu was blamed for keeping Taichung Mayor Jason Hu in the dark over the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO members concerned about ECFA progress: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 22:38:08 (By Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) said Thursday that many WTO members are concerned about the progress of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) being negotiated between Taiwan and China.
In a telephone interview with CNA, Lin Yi-fu said from Geneva, Switzerland that "everyone is concerned about the ECFA, " adding that "we talk about it whenever we meet."
Those WTO members that have expressed concern include the United States, the European Union, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, he said.

He said he has explained the trade deal to them, including each side's early harvest list -- a list of items to be given early tariff exemptions -- as well as the pact's coverage of protection for Taiwanese business interests and intellectual property rights.

Lin also said that during a just-concluded WTO review meeting on China's trade policies, Taiwan expressed hope that China will take into consideration the views of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China when formulating its trade policy, to which China reacted "positively."

Lin said that the Chinese WTO representative, in a written statement, expressed a positive attitude toward Taiwanese businessmen's contributions to China's economic development and said that China "will respect Taiwanese businessmen's views."
WTO members, including Taiwan, were also concerned about China's government procurement list, which they said is not open enough, he added.
The WTO will hold a Taiwan trade policy review meeting, which is held every four years, July 5 and July 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time not ripe for cross-strait military talks: former official
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 22:57:30 (By Jennifer Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese ex-national security chief said here Thursday that the time for talks between Taiwan and China on the building of military mutual trust is not ripe at this time.
Former National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi told CNA that Taiwan needs time to prepare for such talks, although the international community is eager to see them start.

Citing the Taiwanese opposition parties' all-out fight against ongoing trade talks between Taiwan and China, Su said negotiations on building military mutual trust will be much more controversial than the trade talks, despite Washington's support for such talks and Beijing's willingness to engage in them.
"In the near future, there is no possibility for such talks," he said.

However, the situation across the Taiwan Strait is much more stable than before, he said, as Taiwan will not provoke China and China is unlikely to attack Taiwan, in view of the fact that there are many sea and air links across the Taiwan Strait every day.
Su Chi was in Britain on a speaking tour at the invitation of Oxford University and Chatham House, a British think tank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman infected with Japanese encephalitis dies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 23:11:29 (By Chang Jung-hsiang, Chen Li-ting and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: A woman in southern Taiwan's Tainan City infected with Japanese encephalitis died a day earlier, a senior health official said Thursday.

Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said the woman might have caught the disease at the pig farm where she worked in neighboring Tainan County. The disease's carrier, Culex tritaeniorhynchus mosquitoes, were found at the farm after she was diagnosed.

The woman began showing flu-like symptoms May 18 and went to several clinics in the following days, but was not diagnosed with Japanese encephalitis until she was taken to National Cheng Kung University Hospital as her condition worsened.
Lin said the local government cleaned and sprayed pesticide in the area and urged the public to take action against mosquitoes to prevent disease transmission.

He also pointed out that inoculation is the most effective prevention against Japanese encephalitis. Children should receive four vaccinations between the age of 15 months and when they enter elementary schools, while adults can go to public hospitals to be vaccinated.

Lin said it was the second case this year. The first was reported in southernmost Pingtung County and that patient survived. The situation of the disease this year is in line with previous years, he said.
According to CDC statistics, there were 37 cases of Japanese encephalitis in 2007, with two fatalities, 17 cases in 2008 and 18 cases in 2009, with one death in the two latter years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman infected with Japanese encephalitis dies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/03/10 23:11:29 (By Chang Jung-hsiang, Chen Li-ting and Kay Liu)
