DOC.HEADLINE: Review committee says ECFA referendum proposal invalid
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 3 (CNA) 06/04/10 00:04:24 (By Lee Shu-hua, Lillian Wu & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Referendum Screening Committee under the Executive Yuan after a marathon debate rejected late Thursday a referendum initiative on a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait trade deal.

Members of the committee reached the decision on the referendum proposal, submitted by the tiny opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), by a vote of 12-4 with one abstention on the grounds that it's not in conformity with the law.
The referendum proposal would ask the public: "Do you agree that the government should sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China?"
TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei, upon learning of the committee's decision, said that "it (the ruling) goes against democracy" and that his party will launch a drive to have the committee "abolished".
Spokesman Lin Yu-chang of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party that it's regrettable that "the government has used administrative means to kill the referendum proposal."
Spokesman Su Jun-pin of the ruling Kuomintang called on the opposition camp to respect the committee's ruling and not "try to utilize the referendum for political gains.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 4, or the 22nd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the French coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with U.S. Gen. Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1982: U.S. Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
2000: An ROC Navy goodwill flotilla reaches the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles.
2001: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- kicks off at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting a record high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad to take part in the five-day event.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 10:18:04 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday than its previous close, moving up 17.28 points at 7,377.56 on a turnover of NT$1.95 billion (US$60.94 million).
The weighted price index gained 164.57 points, or 2.28 percent, to close at 7,360.28 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Darkest day of Taiwan's democracy

TEXT.P: The Referendum Screening Committee under the Executive Yuan again rejected an initiative for a referendum on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China Thursday, after turning down a similar plan last year.
It was the darkest day in the history of Taiwan's democracy.

Opposing a referendum on the ECFA is not only the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) position but also that of the Communist Party of China. Beijing is concerned about the democratic momentum of referendums, which could bar its attempts to annex Taiwan.
In a democratic Taiwan, the KMT dares not challenge public opinion and therefore has been playing the trick of saying one thing and doing the other. The KMT's plot was finally exposed Thursday night.

The decision by the Referendum Screening Committee raises an alarm for Taiwan's people. It signals that the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has no regard for public opinion and is conspiring with Beijing to pave the way for Taiwan's ultimate annexation by China. (June 4, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. Senate delegation to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 3 (CNA) 06/04/10 10:31:32 (By Jorge Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A United States Senate delegation, headed by Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), will arrive in Taiwan June 5, U.S. Congress sources said Thursday.
It will be the first group of U.S. senators to visit Taipei since President Ma Ying-jeou took power in 2008.
The delegation, to comprise senators, members of their family and aides, will visit Ma during its stay in Taipei, according to the sources.
Feinstein is an influential senator who chaired the Presidential Inaugural Committee for President Barack Obama in 2009. She now serves as chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

The 76-year-old congresswoman is on her fourth term since she was first elected as a senator in 1992. During her long political career, Feinstein has created many "firsts, " including serving as the first female San Francisco mayor, being the first woman elected to chair the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration, and the first woman to chair the Senate Intelligence Committee.
She is also the first woman to have hosted the U.S. presidential inaugural ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 10:31:47 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.198 at 9:45 a.m. Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.077 from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Beijing cannot oppose FTAs

TEXT.P: China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu said recently that Beijing opposes the signing of government-to-government agreements between Taiwan and other countries when asked about Taiwan's expectations that the conclusion of a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation agreement framework (ECFA) will facilitate Taiwan's bids to seal free trade agreements (FTAs) with other trade partners.
This statement has been interpreted by some as meaning that China is against Taiwan signing FTAs with other countries.

The United Daily News later verified the remarks with Chinese officials and was told that Beijing will not block any "purely economic agreements" between Taiwan and other countries that do not involve sovereignty issues. This explanation is reasonable and predictable.

Beijing is unlikely to oppose FTAs signed by Taiwan. The ECFA is not only a cross-strait economic agreement but also an important framework that will create a climate for peaceful development. Whether Taiwan can sign FTAs with other countries has become a main indicator of whether the proposed ECFA is based on sincerity and goodwill.

Self-esteem and trust are the two major pillars of Taiwan's mainstream sentiment. If Taiwan is only allowed to sign an ECFA with China but cannot sign FTAs with other countries, how can the Taiwanese people build their self-esteem and trust? How are the significance and achievements of the ECFA going to stand?

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese choreographer's new work to be performed in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 3 (CNA) 06/04/10 10:42:40 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Berlin-based Taiwanese choreographer Shang Chi Sun's new work, inspired by British playwright Sarah Kane's play "4.48 Psychosis, " will be staged at an annual arts festival in the Japanese prefecture of Shizuoka this weekend.

The dance features an impromptu presentation that incorporates dance, theatrical and violin performances. With its dramatic charm and the strong energy demonstrated by the dancers, the work enchanted German audiences when it was premiered in Berlin in April.

Sun, one of the most active Taiwanese dancers in Europe, will lead an international team of artists to present the work at the Spring Arts Festival Shizuoka. Among the troupe are Czech and French dancers, German actors and a German stage designer, as well as a Bulgarian violinist.

The 33-year-old dancer-choreographer, whose works synchronize with contemporary European dance vocabulary, won great acclaim when his work "Nuewa" was performed at the famous French arts festival Avignon Off last summer. All of the "Nuewa" performances at the festival were sold out.

Among the audience was the artistic director of the Shizuoka arts festival, who was very impressed and fascinated by the show and so decided to invite Sun to present some of his work at this year's event in Japan, according to Sun.
Taipei City's Department of Cultural Affairs and the Taipei-based Lo Man-fei Foundation will provide financial support for the "4.48 Psychosis" presentation in Japan.
Sun said he will continue to create pieces that incorporate dance, images, theater, music and other aspects of the performing arts.
Sun is also a member of German choreographer Sasha Waltz's troupe, which will present a new piece titled "Continu" in Zurich, Switzerland June 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- ECFA referendum initiative rejected 12-4

TEXT.P: After nearly five hours of heated debate, the Referendum Screening Committee (RSC) under the Executive Yuan rejected a referendum initiative presented by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Frustrated by the invalidation of its referendum initiative, the TSU said it will mount an initiative to hold a national referendum on whether the RSC should be abolished.
The invalidation of the referendum initiative is expected to accelerate ECFA talks with China and a long-delayed third round of such talks is expected to take place soon.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:
After the RSC rejected the ECFA referendum initiative by a vote of 12-4 with one abstention late Thursday, a third round of ECFA talks is likely to be held in the coming few days.

Responding to the committee's decision, the Executive Yuan issued a four-point statement, saying that it respects the committee's conclusion and will continue to keep the Legislative Yuan informed on the progress of the ECFA talks.
Once the agreement is signed, the statement said, it will be sent to the legislature for approval.
In the process of the ECFA negotiations, the statement said, the government will ensure that the nation's sovereignty is not compromised and that the people's well-being is enhanced through the deal.

Upon learning of Taiwan's rejection of the referendum initiative, a Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs said he is optimistic about the signing of the ECFA by the end of June as originally scheduled. (June 4, 2010).
China Times:
The RSC rejected the TSU's referendum on the grounds that it is not in conformity with the law.
The referendum initiative would have asked the public: "Do you agree that the government should sign an economic cooperation framework with China?"

Most committee members said the question contradicts the main discourse of the TSU-drafted referendum initiative and that even if the referendum initiative were to be passed, it would not change the status quo.
According to the Referendum Act, TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei, who proposed the ECFA referendum initiative, can appeal the case with the Executive Yuan within 30 days. (June 4, 2010).
Liberty Times:
Huang accused President Ma Ying-jeou of kowtowing to China's will by having the RSC reject his party's ECFA referendum initiative.

He said the TSU will propose a new initiative to hold a referendum on the Ma administration's plan to sign the ECFA, which he said could increase Taiwan's economic reliance on China and lead to China's annexation of the country.
Moreover, Huang said, the TSU will initiate another referendum proposal to have the RSC abolished, since it does not respect public will and opinion. (June 4, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Stop decrying the rich

TEXT.P: As Taiwan imposes only a securities transaction tax and does not tax capital gains, investors who generated sizable profits from the stock market last year were not required to pay any tax on that income when they filed their tax returns in May.

Levying a capital gains tax has always been a taboo issue in Taiwan, and this is just one example of the government's reluctance to raise taxes despite its huge fiscal shortfall. The government has instead been cutting taxes in recent years, with the wealthy benefiting the most from decreases in the gift, estate and value added taxes.

This demonstrates that a core concept is lacking in the government's tax policy, which leaves room for bargaining and lobbying by the rich. This is dragging our policy farther and farther away from fairness and justice, pampering the rich and leading them into unrighteousness.

As a matter of fact, not all wealthy people are unwilling to pay more taxes. The legendary investor Warren Buffett, William H. Gates, father of Microsoft co- founder Bill Gates, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang have all advocated raising taxes for the rich.

Has the government heard the voices of these rich opinion leaders? Rich people pay more attention to gaining social esteem than paying less taxes, but the existing tax system is creating confrontation between the poor and the rich. The authorities should work out some serious plans to reform the tax system without delay.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls on China to smooth June 4 grudge
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 12:18:05 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the Beijing leadership Friday to heal the scars of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Incident with innovative thinking.

A government's existence of power hinges on the trust of its people, he said. In an incident in which a government turns its guns on the people, the innocent public is not the only party to be harmed, but also the trust between the rulers and the people, he added.
Once the people's trust in their government is smashed, it will take a long time for the trust to be rebuilt, he said.

He urged Beijing to face reality courageously and address the major human rights incident that has left scars on its nation's history and to rebuild the mutual trust by demonstrating the patience and tolerance.

The president made the call in the latest issue of his online newsletter that day, the 21st anniversary of the bloodshed when Beijing used tanks and troops to crush a student-led pro-democracy demonstration.
"We people in Taiwan commemorate the June 4 incident in the same manner we observe the anniversary of the 1947 Feb. 28 Incident in Taiwan and the White Terror Era of the 1950s," Ma said.
He said he hopes Beijing will borrow from Taiwan's experience in dealing with historical tragedies to help prevent similar incidents from occurring again.
He also urged Beijing to take action to allay the hurt and the burning sense of injustice among the families of the victims.
By doing so, the Beijing leadership could increase the Chinese people's trust in it and also narrow the human rights gap between Taiwan and China, the president said.

The Tiananmen Incident was a series of demonstrations in and around Beijing's Tiananmen Square that began April 14, 1989. Led mainly by students and intellectuals, the protests occurred in a year that saw the collapse of a number of communist governments around the world.
The protests, which lasted seven weeks, were sparked by the death of a pro- democracy and anti-corruption official, Hu Yaobang, whom the protesters wanted to mourn.

Following the bloody crushing of the protesters by the Chinese military, the Chinese government conducted widespread arrests of protesters and their supporters, cracked down on other protests around China, banned the foreign press from the country and strictly controlled coverage of the events in its press.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct flights to be launched between Kaohsiung and Qingdao, Tianjin
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 13:39:11 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung is expected to launch direct air links with the Chinese cities of Qingdao and Tianjin in mid-June, which will help to boost tourism in southern Taiwan, a tourism industry representative said Friday.

Also, the number of flights between Kaohsiung and China will be almost tripled to 38 per week, according to Lin Fu-nan, leader of an alliance of tourism- related businesses in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas.
Lin said the increase in the number of flights was agreed upon during cross- Taiwan Strait aviation talks last month in Taipei and is the result of lobbying efforts by the alliance.

At present, Kaohsiung International Airport maintains direct air link with eight Chinese cities, namely Fuzhou, Shenzhen, Shanghai, Hangzhou, Ningbo, Guangzhou, Chengdu and Xiamen. A total of 14 flights per week are provided.
Lin said an increase in the number of flights between Kaohsiung and China will help encourage more Chinese tourists to visit southern Taiwan and bring more tourism revenue to the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek settles with British Telecom in patent dispute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 13:43:23 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Integrated circuit (IC) designer MediaTek Inc. said Friday it has settled a patent dispute with British Telecom.

The settlement was reached after British Telecom filed a lawsuit at a district court in the U.S. state of Massachusetts in November 2009, accusing the Taiwanese firm's wholly owned unit MediaTek Wireless of infringing on its patents applied to microchips used in cell phones.

MediaTek said both sides have signed a settlement agreement in which British Telecom will withdraw the litigation from the Massachusetts court and will not pursue legal proceedings related to the same patents anywhere else.
MediaTek declined to elaborate on the settlement or to disclose any possible compensation it will have to pay British Telecom over the patent dispute.
However, the company said in a statement that "the settlement does not pose any impact on the company's financial condition or its operations."
According to the local media, MediaTek had originally insisted on its innocence when British Telecom first filed the lawsuit, saying the company had never used the patents involved in the dispute.
In recent years, MediaTek has obtained IC patents for cell phone use through a spate of acquisitions, as the company has diversifying its business to the mobile communications IC sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. firm on arms sales to Taiwan: AIT chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 13:59:40 (By Garfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States remains firm on its policy for selling defensive weapons to Taiwan under the framework of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt said Friday.

U.S. arms sales to Taiwan are vitally important in terms of maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, and the U.S. will not deviate from this stance on the basis of the 30-year- old TRA, Burghardt said while briefing President Ma Ying-jeou at the Presidential Office on the recent U.S.-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue.

This has been a never-rescinded promise and obligation of the U.S. to Taiwan over the past 30 years, he said, explaining that he communication channels remain smooth between the two countries and that they will immediately contact each other should the need arise.
Ma for his part urged the U.S. to consider selling F-16C/D jet fighters to Taiwan to help the country phase out its aging fleet of fighters and beef up its defenses.
Taiwan requested in 2006 to buy 66 F-16 C/Ds to supplement its aging IDF jet fighters and French-made Mirage 2000s, but Washington has not given a clear reply to date.

Touching on his recent controversial remarks that he will not ask the U.S. to fight for Taiwan, Ma reiterated that he made them simply to underscore to the entire world Taiwan's resolve to defend itself in line with the TRA.

On the prospects for cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the president said the goal of clinching a Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement in June remains unchanged, and he also called on the U.S. to quickly sign an extradition agreement with Taiwan.
"A similar Taiwan-China judicial assistance accord has helped bring several Taiwanese fugitives back to Taiwan," he noted.
Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison official responsible for two-way dealings with Taiwan, arrived in Taiwan June 2 for a six-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex must get bigger: organizers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 14:06:58 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Organizers of the world's second biggest computer show, Computex Taipei, said this week during the 30th show that if the trade exhibition does not expand its venue space, the show may not be able to retain its high position.

"If (participating companies) cannot be accommodated in Taiwan, there are plenty of big exhibition halls in other Asian countries for them," Moses Yen, the head of the Exhibition Department of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , told the Central News Agency during a recent interview.
Although Computex posts small growth almost every year -- with 8 percent more booths this year than last year -- it still has a long way to go, Yen said.

CeBIT, the world's largest show of its kind, draws 4,000-5,000 exhibitors to Hannover, Germany annually, while Computex has never topped 2,000, according to Chang Li, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), which co-hosts Computex.
But the problem isn't as simple as just finding more exhibitors.
"Our problem is that we do not have enough space at the available halls, " said Jeremy Horng, deputy executive director of TAITRA'S Exhibition Department.
More than 100 companies could not exhibit at the event this year because of lack of space, Horng said.
The government is already working to ease the problem by building an extension to the Nangang Exhibition Hall, which currently can accommodate 2,467 booths.

The extension, which will be capable of accommodating a further 2,350 booths, is due to open in 2013, which will make the Nangang Exhibition Hall Taiwan's first international-level large exhibition hall. It will provide space for at least 5,000 booths.

This year, Computex uses a combined 4,861 booths at the Nangang Exhibition Hall, Taipei International Convention Center (TICC) , Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Exhibition Hall 1 and TWTC Exhibition Hall 3.
The government is also considering building another extension to the hall, but is concerned that the second extension might not be fully used all year round, Yen noted.
Chang recently echoed Yen by saying that the government should consider the needs of Taiwan's largest exhibitions, rather than paying too much attention to smaller exhibitions.
"If you don't look at it this way, Taiwan will never be able to organize large activities," he told reporters.
Computex became the world's third largest computer trade show in 1989, three years after organizers moved the event to a bigger venue at the TWTC Exhibition Hall 1.
It became the world's second largest of its kind after the U.S.'s COMDEX was canceled in 2004.
This year's five-day Computex opened to industry professionals beginning Tuesday, and will be open to the public on its final day Saturday.
More than 1,700 companies are exhibiting at the show this year and around 120,000 visitors are expected.
In terms of its influence on the hardware industry, Computex is already the world's No. 1, as Taiwan has a well-established industrial supply chain, Chang said.
Taiwan manufactures nearly 90 percent of the world's notebook computers.
Chang, however, said another issue is the nature of the show.
Computex has been focused mainly on business to business products, but in recent years, it has begun to be geared towards consumers.
This will help it become more appealing, the organizers said.

Many major exhibitors are showcasing some of the latest tablet PCs, 3D gaming notebook computers or e-readers at Computex this year, marking another step in Computex's expansion to cover consumer electronics products in recent years, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.21 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 14:57:36 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.21 percent Friday as profit taking emerged to erode early gains after the bourse staged a strong rebound in the previous session, dealers said later that day.
The weighted index fell 15.69 points to 7,344.59 after moving between 7,337.35 and 7,377.56 on turnover of NT$67.58 billion (US$2.10 billion).

The market opened 0.23 percent higher on follow-through buying from the previous day's 2.28 percent jump, but profit taking emerged in mid-morning trade to compromise the earlier gains, with the index moving closer to the nearest resistance of around 7,400 points, the dealers said.
A total of 1,163 stocks closed up and 1,431 were down, with 420 remaining unchanged.
The financial sector suffered the heaviest losses, down 0.9 percent, followed by a 0.6 percent fall in the construction sector, while cement, along with paper and pulp, lost 0.5 percent.

The foodstuff sector fell 0.4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics with a 0.1 percent decline, while the textile sector closed up 0.4 percent and the plastics and chemicals sector was unchanged.
"Turnover remained thin. The market, therefore, failed to overcome the technical barriers ahead of 7,400 points, " TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.
After an NT$11 billion net buy recorded a day earlier, foreign institutional investors mostly took to the sidelines throughout the trading session, waiting for new leads to act, Shih said.
"Without buying from foreign funds, large-cap high tech stocks appeared stagnant, in sharp contrast to yesterday's strong showing. The local bourse has fallen back to consolidation mode," he said.
However, he added that market sentiment has improved significantly after Thursday's gains, with more and more investors willing to keep their holdings.
"I expect the market will see technical support at the 7,000-7,100 point range next week," Shih said.
Cathay Financial fell 1.92 percent to NT$45.95 and Fubon Financial lost 0.54 percent to end at NT$36.85.
United Microelectronics Corp. dropped 1.68 percent to NT$14.65, while Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. closed up 0.33 percent at NT$61.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industrial Development Bureau to promote electric scooters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 15:22:50 (By Lin Hui-chun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said Friday it will collaborate with Taiwanese firms to promote sales of electric scooters at an event to mark its 40th anniversary Saturday.

The bureau and three motorcycle manufacturers will jointly organize a promotional activity on the sidelines of the anniversary celebrations at Taipei County Civic Square to showcase the latest electric motorcycles and will stage a scooter parade.

The three companies -- E-Ton Power, Kwang Yang Motor and China Motor Corporation which have been recognized for their application of electric motorcycle technology -- will offer prizes of three scooters in a lucky draw.
The scooters are valued at between NT$50, 000 (US$1,600) to NT$60,000 each, the bureau said.
The anniversary celebrations will include an exhibition of a wide range of Taiwan-made items such as socks and towels to display Taiwan's industrial strength, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promotes energy saving in big companies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 15:44:58 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that the government will keep promoting low- carbon communities and he urged big companies to put more efforts into adopting new technologies to reduce carbon emissions.

At a ceremony in which he presented "carbon footprint" labels to five local companies considered eligible to label their products as having small carbon footprints, Wu said that companies with high carbon emissions -- such as Taiwan Power Company, CPC Taiwan Corp., China Steel, China Shipbuilding and Formosa Plastics Group, should consider revamping their infrastructure.
Action taken by China Steel to use new equipment, and Formosa Petrochemical's efforts to reduce carbon emissions should also be encouraged, the premier said.

Wu also noted that the Presidential Office has begun to turn off some of its lights in the daytime, has installed water-efficient faucets, and is turning up the temperature on its air-conditioners, in an effort to reduce carbon emissions and save energy and water.

"In the past year, the energy-saving measures taken by the government and people helped save more than 7 billion units of electricity -- almost equivalent to one year's electricity consumption for the whole of Tainan County and city, which have a combined population of 1.86 million people," Wu said.

Wu also said that over the past six months, the country's water use reduced by a volume equivalent to almost 29 days-worth of water consumption in Taipei City, which has a population of 2.6 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven Taiwan products granted carbon footprint labels
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 15:53:31 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Seven products made by five local companies have been granted carbon footprint labels, making Taiwan the 11th country in the world to introduce the labeling system, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Friday.

The first products in the country to be approved for the carbon footprint label are Taisun Enterprise's bottled drinking water, Hey Song's sarsaparilla and camellia green tea drinks, Hair O'right's green tea shampoos, BenQ's 20-inch LCD monitor and AU Optronic's 32-inch TFT-LCD television, the EPA said.
EPA Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said those companies with products granted the labels not only showed a smaller carbon footprint, but also promised to reduce carbon emissions in the future.

The EPA said that about 50 percent of the carbon footprint for regular shampoos is caused by consumers rinsing with hot water, and the shampoo granted the new label is made with local plant extracts that make it easier to rinse.

The bottled drinking water "Twist Water" was granted the label because it reduces plastic usage by 43 percent, carbon emissions by 50 grams and recycling space by 70 percent, Taisun Enterprise Deputy General Manager Lin Wen-tsung said.
Shen said that the EPA will continue to promote the labeling system and that it hopes consumers will buy more products carrying the labels, try to save energy and recycle more.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hotline wins public service award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 16:40:55 (By Elizabeth Hsu and Mandy Wong)

TEXT.P: Taipei City government's "1999 Citizen Hotline" was recently honored as the best public service in the Asia Pacific region in 2009 by the Hong Kong-based Asia Pacific Customer Service Consortium, according to Mayor Hau Lung-bin.

The hotline won "Public Service of the Year" at the 2009 Asia Pacific Customer Relationship Excellence Awards on June 2, making the city government the second governmental institute in the region to receive the honor after the Hong Kong Observatory won when the category debuted in 2008.
"The award recognizes the efforts of all Taipei City government staff members," Mayor Hau Lung-bin said.

The 24-hour hotline was launched at Hau's initiative on July 3, 2008 to improve public servants' service attitude and efficiency. It was set up to answer various requests for city government help or consultation and to handle citizen complaints.

Hau said that world-renowned Japanese architect Toyo Ito once told him that he was impressed by an operator who spoke fluent Japanese when he called 1999 for information about an exhibition at the Chang Dai-chien Residence in Taipei City's Shilin District.
Some taxi drivers use the call center for help translating foreign customers' needs, Hau added.

According to city government statistics, the service has received over 3.4 million calls since opening. More than 2.68 million calls, or 79 percent of the total, were made to ask for dispatching services while 710,000 calls, or 21 percent, for transfer to other public services.

A Taiwan Institute of Economic Research survey showed 86 percent of those who had called the hotline said they were satisfied with the service, and 88 percent of the satisfied respondents said they would use the service again.
Chen Yeong-ren, Taipei's deputy secretary-general, received the award on behalf of the city government in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

The annual awards were established in 2002 to promote service quality and customer relationship excellence in international cities across the Asia Pacific region, and to recognize companies, business units, teams and individuals that have contributed to the success of both their customers and the organizations that they serve.
The state-funded Chunghwa Telecom Co. received awards for Contact Center of the Year, Outstanding Team of the Year, Best Use of Technology of the Year and CEO of the Year in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes up on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 16:49:45 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, rising NT$0.075 to close at the day's high of NT$32.350.
Turnover totaled US$581 million dollars during the trading session.
The greenback opened at 32.275 and then moved to a low of 32.137 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises Japanese architect
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 17:08:21 (By Garfie Li and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday he appreciated "thought-provoking" advice from a world-renowned Japanese architect who recommended Taiwan ensure its man- made structures coexist with the environment.
During a meeting at the Presidential Office, Ma told Tadao Ando that his advice was enlightening, especially after Taiwan completed two landmark buildings, Taipei 101 and Taipei Arena.
The president said he admires Ando's design philosophy and environment-friendly work.

"Ando is a unique architect as he was not trained to be one, " Ma said. "He was once a boxer but later taught himself the trade through traveling and reading, and went on to win international architecture awards."

Ando currently has four projects in Taiwan, including his first overseas chapel, which is on the northeastern coast. He previously designed four chapels in Japan. His other works in Taiwan include buildings at National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu and Asia University in Taichung, and a cemetery in Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH censured over U.S. beef tongue row
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 17:52:11 (By Sophia Yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan -- the country's top government watchdog -- censured the Department of Health (DOH) Friday for mismanaging a controversy over U.S. beef tongue imports in April.

Pointing to what he described as four "major lapses" committed by the DOH, Control Yuan member Cheng Jen-hung said the DOH did not learn from its mistakes, lacked a sense of crisis, failed to proactively supervise beef imports, and did not clear up public doubts in time.

It was the second time the DOH had been censured over its handling of beef imports from the United States. The last time was in March, when it was reprimanded for mistakes in the government's policy of opening Taiwan's market to U.S. bone-in-beef and other beef parts.

The latest dispute arose after the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) approved April 15 an application by a Taiwanese beef importer to import 453 kg of beef tongues and diaphragm from the United States -- the first application to import such products since Taiwan opened its market wider to U.S. beef products in November 2009.
According to Cheng, the BOFT issued an import permit to the importer because it did not consider tongues to be classed as internal organs, which are not allowed to enter Taiwan.
Although the BOFT notified the DOH immediately after it issued the permit, DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said he remained unaware of the matter until he was asked about it by reporters, Cheng said.
Under pressure from public concern about the safety of the products, the DOH advised the importer to drop the import plan April 20, and the BOFT later said the importer had withdrawn the application.

However, Cheng said, the beef tongues were already being shipped to Taiwan by that time. After the shipment arrived in Taiwan May 7, the importer voluntarily gave it up and it was destroyed by customs authorities, he added.

Referring to the example of South Korea, Cheng said that since South Korea reopened its market to U.S. beef in June 2008, there is no record of beef tongues having been imported there because there is an understanding between the two sides.
In addition, South Korea has listed beef tongue as a controlled item subject to batch-by-batch inspections and tests should it ever be imported there, he went on.
Instead of learning from South Korea, however, the DOH classed beef tongues as regular beef products and handled them according to relevant procedures, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign exchange reserves hit new high in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 17:58:14 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a record US$360.12 billion as of the end of May, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) said Friday.
The May figure was US$2.57 billion higher than a month earlier, the central bank said.
The increase largely reflected returns on foreign exchange reserves investments, it added.
Taiwan remained the world's fourth-largest foreign exchange holder, after China (US$2.45 trillion in March 2010), Japan (US$993.2 billion in April) and Russia (US$425.1 billion in April).

DOC.HEADLINE: Application for Nan Shan Life acquisition hits snag: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 18:15:27 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The acquisition of the Taiwan-based Nan Shan Life Insurance company by a Hong Kong consortium has hit a snag as the Taiwan government requires more information from the group, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Friday.

The Hong Kong group failed to submit some of the documents that are required by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) and other relevant government agencies and which should have accompanied its application in January for the Taiwan government's approval of the acquisition deal, the MOEA said.

The agencies have asked the Hong Kong consortium, which is led by Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic, to provide, in particular, information related to any Chinese shareholding in China Strategic, the MOEA said.
"The government needs all the required documents to complete its review of the application, as the shareholding structure of the consortium is very complicated," MOEA told the Central News Agency.
"Without careful review, we cannot allow the deal to proceed, " the ministry said.

Under Taiwan regulations, Chinese enterprises are not permitted to own Taiwanese insurance companies, and any overseas company in which Chinese investors have more than a 30 percent stake is considered a Chinese company.
The MOEA said it is also looking into whether Raymond Or, chief executive of China Strategic, is currently a member of the Chinese People's Consultative Conference.
Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, which supervises cross-strait relations, will examine whether Or's status will have any impact on the deal, the ministry said.
In addition, the FSC will look at the consortium's financial situation and its ability to deliver on its promise to run Nan Shan Life as a long term investment, according to the MOEA.

The consortium had hoped that the government review of its application would have been completed by mid-July, but according to the MOEA, this all depends on the information that the consortium provides.

The Hong Kong group won the bid last October, beating out Taiwan's Chinatrust Financial Holding, to acquire Nan Shan Life from the debt-ridden American International Group (AIG) for US$2.15 billion (NT$69.16 billion).
However, government approval is required before the deal can go though, as it will involve the interests of 4 million local insurance policy holders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts urge Internet management system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 18:45:42 (By Hsieh Chia-cheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Pundits and experts said Friday in a seminar that a lot of news in today's world is obtained via the Internet and that a management system should be devised to control it, considering the huge impact of the Internet.
In the seminar sponsored by the Ministry of the Interior, the scholars discussed how to deal with the issues of emerging new media and how to maintain discipline among them.
Wang Yu-min, executive director of the Child Welfare League Foundation, said the media's performance has improved.
She cited as an example that when the media reports suicides, they add a "value your life" ticker, " as well as the suicide prevention hotline number, and do not run photos of dead children.
However, she also expressed regret that a media outlet recently covered the rape of a student on a train in lurid detail.
She said the ratio of pornographic content on the Internet tends to be too high but there is no law to govern it, and she urged the media not to vie for sensationalism to boost their ratings.

Public Television Service News Department Manager He Kuo-hua said the Internet has made a massive impact, but the government's regulations governing the new media are insufficient compared with its management of the print and electronic media, and he urged the government to come up with a strategy to regulate the new media.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA to hold Indian hill railway exhibition to mark anniversary
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:02:35 (Wang Shwu-fen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) and the Taipei-based India-Taipei Association will hold an exhibition featuring three Indian mountain railways to mark the TRA's 123rd founding anniversary, an association spokesman said Friday.
This will be the first time that the three Indian railways and Mumbai Railway Station, which have been listed on UNESCO's World Heritage List, will be featured in Taiwan, according to the spokesman.

The exhibition, a collection of photos, posters and other materials related to the railways, will be held at Taipei Main Station June 9-13 and be accompanied by Bollywood dances and food-tasting and prize-drawing events.

The TRA has some history with India, having purchased 113 trains from the southern Asian country more than 30 years ago. Only about 10 of them remain in service today, as commuter trains in southern Taiwan.
One was recently used to support the resumption of operations of a mountain railway line in Miaoli, northern Taiwan.
The three Indian railways to be featured include the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway in northeast India, the Kalka Shimla Railway in northwest India and the Nilgiri Mountain Railway in southern India.
The 88-kilometer Darjeeling Himalayan line, opened in 1881, and the 96-km Kalka Shimla line, opened in 1903, reach altitudes of over 2,000 meters and offer panoramic views of the Himalayas.
UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) described the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway as the most outstanding example of a hill passenger railway.
It said its design applies bold and ingenious engineering solutions to the problem of establishing an effective rail link across a mountainous terrain of great beauty.
The Ghum station along the line is the highest railway station in India at an elevation of 2,258 meters.
The Kalka Shimla line passes through more 100 tunnels and over 800 bridges and provides the chance to get a glimpse of spectacular snow-capped mountains.
The 46-km Nilgiri line, opened in 1899, is the steepest railway line in Asia. Along with a steep gradient, there are curves as sharp as 18 degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayors should name local police chiefs: legislators
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:08:34 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Legislators from across the political spectrum urged the central government Friday to delegate the power to name city and county police chiefs to local government heads.

At present, police forces are administered by the National Police Agency (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior, while mayors and magistrates can only offer advice on police personnel administration, including appointment and discipline.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chiu Yi said the current system is unfair to local government chiefs, who are held accountable for public order in their administrative districts.

"The central government should consider taking steps to correct this disparity by delegating the power to choose police personnel to local government chiefs so that they can better deploy manpower, improve efficiency and streamline police discipline," Chiu said.
Chiu said the power delegation issue has become more urgent after the changing of the guard at the Taichung City Police Bureau the previous day.

The reshuffle, in which Chiu Feng-kuang, originally deputy head of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, replaced Hu Mu-yuan as the Taichung police chief, came at the insistence of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu amid public outrage over the presence of four police officers at a crime scene in which a suspected gang leader died in a shower of bullets.

NPA Director-General Wang Cho-chun said at a news conference late Thursday that out of respect for Mayor Hu's opinion, he decided to reassign Hu Mu-yuan to head a riot police corps, a proposal that was also backed by Wang's superior, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah.

Mayor Hu demanded the personnel replacement after Hu Mu-yuan kept him in the dark for five days after investigators discovered the presence of four police officers at the scene of the May 28 shooting, which claimed two lives.
Initial investigations showed that the four police officers were invited by a retired colleague to the office of suspected gang leader Weng Chi-nan, who was killed in the shooting.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Chun-yee said Friday that the event highlighted poor police ethics and a lack of integrity.

Hu Mu-yuan should not have allowed his subordinates to maintain interactions with members of criminal rings, Lee said, adding that judging from the event, the police chief should have been removed from his post earlier.

Lee also echoed Chiu's appeal, saying that giving local government heads the power to name city or county police bureau chiefs and discipline police officers in their administrative districts would improve operational efficiency and police integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Institutional investors upbeat about notebook shipments
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:23:14 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Institutional investors are increasingly optimistic about the outlook of Taiwan's notebook computer industry, with shipments from the largest contract notebook manufacturers expected to rise by the end of the year.

Goldman Sachs analyst Henry King raised the brokerage's growth forecast for notebook shipments in the second quarter to 7 percent from 6 percent, and also expected increases of 13 percent in Q3 and 5 percent in Q4.

King noted in a report on Thursday that notebook maker Compal Electronics raised its shipment target from 48 million units to 50 million for 2010, while Quanta Computer expected a quarter-on-quarter growth of 15 percent to 20 percent in Q2 shipments.

Although share prices of those notebook manufacturers were not cheap, King still suggested bargain hunting their shares because more good news from the industry is expected in the second half of this year.
King also said Wistron Corporation is his top pick among notebook stocks.

In another report released by Credit Suisse analyst Randy Abrams on Thursday, the brokerage noted that Quanta and Acer were more confident they could achieve their targets for shipment this year, while Wistron and Compal also expected a recovery following a drop in late April and early May.

Quanta was one of the five top picks in the brokerage report, which was completed after the brokerage's local equity research team visited 21 Taiwanese manufacturers at the Computex Taipei trade show, a media report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businessman wins award in Britain
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:36:46 (By Jennifer Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A businessman from Taiwan became the first Asian winner of the prestigious Comms Business Awards in Britain Thursday.
The award presentation was held in London and Jason Tsai, who is the winner of the Channel Entrepreneur of the Year, was honored along with 18 winners of awards in other categories.

Miles Bossom, managing director of the awards, said Tsai was chosen from among 14 candidates and he added that the fierce competition among the candidates underscores the excellence of Tsai's company's service and the high quality of its products.
Tsai founded Enta Technologies Ltd. -- the name of which is a combination of England and Taiwan -- in 1990, distributing computer components from his garage at his home in England.
The company rapidly grew into one of Britain's leading IT distributors.

By 1995, when Enta moved into purpose-built premises, Tsai spotted an opportunity in the market to provide Internet access services, so he set up a second business, Entanet International Ltd., which has grown into a leading voice and data communications provider.
In 1999, he set up his third company, Entacall Telecommunications Ltd., to provide traditional telecom services to his existing Entanet reseller partners.
Then, in 2003, he established his fourth business, Entamedia Ltd., as a separate company providing marketing and design services to its sister companies and external clients.
In an interview with CNA, Tsai said the award is significant to him as it confirms his many years working in Britain, especially as he was the only Asian winner at this year's awards.

Addressing Taiwanese youths who would like to start their own businesses in Britain, Tsai advised them to swim with the tide, choose the right trade, learn the local culture and assimilate into local society.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ready for 10-year fight after referendum initiative rejected
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:43:44 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will launch a "10-year war of resistance" and continue pushing for a referendum on a potential Taiwan-China trade deal after an initiative on the issue was rejected Thursday night, a DPP spokesman said Friday.

By a vote of 12-4 with one abstention, the Executive Yuan's Referendum Screening Committee rejected a referendum petition on Taiwan's signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China presented by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Responding to the rejection, DPP spokesman Julian Kuo said the DPP will ally with the TSU and other social activist groups to launch a 10-year offensive and will help the TSU initiate another ECFA referendum.

Kuo said President Ma Ying-jeou's Kuomintang (KMT) administration has labeled the ECFA as a free trade agreement (FTA) , and under the spirit of FTAs, Taiwan will be forced to open its markets to 90 percent of China's merchandise over a period of 10 years, he added.

He said all DPP officials and grassroots members will pitch in to the offensive in opposing the referendum initiative's rejection -- which he described as tantamount to denying the people their civil rights.

If China moves to disrupt Taiwan's bid to sign FTAs with other nations and locks Taiwan into a "one China" market, it will certainly whip up a second wave of indignation in Taiwan's society, he contended.
Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang reiterated that the DPP will render its support to the TSU in submitting the referendum initiative proposal again.
According to the Referendum Act, TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei, who proposed the ECFA referendum initiative, can appeal the case to the Executive Yuan within 30 days.
The DPP will also organize a series of social activities to press forward the opposition's causes, Lin said, with the first in the series to be held in Kaohsiung City Saturday evening.
Both DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei will be there, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: County government purchases bananas amid price slump
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:57:27 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Pingtung County government has begun to buy bananas from local farmers at eight locations in the southern area to help prop up the fruit's slumping price, in line with an initiative launched by Taiwan's top agricultural authority.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced in late May it would guide food processors to buy bananas for a relatively cheap NT$5 per kilogram to boost flagging demand, and officials in Taiwan's southernmost county said Friday it had begun to comply.
According to the county's Agricultural Department, demand for bananas has been crowded out by the harvests of many other summer fruits like mangos, pineapples and watermelons, causing prices to fall.
"Bananas have been unable to compete with the juicy fruits, " the department said.
The COA has set a goal of purchasing 3,000 tons of healthy green bananas, weighing under 6 kilograms per bundle.

The measure, however, drew the protests of several banana growers in neighboring Kaohsiung County, who complained that the purchasing program only benefits farmers who have contracts with local farmers cooperatives, the Chinese-language United Daily News reported Friday.
"Farmers who don't have ties to the cooperatives can only leave their bananas to rot, " said Chu Hsin-chiang, the former head of the Meinong Township Farmers Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bookstore chain to celebrate World Environment Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 19:57:40 (By Cheng Jin-wen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taipei's largest bookstore chain, Eslite, will host an outdoor fair named "Every Little Green" to celebrate the 2010 World Environment Day, an Eslite spokesman said Friday.
Eslite is scheduled to hold an open-air market Saturday that will feature fresh seasonal produce, organic garden greens and handmade or homegrown goods outside its Dunnan branch, the spokesman said.
The event is mainly in response to the World Environment Day's cause of conserving the planet's biodiversity, he said.
The outdoor market will include an activity in which participants will be able to exchange their creative artworks with each other, as well as an exhibition of environment-related photos.
In addition, three local indie bands will perform songs expressing concern for the planet, he added.

Similar events will be held around the country to mark the day, which was established by the United Nations in 1972 to raise awareness about the environment and enhance political attention and public action.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese to get a taste of 'Chocolate Wonderland' next month
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 20:05:42 (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan baker has made a 170 cm tall chocolate model of the Taipei 101 tower to promote the World Chocolate Wonderland exhibition that will open in Taipei next month.
The baker, Lee Kuo-yi, said at a promotional event Friday that he and his team took a month to create the piece, which is made from almost 20 kg of chocolate.
"The biggest challenge is how to keep the chocolate in perfect condition, " said Lee, who won a silver medal at HOFEX 2009, Asia's leading food and hospitality trade show.
Chocolate is a fragile medium in food art because it melts at temperatures of over 20 degrees Celsius and cracks at temperatures lower than 0 degrees Celsius, he explained.
In an effort to promote Taiwan's cultural and creative industries, the organizers of the exhibition have invited Lee and other Taiwanese master bakers to submit food art for the show.

The show, which was held in Beijing earlier this year and will move to Taiwan on July 3, will exhibit the work of more than 100 world-class bakers, depicting structures like the Great Wall of China, China's terracotta army and the Mogao Caves.
Phoebe Chen, the mother of a three-year-old, said she and her son will go the exhibition because they both loved the movie "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory."
"I think it is great that chocolate is the medium used in the exhibition," she said.
The exhibition will be held at National Taiwan Science Education Center in Shihlin, Taipei City from July 3 to September 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Permanent forum on carbon reduction launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 20:24:53 (By Justin Su and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: An environmental group announced Friday the launch of a permanent forum to bring together the government and the business and academic sectors to tackle the task of reducing carbon emissions in Taiwan.

Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Chu Feng-chi, one of the legislators who attended the bipartisan press conference to show support for the initiative, said she expects the forum to help forge consensus on carbon reduction issues.

Representatives from all sectors of society will meet once every two months to discuss issues related to global warming and low carbon development strategies and make suggestions to the government for its drafting of relevant policies, she said.

The group decided earlier this year to set up the forum to fill the need for cooperation among the various sectors in Taiwan to work toward the government's carbon reduction goals, said opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tien Chiu-chin.
The government's goals are to cut Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions to the 2005 level by 2020, and reduce them to the 2000 level by 2025.
Tien said that as more and more people have fallen victim to climate-related disasters in recent years, there is an immediate need for action to fight climate change.

For example, rising sea levels caused by abrupt climate changes could submerge many coastal industrial zones in Taiwan, she said. In such a senario, economic development would mean nothing, Tien added.
However, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Cheng Li-wen said there is not necessarily a conflict between economic development and environmental protection.
She added that once high-polluting industries undergo full transformation, the mode of economic growth will also change significantly.
Changes in the approaches toward economic development and environmental protection will have to take place in tandem, Cheng stressed.
Taiwan should join the global efforts to reduce carbon emissions, she said.
"If we do not do so today, we would regret tomorrow, " Cheng added.
DPP Legislator Pan Meng-an said that in the past, Taiwan sought economic development at the cost of the environment.
He suggested that in the future, the decisions reached in the forum should be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for June 4 (II)

TEXT.P: one time 31. TSU to file suit against CEC for rejecting its referendum

DOC.HEADLINE: Government recruits 1,000 volunteers to monitor, report flooding
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 21:04:53 (By Chung Hsing-hsian and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Some 1,000 volunteers gathered in Taichung City Friday for the launch of a citizens flood alert team that the government hopes will provide more timely information that helps it prevent flood damage.

Vice Economics Minister Hwang Jung-chiou said at a ceremony in the central Taiwan city that the volunteers in local communities will complement the government's early warning system and help authorities respond to floods more quickly and effectively.
The key to preventing and mitigating flood damage, Hwang said, is getting early warnings and accurate information about situations, a lesson learned in past typhoon seasons.
Last August, Typhoon Morakot battered southern Taiwan with torrential rains, triggering lethal mudslides and flooding a quarter of the country's land area.
The Water Resources Agency said each of its 10 River Management Offices around Taiwan has recruited 100 local citizens and assigned them into groups according to the conditions of each region.
The agency said the volunteers will check places such as pumping stations, river embankments, and drainage systems to see if they are functioning normally.

DOC.HEADLINE: 94% of Chinese tourists satisfied with their Taiwan trips: official
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 21:13:54 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Some 94 percent of the Chinese tourists who have visited Taiwan so far this year were satisfied with their tours, Yang Rui-tsung, chief of the Beijing bracnch of the Taiwan Strait Tourism Association, said here Friday.
That figure represents a rise of 10 percentage points over last year, according to surveys conducted by the Taiwan-based association.
A breakdown of the figures shows that tour bus drivers earned the highest approval rating of 98.9 percent, compared with 94.2 percent
last year, while the level of satisfaction with meals in Taiwan was 82.5 percent, down from 84.6 percent of last year, Yang said.

At a seminar with 18 Beijing travel agencies that handle package tours to Taiwan, Yang said his association pays great attention to the quality of the tours and will spare no effort to ensure the comfort of the visitors.
Citing statistics compiled by Taiwan authorities, Yang said Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan in 2009 were 600,000, while there were 370,000 business arrivals.
The figures are expected to grow this year to 1 million and 500,000, respectively, he said.
Noting that Taiwan limits the number of Chinese tourists arrivals to 3,000 per day, Yang said the restriction takes into consideration the capacity of Taiwan's hospitality industry.
He urged the Chinese travel agencies to keep the cost of Taiwan tours at a minimum of US$60 per capita per day, and refrain from waging price wars that will undermine the quality of tours.
Yang said Taiwan is preparing to allow visits by Chinese backpackers, but this would require careful planning and China's cooperation.
"It will only be approved when both sides of the strait think it is OK," he said.
The seminar was held to mark the one month anniversary of the association's office opening in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: US beef issue 'lingers,' but won't hurt ties: AIT head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 21:28:33 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The controversy surrounding Taiwan's partial ban on beef imports from the U.S. is not resolved but won't affect the countries' strong trade relationship, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt said Friday.

Burghardt told a media roundtable that the beef row was a "lingering issue" because U.S. senators and the U.S. government see Taiwan's market as still not totally open to U.S. beef due to "non-scientific" reasoning.

In January, Taiwan's legislature passed an amendment to the Act Governing Food Safety that banned imports of specific beef products from countries with documented cases of mad cow disease in the past decade. The amendment effectively barred U.S. ground beef, beef offal and other beef parts such as the skull, eyes and intestines from Taiwan's market, in contravention of a bilateral beef trade protocol signed by the two countries last October.
Burghardt said, however, that U.S. beef "is coming in and doing well (on Taiwan's market) and people are buying bone-in and boneless beef... It would be nice to see the market totally open."
Moreover, he said, the fact that Taiwan is the U.S.'s ninth-largest trading partner and sixth-largest market for agricultural products says a lot about the countries' bilateral trade relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chairperson expresses wish to visit China
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 22:05:59 (By Stanley Cheung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Friday that she would welcome a visit by the head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office while also expressing a wish to visit the mainland sometime in the future.
"I would welcome Director Wang Yi to come to Taiwan," Lai said in Hong Kong.
She also felt she would have the opportunity to travel to China because of more institutionalized contacts between Taiwan and China.

"Under the systematic negotiating framework" between the two intermediary bodies from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, an "MAC chairperson's visit to the mainland, or that of the Taiwan Affairs Office director to Taiwan can be expected," she said.
Lai arrived in the special administration region of China Thursday for a three- day visit accompanied by Chu Hsi, the director of the MAC's Department of Hong Kong and Macao Affairs.

Addressing her visit, which was described by a senior MAC official as an ice- breaking "landing on Hong Kong, " Lai said she came here to review the operations of the MAC's Hong Kong office, referring to the Chung Hwa Travel Service.
She also plans to visit Taiwanese associations and other related groups set up in the former British colony, Lai added.

Speaking to MAC staff members stationed in Hong Kong, Lai said that positive cross-strait exchanges have helped promote the improvement in Taiwan-Hong Kong ties, and that her visit is evidence of that.

She expressed hope for the newly-formed Taipei-based Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Co-operation Council and its Hong Kong counterpart -- the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Co-operation and Promotion Council -- to spur visits by Taiwanese officials to Hong Kong and vice versa in the future.
Taiwan formally launched the semi-official organization May 26 to help forge closer cooperation with Hong Kong.
Speaking of Taiwan's Hong Kong policy, Lai said there remain many problems in terms of Taiwan-Hong Kong cooperation and exchanges that need to be resolved.
Matters concerning the welfare of people in Taiwan and Hong Kong, for example, can still only be handled by "official authorities," she said, but hoped there could be breakthroughs in the future.

"We should anticipate the future development of Taiwan-Hong Kong relations in an active and positive manner. Like visa waivers, if people expect that to happen, both governments should work in that direction, " Lai said.
Meanwhile, senior MAC officials confirmed that Lai made the visit in her official capacity as MAC chief. Lai is the first minister-level Taiwanese official to visit Hong Kong, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taichung police chief promises better environment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 22:08:31 (By Hau Hsueh-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The new head of the Taichung City Police Bureau said Friday he will draw up an action plan to improve the city's public order and create a better and more secure living environment.

Chiu Feng-kuang, formally deputy director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, also promised to streamline police ethics and discipline as he took over the helm at a ceremony attended by his predecessor Hu Mu-yuan and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.
Mayor Hu lauded Hu Mu-yuan, who has been reassigned to head a riot police corps, for his arduous efforts to combat crime and maintain public order during his nine-month term of office.

The personnel reshuffle came after a string of daylight gunfights in the central Taiwanese city in recent months, including a May 28 shooting that claimed two lives. More embarrassing was the discovery that four police officers were present at the scene of the latest killings.
Amid public outrage over ties between city police staff and gangs, Mayor Hu urged Chiu to draw a clear line of battle in the fight against crime rings.

After public demand that the police bureau release security camera footage of the May 28 shootout at the office of Weng Chi-nan, an alleged gang boss who was killed in the shootings, Chiu said he will deal with the issue in a speedy and transparent manner.

As to relations between police and criminals, Chiu said he will require all police officers to maintain a distance in dealing with gangsters during criminal investigations, stressing that no gray areas would be tolerable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU to appeal Referendum Review Committee's decision
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 23:13:09 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Hsieh Chia-chen, Sophia Yeh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Friday it will sue the Executive Yuan's Referendum Review Committee for dereliction of duty, a day after the committee rejected the TSU's referendum initiative on a proposed trade pact with China.
The committee turned down the referendum proposal, which asked "Do you agree with the government signing an economic cooperation framework agreement with China?" by a 12-4 margin.
The committee consists of 21 members, but only 19 attended the meeting.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei blasted the committee's decision at a press conference, saying that it is invalid and does not conform to the law. He said the party would file a complaint with prosecutors that the committee should be prosecuted for dereliction of duty.
The opposition party also plans to appeal the committee's ruling, and if the appeal fails, it intends to file an administrative appeal, Huang said.
If the administrative litigation does not succeed, the TSU will then resort to a constitutional interpretation, the TSU leader said.
Huang accused the committee of degrading its status as a government unit that safeguards the people's right of referendum to one that suppresses Taiwan's democracy.
He also urged the public to endorse another referendum proposal the TSU plans to launch Saturday, which is aimed at abolishing the Referendum Review Committee.
The committee rejected the referendum proposal on the grounds that it did not conform with the law because of a "conflict between the reasoning and the question itself, " Huang said.

But a letter previously sent to the TSU by the Central Election Commission said the proposal did not violate the law, according to the TSU leader, and he bashed the committee for denying a fact it first recognized and violating the law in the process.
He said he will take legal action against the 12 members of the committee who rejected the proposal.

Former Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday in an interview with the Central News Agency that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China is a major national policy, and the government should allow the people to express their opinion on the matter through a referendum.
He said it was ridiculous to allow a dozen people write off a referendum proposal supported by more than 100,000 people.

In response, relevant government officials said the committee has the right to screen the content of the proposal, if the proposal initiators are not satisfied with the decision, they can file an appeal and pursue administrative remedies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Families call on minister to kill convicts simultaneously
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 23:18:29 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Tseng Yung-fu on Friday refused to commit to a request by victims' families that the country's 40 death row inmates be executed simultaneously.
During a meeting in his office with a group of crime victims' families, the minister offered his sympathy and voiced his determination to handle the convicts according to law.

"Law is meant to bring justice to the world, and criminals should be punished according to law," he was quoted as saying. "Although the Ministry of Justice has set abolishment of the death penalty as its eventual goal, those who have already been sentenced to death should be executed as required by the law."

The meeting was held behind closed doors, but Hsu Wen-bin, a national policy adviser to the president and a human rights lawyer, said afterward that many families of the victims tearfully pleaded with Tseng to have all death row inmates executed simultaneously.
Tseng took office on March 22 to fill a post left by Wang Ching-feng, who resigned amid a public outcry after refusing to sign execution orders for death row inmates.

Tseng has told the Legislative Yuan that he personally favors the abolishment of death penalty, but that he will follow the law in dealing with death row inmates unless it is altered to end capital punishment.

The minister made headlines when he approved the execution of four death row inmates on April 30. A European Union foreign policy chief condemned the move the next day and asked Taiwan to declare a moratorium on the death penalty and to work to amend laws abolishing the practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. backs Taiwan's WTO rights to seek trade agreements
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 23:26:19 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A United States diplomat on Friday supported Taiwan's right to sign trade agreements with other WTO members, but said that an existing trade and investment framework agreement would be a better vehicle through which to improve U.S.-Taiwan ties.

American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt said in Taipei Friday that the U.S. believes Taiwan's rights as a WTO member should be protected and should not be vulnerable to influence from China.

"The U.S. position has been as clear as anybody that all WTO members have the right and power to sign trade agreements with other WTO members. Period. No need for prior ECFA agreements, no need for permission from China, " said Burghardt at a media roundtable.
Taiwan is trying to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, in part to pave the way for signing free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, including the U.S.
But a Chinese Foreign Ministry official recently seemed to undercut the government's argument when he said China would not agree to the idea, sparking controversy over the issue in Taiwan.

Though Burghardt said the U.S. supported the right of every WTO member to sign a trade agreement, he indicated that the U.S. intends to improve bilateral trade ties with Taiwan under the framework of an existing Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) rather than a full-fledged FTA.
There is not much enthusiasm in Washington for another FTA after the three previous FTAs with South Korea, Panama and Columbia have failed to pass the U.S. Congress, he said.

Both Taiwan and the U.S. have agreed that the last round of talks under the TIFA -- a deputy ministerial meeting which was held in July 2007 -- was too long ago, and "it would be nice to see that happen sometime before the end of the year," he said.
Meanwhile, he emphasized that the U.S. trade agreements are always "very complete" and different from the ones signed between Asian countries, which are usually "weak and partial."

The diplomat reiterated that Taiwan is not ready to fully open its market (to foreign economies) subject to a full free trade agreement, nor did he think that agreement would clear Taiwan's Legislature.

If Taiwan is seeking to sign FTAs with other countries, Asian countries will be better choices because it will be asked for less of a market opening from those countries than the U.S., Burghardt suggested.

Burghardt also confirmed that three U.S. senators -- Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), Kay Hagan (D-NC) and Mark Udall (D-Co.) -- will visit Taiwan on Saturday, the first visit by U.S. senators since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008.
Burghardt said the visit will be "short and unofficial."

DOC.HEADLINE: Nantou to start 'Sun Moon Lake' brand tea
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 23:37:06 (By Lin Heng-li and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Tea growers in central Taiwan's Nantou County plan to create a clearer image for their tea by launching a brand named after the county's famous Sun Moon Lake, local officials said Friday.

Chen Chao-wang, head of Nantou County's agriculture department, said that the county's eight townships produce 62 percent of the country's tea, but that tourists are often unable to tell which tea is from Nantou because the townships use their own branding.

Chen said that local farmers' associations have agreed to create an umbrella brand called "Sun Moon Lake Tea, " and that the county will hold a packaging design contest in which the winner will receive NT$30,000 and a medal.

Tea growers in Nantou can choose whether or not to market their products under the brand, and those who agree can still have their individual growing areas identified on the packaging that will also show the Sun Moon Lake brand, Chen said.
Lan Fang-ren, a Mingjian Township farmers' association official, used the success of Alishan tea as an example to explain the importance of branding.

Lan said that Chinese tourists are more familiar with Alishan tea and that it is not easy to promote tea from Nantou. He said he hoped that with the fame of Sun Moon Lake, the county's tea will be able to carve out a niche in the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan magistrate receives biggest political donations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) 06/04/10 23:46:03 (By Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taoyuan Magistrate John Chih-yang Wu received the most political donations during the Dec. 5 county and city chief elections, according to statistics released by the Control Yuan Friday.
