Among the candidates for the 17 city and county head positions, Wu received the most political donations at NT$89.06 million (US$2.75 million), but his expenses were also the largest at NT$89.78 million.
Following Wu was Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan at NT$76.47 million. Cho's expenditures were also second at NT$77.37 million.

The Control Yuan said most candidates for the elections were in the red. Among them, Hsinchu County Magistrate candidate Chang Pi-chin had political donations of NT$9.66 million and expenditures of NT$25.84 million.

A few had money left after deducting expenditures, including Chiayi County candidate Wong Chong-chun, Keelung Mayor Chang Tung-jung and Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa, who reported a surplus of between NT$2 million and NT$3 million.
Taitung County Magistrate Justin Huang had the biggest surplus at NT$10.86 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 5, or the 23rd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, the Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1883: British economist John Maynard Keynes is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces in China.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective controls.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignia, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends a five-day visit to Taipei.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: U.S. President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.
2000: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew turns down an offer of a job as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says that in addition to financial aid, the Republic of China is to offer economic advice to its allies in the same way the United States helped the island some 50 years ago.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Gangsters and police

TEXT.P: An alleged gangster leader was recently shot dead by an unknown gunman at his own company in Taichung City. Four police officers were found to be at the crime scene when the shooting took place, provoking strong public criticism of their misconduct.

The four policemen claimed they were only chatting and drinking there, but why did they have to meet at a secret guest house at the "biotech" company run by the killed gangster. The suspicious company had no official registration and nobody knows what the company's functions are.

The government has declared war against the underworld, but how can it launch the battle against the gang operations disguised as enterprises, which are then covered up by local political forces? The Taichung shooting incident was just an epitome of the corrupt links between politicians and gangsters.

It is a mission impossible trying to eradicate gang organizations in any society, but the government must draw a clear line between the right and wrong to guide grassroots policemen and maintain the rule of law. This is by no means an easy task.

The gunman who still remains at large must be seized and punished by law, but a bigger challenge that will test the government's wisdom is how it will resolve corruption among government officials as had been exposed by the four policemen. (June 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's cultural affairs council may open shops in China
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 12:39:50 (By M. L. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) is assessing the possibility of opening branches in China to better serve Taiwanese companies dedicated to the cultural innovation industry amid more frequent cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, an official said Saturday.

Johnson Chiu, deputy CEO of Taipei Culture Foundation, told CNA that although the plan is still on the drawing board, the CCA might follow in the footsteps of the quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council by opening footholds in major Chinese cities and stationing officials there to serve more Taiwanese businessmen.
Chiu's remarks echoed a response by CCA Chairman Emile Sheng in a legislative hearing in late April that his council might be able to establish semi-official offices in China this year.
According to Chiu, many Taiwan cultural innovation firms have called for government assistance, particularly on the tax problems and legal consultations, to help them tap the Chinese market.
Chiu is now in Shanghai for the 2010 Taipei-Shanghai twin-cities exhibition on cultural innovation, which will be held June 17-20 in the Chinese city.

"The major purpose of the exhibition is to provide a more effective platform to help the many small cultural innovation businesses from Taiwan build an image and distribute their products," he explained.
Many Taiwanese companies of this kind in Shanghai are promoting their brands through department stores, five-star hotels or shopping malls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- MAC head on low-profile visit to Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) 06/05/10 13:08:24 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan arrived in Hong Kong June 3 for a three-day visit in her official capacity. Though staying low-profile, she was the first minister-level Taiwanese official to visit the special administrative region of China.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage on June 5 of the visit described by MAC ranking officials as "significant" :
Economics Daily News:

Although Lai stressed that she visited Hong Kong only to inspect the MAC's operations there, her appearance on the special Chinese territory, where public visits by Taiwanese officials -- no matter of what rank -- had always been rejected, could definitely be seen as a major breakthrough on Taiwan-Hong Kong ties against the backdrop of the warming relations between mainland China and Taiwan.

Despite Lai not meeting with any Hong Kong officials or Chinese officials stationed in Hong Kong during her stay, her visit in the capacity of MAC chief, Taiwan's highest authority in charge of China affairs, reflects Beijing's new thoughts on Taiwan-Hong Kong and cross-strait ties.
Lai's stepping on China-controlled land also suggests the possibility of higher ranking Taiwanese officials visiting the mainland; they are currently still barred from conducting such visits.
United Daily News:

A Beijing-based scholar anticipated that Lai's visit to Hong Kong in the runup of the signing of a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework cooperation (ECFA) was also aimed at studying Hong Kong's free trade agreements with other countries.
He also expressed that he believes Lai would meet Chinese liaison officials in Hong Kong or other officials from Beijing during her stay in Hong Kong.
China Times:
Although cross-strait links are being expanding in the full scale, the exchanges of governmental personnel between Hong Kong and Taiwan remain low profile.

Concerned sources disclosed that Lai had planned to meet with Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang during her visit to Hong Kong. The plan, however, was not able to be carried out in the end because Lai had a tight schedule and Tsang was occupied with other activities.

Nevertheless, according to reliable sources, Lai's visit was kept low key because she came to Hong Kong at a sensitive time: her visit coincides with the 21st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre on June 4th.

Although Lai, a former member of Taiwan's pro-independent opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, did not deliberately choose the time to make the visit, Beijing and her host Hong Kong chose instead to keep it low key, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan securities association urges signing trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 13:59:49 (By Lin Ye-fong and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Securities Association (TSA) said Saturday that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement ( ECFA) with China should be signed as soon as possible as the trade pact would be very positive for financial industries on both sides.

Gordon Yeh, vice chairman of the TSA, said at a seminar that with China's great market size, and Taiwan's experience, talent and service efficiency, the cooperation between both sides will be able to create a new competitive edge in Taiwan's and China's financial industries.

Taiwan Futures Exchange Vice President Huang Nai-kuan said that Taiwanese futures traders have been focusing on financial futures for a long time, so they will be able to offer experience to China in developing financial futures.
In addition, as major futures companies on both sides have a similar amount of registered capital, they will be more likely to invest shares in each other or set up a joint venture, Huang said.
Huang also noted that China's futures markets at present only offer commodity products, so there is still much room for growth in other business areas, such as options or derivatives in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum drive won't appeal to voters: former vice premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 14:39:05 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's former vice premier said Saturday that the opposition party's "politically maneuvered" campaign against a soon-to-be signed Taiwan-China trade pact would not appeal to most voters in year-end local elections, in which he is taking part.

As campaigning for the mayoral positions in Taiwan's five biggest municipalities and cities is expected to intensify ahead of the November elections, Eric Chu was asked by CNA how he would assess the impacts of the opposition's recently- failed referendum drive on the government's efforts to sign the trade agreement.
Chu said the opposition should adopt a "rational and objective" attitude on the issue.

"I think it is necessary to look at the issue (on the trade pact) from an objective and rational perspective, " he said Saturday on the sidelines of a seminar related to the trade pact known as the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

"If it (the campaign) is handled in a politically maneuvered manner, it will not be able to appeal to the majority of voters, " said Chu, who is also the vice chairman of the ruling party Kuomintang (KMT).

Chu is running for mayor in Xinbei City in northern Taiwan, which has a bigger population than any other city or county in Taiwan. His rival is Tsai Ing- wen, chairwoman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

After a government committee on Thursday rejected another opposition party's proposal to hold a referendum on the issue of whether Taiwan should sign a trade agreement with China, the DPP said that it will launch a "10-year war of resistance" and continue pushing for a referendum on the Taiwan-China pact slated to be signed later this month.

The government committee rejected the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) initiative on the grounds that it did not conform with the law because of a "conflict between the reasoning and the question itself."
The DPP will organize an event later Saturday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, where the party's mayoral candidates will help step up the campaign against the trade pact.

Opposition parties and a significant number of people in Taiwan believe that the trade pact will result in an influx of Chinese workers and cheap goods from China, while also making Taiwan too dependent on China, and potentially undermining Taiwan's sovereignty.

But the government considers the pact as an important way to normalize the trade relations between Taiwan and its largest trading partner, China, and to overcome China's blockage of Taiwan signing free trade agreements with other countries.

The mayoral elections will take place Nov. 27 in five special municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- whose populations together account for 70 percent of the country's total.

The races are viewed as a bellwether for the 2012 presidential election and a gauge of the popularity of President Ma Ying-jeou, who is expected to seek reelection, but whose approval ratings have remained low for most of the two years that he has been in office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The core problem with unemployment

TEXT.P: Under the directive of President Ma Ying-jeou, a delegation of Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials will head for Singapore next week to inspect how its government succeeded in reducing its jobless rate to 2.2 percent.

In recent years, the government has been keener in publishing brilliant statistics than caring for the people's lives. Despite all-out government efforts such as creating temporary jobs to bring down unemployment, it would be pointless if Taiwan is a society without confidence and hopes, due to a lack of stable jobs.

A lower jobless rate does not mean an improvement in employment, and this is the real problem because creating temporary jobs is just an interim measure. With the economy gradually recovering from the financial tsunami, the government should work out a long-term policy to boost employment.

In terms of the impact of industrial development in the job market, Taiwan should send delegations to study what is happening in Japan and South Korea, where the situations are more similar to Taiwan's.
If the government only cares about jobless statistics rather than the core of the unemployment problem, the problem in Taiwan will not be genuinely resolved. (June 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC reports record monthly revenue in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 15:16:29 (By Tien Yu-pin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Global smartphone maker HTC has announced a record revenue of NT$18.66 billion (US$575 million) in May, up 49.5 percent year-on-year, which the company attributed to strong market demand for its high-end mobile phones.

It was the second consecutive month for the company to register a record monthly revenue, according to the company Friday. In the first five months of the year, the company registered a revenue of NT$74.37 billion, up 34 percent from the same period last year.
The company's revenue in May showed an increase of about 3.6 percent, from NT$18 billion in April.

With increasing demand for the company's high-end mobiles, the company's revenue in the second quarter is expected to exceed NT$55 billion, compared to its previous forecast of NT$50 billion, institutional investors said.
They also expected HTC's mobile phone shipments in Q2 will increase to 5 million units, compared to the company's forecast of 4.5 million units.

With the company's high-end mobile phones such as Desire, Incredible, HD2 showing a robust shipment growth, and the company's cooperation with U.S. communication service provider Verizon Wireless expected to expand its reach in the U.S. market, most analysts are upbeat about the company's outlook.
As Apple will release its iPhone 4 next week in the U.S., analysts said they will also closely watch how HTC will deal with the new product competition.
HTC's shares closed at NT$414 Friday, NT$4.0, or 0.96 percent lower than the closing figure Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese firms expected to attend Computex next year: organizer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 15:47:41 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: More Chinese companies may want to take part in Computex Taipei, the world's second biggest computer trade show, next year as this year saw a surge of them using the show to explore overseas business opportunities, an organizer said Saturday.

"For the Chinese at the moment, except for the domestic market, it remains difficult for them to branch out to foreign markets. Therefore, they use Computex as an excellent platform to establish connections with the rest of the world," Jeremy Horng, deputy executive director of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA)'s Exhibition Department, told the Central News Agency in an interview.
The five-day trade show, Asia's biggest computer show, ended Saturday. This year, more than 1,700 companies from around the world showcased their products at Computex, using 4,861 booths.
The Taipei Computer Association, another organizer of the event, said in a statement released Saturday that the number of Chinese buyers visiting the show rose significantly this year from last year.

A total of 106 companies from China used 171 booths at the trade show this year, which was more than double the numbers from last year, when there were 41 Chinese exhibitors using 78 booths, Horng noted.

Computex was open to Chinese exhibitors last year for the first time after the political tensions between Taiwan and China had eased since the inauguration of Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008.
Computex successfully appealed to Chinese exhibitors as the show increased their business opportunities from foreign buyers, Horng said.
However, due to insufficient space at Computex's venues, more than 100 companies from various countries could not exhibit at the annual event, now in its 30th year, according to Horng.
Unless Computex expands its venues, it might be difficult for the show to accommodate the even greater interest expected from Chinese firms next year, organizers said.

"Although we could expect yet another increase in the number of Chinese companies that want to exhibit at the show next year, we will have to see first if we could provide more booths for them to use, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC members concerned about ECFA progress: economics minister
DOC.DATELINE: Sapporo, Japan, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 16:41:13 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Almost every Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) member is concerned about the progress of negotiations and talks on a proposed trade pact between Taiwan and mainland China, Taiwan's minister of economic affairs said Friday.

Taiwan's active move to promote the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China draws APEC members' attention, Shih Yen-hsiang noted in an interview with CNA in Sapporo, Japan.
Shih, leading the Taiwan delegation, arrived here Thursday for the two-day annual meeting of APEC trade ministers that began Saturday.

He attended a formal welcoming dinner the previous evening, in which he was seen chatting with World Trade Organization Secretary General Pascal Lamy, as well as ministers and trade representatives of other nations, including China's Minister of Commerce Chen Deming.
In the coming APEC meeting, Shih will conduct talks with Lamy.

Asked whether he will hold talks with Chen or have a chance to talk about the ECFA issue during the meeting, Shih only said the APEC forum is a public occasion, on which he will meet all trade ministers of all member states to exchange opinions.

Responding to questions on the widely-anticipated early harvest list of items that will have tariffs reduced immediately after the proposed ECFA deal is signed, Shih reiterated that items which are expected to affect Taiwan's employment, farmers and conventional medium and small enterprises, will not be put in the program for tax deduction or exemption.

As to how many items of products will be included in the early-harvest list, Shih only said talks on the issue have not been finalized, but he confirmed that the number of Chinese products on the list will be less than the more than 300 Taiwanese products on the list.

Shih, again, underlined the importance and urgency of the signing of the cross- strait trade pact, saying China, Japan and South Korea recently agreed among each other to be active in promoting the formation of a free trade agreement among themselves.
Once the proposed Northeast Asian free trade zone is formed, Taiwanese companies will not be able to compete with rival businesses that enjoy preferential tax treatment in the region, Shih warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTCH director plots to get Taiwan's performers on world stages

TEXT.P: Huang Pi-twan has been the artistic director of Taiwan's National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) for only two months, but her mission is already clear: to expand efforts to stage productions with international directors and give local performers more experience.

Huang, a former head of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) , feels the NTCH has a duty to boost the standard of performances in Taiwan, and one way to achieve that, she says, is by focusing on collaborations with artists from other countries.

"This not only lets us learn advanced technology and performance skills from other artists, it also helps us promote our shows to the world," she stressed in an interview with the Central News Agency.
Huang's mission is not new for the performance venue.

The NTCH has often worked with international directors in the past, including on the production "1433-The Grand Voyage, " a collaboration between avant-garde American stage director Robert Wilson and Taiwanese percussion group "U Theatre" that was staged in the first half of the year.
But Huang hopes such co-productions will be staged more frequently in the future, and she said there are at least two programs set for the second half of the year.
"One of those is an opera called 'La Peintre, Yu-Lin, ' in which a Taiwanese writer, composer and orchestra and Taiwanese singers will work with a French director, " she indicated.

The production, which will debut at the National Theater Hall at the beginning of July, is based on the story of a legendary Chinese women named Pan Yu-Liang, who first was a prostitute and then a concubine before becoming a famous painter, Huang said.
The opera's composer is National Award for Arts winner Chien Nan-chang, who will team up with playwright Wang An-chi and French director Juliette Deschamps.
"The opera will present a fascinating world of song and performance," Huang said.

The other production, slated for August, will invite Wang Hsin-sing, the founder of Hsin Sing Nanguan (also written Xin Xin Nanguan), to collaborate with French director Lukas Hemleb on a modern Nanguan opera called "Feather."
Nanguan is a style of Chinese classical music originating in the southern Chinese province of Fujian.
Huang revealed that the story of the Nanguan musical is based on a Chinese legend known as "The Double Seventh Festival, " which involves a love story between a goddess and a human being.
"We spent over NT$20 million on each production, but I believe our artists can learn a lot from these opportunities, and we will definitely promote these works in other countries," she said.
Despite the challenge of having to compete with many bigger and more modern venues built in Asia in recent years, Huang maintains confidence in the management ability and technology of the NTCH.

"While we are preparing for the celebration of the 25th anniversary of the NTCH in 2012, I think the first thing we should do is to make a list of our standard operating procedures (SOP) , which include program organization, stage technology, and marketing, among others," she said.
The purpose is to help those who will manage new performance halls that will be opening in the future in northern, central and southern Taiwan.
"We can provide information and experience to help them manage these new venues smoothly," she said.
Another new project Huang feels proud of is successfully raising funds to enable the children of poor families in remote areas to see shows at the NTCH.

"We raised over NT$1.7 million in May, which meant that we reached our goal much earlier than expected, " Huang said, pleased that the fund will help more children enter the beautiful world of the performing arts. By Sunnie Chen, CNA staff reporter CNA Photo No. 26

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Post-ECFA era

TEXT.P: As Taiwan is likely to soon sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Taiwan should devise an effective strategy to take advantage of a Western Taiwan Straits Economic Zone in Fujian Province.
Beijing is promoting the zone to balance regional development and boost economic integration with Taiwan, paving the way for peaceful cross-strait unification.
Taiwan's private sector has responded enthusiastically to the special economic zone on China's west coast, but the government has adopted a "cool-headed" approach because of political concerns.

Although we don't need to dance to Beijing's tune, Taiwan still needs to think positively and try to benefit from China's west coast economic zone. That would enable us to bolster economic development in our own special economic zones and build a new model of two-way industrial cooperation in the post-ECFA era.

We must stress that Taiwan as a whole should avoid engaging with the Fujian zone. Rather, Taiwan should use its special economic zones to deal with the zone on the opposite side so as to not hurt parity and Taiwan's sovereignty.

The special economic zones envisioned by Taiwan's government, where companies will be given preferential tax, labor, financing and customs treatment, will be the best choice Taiwan has to embrace the post-ECFA era and cross-strait dealings. (June 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud computing's time has finally arrived: Computex experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 17:30:34 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: Visitors to the international Computex Taipei trade show have found out quickly that the future is in cloud computing, with industry veterans confident that the concept's technology is launching integrated computing into a new era.
"It may have been around for a long time, but now cloud computing is about to take off, " Tudor Brown, president of British chip maker ARM, said at a forum on Wednesday.
The five-day Computex, which concluded Saturday, included a series of speeches and discussions devoted to cloud computing technology, a sign of its growing importance in the IT field.

Cloud computing provides "highly available" services and data stored on an Internet network (the cloud) that users can access with devices such as desktop personal computers, TVs and smart phones connected to the Web.

The advantage is that users do not have to install or maintain these services on their devices, said Gary Szilagyi, vice president and general manager of American semiconductor developer Atheros Communications, Inc.'s Computing and Consumer Business Unit, at a conference Monday.
"Everyone sees great value in the cloud, and in fact, there have been many businesses founded upon entire requirements of delivering the cloud content," he said.

Cloud computing is expected to be the preferred solution in an era of rapid industrial development, experts believe, and Brown said he saw a lot of opportunity for Taiwan because the market is driven by low-power equipment, innovation, cost and mobility.
"That's what you do here very well," he said.
According to Digitimes Research, there will be 10 billion connected devices in the future, which would have been impossible to believe just a few years ago.

"In 2004, it's very hard to think of a single desktop application which is used by millions of users outside of games, " but now we have popular cloud web applications, such as Gmail, Google Map, Twitter, and Facebook," said Sundar Pichai, vice president of Google.

Cloud computing is also among the Taiwanese government's strategic industries. The government and the private sector jointly formed the Taiwan Cloud Computing Consortium in April, pouring in NT$24 billion (US$740 million) to promote development in the field over the next five years.

"We expect the private sector to invest NT$12.7 billion in research and development and another NT$100 billion for manufacturing and services, " Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said at the Taiwan Business Alliance Conference the day before Computex opened.
"This could create 50,000 new jobs with a turnover of NT$1 trillion," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tadao Ando breaks ground on latest project: his first columbarium
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 18:14:52 (By Huang Huei-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: World-renowned Japanese architect Tadao Ando hosted a groundbreaking ceremony in Taipei County Saturday to kick off construction on the first columbarium complex he has designed in his illustrious career.

Ando said he expects the new facility, consisting of a columbarium -- the memorial building where the cremated remains of the deceased can be stored -- and a landscaped garden with 4,000 cherry trees, to become an international architectural landmark that represents Taiwan.

He also hopes that the site will turn out to be one of the world's best cemeteries and a global attraction for people to appreciate the beauty of cherry blossoms outside of Washington, D.C., said the University of Tokyo professor.
Ando has also incorporated water into his design, putting a reflecting pool on the roof of the columbarium.

Situated on a 26-hectare site in Sanjhih, a coastal township in northern Taiwan, the planned columbarium complex and garden will cost an estimated NT$10 billion (US$308.24 million) to build, according to Taipei-based Lung Yen Life Service Co., which contracted Ando to build the facility.
It is expected to take 10 years to complete.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to offer more public rental housing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 19:08:40 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei City will make a concerted effort to increase the availability of public rental housing over the next 10 years, hoping that 5 percent of all available housing in the city will be public rentals by 2020.

Taipei Mayor Hau Long-bin said Friday that 0.65 percent of the city's housing stock is currently public rental housing, the highest ratio in the country but still low compared with western countries, and he expressed hope that the rate will be able to rise to 5 percent, the same level as in the U.S.
Hau said that the city government is planning to build 200 public rental units of 50 square meters each in six locations by the end of 2014. Each unit will have a monthly rent of NT$10,000 (US$308).
The city will also release houses obtained from private construction companies taking part in urban renewal projects or other joint development projects for public rental.
A total of 1,230 such houses, including some located above MRT complex buildings, will be available for public rental rather than sold via public auction, Hau said.
In addition, the city government also plans to renovate some idle school buildings, or use old market places to build public rental homes, he said.
A city government official said the government will draft regulations to prevent high-income households from benefiting from public rental housing policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boldly push carbon emission cuts: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 19:39:25 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The government will resolutely push for energy conservation and carbon emission cuts in both the public and private sectors this year, Premier Wu Den-yih said Saturday.

He said major carbon emitters, such as Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), CPC Corp., Taiwan, Formosa Plastics and China Steel, will have to cut carbon emissions by replacing aging equipment to enhance energy efficiency.

"If major carbon emission businesses such as Taipower and CPC strive for progress, they will be able to cut millions or tens of millions of tons of carbon emissions every year, " he said on the sidelines of an energy conservation show coinciding with World Environment Day.
The premier pledged that the government would also focus more emphasis on energy saving and carbon reduction in public infrastructure.

One example, he said, was that the government has begun to replace the light bulbs normally used in traffic lights with LEDs in the past two years and that there are only three or four cities that have yet to replace their traffic lights.
"By 2011, all traffic lights will use LEDs, " the premier said.
The government will also encourage the development of renewable energy, solar power, LEDs, biomass energy and wind power, and electric cars and motorcycles, he said.
Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan has also planned to make Green Island as a model low-carbon emission island, the premier said.
"We'll promote the idea to other parts of Taiwan after reviewing the results on Green Island," he added.

Vice Economics Minister Huang Jung-chiou said that in addition to Green Island, the low-carbon island project will also cover three other outlying islands -- Liuchiu Islet (also known as Siaoliouchiou), Penghu and Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: President receives U.S. senators
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 21:37:09 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou spoke of the importance of signing a trade pact with China when he received three visiting U.S. senators Saturday.

The trio -- Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) , Kay Hagan (D-NC) and Mark Udall (D-Co.) -- arrived in Taiwan earlier in the day, marking the first visit by U.S. senators to Taiwan since President Ma took office in May 2008.

The president noted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have signed 12 agreements over the past two years, and that cross-strait ties have been more peaceful and stable than at any time in the past six decades.
The two sides are now negotiating a economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , and Ma said he hoped it could be signed soon to institutionalize cross- strait trade ties.

Citing a comment by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State James Steinberg at the Brookings Institution, a U.S. think tank, on May 10, Ma said the signing of the trade pact is significant in that it will promote peace, resolve differences and avoid confrontation.
Noting that the group flew into Taiwan after visiting Beijing and Shanghai, Ma said this "was unimaginable in the past, and was made possible through improved cross-strait relations."

The president also said that he talked to Feinstein, a former San Francisco mayor, over the phone during his visits to the U.S. in 2006, 2008, and 2009 but did not meet her, and said he was glad to "finally have the meeting in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Mountain line steam railway makes nostalgic return
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 21:52:14 (By Chen Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The old CK124 steam engine sounded its horn at Sanyi Railway Station in Miaoli County Saturday, signaling to the train's 300 passengers and other train aficionados around the country that service on a historic railway line in Taiwan had resumed.
"This is the train I took when I was little, " said a 55-year-old grandmother when describing the old locomotive to her eight-year-old grandson at the station.

The passenger, identified only by the surname Huang, said she had eagerly awaited the reopening of the 15.9-kilometer-long Old Mountain Line between Sanyi and Houli in Taichung County for 12 years, since the rail line's operations were suspended in 1998.
Her 94-year-old mother has still not forgotten the sound of trains on the railway line running through the hills of central Taiwan, Huang said.

To attract tourists, the Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) spent nearly NT$200 million (US$6.16 million) to restore the tracks and facilities along the line, which passes many historic sites, including the Broken Longteng Bridge and the nearby Shengsing station built during the Japanese colonial era.
The project has managed to restore service on 13.6 kilometers of the line thus far, from Sanyi to Taian Station in Taichung County, according to the TRA.
On Saturday the old steam train made two round trips. It will be back in service on June 9, each Wednesday in July and August, and August 29, with two round-trip runs per day.
In addition, the TRA will also offer services by a diesel-powered train every Monday and Friday between July 5 and Aug. 27, with two round-trip runs per day.
The timetable for the line can be found on the TRA's website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Six tons of U.S. cherries fail pesticide test
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:04:37 (By Chen Chin-fan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nearly six tons of cherries recently imported from the United States have been found to contain the pesticide malathion, the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

Pan Chih-kuan, a director of the DOH's Food and Drug Administration, said the two batches of cherries contained 0.02 parts per million and 0.03 ppm of malathion, respectively. Taiwan's regulations do not allow any trace amounts of the substance in cherries.
The two importers are now applying to have the two batches re-examined.

If they are still found to contain the pesticide, the first batch, which had not been cleared by customs, will be returned to the shipper, and the second batch, which had been released to the importer to keep refrigerated pending the results of the examination, will be confiscated and destroyed.
Pan said that if a third batch of U.S. imported cherries were to fail the examination within six months, the DOH will ask the U.S. to come up with a plan to improve the situation.
"We will also step up the examination of all cherries imported from the United States," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: UAV developed by Taiwan to take part in Berlin air show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:14:14 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A multi-purpose unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) developed by a local company will take part in a major air show next week, an official of the company said Saturday.

Cooper Chang, the marketing manager of Carbon-Based Technology Inc., said its UAV, called the UAVER, will take part in the Berlin Air Show June 8-13. It will be the first time an unmanned aerial system (UAS) with a Taiwanese brand has entered a major air show.

The company demonstrated the 3.45-kilogram system on Friday on top of a building at National Chung Hsin University in central Taiwan's Taichung, during which images taken by the airborne UAV were transmitted simultaneously.
Chang said the United States, though a leader in the development of unmanned aerial systems, has generally used much larger systems for military purposes.
But the smaller UAV developed by Carbon-Based Technology can be an effective tool in monitoring disasters, environmental pollution and other problems.

Chen Shu-chun, director of the university's Water & Soil Conservation Department, said traditional unmanned helicopters can monitor the environment, but they have the limitations of being loud, noisy and hard to maneuver.
They also only have a short remote control distance (about 2 kilometers) and cannot stay airborne for long (under 10 minutes).
This is why they are confined to short-distance environmental monitoring and disaster prevention missions, Chen said.
"The Avian UAS developed by Taiwan has solved the above problems," he added.
He said the UAS also does not require a long runway due to its use of a bungee rope launch for take-off and its parachute landing system.
The other advantage is that the whole system can be maneuvered from a disaster prevention center indoors.
The system can stay airborne for 90 minutes and penetrate remote areas to provide often difficult-to-obtain information in real time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex generates record high level of business
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:20:40 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei, Asia's largest computer show, attracted more international visitors this year than ever before and generated a record US$230 million in business on site, the organizers said in a statement on the show's final day Saturday.

Jeremy Horng, deputy executive director of Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) 's Exhibition Department, said the 35,017 international visitors from 216 different countries and regions attending the show's first four days outpaced the 34,892 visitors from 184 countries and regions last year.

According to TAITRA, more than 2,000 one-on-one meetings between buyers and suppliers were held on June 1 and 2, generating on-site business worth US$230 million, more than double the US$100 million generated during similar meetings last year.
The top five countries and regions most represented by international buyers were the United States, Japan, China, Hong Kong, and South Korea.

Aiming to make Computex the world's biggest computer show, Horng said the fair's international significance in the information technology sector was reflected by the 400 foreign exhibitors occupying 830 booths at the show.
The number of booths was 5 percent higher than last year.

But venue size continues to haunt Computex's ambitions to expand. According to the organizers, there were 100 to 200 foreign and local exhibitors on the waiting list this year, and other vendors even plan to apply for more booths next year.

Because another Nangang Exhibition Hall will not be ready until the end of 2012, the organizers said they will consider using Taiwan World Trade Center Hall 2 next year, which can provide another 350 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETC operator, government still at odds over toll collection system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:40:10 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The operator of an electronic freeway toll collection system admitted Saturday that it will fall short of the targeted usage rate for the system by the end of June, but it remains at odds with the government over how the problem should be solved.

Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co. (FETC) , which was commissioned to set up the ETC service, said that with the ETC usage rate at 38 percent at present, it is not likely that the target rate for the end of June of 45 percent will be met.

According to an agreement between the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and FETC, the ETC usage rate is required to reach 45 percent by the end of June, and 65 percent by the end of 2012.

The Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau under the MOTC said it will send a notice to FETC next month asking the company to improve the situation within a specified time, but it acknowledged that the two sides have failed to reach any consensus on how to resolve the issue.

The usage rate of the system, which collects tolls from freeway motorists automatically, has been hampered by resistance to installing the system's transmitter, the "on board unit, " which costs NT$1,199 (US$37).
Since the ETC system was introduced four years ago, about 950,000 vehicles have installed the OBUs.

The bureau has hoped that FETC would offer the OBU at a lower price or for free, but the company has rejected the idea, saying that free installations would cost the company over NT$6 billion, well above the company's NT$3.8 billion in capital.

The FETC, on the other hand, has suggested many times since last year that the government should offer a 20 percent discount on tolls for ETC users, but the proposal has not yet been approved by the MOTC.

Meanwhile, an MOTC official also said on Saturday that the low usage rate of the ETC system could delay the implementation of an automatic distance-based toll collection scheme, but did not elaborate.
The ministry plans to replace both the frequency-based ETC and manned toll booths with a fully automatic distance-based toll collection model by the end of 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for June 5

TEXT.P: organizer 10.HTC reports record monthly revenue in May 11. Commercial Times: The core problem with unemployment 12. Referendum drive won't appeal to voters: former vice premier 13. Talk of the day -- MAC head on low-profile visit to Hong Kong 14. ETC operator, government still at odds over toll collection system 15.Computex generates record high level of business 16.UAV developed by Taiwan to take part in Berlin air show 17.Six tons of U.S. cherries fail pesticide test 18.President receives U.S. senators 19.Government to boldly push carbon emission cuts: premier 20.United Daily News: Gangsters and police 21.HTC reports record monthly revenue in May 22.Taipei City to offer more public rental housing

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Gangsters and police

TEXT.P: An alleged gangster leader was recently shot dead by an unknown gunman at his own company in Taichung City. Four police officers were found to be at the crime scene when the shooting took place, provoking strong public criticism of their misconduct.

The four policemen claimed they were only chatting and drinking there, but why did they have to meet at a secret guest house at the "biotech" company run by the killed gangster. The suspicious company had no official registration and nobody knows what the company's functions are.

The government has declared war against the underworld, but how can it launch the battle against the gang operations disguised as enterprises, which are then covered up by local political forces? The Taichung shooting incident was just an epitome of the corrupt links between politicians and gangsters.

It is a mission impossible trying to eradicate gang organizations in any society, but the government must draw a clear line between the right and wrong to guide grassroots policemen and maintain the rule of law. This is by no means an easy task.

The gunman who still remains at large must be seized and punished by law, but a bigger challenge that will test the government's wisdom is how it will resolve corruption among government officials as had been exposed by the four policemen. (June 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's cultural affairs council may open shops in China
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 12:39:50 (By M. L. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) is assessing the possibility of opening branches in China to better serve Taiwanese companies dedicated to the cultural innovation industry amid more frequent cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, an official said Saturday.

Johnson Chiu, deputy CEO of Taipei Culture Foundation, told CNA that although the plan is still on the drawing board, the CCA might follow in the footsteps of the quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council by opening footholds in major Chinese cities and stationing officials there to serve more Taiwanese businessmen.
Chiu's remarks echoed a response by CCA Chairman Emile Sheng in a legislative hearing in late April that his council might be able to establish semi-official offices in China this year.
According to Chiu, many Taiwan cultural innovation firms have called for government assistance, particularly on the tax problems and legal consultations, to help them tap the Chinese market.
Chiu is now in Shanghai for the 2010 Taipei-Shanghai twin-cities exhibition on cultural innovation, which will be held June 17-20 in the Chinese city.

"The major purpose of the exhibition is to provide a more effective platform to help the many small cultural innovation businesses from Taiwan build an image and distribute their products," he explained.
Many Taiwanese companies of this kind in Shanghai are promoting their brands through department stores, five-star hotels or shopping malls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- MAC head on low-profile visit to Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) 06/05/10 13:08:24 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan arrived in Hong Kong June 3 for a three-day visit in her official capacity. Though staying low-profile, she was the first minister-level Taiwanese official to visit the special administrative region of China.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage on June 5 of the visit described by MAC ranking officials as "significant" :
Economics Daily News:

Although Lai stressed that she visited Hong Kong only to inspect the MAC's operations there, her appearance on the special Chinese territory, where public visits by Taiwanese officials -- no matter of what rank -- had always been rejected, could definitely be seen as a major breakthrough on Taiwan-Hong Kong ties against the backdrop of the warming relations between mainland China and Taiwan.

Despite Lai not meeting with any Hong Kong officials or Chinese officials stationed in Hong Kong during her stay, her visit in the capacity of MAC chief, Taiwan's highest authority in charge of China affairs, reflects Beijing's new thoughts on Taiwan-Hong Kong and cross-strait ties.
Lai's stepping on China-controlled land also suggests the possibility of higher ranking Taiwanese officials visiting the mainland; they are currently still barred from conducting such visits.
United Daily News:

A Beijing-based scholar anticipated that Lai's visit to Hong Kong in the runup of the signing of a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework cooperation (ECFA) was also aimed at studying Hong Kong's free trade agreements with other countries.
He also expressed that he believes Lai would meet Chinese liaison officials in Hong Kong or other officials from Beijing during her stay in Hong Kong.
China Times:
Although cross-strait links are being expanding in the full scale, the exchanges of governmental personnel between Hong Kong and Taiwan remain low profile.

Concerned sources disclosed that Lai had planned to meet with Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang during her visit to Hong Kong. The plan, however, was not able to be carried out in the end because Lai had a tight schedule and Tsang was occupied with other activities.

Nevertheless, according to reliable sources, Lai's visit was kept low key because she came to Hong Kong at a sensitive time: her visit coincides with the 21st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre on June 4th.

Although Lai, a former member of Taiwan's pro-independent opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, did not deliberately choose the time to make the visit, Beijing and her host Hong Kong chose instead to keep it low key, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan securities association urges signing trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 13:59:49 (By Lin Ye-fong and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Securities Association (TSA) said Saturday that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement ( ECFA) with China should be signed as soon as possible as the trade pact would be very positive for financial industries on both sides.

Gordon Yeh, vice chairman of the TSA, said at a seminar that with China's great market size, and Taiwan's experience, talent and service efficiency, the cooperation between both sides will be able to create a new competitive edge in Taiwan's and China's financial industries.

Taiwan Futures Exchange Vice President Huang Nai-kuan said that Taiwanese futures traders have been focusing on financial futures for a long time, so they will be able to offer experience to China in developing financial futures.
In addition, as major futures companies on both sides have a similar amount of registered capital, they will be more likely to invest shares in each other or set up a joint venture, Huang said.
Huang also noted that China's futures markets at present only offer commodity products, so there is still much room for growth in other business areas, such as options or derivatives in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum drive won't appeal to voters: former vice premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 14:39:05 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's former vice premier said Saturday that the opposition party's "politically maneuvered" campaign against a soon-to-be signed Taiwan-China trade pact would not appeal to most voters in year-end local elections, in which he is taking part.

As campaigning for the mayoral positions in Taiwan's five biggest municipalities and cities is expected to intensify ahead of the November elections, Eric Chu was asked by CNA how he would assess the impacts of the opposition's recently- failed referendum drive on the government's efforts to sign the trade agreement.
Chu said the opposition should adopt a "rational and objective" attitude on the issue.

"I think it is necessary to look at the issue (on the trade pact) from an objective and rational perspective, " he said Saturday on the sidelines of a seminar related to the trade pact known as the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

"If it (the campaign) is handled in a politically maneuvered manner, it will not be able to appeal to the majority of voters, " said Chu, who is also the vice chairman of the ruling party Kuomintang (KMT).

Chu is running for mayor in Xinbei City in northern Taiwan, which has a bigger population than any other city or county in Taiwan. His rival is Tsai Ing- wen, chairwoman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

After a government committee on Thursday rejected another opposition party's proposal to hold a referendum on the issue of whether Taiwan should sign a trade agreement with China, the DPP said that it will launch a "10-year war of resistance" and continue pushing for a referendum on the Taiwan-China pact slated to be signed later this month.

The government committee rejected the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) initiative on the grounds that it did not conform with the law because of a "conflict between the reasoning and the question itself."
The DPP will organize an event later Saturday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, where the party's mayoral candidates will help step up the campaign against the trade pact.

Opposition parties and a significant number of people in Taiwan believe that the trade pact will result in an influx of Chinese workers and cheap goods from China, while also making Taiwan too dependent on China, and potentially undermining Taiwan's sovereignty.

But the government considers the pact as an important way to normalize the trade relations between Taiwan and its largest trading partner, China, and to overcome China's blockage of Taiwan signing free trade agreements with other countries.

The mayoral elections will take place Nov. 27 in five special municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- whose populations together account for 70 percent of the country's total.

The races are viewed as a bellwether for the 2012 presidential election and a gauge of the popularity of President Ma Ying-jeou, who is expected to seek reelection, but whose approval ratings have remained low for most of the two years that he has been in office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The core problem with unemployment

TEXT.P: Under the directive of President Ma Ying-jeou, a delegation of Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials will head for Singapore next week to inspect how its government succeeded in reducing its jobless rate to 2.2 percent.

In recent years, the government has been keener in publishing brilliant statistics than caring for the people's lives. Despite all-out government efforts such as creating temporary jobs to bring down unemployment, it would be pointless if Taiwan is a society without confidence and hopes, due to a lack of stable jobs.

A lower jobless rate does not mean an improvement in employment, and this is the real problem because creating temporary jobs is just an interim measure. With the economy gradually recovering from the financial tsunami, the government should work out a long-term policy to boost employment.

In terms of the impact of industrial development in the job market, Taiwan should send delegations to study what is happening in Japan and South Korea, where the situations are more similar to Taiwan's.
If the government only cares about jobless statistics rather than the core of the unemployment problem, the problem in Taiwan will not be genuinely resolved. (June 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC reports record monthly revenue in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 15:16:29 (By Tien Yu-pin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Global smartphone maker HTC has announced a record revenue of NT$18.66 billion (US$575 million) in May, up 49.5 percent year-on-year, which the company attributed to strong market demand for its high-end mobile phones.

It was the second consecutive month for the company to register a record monthly revenue, according to the company Friday. In the first five months of the year, the company registered a revenue of NT$74.37 billion, up 34 percent from the same period last year.
The company's revenue in May showed an increase of about 3.6 percent, from NT$18 billion in April.

With increasing demand for the company's high-end mobiles, the company's revenue in the second quarter is expected to exceed NT$55 billion, compared to its previous forecast of NT$50 billion, institutional investors said.
They also expected HTC's mobile phone shipments in Q2 will increase to 5 million units, compared to the company's forecast of 4.5 million units.

With the company's high-end mobile phones such as Desire, Incredible, HD2 showing a robust shipment growth, and the company's cooperation with U.S. communication service provider Verizon Wireless expected to expand its reach in the U.S. market, most analysts are upbeat about the company's outlook.
As Apple will release its iPhone 4 next week in the U.S., analysts said they will also closely watch how HTC will deal with the new product competition.
HTC's shares closed at NT$414 Friday, NT$4.0, or 0.96 percent lower than the closing figure Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese firms expected to attend Computex next year: organizer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 15:47:41 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: More Chinese companies may want to take part in Computex Taipei, the world's second biggest computer trade show, next year as this year saw a surge of them using the show to explore overseas business opportunities, an organizer said Saturday.

"For the Chinese at the moment, except for the domestic market, it remains difficult for them to branch out to foreign markets. Therefore, they use Computex as an excellent platform to establish connections with the rest of the world," Jeremy Horng, deputy executive director of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA)'s Exhibition Department, told the Central News Agency in an interview.
The five-day trade show, Asia's biggest computer show, ended Saturday. This year, more than 1,700 companies from around the world showcased their products at Computex, using 4,861 booths.
The Taipei Computer Association, another organizer of the event, said in a statement released Saturday that the number of Chinese buyers visiting the show rose significantly this year from last year.

A total of 106 companies from China used 171 booths at the trade show this year, which was more than double the numbers from last year, when there were 41 Chinese exhibitors using 78 booths, Horng noted.

Computex was open to Chinese exhibitors last year for the first time after the political tensions between Taiwan and China had eased since the inauguration of Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008.
Computex successfully appealed to Chinese exhibitors as the show increased their business opportunities from foreign buyers, Horng said.
However, due to insufficient space at Computex's venues, more than 100 companies from various countries could not exhibit at the annual event, now in its 30th year, according to Horng.
Unless Computex expands its venues, it might be difficult for the show to accommodate the even greater interest expected from Chinese firms next year, organizers said.

"Although we could expect yet another increase in the number of Chinese companies that want to exhibit at the show next year, we will have to see first if we could provide more booths for them to use, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC members concerned about ECFA progress: economics minister
DOC.DATELINE: Sapporo, Japan, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 16:41:13 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Almost every Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) member is concerned about the progress of negotiations and talks on a proposed trade pact between Taiwan and mainland China, Taiwan's minister of economic affairs said Friday.

Taiwan's active move to promote the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China draws APEC members' attention, Shih Yen-hsiang noted in an interview with CNA in Sapporo, Japan.
Shih, leading the Taiwan delegation, arrived here Thursday for the two-day annual meeting of APEC trade ministers that began Saturday.

He attended a formal welcoming dinner the previous evening, in which he was seen chatting with World Trade Organization Secretary General Pascal Lamy, as well as ministers and trade representatives of other nations, including China's Minister of Commerce Chen Deming.
In the coming APEC meeting, Shih will conduct talks with Lamy.

Asked whether he will hold talks with Chen or have a chance to talk about the ECFA issue during the meeting, Shih only said the APEC forum is a public occasion, on which he will meet all trade ministers of all member states to exchange opinions.

Responding to questions on the widely-anticipated early harvest list of items that will have tariffs reduced immediately after the proposed ECFA deal is signed, Shih reiterated that items which are expected to affect Taiwan's employment, farmers and conventional medium and small enterprises, will not be put in the program for tax deduction or exemption.

As to how many items of products will be included in the early-harvest list, Shih only said talks on the issue have not been finalized, but he confirmed that the number of Chinese products on the list will be less than the more than 300 Taiwanese products on the list.

Shih, again, underlined the importance and urgency of the signing of the cross- strait trade pact, saying China, Japan and South Korea recently agreed among each other to be active in promoting the formation of a free trade agreement among themselves.
Once the proposed Northeast Asian free trade zone is formed, Taiwanese companies will not be able to compete with rival businesses that enjoy preferential tax treatment in the region, Shih warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTCH director plots to get Taiwan's performers on world stages

TEXT.P: Huang Pi-twan has been the artistic director of Taiwan's National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) for only two months, but her mission is already clear: to expand efforts to stage productions with international directors and give local performers more experience.

Huang, a former head of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) , feels the NTCH has a duty to boost the standard of performances in Taiwan, and one way to achieve that, she says, is by focusing on collaborations with artists from other countries.

"This not only lets us learn advanced technology and performance skills from other artists, it also helps us promote our shows to the world," she stressed in an interview with the Central News Agency.
Huang's mission is not new for the performance venue.

The NTCH has often worked with international directors in the past, including on the production "1433-The Grand Voyage, " a collaboration between avant-garde American stage director Robert Wilson and Taiwanese percussion group "U Theatre" that was staged in the first half of the year.
But Huang hopes such co-productions will be staged more frequently in the future, and she said there are at least two programs set for the second half of the year.
"One of those is an opera called 'La Peintre, Yu-Lin, ' in which a Taiwanese writer, composer and orchestra and Taiwanese singers will work with a French director, " she indicated.

The production, which will debut at the National Theater Hall at the beginning of July, is based on the story of a legendary Chinese women named Pan Yu-Liang, who first was a prostitute and then a concubine before becoming a famous painter, Huang said.
The opera's composer is National Award for Arts winner Chien Nan-chang, who will team up with playwright Wang An-chi and French director Juliette Deschamps.
"The opera will present a fascinating world of song and performance," Huang said.

The other production, slated for August, will invite Wang Hsin-sing, the founder of Hsin Sing Nanguan (also written Xin Xin Nanguan), to collaborate with French director Lukas Hemleb on a modern Nanguan opera called "Feather."
Nanguan is a style of Chinese classical music originating in the southern Chinese province of Fujian.
Huang revealed that the story of the Nanguan musical is based on a Chinese legend known as "The Double Seventh Festival, " which involves a love story between a goddess and a human being.
"We spent over NT$20 million on each production, but I believe our artists can learn a lot from these opportunities, and we will definitely promote these works in other countries," she said.
Despite the challenge of having to compete with many bigger and more modern venues built in Asia in recent years, Huang maintains confidence in the management ability and technology of the NTCH.

"While we are preparing for the celebration of the 25th anniversary of the NTCH in 2012, I think the first thing we should do is to make a list of our standard operating procedures (SOP) , which include program organization, stage technology, and marketing, among others," she said.
The purpose is to help those who will manage new performance halls that will be opening in the future in northern, central and southern Taiwan.
"We can provide information and experience to help them manage these new venues smoothly," she said.
Another new project Huang feels proud of is successfully raising funds to enable the children of poor families in remote areas to see shows at the NTCH.

"We raised over NT$1.7 million in May, which meant that we reached our goal much earlier than expected, " Huang said, pleased that the fund will help more children enter the beautiful world of the performing arts. By Sunnie Chen, CNA staff reporter CNA Photo No. 26

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Post-ECFA era

TEXT.P: As Taiwan is likely to soon sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Taiwan should devise an effective strategy to take advantage of a Western Taiwan Straits Economic Zone in Fujian Province.
Beijing is promoting the zone to balance regional development and boost economic integration with Taiwan, paving the way for peaceful cross-strait unification.
Taiwan's private sector has responded enthusiastically to the special economic zone on China's west coast, but the government has adopted a "cool-headed" approach because of political concerns.

Although we don't need to dance to Beijing's tune, Taiwan still needs to think positively and try to benefit from China's west coast economic zone. That would enable us to bolster economic development in our own special economic zones and build a new model of two-way industrial cooperation in the post-ECFA era.

We must stress that Taiwan as a whole should avoid engaging with the Fujian zone. Rather, Taiwan should use its special economic zones to deal with the zone on the opposite side so as to not hurt parity and Taiwan's sovereignty.

The special economic zones envisioned by Taiwan's government, where companies will be given preferential tax, labor, financing and customs treatment, will be the best choice Taiwan has to embrace the post-ECFA era and cross-strait dealings. (June 5, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud computing's time has finally arrived: Computex experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 17:30:34 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: Visitors to the international Computex Taipei trade show have found out quickly that the future is in cloud computing, with industry veterans confident that the concept's technology is launching integrated computing into a new era.
"It may have been around for a long time, but now cloud computing is about to take off, " Tudor Brown, president of British chip maker ARM, said at a forum on Wednesday.
The five-day Computex, which concluded Saturday, included a series of speeches and discussions devoted to cloud computing technology, a sign of its growing importance in the IT field.

Cloud computing provides "highly available" services and data stored on an Internet network (the cloud) that users can access with devices such as desktop personal computers, TVs and smart phones connected to the Web.

The advantage is that users do not have to install or maintain these services on their devices, said Gary Szilagyi, vice president and general manager of American semiconductor developer Atheros Communications, Inc.'s Computing and Consumer Business Unit, at a conference Monday.
"Everyone sees great value in the cloud, and in fact, there have been many businesses founded upon entire requirements of delivering the cloud content," he said.

Cloud computing is expected to be the preferred solution in an era of rapid industrial development, experts believe, and Brown said he saw a lot of opportunity for Taiwan because the market is driven by low-power equipment, innovation, cost and mobility.
"That's what you do here very well," he said.
According to Digitimes Research, there will be 10 billion connected devices in the future, which would have been impossible to believe just a few years ago.

"In 2004, it's very hard to think of a single desktop application which is used by millions of users outside of games, " but now we have popular cloud web applications, such as Gmail, Google Map, Twitter, and Facebook," said Sundar Pichai, vice president of Google.

Cloud computing is also among the Taiwanese government's strategic industries. The government and the private sector jointly formed the Taiwan Cloud Computing Consortium in April, pouring in NT$24 billion (US$740 million) to promote development in the field over the next five years.

"We expect the private sector to invest NT$12.7 billion in research and development and another NT$100 billion for manufacturing and services, " Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said at the Taiwan Business Alliance Conference the day before Computex opened.
"This could create 50,000 new jobs with a turnover of NT$1 trillion," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tadao Ando breaks ground on latest project: his first columbarium
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 18:14:52 (By Huang Huei-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: World-renowned Japanese architect Tadao Ando hosted a groundbreaking ceremony in Taipei County Saturday to kick off construction on the first columbarium complex he has designed in his illustrious career.

Ando said he expects the new facility, consisting of a columbarium -- the memorial building where the cremated remains of the deceased can be stored -- and a landscaped garden with 4,000 cherry trees, to become an international architectural landmark that represents Taiwan.

He also hopes that the site will turn out to be one of the world's best cemeteries and a global attraction for people to appreciate the beauty of cherry blossoms outside of Washington, D.C., said the University of Tokyo professor.
Ando has also incorporated water into his design, putting a reflecting pool on the roof of the columbarium.

Situated on a 26-hectare site in Sanjhih, a coastal township in northern Taiwan, the planned columbarium complex and garden will cost an estimated NT$10 billion (US$308.24 million) to build, according to Taipei-based Lung Yen Life Service Co., which contracted Ando to build the facility.
It is expected to take 10 years to complete.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to offer more public rental housing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 19:08:40 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei City will make a concerted effort to increase the availability of public rental housing over the next 10 years, hoping that 5 percent of all available housing in the city will be public rentals by 2020.

Taipei Mayor Hau Long-bin said Friday that 0.65 percent of the city's housing stock is currently public rental housing, the highest ratio in the country but still low compared with western countries, and he expressed hope that the rate will be able to rise to 5 percent, the same level as in the U.S.
Hau said that the city government is planning to build 200 public rental units of 50 square meters each in six locations by the end of 2014. Each unit will have a monthly rent of NT$10,000 (US$308).
The city will also release houses obtained from private construction companies taking part in urban renewal projects or other joint development projects for public rental.
A total of 1,230 such houses, including some located above MRT complex buildings, will be available for public rental rather than sold via public auction, Hau said.
In addition, the city government also plans to renovate some idle school buildings, or use old market places to build public rental homes, he said.
A city government official said the government will draft regulations to prevent high-income households from benefiting from public rental housing policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boldly push carbon emission cuts: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 19:39:25 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The government will resolutely push for energy conservation and carbon emission cuts in both the public and private sectors this year, Premier Wu Den-yih said Saturday.

He said major carbon emitters, such as Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), CPC Corp., Taiwan, Formosa Plastics and China Steel, will have to cut carbon emissions by replacing aging equipment to enhance energy efficiency.

"If major carbon emission businesses such as Taipower and CPC strive for progress, they will be able to cut millions or tens of millions of tons of carbon emissions every year, " he said on the sidelines of an energy conservation show coinciding with World Environment Day.
The premier pledged that the government would also focus more emphasis on energy saving and carbon reduction in public infrastructure.

One example, he said, was that the government has begun to replace the light bulbs normally used in traffic lights with LEDs in the past two years and that there are only three or four cities that have yet to replace their traffic lights.
"By 2011, all traffic lights will use LEDs, " the premier said.
The government will also encourage the development of renewable energy, solar power, LEDs, biomass energy and wind power, and electric cars and motorcycles, he said.
Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan has also planned to make Green Island as a model low-carbon emission island, the premier said.
"We'll promote the idea to other parts of Taiwan after reviewing the results on Green Island," he added.

Vice Economics Minister Huang Jung-chiou said that in addition to Green Island, the low-carbon island project will also cover three other outlying islands -- Liuchiu Islet (also known as Siaoliouchiou), Penghu and Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: President receives U.S. senators
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 21:37:09 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou spoke of the importance of signing a trade pact with China when he received three visiting U.S. senators Saturday.

The trio -- Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) , Kay Hagan (D-NC) and Mark Udall (D-Co.) -- arrived in Taiwan earlier in the day, marking the first visit by U.S. senators to Taiwan since President Ma took office in May 2008.

The president noted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have signed 12 agreements over the past two years, and that cross-strait ties have been more peaceful and stable than at any time in the past six decades.
The two sides are now negotiating a economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , and Ma said he hoped it could be signed soon to institutionalize cross- strait trade ties.

Citing a comment by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State James Steinberg at the Brookings Institution, a U.S. think tank, on May 10, Ma said the signing of the trade pact is significant in that it will promote peace, resolve differences and avoid confrontation.
Noting that the group flew into Taiwan after visiting Beijing and Shanghai, Ma said this "was unimaginable in the past, and was made possible through improved cross-strait relations."

The president also said that he talked to Feinstein, a former San Francisco mayor, over the phone during his visits to the U.S. in 2006, 2008, and 2009 but did not meet her, and said he was glad to "finally have the meeting in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Mountain line steam railway makes nostalgic return
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 21:52:14 (By Chen Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The old CK124 steam engine sounded its horn at Sanyi Railway Station in Miaoli County Saturday, signaling to the train's 300 passengers and other train aficionados around the country that service on a historic railway line in Taiwan had resumed.
"This is the train I took when I was little, " said a 55-year-old grandmother when describing the old locomotive to her eight-year-old grandson at the station.

The passenger, identified only by the surname Huang, said she had eagerly awaited the reopening of the 15.9-kilometer-long Old Mountain Line between Sanyi and Houli in Taichung County for 12 years, since the rail line's operations were suspended in 1998.
Her 94-year-old mother has still not forgotten the sound of trains on the railway line running through the hills of central Taiwan, Huang said.
