To attract tourists, the Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) spent nearly NT$200 million (US$6.16 million) to restore the tracks and facilities along the line, which passes many historic sites, including the Broken Longteng Bridge and the nearby Shengsing station built during the Japanese colonial era.
The project has managed to restore service on 13.6 kilometers of the line thus far, from Sanyi to Taian Station in Taichung County, according to the TRA.
On Saturday the old steam train made two round trips. It will be back in service on June 9, each Wednesday in July and August, and August 29, with two round-trip runs per day.
In addition, the TRA will also offer services by a diesel-powered train every Monday and Friday between July 5 and Aug. 27, with two round-trip runs per day.
The timetable for the line can be found on the TRA's website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Six tons of U.S. cherries fail pesticide test
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:04:37 (By Chen Chin-fan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nearly six tons of cherries recently imported from the United States have been found to contain the pesticide malathion, the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

Pan Chih-kuan, a director of the DOH's Food and Drug Administration, said the two batches of cherries contained 0.02 parts per million and 0.03 ppm of malathion, respectively. Taiwan's regulations do not allow any trace amounts of the substance in cherries.
The two importers are now applying to have the two batches re-examined.

If they are still found to contain the pesticide, the first batch, which had not been cleared by customs, will be returned to the shipper, and the second batch, which had been released to the importer to keep refrigerated pending the results of the examination, will be confiscated and destroyed.
Pan said that if a third batch of U.S. imported cherries were to fail the examination within six months, the DOH will ask the U.S. to come up with a plan to improve the situation.
"We will also step up the examination of all cherries imported from the United States," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: UAV developed by Taiwan to take part in Berlin air show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:14:14 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A multi-purpose unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) developed by a local company will take part in a major air show next week, an official of the company said Saturday.

Cooper Chang, the marketing manager of Carbon-Based Technology Inc., said its UAV, called the UAVER, will take part in the Berlin Air Show June 8-13. It will be the first time an unmanned aerial system (UAS) with a Taiwanese brand has entered a major air show.

The company demonstrated the 3.45-kilogram system on Friday on top of a building at National Chung Hsin University in central Taiwan's Taichung, during which images taken by the airborne UAV were transmitted simultaneously.
Chang said the United States, though a leader in the development of unmanned aerial systems, has generally used much larger systems for military purposes.
But the smaller UAV developed by Carbon-Based Technology can be an effective tool in monitoring disasters, environmental pollution and other problems.

Chen Shu-chun, director of the university's Water & Soil Conservation Department, said traditional unmanned helicopters can monitor the environment, but they have the limitations of being loud, noisy and hard to maneuver.
They also only have a short remote control distance (about 2 kilometers) and cannot stay airborne for long (under 10 minutes).
This is why they are confined to short-distance environmental monitoring and disaster prevention missions, Chen said.
"The Avian UAS developed by Taiwan has solved the above problems," he added.
He said the UAS also does not require a long runway due to its use of a bungee rope launch for take-off and its parachute landing system.
The other advantage is that the whole system can be maneuvered from a disaster prevention center indoors.
The system can stay airborne for 90 minutes and penetrate remote areas to provide often difficult-to-obtain information in real time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex generates record high level of business
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:20:40 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei, Asia's largest computer show, attracted more international visitors this year than ever before and generated a record US$230 million in business on site, the organizers said in a statement on the show's final day Saturday.

Jeremy Horng, deputy executive director of Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) 's Exhibition Department, said the 35,017 international visitors from 216 different countries and regions attending the show's first four days outpaced the 34,892 visitors from 184 countries and regions last year.

According to TAITRA, more than 2,000 one-on-one meetings between buyers and suppliers were held on June 1 and 2, generating on-site business worth US$230 million, more than double the US$100 million generated during similar meetings last year.
The top five countries and regions most represented by international buyers were the United States, Japan, China, Hong Kong, and South Korea.

Aiming to make Computex the world's biggest computer show, Horng said the fair's international significance in the information technology sector was reflected by the 400 foreign exhibitors occupying 830 booths at the show.
The number of booths was 5 percent higher than last year.

But venue size continues to haunt Computex's ambitions to expand. According to the organizers, there were 100 to 200 foreign and local exhibitors on the waiting list this year, and other vendors even plan to apply for more booths next year.

Because another Nangang Exhibition Hall will not be ready until the end of 2012, the organizers said they will consider using Taiwan World Trade Center Hall 2 next year, which can provide another 350 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETC operator, government still at odds over toll collection system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) 06/05/10 22:40:10 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The operator of an electronic freeway toll collection system admitted Saturday that it will fall short of the targeted usage rate for the system by the end of June, but it remains at odds with the government over how the problem should be solved.

Far Eastern Electronic Toll Collection Co. (FETC) , which was commissioned to set up the ETC service, said that with the ETC usage rate at 38 percent at present, it is not likely that the target rate for the end of June of 45 percent will be met.

According to an agreement between the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and FETC, the ETC usage rate is required to reach 45 percent by the end of June, and 65 percent by the end of 2012.

The Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau under the MOTC said it will send a notice to FETC next month asking the company to improve the situation within a specified time, but it acknowledged that the two sides have failed to reach any consensus on how to resolve the issue.

The usage rate of the system, which collects tolls from freeway motorists automatically, has been hampered by resistance to installing the system's transmitter, the "on board unit, " which costs NT$1,199 (US$37).
Since the ETC system was introduced four years ago, about 950,000 vehicles have installed the OBUs.

The bureau has hoped that FETC would offer the OBU at a lower price or for free, but the company has rejected the idea, saying that free installations would cost the company over NT$6 billion, well above the company's NT$3.8 billion in capital.

The FETC, on the other hand, has suggested many times since last year that the government should offer a 20 percent discount on tolls for ETC users, but the proposal has not yet been approved by the MOTC.

Meanwhile, an MOTC official also said on Saturday that the low usage rate of the ETC system could delay the implementation of an automatic distance-based toll collection scheme, but did not elaborate.
The ministry plans to replace both the frequency-based ETC and manned toll booths with a fully automatic distance-based toll collection model by the end of 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Perfectionist chef relentless in quest to present good food

TEXT.P: Veteran chef Huang Shih-chan, a perfectionist who is his own most fastidious critic where food is concerned, has turned his back on the Western-style steakhouses and Chinese restaurants in which he learned his craft, and is now putting his considerable skill and talent into a new venture -- in fact a whole new genre -- a fusion cuisine restaurant that also serves breakfast.

Huang's diners could find themselves being served, for example, with Taiwanese egg rolls with basil and bacon, or Japanese sushi wrapped in thin-pressed bread, coupled with a cup of freshly brewed coffee Huang has developed after trying around 20 types of beans and preparation methods.
"Eating should be far more than just putting food into your mouth," Huang said during a recent interview.
"Eating just to feel full is not enough. My patrons are not allowed to leave my restaurant until they feel totally satisfied, " said an ebullient Huang, his face wreathed in its customary smiles.

Huang honed his skills and techniques in various Taiwanese and traditional Chinese restaurants for 23 years before turning his hand to Western cuisine. Prodigiously talented, he became a chef within just two years of his apprenticeship.
It was during the busiest time of his career, when he was running three steakhouses-cum-piano bars at the same time, that he picked up the idea of fusion cuisine from the West.
Huang would begin his day by trying a new dish or type of food, perhaps at a decent restaurant, other times at a simple roadside diner, during daily scouting missions.

Through these scouting missions, he has developed his own scheme for running restaurants -- either turning expensive dishes normally served only at upscale restaurants into food for the average person, or absorbing the ingredients and the secret knacks of roadside eatery cooking to transform lowly, everyday food items into dishes one would expect to see only in luxury restaurants.
On one occasion, he had afternoon tea at a five-star hotel in Taipei, where he was bowled over by the assorted sandwiches and brought some of them home to study more closely.

Another foray took him to a renowned steak restaurant franchise in Taipei. Upon discovering that his NT$450 "steak" was actually a piece of re-formed meat, he called for the manager and demanded a replacement, only to be presented with another fake steak in its place. And another. And another. Not until he had sent back four of the impostors did he finally get his steak.
Amazingly, this did not turn him into persona non grata at the franchise but instead, he became a VIP patron and is now regularly invited to test new menu items.

In his search for good coffee, meanwhile, Huang tested ceaselessly, so much so that during one tasting session, his mouth and tongue became numbed by the caffeine, whereupon he simply chewed on a little bread and soldiered on.
Huang is extremely critical when choosing food and ingredients. "Just like choosing a spouse, I'm critical of the foods' appearance, as well as its content," he said.
"You can't present a good dish unless you have developed an absolute insight into the tastes, textures, smells and colors of the foods, " he noted.

For example, tuna is one of the major ingredients in his latest venture, but Huang said he has had a long and difficult time trying to get rid of tuna's fishy odor. After months of research, however, he finally worked out a knack in which the oil from the cooked tuna is squeezed out before the fish is seasoned, after which, the oil is allowed to soak back in -- a method that Huang says makes the tuna smell less fishy without altering the smooth taste.
Ever the stickler to detail, Huang goes as far as examining his customers' leftover food and drinks -- sometimes even tasting the leftovers in his quest to find out why something has not been eaten.
"Being critical is probably one of the prerequisites for preparing good food," he said. By CNA staff writers Deborah Kuo, Inky Kao
CNA June 4 photo No. 11

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 6, or the 24th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
2001: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County is quarantined after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis the previous day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady will head Cloud Gate on Russia performance tour
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 11:06:03 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching will lead Taiwan's world renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre on a performance tour of Russia later this week, the Presidential Office confirmed Sunday.

This will be the second time that Chow has served as honorary director of the Cloud Gate on its overseas performance engagement. She assumed such a role for the first time early this year when the troupe performed its acclaimed pieces, including "Moon Water," in the United States and Canada between late January and early February.
Chow, who is scheduled to depart for Moscow Tuesday, will be the first Republic of China first lady ever to visit Russia.
The Presidential Office kept a low profile on Chow's upcoming Moscow trip, describing it as a "journey of arts and culture."
Cloud Gate dancers will perform the "Whisper of Flowers" at the 2010 Chekhov International Theatre Festival from June 10-13.
The dance theatre is scheduled to host a news conference on details about its Russia performance tour later Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Let graduates make their own choices
DOC.DATELINE: 06/06/10 15:09:14 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: It is a matter of opinion whether it is right or wrong for a graduate of the country's most prestigious university, National Taiwan University, to take a job as a show girl. But "adults" should adopt a new way of thinking toward the younger generation's career choices.
NTU President Lee Si-chen described the NTU graduate's choice to be a show girl at 3C exhibitions as "a pity" in his speech at the university's commencement ceremony on Saturday.
Lee harbors a mentality similar to that of Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou, who once was dismissive of the aspirations of a member of the X-generation to open a coffee shop.

Both Lee and Gou probably lack imagination when it comes to the new generation's career choices. Why must today's young people make job decisions based on thinking that belongs to the more traditional industrial development era? Why not allow them access or the right to career options that are more creative or innovative?
Many careers or work models that people have not even conceived of in the past are still in the works.

As commencement season approaches, over 20 percent of the yearly 250,000 college graduates will need to spend at least one year to land a job, and those who are lucky enough to find one will not necessarily be happy because their starting pay will be below average.

The "high degree, low pay" or "high academic credential, high unemployment" phenomena in the country have not yet been addressed, despite government figures showing 13.27 percent economic growth in the first quarter of the year, the biggest single quarter rise in 30 years.
With the unemployment rate remaining historically high, the Q1 surge was actually an "unfelt" or "jobless" recovery.
Statistics are one thing, but the people's actual experiences are another. The change in graduates' starting salaries is a direct benchmark in discerning the reality. (June 6, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- NTU president's 'show girls' remarks backfire

TEXT.P: Responding to a press inquiry Saturday about his views on dozens of National Taiwan University (NTU) students who became big hits on the Internet and television recently for working as "show girls," the president of the prestigious school said he feels kind of disappointed.

"While nobody should be discriminated against over his or her occupation, I have higher expecations of NTU graduates, " said NTU President Lee Si-chen. "Since our school uses a large amount of national resources, I hope our students will have better career development and make greater contributions in professional fields."
Lee's remarks have drawn mixed reaction from the school's students and alumni. While some agreed with his views, others said students' free will in career development should be respected.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Thirteen NTU students have emerged as Internet sensations because of their charming good looks. Some of them have even attracted considerable media attention after serving as "show girls" at major trade fairs or appearing in TV video game commercials.
After presiding over the school's 2010 graduation ceremony on Saturday, NTU President Lee was approached by a group of reporters seeking his opinions on the phenomenon.
In response, Lee said NTU students are generally very talented and creative.

"I hope they will develop their talent and ability to their fullest in order to contribute to society and civilization, " Lee said, adding that it would be a pity for NTU graduates to land jobs based on their appearance instead of their professional competence.

In his speech at the graduation ceremony, Lee encouraged NTU graduates to set a goal of becoming an outstanding world-class figure who works diligently to help resolve problems faced by mankind and to enhance the common well-being. (June 6, 2010).
China Times:

Yang Yi-mei, an NTU graduate who has served as a show girl or host at more than 100 trade fairs during her time at NTU because of her proficiency in Chinese and English, said she has just signed with an entertainment management company and will pursue her dream of becoming a TV host.

"I know what I am doing and have good judgment. I plan to write a book on my career experiences and visions, and I am studying Cantonese in order to get into Hong Kong's entertainment world, " she said.
She said she believes that when Lee reads her book, he will have a different view on NTU students' career pursuits.
Huang Shu-chun, a popular singer and songwriter who holds a master's degree from NTU's Graduate Institute of Business Administration, said he agrees with Lee's views.

"If I had known I would end up entering the entertainment world, I would have begun developing the skills needed for this profession starting in my teenage years, and would not have had to enroll in NTU," Huang said.
He further said he believes Lee's remarks were not aimed at denigrating "show girls" but rather at encouraging NTU graduates to make greater contributions to society. (June 6, 2010).
Liberty Times:
With the economy regaining momentum, new college and university graduates have become more optimistic about their job prospects, according to the results of an online survey.
The survey conducted by the 1111 Job Bank showed that more than 80 percent of new graduates are choosing to enter the job market right after graduation.

Moreover, the poll found that 44.7 percent of the respondents said they expect they can land a job within one month of their graduation, and 23.84 percent said they believe they can get a job within 31 to 60 days after their graduation.
On average, the new graduates believe they can land a job within 41 days of graduation, shorter than the 78 days estimated in a similar poll conducted last summer.
The survey also found that technology and science graduates feel they will have an easier time landing jobs than their humanities peers. (June 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Catholic sister, devoted to Taiwan for 35 years, dies at 92
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 5 (CNA) 06/06/10 15:55:45 (By Tsao Yu-fang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Sister Madeleine Severens, who devoted 35 years to assisting people in need in Taiwan as a missionary, died Friday at the Congregation of the Immaculate Heart of Mary (CICM) in Leuven, Belgium, at the age of 92.
After learning of Severens' death, Taiwan's representative to Belgium Lin Yung- lo headed to Leuven and paid tribute to her at a memorial Mass held at CICM Saturday.
During the Mass, a CICM sister read in Chinese and Dutch an article written by Severens to pray for residents of Taiwan's outlying island of Matsu, where she worked for 25 years.
Severens spent much of her life in China and Taiwan.
In 1945, she decided to devote her life to missionary service after joining the CICM religious order and was sent to China in 1948 while the civil war there was still raging.

While in China, she worked in Kunming, Inner Mongolia, and Beijing, but after the Communists won the civil war and founded the People's Republic of China (PRC) in 1949, the Belgian missionary was jailed for two and a half years because of PRC leader Mao Zedong's opposition to deism.

Severens was then repatriated to her country, but eventually returned to the Far East in 1966 when her religious order sent her to Taiwan. She was eventually transferred to Matsu in 1976 and stayed there until retiring in 2001.
During her time in Matsu, Severens helped deliver more than 1,000 babies on an island with only about 3,000 residents. Her devotion earned her the nickname of "Mou Mou," meaning mother.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former U.S. governor Huckabee to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 16:01:57 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Mike Huckabee, a former governor of Arkansas and candidate for the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, will visit Taiwan in a private trip next week, organizers announced Sunday.

The former governor is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Monday for the promotion of his book "Do the Right Thing" and will make an invitation-only appearance at the Taipei International Convention Center on June 8, according to Jack Hu, managing director of the visit's organizer London International Group.
Hu did not elaborate on details of Huckabee's visit, which will not be announced until Monday, but he said Huckabee may meet with local political heavyweights during his stay.
The June 8 event, called "An Evening with Governor Mike Huckabee," will begin with remarks from Huckabee and then be followed with a moderated question and answer session, Hu said.
Huckabee last visited Taiwan in June 2006 when he was still governor of Arkansas and chairman of the National Governors Association and met with former president Chen Shui-bian.

The association passed a resolution in 2003 supporting Taiwan's bid to become an observer in the World Health Assembly, and in 2005, Huckabee's state of Arkansas passed a resolution recommending the signing of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement.
In his bid for the Republican nomination for President, Huckabee won eight states and more than 4 million votes in the primaries before pulling out of the race in March 2008.

Huckabee was elected as lieutenant governor of Arkansas in 1993 by special election and re-elected in 1994. He became governor in July 1996 when his predecessor resigned and was one of the youngest governors in the country at the time. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1996 to 2007 and has been recognized by Time Magazine as one of the five best governors in America.
Huckabee currently hosts a weekend political talk show, "Huckabee," on Fox News Channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to show global competitiveness through Flora Expo: officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 16:56:06 (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taipei International Flora exposition will transform Taiwan's capital into a city of gardens and help showcase its achievements to the world, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Sunday.

The event, the most important internationally recognized expo ever to take place in the country, will allow Taiwan to share with the world its exploits in biotechnology, horticulture and tourism, Hau said during a ceremony marking the signing of a memorandum of understanding (MOU) between the city and Rotary International Taiwan.

Vice President Vincent Siew, who was also present at the ceremony, echoed Hau's vision, describing the expo as an event that will show the world the country's soft power and commitment to green technology.
The MOU with Rotary International was patterned after cooperation between the Rotary Club and the city when Taipei hosted the 2009 Summer Deaflympics.

Hau said the city was better able to promote itself during the Deaflympics, held in September 2009, because of the help of more than 5,500 Rotary Club members, who offered translating, catering and tour guide services.

Eva Hsiao, a three-year member of Rotary International District 3520, said she is looking forward to helping bring about a qualitative change in Taipei after visiting the Shanghai World Expo last month.
"Shanghai has become such a giant magnet, " she said. "I believe we can achieve that as well if we work together."

Forty-five countries have already registered for the Flora Expo, which is to be held from November 6, 2010 to April 25, 2011. The organizers said they expect the six-month event to draw as many as 6 million visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Disappointing special economic zones
DOC.DATELINE: 06/06/10 17:04:03 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: After two-years of twists and turns, Christina Liu, head of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, announced that the country's six free trade ports will be converted into special economic and trade zones.
We are disappointed in how the government has set up these special zones by doing away with some restrictions on the free trade ports.

Reforms that involve creative destruction are never easy. Only if their benefits are fully realized and their shortcomings eliminated during experimentation in special zones on a small scale should they be carried out on large scale.

Taiwan needs the special economic and trade zones because it has lagged far behind Singapore and Hong Kong in its liberalization of foreign trade, especially after the previous government's "no haste, be patient" policy on trade with China painted the country into a tight corner.

The political taboo for exchanges with China has now been erased, but the island is still closely bound by outdated regulations and suffers from backward infrastructure relative to Singapore and Hong Kong, dashing its hopes to become a regional operations hub.
In order to make up the two decades it lost, the country has to set up some special zones as an experiment in developing itself into a free trade island.

But these special zones should not be a more-open version of free trade ports, which are too small in scale to handle the production, transportation and logistics related to supplying upstream and midstream materials to processing zones in the Asia Pacific region, which employ more than 3 billion workers.

Furthermore, the "special" zones have belied their names by failing to follow Singapore's approach of employing foreign workers according to market forces, rather than imposing minimum wage and quota restrictions.
The special zones should have something special to justify their names. (June 6, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President joins 3-kilometer run to promote Flora Expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 17:29:41 (By Pao-hsiang Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou took part in a 3-kilometer road run Sunday that was part of an event designed to promote the upcoming Taipei International Flora Exposition.

Ma ran in one of the road run's three divisions -- the 3-km LOHAS group run -- and completed the course that started at the Presidential Office plaza and wove through nearby streets in under 30 minutes.
The run's sponsor, the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, incorporated it into the promotional campaign for the Taipei Flora Expo, which is scheduled to open in November.

Addressing the opening of the road run, Ma exhorted Taipei residents to exercise more and urged them to throw their support behind the flora expo -- one of the largest-scale international activities that the city has ever hosted.
A total of 2,648 runners took part in Sunday's run, which was divided into three divisions -- the 10-km competition, 3-km family run and the 3-km LOHAS run.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to continue negotiating on eastern Taiwan development bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 17:41:27 (By Justin Su and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday that it will continue negotiating with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) over including transportation subsidies to residents of eastern Taiwan in a bill on developing that part of the country.

A report in Sunday's Chinese-language China Times said the Legislative Yuan is expected to pass the bill on eastern Taiwan development to pave the way for an eastern Taiwan sustainable development fund, but will block the transportation subsidy proposal.
The subsidy proposal was originally floated by the DPP's candidate, Hsiao Bi- khim, during a legislative by-election in Hualien County earlier this year.
She proposed that people with household registrations in eastern Hualien and Taitung counties receive subsidies on air, train and highway bus fares of up to 50 percent.

DPP Legislator Lai Kun-cheng from Taitung County said Sunday that the DPP will stick to its guns on the subsidy program, but indicated there was room for discussion on the size of the subsidies and how they would be delivered.

Pointing to rail service, Lai argued it was unreasonable that passengers in eastern Taiwan are charged ticket prices on a par with those charged in other parts of Taiwan, given the region's old rail equipment and relatively slow train service.

Lin Yi-shih, the head of the KMT Policy Committee, said his legislative caucus has no intention of blocking the plan, but insisted that the DPP must come up with concrete steps for the implementation, such as how to prove passengers are local residents.
However, Ker Chien-ming, executive director of the DPP Policy Committee, said the DPP will insist on its version of the bill, which includes the subsidy program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.S. compare notes on trade issues in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Sapporo, Japan, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 18:02:06 (By Yang Ming-chu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Trade officials from Taiwan and the United States compared notes on bilateral trade issues here Sunday on the sidelines of a conference sponsored by the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Huang Chih-peng, the director-general of Taiwan's Bureau of Foreign Trade, said that Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang met with the U.S. delegation to the APEC conference of trade ministers Saturday.
Without naming names, Huang said U.S. officials conveyed their hopes that Taiwan would speed up its examination procedures and customs clearance for U.S. beef imports.
For his part, Shih explained that Taiwan's Legislative Yuan had revised the law to forbid imports of the skulls, brains, eyes and internal organs of U.S. cattle.

Imports of beef tails and tongues, which are not internal organs and are thereby not banned, will be subject to careful examinations because of public concerns about their safety, Huang quoted Shih as saying.
Shih also called for the earlier resumption of talks between Taipei and Washington under an existing Trade and Investment Framework Agreement.

American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt said in Taipei on June 3 that talks, which began in 1994 but were suspended in July 2007 because of a dispute over imports of U.S. beef, would be resumed later this year.
Washington may broach any questions about beef imports at those talks, which are usually attended by senior trade officials or vice trade ministers of both sides, Huang said.

During Shih's stay in Sapporo, Taiwan's delegation was also to hold bilateral talks with many APEC member economies and express its wishes to negotiate free trade agreements or economic cooperation pacts with its leading trade partners, including the U.S., Japan, the European Union and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

Huang was part of Taiwan's delegation during the June 5-6 APEC conference, which has gathered trade delegations from 21 APEC member economies to discuss regional trade liberalization, economic cooperation and growth strategies.
The U.S. delegation was led by Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Demetrios Marantis.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady to lead Cloud Gate on Russia performance tour (Updated)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 18:34:00 (By Cheng Ching-wen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching will lead Taiwan's world renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre on a tour of Russia later this week, the Presidential Office confirmed Sunday.

This will be the second time that Chow has served as Cloud Gate's honorary director on an overseas performance engagement. She previously assumed the role early this year when the troupe performed in the United States and Canada in late January and early February.
Most Cloud Gate dancers headed for Moscow Sunday afternoon ahead of their performances of "Whisper of Flowers" at the 2010 Chekhov International Theatre Festival from June 10-13.
Chow, who is scheduled to depart for Moscow Tuesday and meet up with the Cloud Gate dancers there, will be the first Republic of China first lady ever to visit Russia.
The Presidential Office refused to play up the trip, describing it simply as a "journey of arts and culture."

According to a front-page report in the Sunday edition of the local United Daily News (UDN), however, Chow's Moscow trip could be of significance and might usher in a period of closer official exchanges between Taiwan and Russia.

Chow will be given special courtesies in passing through immigration in Moscow, and Taiwan's representative office there will arrange dinner parties for the first lady to reach out to Russian politicians and other celebrities, the report said.
If all goes well, the paper said, Taiwan will have a better chance to expand its official ties with Russian authorities.

Chow was invited by Cloud Gate founder Lin Hwai-min to join the troupe in Russia because of the fond memories of her participation when the troupe performed in Washington, D.C. Jan. 29-30 and at the Vancouver Cultural Olympiad in early February.
One Cloud Gate executive said Chow touched the hearts of the troupe's dancers and stage staff with her warmth and kindness.

"Chow stayed at the same hotel where all troupe members stayed and attended each of the troupe's performances, " the executive said, adding that Chow could easily identify each dancer and stage technician, and would often chat with them and offer them a loving hug to boost their morale.
Though Chow suffered a lower back injury a few weeks ago, the Presidential Office said the first lady had fully recovered and was healthy enough to make the trip.
This is the fourth time that the troupe has been invited to perform in the internationally important Moscow arts festival.
Chow is scheduled to wrap up her Moscow trip and return to Taipei June 13, while the Cloud Gate dancers will fly on to Italy in preparation for performances in the June 22-23 arts festival in Rome.

DOC.HEADLINE: Zhejiang group to visit Taiwan for economic, cultural cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 18:40:54 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A delegation of 500 to 1,000 people headed by Zhejiang Governor Lu Zushan is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan June 9 for a week-long visit and attend a Taiwan- Zhejiang economic and cultural cooperation forum on June 10.

Lu, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan will speak during the forum that will be hosted by Preston Chen, the chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries.

Zhejiang Vice Governor Gong Zheng, and Yang Wei, president of Zhejiang University, will also attend the conference, as will several Taiwanese business leaders, including Hon Hai Precision Industry Chairman Terry Gou and Yulon Group Chairman Kenneth Yen.

Representatives of six Zhejiang companies in the delegation will also evaluate the feasibility of investing about US$10.12 million in Taiwan in exhibition centers for cosmetics and brand name products and light industrial machinery.
The delegation will also call on a number of companies in the banking and industrial sectors, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the world's largest contract chip maker.
It will also attend a cross-Taiwan Strait forum on agricultural and tourism development in Nantou, central Taiwan.
In Kaohsiung County, the group will participate in a seminar on village exchanges and a signing ceremony for the procurement of Taiwanese fruit.
It will also attend an event in Kaohsiung City to promote tourism in Taiwan and Zhejiang.

Before concluding its visit in Taiwan, the group will head north for an exhibition featuring Zhejiang's Liangzhu culture, which will open June 15 at the Shihsanhang Museum of Archaeology in Taipei County, a spokesman for the museum said.
A total of 100 Neolithic jade items from the Liangzhu period, dating back about 4,300 to 5,300 years, will be showcased during the exhibition that runs until Sept. 5.
The items were found in 1936 in tombs near Liangzhu, located about 30 kilometers north of Hangzhou.

During the exhibition, the Zhejiang Provincial Museum will sign an agreement with Taiwan's Quanta Culture and Education Foundation to loan it a collection of works from the 1127-1279 Southern Song Dynasty for an exhibition to be held in October at the National Palace Museum in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport MRT travel time should be cut to 20 minutes: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 19:02:13 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the travel time of the planned rapid transit system connecting Taipei to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport must be shortened to stay competitive with the existing freeway network.

The drive between Taipei and the airport currently takes approximately 40 minutes, and the airport rail system should therefore take half of that for travelers to find it competitive, the president said.

"Frankly speaking, since it is a 40-minute car ride to get to the airport, no one would want to ride the MRT if it takes 35 minutes. Therefore, you must shorten the time down to 20 or 25 minutes, " Ma said to the director general of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail during a visit to the airport.

The 22-station, 51.5-kilometer Taoyuan International Airport Access MRT system began construction in 2003 and is scheduled to begin operations in three years. Travel time between Taipei and the airport was originally estimated at 35 minutes.
The airport, formerly known as Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, is the biggest airport in the country and serves as the main hub for international flights.

The train to the airport is part of the government's NT$10.7 billion "Taoyuan Aerotropolis" plan, which also aims to lengthen runways and taxiways to accommodate aircraft as large as the Airbus A380, add a new third terminal, and establish an aerospace industrial park and special zones for cargo, passenger and logistics services.
The airport's aging Terminal One is currently undergoing a NT$3.2 billion facelift, the Civil Aeronautics Administration said. The renovation is slated to be completed in August 2011.
According to the Airports Council International's (AIC) 2009 Airport Service Quality Survey, Taoyuan International Airport fell to 27th place in the 2009, a sharp drop from the previous 18th.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fish farmers urged to change focus to skirt Chinese competition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 19:13:40 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tilapia aquaculture farmers were urged Sunday to shift to production of higher added value fish fillets to skirt fierce competition from their Chinese rivals.

Chen Tien-shou, deputy director-general of the Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture, called for Taiwan tilapia farms to increase exports of fish fillets, which are higher priced, instead of producing whole fish, which face cutthroat competition from China.

China's mass production and low price strategy have caused the price of whole tilapia to plummet since early this year. It fell to NT$33 (US$1.03) per kilogram at its lowest point from NT$45 two years ago, Chen said.

The pricing problem prompted the Fisheries Agency to put forth a subsidy plan in May to encourage local tilapia farms to cooperate with seafood processing factories to increase their export of skinless, boneless tilapia fillets, which can be sold for US$6.5 per kilogram on an FOB basis.
Under the incentive program, fish farmers are given NT$5 per kilogram in subsidies for their production and export inspection fees , according to Chen.

Because of its large size, rapid growth and palatability, Taiwan's tilapia has become the most important fish in the country's aquaculture sector, with annual exports of whole fish and fish fillets reaching between 30,000 and 40,000 metric tons and some 4,000 metric tons, respectively, according to Chen.
The annual global output of tilapia is roughly 2.7 million metric tons, with about 1.1 million metric tons of that coming from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan grouper prices rise on increasing demand from China
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 19:23:19 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A big increase in Chinese demand for Taiwan's cultured grouper has pushed prices for the fish in southern Taiwan higher by 10-15 percent recently, a grouper farmer in Gangshan, Kaohsiung County, said Sunday.

As live grouper is seen as a valuable gift or upscale dish in restaurants by ordinary Chinese, demand for the fish has increased, sending prices soaring, according to Chen Wen-ge, head of the Kaohsiung County Aquaculture Development Association.
The prices of giant grouper are particularly high because of their limited availability, Chen said, noting that a 1.2-kilogram giant grouper can sell for NT$4,000 (US$123.65) in China.
The average price of grouper in the 525 gram-825 gram range -- the most popular size in China -- has risen to NT$230 from NT$200 per 600g, according to Chen.
China's coastal cities are the main export destinations for the fish, mainly raised in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan.

The fish are usually transported by 13 fishing boats to various harbors in China while they are still alive immediately after wholesalers agree on quantities and prices, increasing survival rates and improving competitiveness, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: 86-year-old Tao man wins prize for quitting smoking
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, May 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 19:44:57 (By Chen Li-ting & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: An 86-year-old Tao elder from Orchid Island was presented with a top award for quitting smoking and prize money of NT$300,000 from the anti-smoking campaign's organizer, the John Tung Foundation, at a ceremony in Taipei Sunday.
Chou Lung-fa, who had smoked one to two packs of cigarettes daily over the past 60 years, had originally planned not to give up smoking until he turned 90, said Chou Chang-jung, his son.

But the elder Chou, a resident of the island off eastern Taiwan's Taitung County, said the prize money offered by the association prompted him to move up his schedule and "win the sum to help build houses for younger generations and for health reasons."
Yu Tseng-li, a 64-year-old woman, was awarded the "Best Witness Prize" for helping his only son, nicknamed "big head," quit smoking.

"Big head" once successfully gave up smoking when he was hospitalized after suffering serious burns on almost half of his body, but after recovering, he started to smoke again while attending a job training program.
Yu organized a group of monitors -- including neighbors, relatives and her son's friends -- to remind "big head" of swearing off cigarettes whenever he was found to have smoked.

The mother, in addition to inviting neighbors to leave messages on the "quit notebook' to encourage her son to carry on, read the notebook carefully every day to examine any problems her son encountered.
Touched by his mother's insistence and seriousness, Big Head finally succeeded, even though he suffered discomfort, such as vomiting, during the process and lost 16 kilograms.

The John Tung Foundation first launched the "Quit and Win" campaign, endorsed by the World Health Organization, in 2002 to provide a platform for Taiwan's 4 million smokers to overcome their habit and quit.
Speaking at the award presentation ceremony, Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said the biggest award for those who quit smoking would be "winning back their health."
He cited the example of his mother, who gave up smoking 26 years ago when she was 60, and she is now in good shape and able to "go around everywhere on her own."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will change Taiwan's status on world trade map: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 19:49:04 (By Bien Chin-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will ultimately change Taiwan's place on the global trade map.

Speaking during a visit to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Ma said that over the past decade, Taiwan has lacked a strategic vision to guide its national development because of a closed-door mindset.

On the presidential campaign trail two years ago, Ma said, he proposed three national development goals -- making Taiwan a global innovation center, an Asia-Pacific trade center and a global operations hub for Taiwanese conglomerates and a regional operations hub for foreign business groups.

"The discourse was based on the fact that Taiwan is located at the center of East Asia, " Ma said, adding that Taiwan's major airports and sea ports are the closest to those in other East Asian countries.
Regrettably, Ma said, Taiwan had failed to cash in on this advantage over the past 10 years due to a closed-door mindset and a lack of strategic vision.

With Taiwan unable to forge a cooperative relationship with China, Taiwan's air carriers and logistic service operators had been reluctant to make new investment as they were not sure how relations across the Taiwan Strait would develop, the president said.
Now that China has emerged as the world's second largest economy, Ma argued, Taiwan can no longer dodge the need to foster and maintain an appropriate relationship with it.

"It's not an issue of 'want or not want' or 'like or dislike.' It's a 'must.' If we do nothing in this regard, we are sure to lag behind, to be forced out of the global economic sphere and to be marginalized. Taiwan must grasp any possible opportunity to catch up with mainstream world trends at this time of global economic recovery," Ma stressed.
Once Taiwan strikes an ECFA deal with China, Ma said confidently, its status on the world trade map will no longer be the same.
The world will "feel that Taiwan's public and private sectors are determined and have far-sighted visions to move forward and upward in the pursuit of excellence," he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to conduct inspections of U.S. beef slaughterhouses
DOC.DATELINE: 06/06/10 20:53:58 (By Chen Li-ting & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 6 (CNA Taiwan will for the first time send officials to conduct on- site inspections of slaughterhouses that have their beef exported to Taiwan, Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Sunday.
Yaung said the move, slated for August or September, is to he taken to ensure that all U.S. beef exports are adequately labeled, as required by the country's regulations.

"Five to 10 slaughterhouses or packing facilities in the U.S. will be inspected by Taiwanese officials this time, " Yaung said in response to a Central News Agency question on the latest U.S. calls for Taiwan to accelerate its imports of U.S. beef products.

In a meeting on the sidelines of the conference of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) trade ministers held June 5-6 in Sapporo, Japan, U.S. officials told their Taiwanese counterparts that Washington would be happy to see Taipei speed up its examination procedures and customs clearance for U.S. beef imports.
"The examination procedures and customs clearance will be able to become faster after the labeling problems are addressed," Yang said.
Taiwan's legislature revised laws late last year to ban imports of certain U.S. beef products, including skulls, brains, eyes and internal organs of U.S. cattle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei, Paris to pool resources in film production
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 20:59:05 (By Lo Yuan-shao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The general director of the Paris-based Ile de France Film Commission said Sunday he is scheduled to travel to Taipei late this month to sign an agreement with the Taipei Film Commission on mutual assistance in film production and marketing.

Olivier-Rene Veillon told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview that the film commissions in both Taipei and Paris are keenly interested in pooling resources to help each other's filmmakers in movie production and marketing.
In addition, Veillon said, the two commissions hope to support Taiwanese and French filmmakers in joint film production.

According to Veillon, two award-winning Taiwanese directors -- Hou Hsiao-hsien and Tsai Ming-liang -- have received assistance from the French film commission in shooting their films "the Flight of Red Ballon" and "Face," respectively.
"In the future, we hope to help foster more similar projects," he said.

Acknowledging that Taiwan has a profound understanding of Mandarin films, Veillon said his commission hopes that cooperative ties with Taiwan will ultimately help French filmmakers reach out or gain access to larger Mandarin film markets, including China, Singapore and other Chinese communities around the world.
Taipei will be the first Asian city with which the French film commission has signed a cooperative agreement on the sharing of film resources, Veillon added.

Once the agreement is inked, television and film producers in the two cities will enjoy preferential treatment granted to local producers, a Taipei Film Commission official said recently when discussing the cooperative project.
Parisian moviemakers working in Taipei City, for example, will be issued "preferential cards for film production, " and film producers from Taipei will receive similar treatment in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese lawmaker with family link to Taiwan tapped for new Cabinet
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 21:06:21 (By Mike Chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Renho, a member of Japan's House of Councilors whose father was Taiwanese, has been tapped to be the state minister in charge of administrative reform in the Cabinet to be formed by Prime Minister Naoto Kan.

The Kyodo news agency reported that in light of Renho's experience in working closely with ex-Minister for Administrative Reform Yukio Edano to cut waste in the administration, Kan decided to appoint her to replace Edano for the sake of continuity.
Edano is set to serve as the secretary-general of the Democratic Party of Japan, or the No. 2 figure of the ruling party.
Born Hsieh Lien-fang on Nov. 28, 1967 in Tokyo to a Taiwanese father and Japanese mother, Renho, who goes by her first name, studied at Aoyama Gakuin school in Tokyo during her youth.
After taking Japanese citizenship in 1985, she enrolled in the law faculty of Aoyama Gakuin University, graduating in 1990.
She worked on several television and radio programs as a commentator and eventually became a newscaster on TBS and TV Asahi, covering several major events, including the Great Hanshin Earthquake.
She was married in 1993 and studied Chinese at Beijing University in 1995, where she gained fame for arguing with a Chinese professor who spoke with contempt about Taiwan and Japan in class.

After giving birth to twins in 1997, she returned to television in 2000, serving as an anchor or reporter on several TBS programs. She reported from Taiwan during Chen Shui-bian's presidential campaign, which brought her to the attention of Taiwanese political leaders.
In 2004, she ran a successful campaign for membership in the House of Councilors on the ticket of the Democratic Party of Japan, earning her a six-year term.
As an upper house lawmaker in Japan, Renho has maintained close contacts with groups of Taiwanese living in Japan and has criticized Japan's diplomacy with China and its refusal to recognize Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition leader urges Central Election Commission to do its job
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/10 21:52:58 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The chief of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the Central Election Commission to speak out against the rejection of a TSU referendum initiative or face a possible investigation by the Control Yuan into "dereliction of duty."

The Executive Yuan's Referendum Review Commission rejected on June 3 a TSU referendum initiative that would have asked voters, "Do you agree that the government should sign an economic cooperative framework agreement (ECFA) with China?"

It nixed the initiative, its chairman Chao Yung-mao said, because the stated purpose of the referendum was to determine if the government had the right to sign an ECFA, but the question was focused on the ECFA's content.
"The referendum question's content and purpose were contradictory," Chao said.
TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei contended Sunday that the review commission had infringed on the power of the Central Election Commission (CEC) in making such a judgment.

According to Huang, the review commission is only authorized by law to check whether the subject of the referendum proposal is suitable for a national referendum and whether it was a subject that had already been put to a referendum within the previous three years.

But the grounds for rejecting the proposal -- that the actual question was inconsistent with the stated purpose of the referendum -- was for the CEC and not the review commission to decide, according to the Referendum Act, Huang said.
The CEC actually reviewed the referendum question before handing it over to the review commission, and in doing so had given its green light to the proposal, Huang contended.

Therefore, he said, unless the CEC defends its authority by tossing out the review commission's decision, "we will bring the issue to the Control Yuan for an investigation into the CEC's 'dereliction of duty,'" Huang said.

The TSU, along with the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, is trying to sink the government's push for the framework agreement on trade with China, which is expected to be sealed later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 7, or the 25th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/10 09:33:44 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Monday than its previous close, moving down 204.83 points at 7,139.76 on a turnover of NT$4.1 billion (US$128.13 million).
The weighted price index lost 15.69 points, or 0.21 percent, to close at 7,344.59 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Talk of the day -- Is it time for Taiwan firms to exit China?

TEXT.P: The recently reelected head of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) said over the weekend that Foxconn Group's recent pay raise signals an upward trend of production costs in China.

Against this backdrop, TEEMA President Arthur Chiao said the association will begin to promote a "southward strategy" to encourage China-based Taiwanese technology companies to relocate to India, Indonesia and Vietnam.

Meanwhile, Foxconn Group announced Sunday that workers at its Shenzhen plants will get another pay raise from Oct.1, which would bring their standard monthly salary to 2,000 yuan, (about NT$9,600). The group's move now puts strong pressure on its peers.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:
Chiao said the Foxconn Group's decision to raise the wages its Chinese workers is an indication that the good old days of cheap Chinese labor are gone.

Many Taiwan-owned companies that manufacture umbrellas and footwear, which were the first to set up in China, have already relocated elsewhere. Now it is the turn of export-oriented electronic and information-technology companies, Chiao said.

In response to the labor shortage and rising wages in coastal Chinese provinces, a number of Taiwanese enterprises have relocated to China's hinterland in recent years with an eye on the growing Chinese consumer market.

However, companies whose main markets are in the United States and Europe should consider relocating as soon as possible to places with better potential for development and profit making, Chiao said. The TEEMA will step up information gathering and market surveys to help its members secure better investment opportunities, he said.

In addition to arranging visits to South Asian and Southeast Asian countries by market survey groups, Chiao said, the association will also organize for a delegation to visit Japan next year to scout business opportunities and joint venture deals there. (June 7, 2010).
Commercial Times:

Foxconn Group, a subsidiary of the Taiwan-based Hon Hai Group, announced Sunday that assembly workers and division chiefs at all of its factories in Shenzhen, China will get a second round of pay raises from Oct. 1, once they pass the basic performance assessment.
This will push up their basic monthly salary from the current 1,200 yuan to 2,000 yuan, the highest at any enterprise in China.

Foxconn's Shenzhen plants had just offered its workers a 30 percent pay raise at the beginning of this month amid a string of reported suicide attempts at its sprawling factory complex in the southern Chinese city, in which 11 people died and two were injured.

Foreign institutional investors estimated that the pay increases will eat up at least a third of Hon Hai Groups's earnings. It will be a challenge for the group to earn a profit of NT$8 per share for 2011, they forecast.

The group's pay raise decision has also put strong pressure on other Taiwanese companies in China. Heads of major Taiwanese business associations in China said they will encourage their member companies to transform and upgrade their technology in order to survive in an environment of rising costs and stiffer competition. (June 7, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Selling on Taiwan market accelerates in mid-morning trade
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/10 10:51:19 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices extended losses across the board in mid-morning trade Monday, following a dive on Wall Street at the end of last week, as debt problems in Hungary added to the worry over the European debt crisis, dealers said.
At 10: 27 a.m., the weighted index fell 243.63 points or 3.32 percent to 7,100.96, after opening 2.79 percent lower, on turnover of NT$40.92 billion (US$1.27 billion).

"It was no surprise to see investors scrambling to dump stocks this morning, " said Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang. "The problems in Hungary have greatly affected market confidence at home and abroad."
In addition, Chiang said, the euro's dive against the U.S. dollar has renewed concerns about consumption in the eurozone.
"That's why we're seeing heavy losses in local high tech stocks on fears that weakening demand in Europe will affect their global sales and their bottom line," Chiang said.
Hon Hai Precision fell 6.43 percent to NT$116.50 and Acer 2.52 percent to NT$77.50.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. lost 3.61 percent, dropping to NT$58.80, and United Microelectronics Corp. fell 3.75 percent to NT$14.10.
Chiang said investors should watch closely to see how foreign institutional investors cut their holdings after the Wall Street losses.
"If foreign selling accelerates, it is possible that the local bourse will test the psychological 7,000 mark soon," Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: More sense less party scheming on ECFA referendum
DOC.DATELINE: 06/07/10 11:12:24 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: We think the Cabinet's Referendum Review Committee made the right decision to reject a proposal by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for a referendum on whether Taiwan should sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The TSU, which has been outspoken in its opposition to the ECFA, accused the committee of attempting to block the referendum. However, we noticed that the party worded the referendum question in the affirmative, a linguistic trick that we think was meant to confuse voters.
If the TSU wants the electorate to reject the ECFA, it should pose the referendum question in way that would require a straight yes or no answer.

However, we think that any referendum on the ECFA would be premature as the contents of the pact have not yet been fully worked out. There are still many details related to the ECFA that still have to be resolved, including whether or not it should be subject to legislative approval.

If the electorate wants a referendum on the ECFA, the proposal should be made though proper and rational procedures. We don't want Taiwan's referendum system to be haunted by the ghosts of crafty political schemes. (June 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Permission required for development of hillside land: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/10 11:30:13 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Monday that official approval will now be required for the development of hillside land in Taiwan, whether for agricultural or other purposes.

With the approach of the rainy season in Taiwan, Lee Chen-yang, deputy director- general of the COA's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, called on farmers and developers to submit their plans for soil and water conservation in the use of such lands.

The screening plan is designed to ensure soil and water conservation on Taiwan's fragile land areas, lower the possibility of landslides and promote proper land use, Lee said in an announcement on the bureau's Web site.
Lee called for all those concerned to follow the rules on the use and development of hill-slope land. Violators could face fines of between NT$60,000 and NT300,000, he said.

Those whose development projects are found to have resulted in water and soil erosion or damage to water conservation facilities could face fines of up to NT$600,000 or a maximum prison term of five years, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Can suicide prevention system withstand test?

TEXT.P: A 9-year-old-girl helped save her mother's life last week by making repeated emergency calls to the police to tell them that her mother was about to commit suicide. Her precocious sense and courage are admirable, but the case has once again exposed the flaws and deficiencies in our suicide prevention system.

The "saving mother" case showed that there is ample room for improvement in suicide reporting, assessment and care. Police, firefighting and medical staff should also be trained to be more sensitive to possible suicides.
The case last week, coupled with the deaths of a fifth grader and her mother in a familicide tragedy, also reflects the government's incompetence in dealing with high-risk family problems.

Inter-agency coordination and enforcement are badly needed to help disadvantaged families and to prevent suicides. The government should also make an overall review of the allocation of its suicide prevention budget. Usually, a large amount of money is spent on data analysis and hosting seminars and overseas survey trips, which defeats the purpose of the funds.
The budget should be used to train those on the frontline of suicide prevention, including teachers, borough chiefs and police officers.
More importantly, a special bill on suicide prevention and control should be enacted to provide a solid and comprehensive legal basis for various suicide prevention operations.
With suicide being one of the top 10 causes of death in Taiwan for 13 consecutive years, we should not continue to drag our feet on such legislation. (June 7, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/10 11:54:45 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.442 at 10 a.m. Monday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.092 from Friday's close.
