DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank auctions out another NT$100 billion in NCDs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 16:30:50 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank auctioned out another NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion) in 364-day negotiable certificates of deposit (NCDs) Friday as part of its ongoing efforts to withdraw excess liquidity from the market.
This marks the third consecutive month in which 364-day NCDs have been issued by the central bank. Certificates worth NT$100 billion were also auctioned out in April and May.
According to the bank, issuing short-term and long-term NCDs has the same effect as raising the reserve requirement.
It is estimated that draining NT$300 billion through the issuance of NCDs is equal to increasing the reserve ratio by more than 1 percentage point.

DOC.HEADLINE: Turkish diplomat to join Taiwan World Cup
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11(CNA) 06/11/10 16:32:05 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Ali Demirtas, the deputy representative from the Turkish Trade Office in Taiwan, told the Central News Agency Friday that he will participate in a mini-World Cup in Taipei on June 16.

Despite having undergone four surgeries on his toes, Demirtas said he would never give up playing and that he had been training heavily for weeks to participate in the Taiwan World Cup at Ying Feng Riverside Park on June 16.
The tournament, which was originally scheduled for June 5 but was delayed due to rain, hopes to feed on excitement over the 2010 FIFA World Cup in South Africa, which opens on June 11.

Demirtas said that when he was working in South Korea, he couldn't find anyone to play football with in the beginning, but he eventually managed to put together a team with players from around the world after calling for football lovers in a newspaper advertisement.
The first ever Taiwan World Cup, organized by British banker Russel Curtis, will gather 16 teams of players residing in Taiwan with different nationalities and occupations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists urge EPA to follow normal assessment process
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 16:59:56 (By Lee Shien-feng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Environmental protection groups held a flash mob protest Friday in front of the Presidential Office, calling on the government to draw a clear line between government and business and to respect the normal environmental impact assessment process for a petrochemical park project.

Gan Chen-yi, a spokesman for Taiwan Matsu's Fish Conservation Union, said the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has held intensive meetings on issues related to the Kuokuang Petrochemical Park development project in central Taiwan's Changhua County.

Last week, a meeting was held on the possible impact of the project on the coastal topography in the area. This week, three experts meetings were convened on the possible impact of the project on dolphins, water resources and human health, according to Gan.
The frequency and intensity of the meetings has broken all records, including the weekly meetings that preceded the fourth phase of the Central Science Park development project, Gan said.
The EPA's move to speed up the environmental assessment process for the project was made under the instruction of Premier Wu Den-yih to allow the construction of the project to go ahead as planned.

Wu's order came after a threat from Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co. in May that private investors will withdraw their funds from the project if it fails to pass the EPA environmental assessment at the end of this year.

Some of the environmentalists who showed up at the flash mob event said that President Ma Ying-jou came up with the line of saving the country through environmental protection, but he was mouthing only empty platitudes as the government is only serving the interests of a few business conglomerates.
They said they therefore staged the protest to demand that the government match its deeds to its words and to impose strict restrictions on high-polluting industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei exchange
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 17:04:49 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, dropping NT$0.051 to close at NT$32.439.
Turnover totaled US$906 million dollars during the trade.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.490, and then moved to a low of 32.240 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor urges Hong Kong residents to visit Flora Expo
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 17:18:39 (By Stanley Cheung and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei City is inviting Hong Kong residents to attend the six-month International Flora Expo that will open on Nov. 6 and to visit some of the other attractions in the city, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday.
Hau, who is in Hong Kong to promote the flora expo, said visitors can expect to see new developments in horticulture and advanced green technologies at the flower show.
To date, 45 countries have confirmed their participation in the flora expo, which will be one of the biggest in the world, he said.
Two Taiwanese carriers, China Airlines and Eva Airways, have said they will offer discount fares for Hong Kong travelers to Taipei during the flower show.
Telling his audience that he feels at home whenever he is in Hong Kong, Hau said he thinks Hong Kong visitors visiting Taipei will feel the same, as the two cities have similar cultures.

Hong Kong entertainer Jaycee Chan, son of actor Jackie Chan, said at the promotional event that he would fly to Taipei just for Taiwan's famous beef noodles and that he would recommended the city to other Hong Kong residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer shares sharply higher on strong May sales
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 17:32:40 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of personal computer vendor Acer Inc. closed sharply higher Friday after its robust May figures boosted buying, overcoming concerns over reduced consumption in Europe, dealers said.
Acer rose 3.13 percent at NT$79.20 (US$2.44) with 20.39 million shares changing hands, while the weighted index closed up 1.63 percent at 7,299.49.
The world's largest notebook computer vendor posted NT$50.49 billion in sales for May, up 36.38 percent from April and up 45.29 percent from a year earlier.
"The figures did surprise me, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
"The May sales showed Acer was not affected by falling demand from Europe amid lingering debt worries, but shipments of its rivals are weakening," he said.
AsusTek Computer reported a 22 percent decline in May sales from April, while Quanta Computer recorded a 4.7 percent fall.
An analyst with a regional brokerage pointed out that Acer posted a 17 percent decline in April from March after the European debt crisis surfaced.

"Acer's performance in April and May was not consistent. We need more sales figures to determine whether Acer will be able to weather the weakness of the euro," said the analyst, who requested anonymity.
The analyst added that she suspected Acer's May figure came after the company delayed deliveries from April to May.

In the first quarter, Acer ranked the largest PC computer vendor in Western Europe, taking a 23.4 percent share of the market, according to Gartner Inc., a U.S.-based information technology research firm.
Tang said Acer's performance on Friday largely came from bargain hunters after a recent sell-off.
"They just needed an excuse to buy stocks, and the May sales figures provided them with the chance," Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president offers to wire more money back in return for release
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 18:08:03 (By Lai You-chia and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former president Chen Shui-bian, who has been in detention since Dec. 30, 2009 in connection with corruption, forgery and money laundering charges, promised Friday to wire more of his overseas funds back to Taiwan if the court releases him.

In his oral plea for release on bail, the former president told the Taiwan High Court that he will wire another NT$570 million back to Taiwan in addition to the US$21 million that the court is seeking to confiscate from the former first family.

During a hearing on his request for release on bail, Chen thanked the court for cutting his sentence from life imprisonment to 20 years. He said he appreciated the court's refusal to grant the prosecutors' request for the harshest penalty to be handed down to him or for lower court's sentence to be upheld.
"It gave me hope that the court will free me to allow me to clear my name though the justice system," Chen said.

He said that his family has NT$570 million in the Wegelin bank in Switzerland, in addition to funds in Merrill Lynch Bank and Royal Bank of Scotland in that country. If he is released, he said, he will complete the paperwork to transfer the Wegelin bank funds to Taiwan within one week.
"All of that money was political contributions from my supporters and has nothing to do with the charges against me, " the former president said.

Regarding the US$21 million deposits at Merrill Lynch Bank and Royal Bank of Scotland, one of Chen's lawyers said US$14.52 million has already been remitted to Taiwan as requested by prosecutors, and the balance has been frozen by Swiss authorities.
The attorney said the prosecutors' claim that Chen would try to flee the country if he was released cannot hold water.
The prosecutors have asked the court to keep Chen in custody to ensure that he serves his full sentence when the trials end.

The high court, which had suggested during its hearing of Chen's appeal that it might favorably consider his request for bail if he transfers his overseas funds back to Taiwan, ordered that he be remanded in custody while he is awaiting the ruling.
The court will decide before June 23, when Chen's detention period expires, whether to detain him for another two months.
Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen were accused of accumulating about NT$1 billion in embezzled public funds and bribes during Chen's terms as president.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police seize fake red-label rice wine and kaoliang
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 18:21:42 (By Cheng Che-fon and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Police arrested 12 people for allegedly making fake red-label rice wine and Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor, confiscating more than 9,000 bottles of counterfeit brand-name beverages, officials said Friday.

Police said that the fakes look almost the same as the real ones, and even carry labels adopted by Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corporation late last year to distinguish counterfeits from genuine products.

A total of 7,610 bottles of fake red-label rice wine, 1,197 bottles of fake Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor and more than 500 bottles of other fake drinks were seized at various places on Wednesday, police said.
The fakes were inferior, police said, and samples have been sent for examination to see if they contain hazardous substances.
Police said that the fake wines were mostly sold to restaurants serving ginger duck and goat hot pots, small shops, street vendors and local traditional markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Special entertainment business' cools off under police crackdown
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 18:40:14 (By Chen Chao-fu, Huang Hsu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Public places providing "special entertainment services, " such as KTV lounges, massage parlors, pubs and video game arcades were affected Friday by a nationwide police crackdown on gangster activity.

Many of these businesses in the Taipei and Kaohsiung metropolis areas were found to have far fewer customers than usual during surprise checks by police in the early hours of the morning, according to local police.

The checks were part of a joint crackdown launched by the Ministry of the Interior the previous day in an attempt to improve social order in the wake of recent public outrage at police involvement in gang-related activities.

The Kaohsiung City Police Bureau said its officers had raided 309 special businesses notorious as gangster hangouts, taking into custody more than 80 people suspected of violence or drug-related crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: S&P upgrades long-term credit outlook for Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 19:11:17 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services has upgraded its outlook on Taiwan's long-term sovereign credit rating to stable from negative on optimism over the prospects for sustained growth.
In a statement issued by S&P Friday, the rating agency also affirmed its 'AA-' long-term and 'A-1+' short term ratings for the country.

"The revision in outlook reflects our expectations that the Taiwan economy will build on its strong rebound from the recent slowdown to achieve sustained growth at close to a trend annual rate of 4 percent," said KimEng Tan, an S&P credit analyst.
"We believe that this will help to stabilize Taiwan's public finances by gradually bringing down the general government fiscal deficit," Tan added.
Taiwan emerged from a recession in the fourth quarter of 2009 after its economy contracted by a record 9.06 percent in the first quarter of the year amid a global financial meltdown.

In May, Taiwan's government raised its forecast for economic growth in 2010 to 6.14 percent from a previous estimate of 4.72 percent after the country's economy grew 13.27 percent in the first three months of 2010, the highest rate of quarterly growth since Q3 1978.
"The stable outlook reflects our expectation that sustained growth will contribute to the stabilization of the government's fiscal position in the coming three-to-five years," said Tan.
S&P said that because Taiwan has a strong external balance sheet, a dynamic private sector and abundant domestic liquidity, it can fund government deficits through domestic channels.
Those strengths were tempered, however, by a high government debt burden and high structural deficits relative to similarly rated peers, the rating agency said.

Taiwan's outstanding government debt totals NT$4.2 trillion (US$130 billion) , roughly 32 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) . The figure is expected to rise to NT$4.5 trillion next year, or about 35 percent of GDP.
The government has repeatedly said its finances are tight but stable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien, Miaoli most satisfied with leaders' tourism efforts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 19:35:57 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: Hualien and Miaoli residents are more satisfied with their leaders' efforts to promote tourism than any other people in Taiwan, according to a survey conducted by a local magazine.

"I hope this survey's results can stimulate tourism, a pollution-free industry, in every city and county in Taiwan, " Hsia Chen, president of China Times Weekly magazine, said at an award ceremony Friday.
Thanks to government efforts, the number of foreign visitors in 2009 reached almost 4.4 million, the highest in the Asia Pacific region, Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-General Wu Chao-yen said.
Visitor numbers hit a record high of more than half a million in each of the past three months, Wu added.
According to the survey, people are most satisfied in the eastern county of Hualien, the northern county of Miaoli, Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County, and Tainan City in southern Taiwan.
Taipei City did not make the top 10, despite city government efforts to promote the upcoming international Flora Expo.
The survey, which Hsia said was part of the company's 60th anniversary celebrations, was conducted between May 12-28 among 20,495 citizens from 25 cities and counties in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Indonesia to discuss prevention of foreign worker abuse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 19:49:29 (By Wang Shu-Fen and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan will lead a delegation to Jakarta June 17 mainly to discuss how Taiwan and Indonesia can work together to bridge cultural gaps and prevent inhumane treatment of Indonesian workers in Taiwan, the CLA said Friday.
Indonesian labor authorities became concerned about working conditions in Taiwan after a case of a Taiwanese employer forcing Indonesian Muslim workers to eat pork was revealed in May.
At the upcoming meeting, labor officials of both countries will discuss how best to improve understanding of cultural differences and prevent abuse of foreign workers.

They will also review the progress of plans agreed on in their last meeting in 2008, including the decisions to lower the fees of job brokers and to expand the direct employment system to include, not just caregivers, but all categories of Indonesian workers.
Of the approximately 360,000 foreign workers currently in Taiwan, 140,000 are Indonesians, who make up the biggest group.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises Taipei County's English program
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 19:55:15 (By Sunrise Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Friday praised Taipei County for its efforts to promote language education.

At the opening of the Guangfu branch of the English Express Wonderland in Banciao, Taipei County, Ma greeted students in English and said that with about 500 million speakers, English was second only to Mandarin, which he said has over 800 million speakers. The Taipei County government's decision to emphasize English learning was correct, he said.

Ma said that aside from developing early learning programs and learning-friendly environments, English teaching institutes should work to infuse international perspectives into courses and promote the universal values of mutual respect and cultural diversity.
He said that in addition to English, Taipei County is also putting emphasis on people's mother tongues and the learning of Chinese language and literature.

Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei described teaching as a "profession that can touch the hearts of people around the world" and said the county is working to promote English education through language immersion and the use of vivid teaching methods.

The Taipei County government has commissioned private English teaching institutions for the establishment of the English Express Wonderland, which hires licensed foreign language instructors to teach students in a total immersion learning environment.
The project also has branches in Shihmen and Pinglin townships.
The Guangfu branch offers courses ranging from American football and digital photography to a class that teaches students an English version of Sun Yat-sen's "three principles of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: World renowned Dominican Republic dance troupe to make Taiwan debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 20:12:32 (By Chung Hsing-hsien and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A reputed dance troupe from the Dominican Republic will tour Taiwan in mid-June to give Taiwan's people a greater appreciation for the Caribbean country's art and culture, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
The MOFA has invited the 25-member "Ballet Folklorico Nacional Dominicano" to give four performances of "Pasion Criolla" around Taiwan between June 16-19.
The performances will be staged in Yilan County, Taipei City, Kaohsiung City and Taichung City on consecutive days.

"Criolla" describes the Dominican Republic's special mix of Spanish and African influence that combine to create a special local culture, consisting of romantic and passionate musical and dance styles, such as the merenge and bachata, the MOFA said.
The troupe, which is being led on its first trip to Taiwan by deputy culture minister Bernarda Jorge, will dance to 11 songs expressing love, celebration, nostalgia and national passion.
Josefina Minino, the current head of the Ballet Folklorico Nacional, has infused modern elements into traditional folk dances to help make the troupe the representative dance group in the country.
Minino has been devoted to the performing arts for more than 50 years, and she was recognized by the Dominican Republic's Congress in 2006 for her contribution to the field, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports to PIIGS only accounts for 1.6% of total: ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 20:17:41 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to Europe's PIIGS countries (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece and Spain) totaled US$1.72 billion in the first five months of this year, accounting for 1.6 percent of the country's total exports, the Ministry of Finance said Friday.
Taiwan exported a total of US$109.3 billion in goods in the first five months, up nearly 53 percent from the same period last year.
Exports to all of Europe reached US$11.5 billion during the five-month period, representing 40.4 percent growth year-on-year, while imports from Europe increased by 59.3 percent to US$10.1 billion.
Germany was Taiwan's biggest export market in Europe, with US$2.5 billion in exports between January and May, followed by exports of US$2.1 billion to the Netherlands and US$1.4 billion to the U.K.

Hu Chung-ying, deputy minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that only those countries and businesses relying on exports to Europe will feel the impact of decreasing European demand because of the debt crisis.

Taiwan's exports to Europe's PIIGS countries accounted for a very small amount of the total exports, and Taiwan's financial institutions have only US$4.7 billion in exposure to those five countries, Hu said.

"In fact it would be the best time for Taiwan, in steady economic recovery, to attract international investment, " he said, explaining that the European debt crisis had resulted in some funds seeking investment alternatives.

At the current stage, Hu suggested that Taiwan improve its investment environment to attract more international investors, as well as stimulate Taiwanese businesspeople operating in China to invest in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banking sector mergers a must for survival: local banker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 20:24:53 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Consolidation in Taiwan's local banking sector is essential for the survival of local banks in an environment where interest rate spreads are falling below one percent, a prominent local banker said Friday.

Victor Kung, president of Fubon Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's second-largest publicly traded financial holding company, said local banks will only be able to operate profitably in the future if they merge with their counterparts.

At present, fierce competition among local banks and the low interest rate environment are narrowing profits and present major obstacles to future development, Kung said in a speech at a seminar organized by Taipei-based Shih Chien University and the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance.

Narrowing interest spreads -- the difference between the rates at which banks lend and the rates they pay on deposits -- have particularly squeezed bank profits since the financial crisis in late 2008.
The excessive fragmentation of Taiwan's banking sector has also limited profit potential, Kung said.

Though the top five banks account for market shares of more than 80 percent in Singapore and South Korea respectively, the top five banks in Taiwan have a relatively small 43 percent share of the local market, he said.
"No one can earn enough to thrive unless they can expand their scale of operations through mergers to ease competition, " Kung argued.

Because state-controlled banks control half of Taiwan's market, Kung said they must play an important role in the sector's consolidation and should move toward privatization and mergers as part of a financial reform campaign.
While the Fubon Financial president advocated the approach, he acknowledged the process would be challenging because of the difference in corporate cultures between private and state-owned banks.
Fubon engineered such a union in 2005 when it formally merged its Fubon Commercial Bank with the publicly-owned Taipei Bank, which it acquired in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait conflict could be larger than Mideast wars: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 20:30:25 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: If there is going to be a conflict between the United States and China, it would start with Taiwan, and the scale of the conflict would be larger than the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, U.S. scholars said in Taipei on Friday.

"The rise of China will be one of the most important issues in 21st century U.S. foreign policy" and the Taiwan Strait is the core of potential conflict between the world's two superpowers, although the possibility is low, said Richard Bush, former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and director of the Brookings Institution's Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies.

Bush and Michael O'Hanlon, a researcher at Brookings Institution who specializes in national security and defense policy, were in Taipei launching "A War Like No Other -- The Truth About China's Challenge to America, " a book they co-authored in 2007 that is now being released in Chinese.

"As a defense analyst like many others in the United States who spent a lot of time studying Bosnia, Kosovo, Iraq and Afghanistan, these problems -- as bad as they have been -- are modest in scale compared to what the cross-strait conflict can quickly become, " O'Hanlon said.
Most Americans and people on this side of the Pacific Ocean were not aware of the potential size of the conflict, he added.

The risk of Chinese invasion of Taiwan is small, O'Hanlon said, because modern technology makes it unlikely that big ships could cross the Taiwan Strait without being detected. China is more likely to use a blockade, complemented by missile strikes and a cyber-attack -- a move that is "less threatening but in a more acute sense, " he said.
China would be able to carry out offensives against merchant ships during the blockade, cease the operation if the U.S. reacts, and re-impose it later, he said.

Contrary to what some people think, O'Hanlon said, China would not be able to take Taiwan by force easily because Taiwan has a "robust survivable commanding control." The survivability of Taiwan's air force, including its ability to repair airfields quickly, would be crucial in the early days of an attack because it could make it very difficult for China to carry out a successful assault. Anti-submarine warfare is also important for Taiwan, he said.
Meanwhile, avoiding conflicts is equally important, Bush said, because "when you realize modern war, you treasure peace even more."

Although the U.S. is bound by the Taiwan Relations Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1979, to provide Taiwan with arms of a defensive character and help Taiwan resist any force of coercion that would jeopardize its people, whether or not the U.S. would intervene in a cross-strait conflict has been much discussed.
Bush said that how the U.S. reacts would depend on who made the provocation, although he added that sometimes the definition of "provocation" is ambiguous.

Alexander Huang, a professor at Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies, said that as the Chinese economy is rising rapidly, it would not be wise for China's next generation of leaders to ignite a conflict.
"How Taiwan shapes up its China policy is more important, " Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No new conditions set for private school tuition subsidy: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 20:51:21 (By Lin Szu-yu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Education Minister Wu Ching-ji reaffirmed Friday that his ministry's plan to level the difference in tuition payments at private and public high schools will be implemented based on three factors that would exclude well-to-do families.

Wu said that in addition to annual household income, the value of real estate and annual interest income will also be factored into the formula to determine which families would be eligible to receive subsidies for private school tuition fees.

"When the ministry devised the plan to offer the subsides, real estate value and annual interest income were considered as factors to be used to determine eligibility, " he said. "These are not new conditions."

Wu's remarks came on the heels of his ministry's statement Thursday that the initiative will exclude families with an annual household income of more than NT$900,000, those who own three or more pieces of real estate with a minimum total value of NT$6.5 million, or have annual interest income of more than NT$100,000.
The Ministry of Education (MOE) first announced the new tuition policy in March, saying it will be a major step toward its goal of 12-year compulsory education.

Since then, many private high schools have been using the ministry's promise of subsidized fees in their advertisements, and some 10,000 junior high school graduates have been accepted to private vocational and high schools for the new academic year that starts in September.

However, the Cabinet announced early this month that families with an annual household income of more than NT$600,000 will not qualify for the subsidy. But amid public criticism of that decision, the income ceiling was raised to NT$900,000.

Under the policy, students in the first, second and third year of senior and vocational high schools and the first three years of junior college, whose families qualify for the subsidy, will receive around NT$17,000 per semester from the government. This means they would be left to pay only around NT$6,000 per semester, which is in line with the fees at public senior high schools.

According to the MOE's initial estimates, raising the annual household income ceiling to NT$900,000 will allow an additional 40,000 students to receive the subsidy, instead of the 120,000 originally estimated.

When added to the 170,000 students who receive tuition waivers or reductions under various programs, it will bring the number of private school students at that level receiving subsidies to 330,000, which is 70 percent of the total number attending such schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stricter 'embezzlement' standard leads court to cut Chen's sentence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 21:00:23 (By An Chih-hsien and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court reduced the sentence of former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife on appeal in a corruption case because it used a tighter standard than a lower court in defining what constituted "embezzlement," the court said Friday.

Chen and wife Wu Shu-jen were found guilty last September by the Taipei District Court of embezzling more than NT$100 million (US$3.09 million) from a special state affairs fund, receiving bribes worth NT$870 million, and laundering part of the money through Swiss bank accounts.

After Chen and Wu appealed the verdict, the Taiwan High Court upheld the convictions Friday but reduced their life sentences to 20 years in prison after concluding the couple embezzled less from the state affairs fund than the district court had ruled, presiding judge Teng Chen-chiu said.

Unlike the district court, which found that the couple had siphoned off NT$100 million from the fund designated for the president's discretionary use for official purposes, the high court said the couple embezzled about NT$14 million.
The high court determined that part of the funds deemed by the district court as being misused were actually allocated to secret diplomatic missions and therefore went to appropriate public uses.

Other funds that went to cover expenses in the presidential residence were considered by the lower court to be embezzled were appropriately spent, the high court said, because the residence is an official entity.

The former first couple were given life sentences and fined NT$35 million each by lower court for the abuse of the state affairs fund, but the high court cut the sentences to 14 years and the fines to NT$20 million.

On the charges of taking kickbacks in a Longtan land deal, the former first couple saw their 20-year imprisonment shortened to 12 years in prison, but the high court maintained the couples eight-year sentences for taking bribes after helping a businesswoman land the Taipei 101 CEO post.
The 18-year prison term for Wu for her role in a Nangang Exhibition Hall construction kickback case was reduced to 16 years.
Only Wu had been indicted of money laundering charges and the high court meted out a seven-month prison term for the wheelchair-confined former first lady.
The high court combined the sentences to a total of 20 years in prison for Chen and Wu.
Chen and Wu's fines were also reduced to NT$170 million and NT$200 million, respectively, down from the original NT$200 million and NT$300 million.
The period for which each of them will be deprived of their civil rights was also shortened to 10 years from life.
Chen has adamantly insisted on his innocence, arguing that he is the victim of efforts by incumbent President Ma Ying-jeou to punish him for his pro- independence stance.
According to his lawyer, Chen accepted the high court ruling with mixed feelings.

"He was not pleased by the ruling and believes he should have been acquitted, " said Shih Yi-lin. "But he also believes he has a good chance on the next appeal to the Supreme Court, so he was not especially upset."
Prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said they will decide whether to appeal the reduced sentences after receiving the high court ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Firms mull moving production from China to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 21:07:10 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A growing number of China-based Taiwanese companies are planning to move parts of their production lines back to Taiwan amid rising wages in China, a Taiwanese business alliance said Friday.

"It is obvious that the labor cost (in China) is no longer low," Taiwan's General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China said in a statement. "Taiwanese companies have lost their advantages in setting up factories in the mainland."
"Many companies are thinking about relocating some of their production lines back to Taiwan," the statement noted.

The statement came after Foxconn Technology Group, as the world's biggest contract electronics maker Hon Hai is known in China, and Japanese carmaker Honda raised their Chinese workers' pay to cope with labor disputes.
In the statement, the chamber urged the Taiwan government to help local businesses investing in China deal with the fallout from wage hikes.
The chamber also recognized the government's efforts in easing restrictions to attract more Taiwanese companies to return from China.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday that NT$22.1 billion (US$683 million) from China-based Taiwanese companies was invested in Taiwan between January and May this year.
The combined amount accounts for 58 percent of the ministry's goal of NT$38 billion for the entire year, the ministry said in a statement.

A cross-strait pact that is expected to be signed later this month to further liberalize trade could also prompt some China-based Taiwanese businesses to increase their investment in Taiwan, said C.Y. Ling, the director-general of the ministry's Department of Investment Services.

For example, Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding Corp., a Taiwanese-owned company that is the biggest maker of instant noodles in China, told Ling late last year that it might expand its production line in Taiwan and transport goods from Taiwan to its markets in central and southern China to save costs.
The ministry will organize a summit on June 15 to better inform China-based Taiwanese businesses on how to use Taiwan's research and development to upgrade their competitiveness.
Meanwhile, Chang Pen-tsao, the chairman of the chamber of commerce, told reporters before a seminar in Taipei that Foxconn's pay hikes could force other Taiwanese companies to follow suit.
"We don't want to see Foxconn's large pay raises trigger a domino effect that forces other companies to increase their workers' pay, " he said.
"Many Taiwanese companies might be forced out of business, as electronics companies' profits are already small," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Futures company in Taiwan to cooperate with Chinese counterpart
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 21:40:34 (By Tien Yu-bin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Yuanta Futures signed a cooperation agreement with a Chinese futures company Friday to take advantage of new opportunities in the cross- Taiwan Strait market and possibly set the stage for investing in each other in the future.
The cooperative arrangement with Hangzhou-based Yongan Futures is the largest strategic alliance between futures companies across the strait, Yuanta said in a statement issued Friday.

Because Taiwan's futures market has long stressed the development of financial futures, coinciding with futures development trends in China, Yuanta said the cooperative alliance between the two companies should be mutually beneficial.
Yuanta and Yongan also have similar levels of capitalization, making it easy for them to invest in each other or to form joint ventures, the statement said.
As a state-run company, Yongan has capital of 184 million yuan, and has memberships in the stock exchanges in Shanghai, Dalian, northeastern China, and Zhengzhou, central China.
It has 22 business outlets around China's coastal economic zones, in addition to a branch office in Hong Kong.
Yongan led China's futures companies last year in brokerage income and net income and third in trading volume.
According to the statement, Yuanta and Yongan will explore the possibility of further commercial cooperation once investment in futures companies across the Taiwan Strait is permitted.
For now, the two companies will share their experience in training staff members and may cooperate on futures consulting if approved by the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local leader elections to be held Saturday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 22:16:00 (By M. T. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Seventeen cities and counties across Taiwan will elect township representatives and borough chiefs Saturday, the Central Election Commission said Friday.
According to the commission, a total of 3,819 candidates will vie for 2,322 township representative seats in Saturday's elections, while 8,291 hopefuls will compete for 4,077 borough chief seats.

Similar local elections for wards in the five special municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- will be held on Nov. 27 as part of three-in-one polls. Voters will also elect mayors and councilors in the five special municipalities, four of which will be formed by upgrade or merger by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business in China difficult for foreign banks: local banker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 22:37:21 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A senior Taiwanese executive at China's First Sino Bank said Friday that despite the vast Chinese market, it is very difficult for foreign banks to do business in China.
Steve H. Y. Hsieh, who has served as CEO and president of the bank since 2006, said at a forum in Taipei that Taiwanese banks should not be overly optimistic about venturing into China.

Noting that the market share held by foreign banks is less than 2 percent, Hsieh said that although many Taiwanese financial holding companies think China offers tremendous opportunities, based on his four years of work experience in China, he feels business there is very difficult for foreign banks.
Hsieh said that as China has lifted banking restrictions only gradually, foreign banks in China have limited access to China's financial services market.

Despite acknowledging the difficulties, Hung Hsin-shih, vice president of Taiwan's First Financial Holding Co., said that Taiwan's financial institutions and banks still need to tap into China's market because Taiwan is saturated.

Taiwan's financial services sector hopes to be included in the "early harvest" list of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that will give it better access to the Chinese market.
The "early harvest" list refers to merchandise and services that will be granted tariff concessions or more liberal market access immediately after the ECFA is signed.
Victor Kung, president of Fubon Financial Holding Co., said earlier this year that the company hopes to set up 200 outlets in China within five to 10 years.
Taiwan's government began accepting applications in late May from Chinese banks wishing to set up offices in Taiwan or purchase stakes in domestic banks.

Shen Chung-hua, a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Finance, said Chinese banks' investment in Taiwan is aimed at attracting Taiwanese clients operating large companies in China, rather than local customers in Taiwan or China-based small and medium-sized enterprises. They will also target Chinese businesses with investments in Taiwan, Shen said.

By investing in Taiwan, Chinese banks could also acquire knowledge of financial services and hire local talent to set up footholds, Shen said. They will be able to gather credit information about Taiwanese businesses in China and use it to expand mortgage lending to those companies.

Chinese banks can also collaborate with foreign banks that have operated in Taiwan for years by gaining stakes or forming strategic alliances in order to gain access to more potential customers, Shen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yangmingshan butterfly season starts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 22:40:23 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A series of activities will be held this weekend in Yangmingshan National Park to mark the start of this year's Yangmingshan butterfly season, the park administration said Friday.

This will be the eighth year that the park administration showcases the butterfly season by organizing a range of programs and activities, most of which will take place in the Erzihping parking lot and the Datunshan recreation area, according to Lin Yung-fa, director of the administration.
Traffic controls will be imposed on the two sites from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. during June 12-13, Lin said.

Taiwan has more than 400 species of butterflies and 174 of the species have been recorded at the park, with 90 percent belonging to the Danaidae family, such as the purple crow butterfly and the chestnut tiger butterfly, Lin added.

The series of 15 activities will begin with an opening ceremony June 12. There will be shuttle buses running over the two days from Jhongshan Building and make stops near the Yangmingshan National Park Visitor Center and on Yangmingshan- Jinshan Highway.
Along the bus route, visitors can walk with the dancing butterflies during the butterfly season, which is expected to end in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: No plans to move forward nuclear plant opening: Cabinet
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/10 22:51:27 (By Lee Min-tsung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Safety is absolutely essential for the country's fourth nuclear plant and there is no timetable for it to began commercial operation, a spokesman for the Cabinet said Friday.

Johnny Chi-chen Chiang, the head of the Government Information Office, dismissed reports that Premier Wu Den-yih has asked the plant's builders to move ahead its scheduled opening from the end of 2011 to Oct. 10 to coincide with the country's 100th founding anniversary next year.

Chiang said that the premier was briefed by officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Atomic Energy Council and Taiwan Power Company earlier Friday on the construction progress and that Wu instructed them to control the quality of the building to ensure the safety of the plant.
Chiang quoted the premier as telling the officials that there is no point in cutting corners to move ahead the plant's opening, "as we've already waited more than 10 years."

Chiang said the premier has put Lin Join-sane, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, in charge of coordinating government agencies involved in the building of the plant to ensure it meets rigorous safety standards.
The spokesman made the comments after Legislator Tien Chiu-chin from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party urged the premier Friday to abstain from pushing for the plant's early opening.
Tien said the safety of the plant has been the cause of great public concern after its control room was gutted by a fire in March.
The Taiwan Power Company attributed the accident to an electrical short.
