The European Parliament, the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives, as well as 17 U.S. State Congresses, have all passed resolutions in the past few months in support of Taiwan's participation in the ICAO assembly that will take place in Montreal, Canada, while Taiwan's diplomatic allies Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and Panama have all publicly voiced their support, Hsu said.
She declined to elaborate in detail about Taiwan's efforts to secure the ICAO observer status.
Taiwan has been also working on the mission in the APEC Economic Leadership Meeting that will take place in Japan's Yokohama in November, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China to resolve Taiwan's FTA bids appropriately: negotiator
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 24 (CNA) 06/24/10 22:41:33 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior Chinese negotiator with Taiwan said Thursday that Beijing will resolve appropriately issues regarding Taiwan's desire to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with its major trade partners.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), made the remarks at a news conference held after the end of preparatory talks with Taiwanese negotiators for a fifth meeting between ARATS President Chen Yunlin and his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.
The main agenda of the June 28-30 meeting in Chongqing, China is the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which mainly deals with tariff concessions for bilateral trade.

In promoting the ECFA initiative, Taiwan hopes the deal with China will help convince its other major trade partners, such as the United States, Japan, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the European Union, to sign full- fledged FTAs or FTA-like agreements with it to facilitate its inclusion in mounting regional economic integration, particularly in the wake of the inauguration of the "ASEAN plus China" free trade bloc early this year.

Asked about China's attitude or position on the issue, Zheng appeared reluctant to go into detail and merely repeated previous statements made by other Chinese officials, saying that as far China is concerned, the ECFA initiative is aimed at forging a closer cross-strait economic cooperative mechanism and exploring a feasible channel to connect the cross-strait interactive mechanism with existing Asia-Pacific regional trade blocs.

Against this backdrop, Zheng said, China will properly address the issue to help create an environment in which Taiwan can tackle opportunities and challenges arising from growing cross-strait economic integration.

Earlier this year, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu was asked a similar question at a regular press news conference. At the time, Ma said China does not object to Taiwan developing non-official trade ties, but objects to Taiwan signing official agreements with other countries.
His remarks drew a strong backlash in Taiwan. Another Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Jiang Yu, later urged the media not to "overinterpret" Ma's remarks, in an attempt to calm the ripples.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to address Taiwan's post-ECFA global economic strategy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 24 (CNA) 06/24/10 23:11:04 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will deliver "in due time" Taiwan's global economic strategy in the post cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact era, the Presidential Office spokesman said Thursday.

Lo Chih-chiang said the president was glad to see both sides complete their talks on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) by late June as scheduled and to reach a mutually beneficial agreement.
But he also thinks the text of the ECFA, the "early harvest" lists and an agreement on intellectual property rights protection are only the "appetizer" of the pact and not the "main course."
In addition, the ECFA will only be part of Taiwan's global economic strategy involving cross-strait economy, Lo cited Ma as saying.

The completion of the "early harvest" lists, which form the backbone of the ECFA and which were unveiled that day, only shows that both sides have entered the post-ECFA era, so the president wants to present the nation's global economic strategy to the public in the post-ECFA era, Lo said.
In a meeting with Oliver Williamson, the Nobel laureate in economics in 2009, at the Presidential Office earlier that day, Ma said the signing of the ECFA is only a first step.

The ECFA, that will allow tariffs on certain Taiwanese exports to China to be reduced to zero within two years after it takes effect, will make more Taiwanese businessmen willing to return to Taiwan and will make more foreign investors willing to invest in Taiwan, Ma said.
Taiwan will also seek to forge free trade agreements with its major trading parrners, President Ma said.

Meanwhile that day, Vice President Vincent Siew said the ECFA will be similar to a pact China signed with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , but will not be like the closer economic partnership arrangement signed between Hong Kong and China.
"This is because Taiwan has insisted on the principle of parity," Siew said, adding that "Taiwan's economy will be transformed after the inking of the ECFA."
Siew said the items on the "early harvest" lists are not the result of China making concessions, but the result of China considering the principle of "division of labor."
Taiwan's list contains 539 items -- double the number of China's items -- with total exports worth around US$13.83 billion, nearly 4.8 times that of China's.

The ECFA is expected to be signed during the fifth round of cross-strait talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin that will be held in Chongqing June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 25, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th U.S. state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Co. turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was the supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia during World War II, the last viceroy of India, then the commander in chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration, and other elements.
1942: Maj. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of U.S. forces in Europe and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the U.N. Charter. The ROC, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain are made members of the U.N. Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second- place finish.
1975: Mozambique gains independence, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as U.S. secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news- gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua- lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
2000: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh is elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
2001: The Council for Economic Planning and Development announces that the government will encourage the formation of 50 private venture capital funds, totaling NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), to boost the development of the local bio-tech industry.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan shares open lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 10:16:11 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday from its previous close, moving down 80.17 points at 7,509.72 on a turnover of NT$3.16 billion (US$98.75 million).
The weighted price index gained 7.74 points, or 0.10 percent, to close at 7,589.89 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: ECFA challenge has just begun

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are expected to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) next week after finalizing their respective "early harvest" lists Thursday.

The signing of the ECFA is not a panacea that will automatically reactivate Taiwan's economic engine and create a "golden decade." The government needs to continue to work to improve Taiwan's investment environment, enhance its economic fundamentals and reduce unemployment.

Although the ECFA will benefit 539 Taiwanese export items, it will also open Taiwan's market to 267 Chinese products. Finding ways to expand Taiwan's gains and reduce its losses is an immediate problem that the government needs to face.

The government should also take into account the possible political repercussions, because any negative impact of the ECFA will be scrutinized under a magnifying glass by its opponents. Another challenge facing the government is whether it can conclude free trade agreements with other countries after the ECFA takes effect.

Following the signing of the ECFA, Taiwan will certainly benefit more from closer economic and trade ties with China. The biggest challenge facing the anti-ECFA Democratic Progressive Party is whether it can present a new and convincing argument with regard to Taiwan's ties with China. (June 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese tennis player advances at Wimbledon
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 24 (CNA) 06/25/10 10:38:07 (By Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun added another record to his tennis career by defeating a U.S.-French pair together with his Serbian partner Janko Tipsarevic to advance to the second round of the male doubles at Wimbledon Thursday.
Lu and Tipsarevic beat James Cerretani of the United States and his French colleague Jeremy Cardy 6-4, 6-4, 7-6.

After achieving a career high by reaching the third round of the male singles at the venerable grand slam for the first time, 27-year-old Lu, touted as Taiwan's best male singles tennis player, compounded his success in the doubles competition.
Lu told CNA that it was the first time he had been teamed with Tipsarevic at Wimbledon, although the two played together at the Australian Open in January but failed to get through the first round.
He said he was very satisfied with their performance Thursday. "Except for the third set, we controlled almost the whole game, " he said.

"We bolstered each other on court, " Lu went on, adding that he did not feel great stress while playing. "We both concentrated on playing and did not spent much thought on winning or losing, " he said.

Lu was scheduled to play against the unseeded but dangerous Florian Mayor of Germany the following day in the third round of the male singles. He said the doubles match had helped him stay in fighting form.
Meanwhile, on the women's singles battlefield, Taiwan's Chang Kai-chen lost 4-6, 3-6 to third-seeded Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark in the second round.
It was Chang's first time playing at Wimbledon and despite her defeat, the 19 -year-old said she was satisfied with her performance.
"I enjoyed the feeling of playing on Centre Court. I fell, but I am astonished at how well I performed today," she said.
Playing on Centre Court was "a good chance to learn and is something I'll never forget," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Many birds with one stone

TEXT.P: In a surprise move, Taiwan's central bank announced a 0.125 percentage point increase in its discount rate Thursday.
The decision will inevitably put pressure on financial markets, but it is a necessary step for economic adjustment. If managed properly, it can kill many birds with one stone.

In fact, the interest rate hike is the realization of the central bank's previous announcement in March that the quantitative easing policy was over. It displays the consistency and credibility of the country's monetary policy.

Another goal of the hike is to cool the red-hot housing market and deflate asset bubbles. The central bank is finally resorting to this means because the various measures adopted for this purpose since last November have produced few results.

The most immediate effect of the interest rate hike is a reversal of the negative real interest rate that has continued in Taiwan for a quarter. The hike will also help improve the difficult business environment faced by the banking and insurance sector as a result of low interest rates. (June 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Is rate hikes signaling crisis policy exit?
DOC.DATELINE: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) 06/25/10 11:44:25 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: unexpectedly announced a 0.125 percentage point hike in its benchmark interest rates Thursday, the first tightening since June 2008, with effect from Friday.
The central bank said in a statement that the rate hikes were taken amid signs that the domestic economy has surged back from the worst of the recession.
Market analysts said the surprise move could signal that the central bank has begun an exit from the stimulative policy adopted during the 2008-2009 global financial crisis.
The adjustment brought the CBC discount rate to 1.375 percent from a record low of 1.25 percent, a figure that had been kept unchanged for more than five consecutive quarters.
Two other CBC benchmark interest rates -- the secured accommodation rate and the unsecured loan rate -- have also been raised to 1.75 percent and 3.625 percent, respectively.
Besides raising interest rates, the central bank also announced mortgage-lending curbs for the greater Taipei area, out of concern about a possible real estate bubble.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Skyrocketing housing prices in the Taipei area have become a nightmare for residents. Starting Friday, loans extended by local banks to applicants to buy second houses in metropolitan Taipei and 10 cities in neighboring Taipei County will not be allowed to exceed 70 percent of the apprised house value.

Under this policy, those who purchase more than one house in Taipei City or Taipei County's Banciao, Sanchong, Jhonghe, Lujhou, Shulin, Sijhih, Sindian, Sinjhuang, Tucheng and Yonghe will be subject to the selective credit control and will not be allowed to enjoy any grace period for repayment or apply for housing repair loans.

It marks the first time since 1989 that the central bank has adopted selective credit controls on mortgage lending. Last time, the curb remained valid for 18 months. The duration of this round of selective controls will depend on market reaction, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said.

According to Perng, a large amount of mortgage loans are concentrated in the greater Taipei area, an indication that property investors tend to borrow money from banks to buy houses in the region, driving up prices.

As housing prices in the 10 satellite cities are still far lower than those in Taipei City, they are very likely to become a new target for property speculators, Perng said. Therefore, those cities have also been included on the list and are subject to the new credit control measures. (June 25, 2010).
China Times:

Perng said the central bank has repeatedly asked local banks to enhance their risk controls since last October and even asked them in March this year to lower mortgage lending ratios and raise interest rates for major property buyers.
This moral advice, however, has fallen on deaf ears in some cases, leading to a continued rise in local housing prices, Perng said.
To nip a possible property bubble in the bud, Perng went on, the central bank has been forced to adopt the selective credit control move.

By issuing clear-cut restrictions on loans to non-first-time home buyers, Perng said, the housing market should become less volatile. He also promised that the central bank will keep a close watch on local banks' mortgage loans to land developers and construction companies to prevent abnormal lending and maintain market stability. (June 25, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
Perng stressed that the interest rate hikes and selective credit control measures are not aimed at real estate speculators but rather at regulating risky lending activities.

The CBC's latest interest rate adjustments have drawn mixed reactions from local economists. Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the move indicates that the central bank is optimistic about the country's economic prospects.

However, Yin Nai-ping, a National Chengchi University professor, said it appears that the adjustments have come a bit too early because Taiwan's economic situation has not yet been fully stabilized and the global economy is still shrouded in uncertainty, including the eurozone debt crisis and the U.S. job market woes.
Moreover, Yin said, Taiwan's current recovery is mainly bolstered by exports to China, which will make the local economy more vulnerable to outside changes. (June 25, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese shippers to launch northern China-SE Asia services
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 12:29:34 (By Cheng Hseuh-wen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Evergreen Marine Corp. and Wan Hai Lines Ltd. will join forces to launch shipping services between northern China and Southeast Asia in July, in light of strong demand caused by booming trade in the area, a spokeswoman for Evergreen said Friday.
Evergreen Marine, Taiwan's largest shipper, and Wan Hai will take turns serving the new 28-day round trip route that will operate out of the Chinese port of Dalian.

"After China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) launched a free trade agreement (FTA) at the beginning of this year, trade in the bloc has increased significantly, " the spokeswoman said.

She said that with the FTA operational, ASEAN has replaced Japan as China's third-largest trading partner, and added that the economic integration in the area has paved the way for growing purchasing power and rising consumption.
"Booming trade in the area is an irreversible trend and we are witnessing rising demand for cargo deliveries in the bloc," she said.
Wan Hai will start the first service July 3 and Evergreen Marine will start its service July 17, she added.

The new route will start from China's Dalian, with stops in China's Tianjin, Qingdao, Hong Kong and Shekou, Indonesia's Jakarta, Port Kelang in Malaysia, Singapore, Tanjung Pelepas in Malaysia, Hong Kong and Shanghai before returning to Dalian, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The ever-heating housing market

TEXT.P: Taiwan's housing prices have continued to rise despite the various measures adopted by the government since late last year to try to cool the red-hot real estate market. The central bank on Thursday announced a 0.125 percentage point increase in its key interest rates and more control measures to further its efforts to curb property speculation.

As a matter of fact, land-hoarding by owners is the main reason behind the skyrocketing housing prices. The Ministry of Finance should impose an expensive "idle land tax" to force owners to release their land for construction. This method would resolve the shortage of land and eliminate speculation on higher land prices.
In addition, the MOF could levy an "empty home tax" to reduce housing speculation.

The Ministry of the Interior, meanwhile, should strictly require housing developers that have obtained construction licenses to begin their construction work within six months. Fines should be imposed on developers who fail to complete their work by the target dates. This would prevent the developers from deliberately delaying their projects, which causes supply shortages and pushes housing prices even higher. (June 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Local businesses must change operational structure: vice president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 12:41:44 (By Garfie Li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Friday that President Ma Ying-jeou hopes Taiwanese businesses will change their operational structures from contract to own-brand manufacturing in the post-economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) era.

To achieve this goal, the government and private enterprises should "be prepared mentally and should work out implementation measures, " Siew said at a conference in which he addressed Taiwan's moves to promote the signing of the ECFA with China.

He also reminded businessmen to be clearly aware that China is undergoing policy changes amid changes in its domestic market, in which wages are being hiked and calls are mounting for environmental protection measures.

Siew explained that economic development undergoes a transformation every 20 years and that China is at present going through its transformation, attaching importance to the development of new energy, new materials, biotechnology and cloud computing.

China appears to want to catch up with the developed countries while placing importance on domestic demand. As a result, it is attempting to get rid of its full dependence on exports and is hoping to narrow the economic development gap between its inland and coastal regions and between urban and rural areas.
Amid the changes in China, Siew suggested, Taiwanese businesses operating there should adjust their operational structures and perspectives.
ECFA, he said, comes "at the right time" because it will push companies to redefine the China market and initiate new business strategies.

The one-day conference on Taiwanese businesses and China's economic development was organized by the Institute for National Policy Research and the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: President getting fatter: hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 12:56:17 (By Garfie Li and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has put on some weight, which not only shows in his appearance, but is also confirmed by the results of his most recent health checkup, hospital officials said Friday.

Ma went to the Tri-Service General Hospital earlier in the day for his routine checkup, the initial results of which showed that he is now 177.5 cm tall, 0.5 cm shorter compared with the previous results, and weighs 72.7 kg, a 1.5 kg increase. His blood pressure was 126/90 mmHG, while his heart rate was 58 beats per minute.

Unlike previous presidents, Ma goes to different hospitals every year for his routine checkups. He went to National Taiwan University Hospital in 2008 and to the Taipei Veterans General Hospital in 2009.
The hospital said they would give the media a full briefing on the results later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation departs after ECFA-signing preparatory talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 13:53:22 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Vice President Zheng Lizhong left Taiwan after concluding negotiations on preparations for the fifth round of talks between ARATS President Chen Yunlin and his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Asked upon his departure from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at the head of a Chinese delegation whether he was satisfied with the results, Zheng said with a smile that the talks were "very good." He did not comment further.
The SEF and ARATS are two quasi-official intermediary bodies established to handle exchanges between the two sides in the absence of official links.

The primary agenda of the June 28-30 fifth round of Chiang-Chen talks in the southwestern Chinese city of Chongqing is the signing of two key agreements -- a wide-ranging economic cooperation framework agreement and an intellectual property rights protection agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA to be signed amid optimism, concerns
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 15:16:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China finalized details of a key trade pact Thursday to cut export tariffs and allow more market access to each other, but Taiwan's opposition is planning a massive rally Saturday to protest the deal.

According to President Ma Ying-jeou, the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) -- expected to be signed in the Chinese city of Chongqing June 29 -- will prevent Taiwan's economy from being marginalized in the process of East Asian economic integration and will help reduce Taiwan's jobless rate.
The Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research has said the ECFA could create more than 260,000 jobs in Taiwan and increase the gross domestic product by around 1.7 percent per year.

However, opposers of the deal, led by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , fear that the ECFA will make Taiwan, which exports more than 40 percent of its products to China, even more dependent on the other side of the Taiwan Strait and increase the unemployment rate when an influx of Chinese products and services jeopardizes local industries.

The DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a minor opposition party led by former President Lee Teng-hui which will organize Saturday's rally, will again demand a referendum on whether the deal should go ahead. Similar demands have already been rejected by the government.
The DPP said it was hoping to mobilize 100,000 supporters to take part in the protest.

The ECFA will be reviewed by the Legislative Yuan in an extra session in July. While the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has said the legislature can only decide whether it will ratify the pact or not, opposition legislators have insisted on an article-by-article review.

Another concern is whether China will stop interfering with Taiwan's effort to seek free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, especially its major trading partners such as the United States, the European Union and Japan, once the ECFA is signed.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, did not give a direct answer Thursday when asked about the issue, saying only that "China will properly address the issue to help create an environment in which Taiwan can tackle opportunities and challenges arising from growing cross-strait economic integration."
The agreement has been welcomed by various countries, including the United States and the European Union.

Meanwhile, a Presidential Office spokesman said the government realizes that the ECFA does not solve all the country's problems because local businesses will have to upgrade themselves after the pact kicks in to increase their global competitiveness. President Ma Ying-jeou will deliver "in due time" Taiwan's global economic strategy in the post-ECFA era, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shops selling falsely labeled goods will be punished: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 15:21:48 (By H. C. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Names of shops caught selling illegal products or falsely labeled goods will be made public on the Internet, government sources said Friday.

Huang Lai-ho, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the name of serious offenders will be published on the bureau's website starting in August.
Businesses failing to stop selling such goods will also face fines ranging from NT$20,000 (US$623) to NT$200,000, Huang said.
The bureau is Taiwan's authority responsible for standardization, metrology and product inspection.

The ministry set up a squad in early May to crack down on products with fake labels. Since then, law enforcement agents have seized a total of 14,137 substandard goods across Taiwan, ranging from clothes and underwear to bedding and shoes.
Six raids were launched this week alone, with agents seizing 1,759 falsely labeled products.

Huang said law enforcement agents recently raided a warehouse in Kaohsiung full of garments with the labels removed, a trick sometimes used to fool buyers into thinking counterfeits are genuine products that have been rejected by the company for a very minor flaw or for being out of season.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 1.51 percent on raised interest rates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 15:34:47 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 1.51 percent Friday after the central bank unexpectedly raised interest rates in a move to rein in soaring domestic property prices, dealers said that day.
The weighted index fell 115.18 points to 7,474.71 after moving between 7,463.29 and 7,537.37, on turnover of NT$87.82 (US$2.73 billion).

The market opened down 1.06 percent as market confidence was dampened by the 0.125 percentage point hike in the discount rate announced by the central bank the previous day, and selling accelerated during the trading session, led by property stocks, amid fears that the tightening monetary policy will hurt their bottom lines, the dealers said.
A total of 2,454 stocks closed down and 643 were up, with 210 stocks remaining unchanged.

The construction sector suffered the steepest decline, dropping 3.7 percent. Textile shares closed down 3.1 percent, plastics and chemicals, along with paper and pulp, each closed down 2.1 percent, the cement sector fell 1.7 percent and machinery and electronics shares lost 1.5 percent.
The foodstuff sector closed down 0.9 percent but financial stocks ended the day up 0.1 percent.
"The rate hike surprised many investors and was the last thing the market wanted to see, evidence of which can be seen in the amount of selling," Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said.

Huang said that prior to Thursday, the market had expected the central bank to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged, believing that it did not want to see any immediate rate hike to disrupt the pace of economic recovery.

Apart from the higher discount rate, the central bank also announced a ceiling on bank loans for second home buyers in Taipei and other major cities in the greater Taipei area to prevent property speculation.
"The central bank move shows that it is concerned about a possible property bubble. Before things got really bad, it had to take action," Huang said.

Among property developers, Kuo Yang Construction shed 6.75 percent to NT$19.35, Goldsun Development lost 2.81 percent to close at NT$13.85, and Cathay Real Estate fell 2.12 percent to end the day at NT$11.55.

"And worse, most of the recent U.S. economic data suggests that the U.S. economy will slow down in the second half of this year. Wall Street's performance has also worried investors here," said Huang.
"I do not expect any breakthrough in the local bourse in the short term. The index might continue to fall gradually to find new technical support," he said.

The financial sector outperformed the broader market, as the local financial services business has been put on Taiwan's "early harvest" list subject to easier market access to China under the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, according to the dealers.
Chang Hwa Bank rose 4.85 percent to close at NT$14.05, while First Financial gained 3.18 percent to finish at NT$17.85.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chicken chain to stop giving away toys with children's meals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 15:56:04 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) Taiwan announced Friday that from July 5 it will no longer give away toys with its children's meals -- a promotional method commonly adopted by fast food chains that has been blamed for encouraging unhealthy diets among children.
In line with the decision, the price of KFC's children meals will be reduced from NT$89 to NT$69, the company said.
Ku Wen-chen, a senior manager with KFC's public affairs department, explained that the new policy is based mainly out of environmental concerns, because most children already have a lot of toys.
"The toys obtained from fast food restaurants very often end up in recycling bins, so we think it would be better to set a realistic price to give back to consumers," Ku said.
KFC will also donate NT$1 for each children's meal sold to World Vision Taiwan to sponsor the charity group's meal delivery services for children living in remote areas, Ku said.

The decision came one month after a group of 17 legislators, led by the ruling Kuomintang's Chiang Nai-shin, signed a petition calling for a ban on toys given away with children's meals to address the increasing problem of childhood obesity.
Citing the results of a survey by the Bureau of Health Promotion, Chiang said the obesity rate among the 2-18 age group in Taiwan has risen from 6 percent to 25 percent over the past 10 years.
Another survey by the John Tung Foundation shows that approximately 30 percent of school children eat fast food four to five times a month, Chiang said.
Asked about the issue Friday, Chao Min-su, public relations manager for Burger King in Taiwan, said her company welcomes KFC's decision.

Chao also said Burger King is evaluating whether to stop giving away toys with its children's meals, although she added that even if it decides to do so, the measure will only be implemented next year at the earliest because the toys are purchased annually.
McDonald's, whose Happy Meals are very popular among children in Taiwan, declined to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rescuers overpower fishing boat hijackers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 16:45:04 (By Johnson Sun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration rescued a fishing vessel named Yu Chan Hsiang that had been hijacked by its Indonesian crew in waters off Pingtung, Taiwan's southernmost county, an official said Friday.
The rescue mission, carried out by a Taiwanese patrol boat, led to the arrest of seven Indonesian crew members, according to a spokesman for the administration's Maritime Patrol Directorate General.

The spokesman said the directorate general has been maintaining contact with the patrol boat on a regular basis to keep abreast of developments and the fishing boat, registered in Pingtung County's Liouciou Township, is expected to be escorted to Kaohsiung Harbor in the next three to four days.

Coast guard officers in southern Taiwan received a report June 23 from the Donggang Fishery Radio Station that said captain Tsai Kun-he and chief engineer Lee Hui-fa were threatened and held captive after a clash with Indonesian crew members. Their ship was 800 nautical miles southeast of Eluanbi on the southern tip of the island, the spokesman added.

The directorate general sent a Taiwanese patrol vessel carrying five armed special service officers and two inspectors to carry out the rescue mission later that day. The 51-ton fishing boat was not found until Friday, when patrol guard officers spotted it with a telescope.
The officers approached the fishing boat and overpowered the Indonesian crew after making certain that Tsai and Lee were safe, according to the spokesman.
After the coast guard officers brought the situation under control, however, Lee suffered minor cuts on his left arm from a crew member's knife when he tried to go to the toilet, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 16:49:22 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, losing NT$0.036 to close at NT$32.180.
Turnover totaled US$717 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.216 and moved to a low of NT$32.009 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mosel Vitelic sees limited impact from price-fixing settlement
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 17:01:14 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Memory chip maker Mosel Vitelic Inc. said Friday that a settlement it has reached with 33 states in the United States to resolve price-fixing allegations will have only limited impact on the company's operations.
Mosel Vitelic and five other dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip makers reached the US$173 million agreement to settle the price-fixing allegations with the 33 U.S. states.

The five other manufacturers are Micron Technology Inc. of the U.S., NEC Electronics America Inc., Infineon Technologies AG of Germany, Hynix Semiconductor Inc. of South Korea and Elpida Memory Inc. of Japan.

While Mosel Vitelic declined to disclose the share it will pay for the settlement, it noted that it has assigned an unspecified provision for litigation costs and settlement payments, and admitted that the litigation process in the U.S. has cost the company dearly.

The U.S. Department of Justice launched probes into price-fixing allegations involving the six DRAM firms in 2002, alleging that all six colluded to fix prices for their products between 1998 and 2002.
The 33 states moved to file a class action lawsuit against the six companies in 2006, claiming that the collusion had hurt consumers, state agencies, universities and other groups.

According to California Attorney-General Edmund Brown Jr., who was involved in the investigation, salespeople and management of the DRAM firms met frequently to exchange pricing information, and agreed to overcharge their customers.

Earlier this month, the Justice Department indicted Taiwanese flat panel maker AU Optronics and six of its executives on charges of price-fixing, but the company has repeatedly denied the allegations.
AU Optronics has vowed to fight the charges to clear the company's name and protect its reputation and credibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan firm to enter U.S. green energy market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 17:41:23 (By Han Ting-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A planned joint venture between Taiwanese lithium battery maker Amita Technologies Inc. and a U.S. counterpart, Gold Peak Industries North America (GPINA), will help give Taiwan the upper hand in the green energy market, analysts said Friday.

The joint venture -- a plant that will be established in San Diego, California -- will assemble lithium electrodes manufactured by Amita along with other components to make lithium batteries designed for use in electric vehicles in North America.

According to EnergyTrend, a research subsidiary of market intelligence provider TrendForce, the U.S. lithium battery industry is still in the R&D stage, with many problems needing to be overcome with regard to its commercialization capacity.
The situation in Taiwan is just the opposite, because Taiwanese businesses have mostly focused on production and have not invested so much in R&D, EnergyTrend said.
The joint venture, which was brokered by the governments of the two countries, will allow for a perfect division of labor that complements each other's strengths, the research organization said.

It noted that since 2009, the United States has injected US$100 million into a project aimed at building an electric vehicle industry. This year, the U.S. Department of Energy is planning to invest US$30 million in the setting up of charging stations to increase convenience for users and make the concept of electric vehicles more attractive.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady wows Italian children with storytelling
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 24 (CNA) 06/25/10 18:03:06 (By Huang Ya-shih and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady, Chow Mei-ching, enthralled Italian children Thursday with a Chinese legend during a storytelling session at a municipal children's library in suburban Rome.

Speaking through an interpreter, Chow told the story of how the 12 animals were chosen for the Chinese zodiac to a group of young children, using lively body language to increase the children's interest and understanding.

Her imitation of the sounds and actions of the various zodiac animals fascinated the children, who started off sitting quietly but later lost their reserve and some of them even ended up sitting in her lap.
At the end of her story, the children clamored around Chow, asking her which zodiac sign they belong to.
Following the storytelling session came a dance-and-sing-along routine in which Chow sang and danced with the children and their parents despite an injury to her waist.
At one point, a 7-month-old extended her hand to Chow from her month's arms, providing a touching photo-op when Chow took the child in her arms.

The library is exclusively set up for children and is the only facility of its kind in Rome. Despite its compact size, the library offers services not only to children but also to mothers-to-be and those with newborns.
The library's chief executive told Chow that the library is open nearly all year round. It has more than 6,000 books, including English, French and Spanish volumes, but no Chinese books.
Chow then presented scores of Chinese-English bilingual children's books published in Taiwan to the library.

In return, the chief executive gave Chow a hand-made photo album which she had made herself. On the first page is a photo of Italian children and the message: "greetings from Italian children to Taiwanese children."
Chow, who arrived in Rome Sunday in her capacity as honorary director of Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, was accompanied by Taiwan's representative to Italy, Yih Jung-tzung.
Cloud Gate performed its signature "Songs of the Wanderers" Tuesday and Wednesday at Villa Adriana in Tivoli, on the outskirts of Rome.

After the troupe performs at the Ravenna Festival in northeastern Italy June 27-29, Chow will also accompany it to the Grec Festival in the Spanish city of Barcelona, where it will perform its widely acclaimed "Wild Cursive" from July 1-4.

Chow began to assume the role as Cloud Gate's honorary director on its overseas engagements early this year when she accompanied the group on a tour of the United States and Canada in late January and early February.
Earlier this month, she led the Cloud Gate dancers on a tour of Russia, where they performed "Whisper of Flowers" at the 2010 Chekhov International Theatre Festival from June 10-13.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan holds off South Korea in U18 Asian basketball tournament
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 18:18:18 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's under-18 women's national basketball team held off a furious rally by South Korea to win its third consecutive game at the International Basketball Federation (FIFA) Asia U18 Championship for Women in Thailand Friday.
"I'm proud of the way the girls kept their composure," head coach Chen Mei-li said after Taiwan was forced to regroup in the final minute for an 84-82 victory after blowing a 20-point lead.

By edging the South Koreans, Taiwan virtually assured itself a berth in the final four of the tournament, which serves as a qualifying event for the FIBA World U19 Championship for Women to be held in Chile next year.
It will likely be joined by China, Japan and South Korea, because the other countries in the six-team preliminary round group, Malaysia and Kazakhstan, remain winless.
Taiwan will play China Saturday and Japan Sunday in the last two games of the preliminary round. The top three teams in the tournament will represent Asia in Chile.
Taiwan maintained a lead throughout much of the game and had a 70-54 advantage after three quarters.

But the Koreans mounted a 12-3 run in the first five minutes of the fourth quarter to pull close and actually grabbed a lead with 2: 45 left, behind three three-pointers from Cha Hongjin and nine points from Lee Seungah.
Chang Chi-fang paced Taiwan with a team-high 23 points while Lin Yu-ting had 19 points and Chang Yi-lin added 16.

The biennial competition had been dominated by China and South Korea, winners of 11 and seven U18 Asian titles, respectively, before Japan upset China to capture the gold medal for the first time in 2008. Taiwan has won silver and bronze three times each.
Twelve teams are participating in the biennial tournament, which runs June 23-30 in Surat Thani, Thailand. They are divided into two six-team levels -- the elite Level I and the qualifying Level II.

Teams play all other teams in their group, with the top four in Level I qualifying for the semifinals, while the top two Level II teams will play the bottom two Level I teams for a chance to enter Level I competition in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA may affect Japanese industry: Japanese media
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 18:31:16 (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Major Japanese newspapers said Friday that the preferential tariffs Taiwanese goods will enjoy once a trade pact with China is signed will be beneficial to Taiwan's companies, but may affect Japanese or South Korean industries.

Nihon Keizai Shimbun said that Taiwan's LED panel and automobile sectors, which could compete directly with those in Japan and South Korea, are not included in the economic cooperation framework agreement's (ECFA) "early harvest" list of goods that will get tariff reductions or exemptions.
But if more items are put on the list in the future, they will provide a boost to Taiwan businesses, the paper said.
To Japanese businesses, the inking of the ECFA will mean that Japan can more flexibly divide its production bases on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the paper added.
Sankei Shimbun, another Japanese daily, concluded that based on the information unveiled Thursday, the "early harvest" list is more favorable to Taiwan than to China.
It contended that the Chinese are accepting a pact that favors Taiwan with an eye on gaining leverage to move from economic integration to political integration.
Asahi Shimbun said that overall, China has made greater concessions, while Yomiuri Shimbun said the concessions could be seen as China's gesture to woo Taiwan back into its fold.

A total of 539 Taiwanese goods and services with an export value of US$13.83 billion are on the "early harvest" list, compared with 267 Chinese items that have an export value to Taiwan of US$2.86 billion.
With the completion of talks on the "early harvest" list, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are expected to sign the agreement June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan service sector may face boycott after ECFA signing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 18:34:01 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's service sector might face a boycott or resistance from its Chinese counterparts, although certain service businesses have been put on an "early harvest" list under a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, a China-based business advisor said Friday.
Taiwan and China Thursday exchanged their "early harvest" lists of items that will be subject to tariff waivers or easier market access under the trade pact.

Taiwanese investors will be allowed to set up wholly owned hospitals in major areas such as Shanghai, Jiangsu Province and Fujian Province after the signing of the ECFA, while Taiwanese banks will be granted preferential status compared with foreign counterparts, when opening branches or subsidiaries in China.
However, Lee Jen-hsiang, general manager of Kunshan-based Hamber Consultant Services Co., said things are unlikely to proceed as smoothly as many Taiwanese investors are anticipating.
"The Chinese service sector will resist the opening out of concern that foreign investors will compete with them and take away their business," Lee told CNA.
"The signing of the ECFA is just a beginning. Taiwanese investors are still expected to face a great deal of difficulty getting into the Chinese market," Lee added. "It will take time," he added.

Lee said Taiwanese investors will need to take on bureaucratic red tape as they seek regulatory approval to open hospitals in China, adding that resistance or boycotts from Chinese hospitals could further complicate the application process.
He added that he does not expect state-owned Chinese hospitals, which provide poor service but enjoy a large number of patient visits, to welcome the competition from Taiwan.

While many Taiwanese banks are eager to set up footholds in China, Lee went on, it will not be easy for them to find good locations as most of the existing premier office space in major cities is occupied and unavailable to newcomers.

Lee said it is likely that Taiwanese banks will have to wait for two to three years until construction of new commercial buildings has been completed before they will be able to find suitable office locations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors file appeal against Chen ruling
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 19:16:33 (By Lin Chang-shun and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Prosecutors filed an appeal Friday against the Taiwan High Court's lightening of sentences in the case involving former President Chen Shui-bian, his family members and former aides.

Hours before the deadline for appeal, prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Taiwan High Prosecutors' Office presented their appeal against the High Court sentences for all of the 10 defendants involved.

The prosecutors said the judges, who commuted the punishment for most of the defendants in the case, gave conflicting reasons in their decision and applied the wrong articles of the law to back up their judgment.

They said the judges allowed Chen Shui-bian's defense that he used parts of his state affairs funds -- an allowance set aside for the president's discretionary use for state business -- for secret diplomatic operations. Secret diplomatic operations could be financed by other public funds, however, and Chen didn't need to disguise his spending by collecting invoices from others to claim reimbursement from the state affairs funds, the prosecutors said.

They also noted that the judges said Chen's confidant Ma Yung-cheng, who helped Chen claim reimbursement from the state affairs funds under the pretext of rewarding Chen's body guards, had created false private documents. But when the judges gave the reasons for Ma's sentence, they applied the rules for punishing an official who writes false information on state documents.
The difference between the court's sentences and reasons undermined the grounds on which the judgment was based, the prosecutors said.
Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen were indicted on Dec. 12, 2008 for allegedly accumulating about NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) in embezzled public funds and bribes during Chen's terms as president.
His son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and four others were charged with helping the former president collect the funds or to transmit them to foreign bank accounts.
Chen and his wife each were sentenced to life imprisonment by a district court, but the sentences were cut to 20 year prison terms by the Taiwan High Court on June 11.
Others who received jail terms from six months to 20 years by the district courts saw their sentences commuted by the high court, except for a cashier.
The cashier -- who was given immunity for testifying on behalf of prosecutors in the first trial -- was handed a seven-month jail term that is suspended for two years.

Chen Shui-bian and Wu Shu-jen denied the charges from the beginning of the trial, claiming that their funds were political contributions from supporters, and have filed an appeal against the Taiwan High Court ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to help sell more bananas to stabilize prices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 19:18:48 (By Lee Hsi-Chang and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) is set to help sell more than 8,000 additional tons of locally grown bananas by the end of August to further stabilize the price of the fruit, according to a statement released Friday.

The council has taken actions to battle a banana glut by helping to prop up prices since the middle of May, including the arrangement of group purchases, buying bananas for disadvantaged groups, stimulating banana exports and increasing the consumption of processed green banana products.

The council's Agriculture and Food Agency (AFA) said it aims to export 4,605 tons of bananas to Japan and 339 tons to China, and it will also encourage processing companies to purchase 2,633 tons of green bananas at NT$5 per kilogram.
The other 487 tons will be sold to the military, prisons and other government agencies, the agency said.
According to the AFA, demand for bananas has been affected by the harvest of many other summer fruits between May and July, which caused prices to drop.

AFA said the result of the council's efforts since May have been positive as the domestic price of green bananas rose from NT$3-6 to NT$6-10 per kilogram in June, while export prices rose from NT$12-15 to NT$15-20 per kilogram.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan Highway fully reopens to large vehicles
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 20:45:58 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The main road to Alishan, one of Taiwan's most popular tourist destinations, fully reopened to large vehicles Friday after being inaccessible because of serious damage caused by Typhoon Morakot.

Premier Wu Den-yih, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo, Chiayi County Magistrate Chang Hua-kuan and other local politicians braved heavy rains to attend a reopening ceremony at the main entrance of the Alishan National Forest Recreation Area.

The officials greeted groups of tourists who arrived in big tour buses at the mountainous recreation area in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, ready to take advantage of the road's reopening to large vehicles.

Addressing the reopening ceremony, Premier Wu said the government also plans to build a gondola or cable car system in the Alishan mountain resort area to offer another appealing attraction for tourists from both home and abroad.
The Alishan Highway, which serves as the scenic area's main lifeline, was seriously damaged by torrential rains and mudslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot in August 2009.
The foundations of two sections in the road -- at the 59 kilometer and 71 kilometer marks -- were washed away, making repairs difficult.
The highway reopened to compact vehicles last October and to medium-size vehicles last November.

Although large vehicles have been allowed to travel on the road since February this year, they could only go as far as the 66-km point. Passengers then had to transfer to medium-sized buses to reach the road's terminus -- the Alishan Forest Recreation Area.
Although the road has now been fully opened, work is still progressing in eight spots, and large vehicles will be subject to a 20 km/h speed limit in those sections, Mao said.
Tourism in the Alishan area was dealt a severe blow by Typhoon Morakot, which destroyed both the area's main road artery and its popular mountain railway.
Mao said he hoped the full reopening to large vehicles could revive the industry in the area.
It already received a badly needed boost when two sections of the Forest Railway -- the Shushan Sunrise-Watching Line and the Divine Tree Line -- resumed service June 19.

In addition to its existing "five wonders" -- the sea of clouds, the sunrise, the sunset, the mountain-climbing railway, and the forest through which the railway line winds -- the Chiayi Forestry Bureau that administers the Alishan recreation area said it has developed eight new tourist attractions to add to the area's appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's textile industry to benefit from ECFA: industry group
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 20:51:44 (By Huang Chi-kuang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share of China's textile market should increase significantly once 136 textile items benefit from preferential duties under a trade pact that Taiwan and China plan to sign later this month, a textile industry association said Friday.

The two countries reached a consensus Thursday that 136 Taiwanese textile items and 22 Chinese textile products will be among the items on the economic cooperation framework agreement's (ECFA) "early harvest" list, the list of goods that will be the first to benefit from tariff reductions under the pact.

The 136 items account for 67 percent of all of Taiwan's textile exports to China and represents the extent to which China was willing to open its market for Taiwanese textile products, said Huang Wei-chi, secretary-general of the government-backed Taiwan Textile Federation.
Between 2007 and 2009, Taiwan's textile exports to China totaled approximately US$2.8 billion to US$2.9 billion annually, Huang said.
China currently imposes import duties of 5 percent on Taiwan's chemical fibers and yarns, 10 percent on fabrics, and 14-18 percent on apparel.
In contrast, Taiwan levies tariffs of less than 3 percent on imported chemical fibers and yarns and less than 10 percent on fabrics, lower than those imposed by China, according to Huang.
Taiwan also imposes bans or restrictions on the import of more than 600 Chinese textile items, he added.

Because China will fully remove its tariffs for the 136 Taiwanese textile goods in three stages over two years after the ECFA takes effect, Huang expected that sales of Taiwan's textile products in the Chinese market will grow sharply because of lower import costs.
The growth could come from an anticipated increase in demand for Taiwan's fabrics from Chinese textile exporters or from China's domestic market, Huang predicted.

Regarding the 22 Chinese textile items that will receive preferential tariffs from Taiwan, Huang said they would not have a major negative impact on the local textile industry because they account for only 10 percent of China's total textile exports to Taiwan.

Despite the competitiveness of China's yarn manufacturing and its large scale of production, for instance, most of its yarn products are standardized commodities, in contrast to Taiwan's smaller production scale but more diversified product line, Huang said.
Manufacturers on the two sides could complement each other well, he believed.
Huang also downplayed the possibility that the higher number of Taiwanese textile products on the early harvest list would adversely impact China's textile industry.

He cited China's strength in the production of natural and chemical fibers, its large production scale, and the relatively limited value of Taiwan's textile exports to China as factors that would limit the impact of the deal there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau plans more area-specific forecasts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 20:52:16 (By Wang Shu-fen and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau and the Taipei City government signed a memorandum of understanding on Friday to build two temporary monitoring stations as a test of the bureau's plan to give more accurate weather forecasts.

The trial run of the planned system, which aims to give forecasts for more specific areas, will take place during the Taipei International Flora Expo from November through next April, officials said. Weather forecasts for the event's area will be available online throughout the exhibition to allow people to plan their visit accordingly.
The trial project aims to examine and improve the bureau's plan to provide forecasts in areas the size of townships by 2012.

The bureau's current forecast areas are based on counties, which cover a broad region. For example, the distance from the northern tip to the southern tip of Hualien in eastern Taiwan is about 137.5 kilometers, and the weather is often different at each end.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Hot pot's success built from night market stall
DOC.DATELINE: 06/25/10 20:52:53 (CommonWealth 448)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: High-end decor and consistent service are two of many reasons people are willing to make reservations two months ahead or wait in line for one and a half hours just to enjoy the spicy hot pots at Tripod King's Taipei branch.

Tripod King had its start in a night market in central Taiwan's Taichung City, where owner Chen Shih-ming spent six years running a stall and pondering his next step. After reading a survey saying three out of every 10 people like spicy food, he opened his first hot pot restaurant in 1997. Now the brand has five restaurants around Taiwan, with three in Taichung, one in the southern city of Kaohsiung and one in the country's capital.

As the head chef of Tripod King, Chen developed its spicy soup stock with a dozen vegetables, tea leaves, and more than 30 Chinese medicinal herbs to create a unique taste that stands out from most hot pot restaurants, which often make their stock with bones. He also insists on making ingredients like dumplings and other hot pot additives in-house rather than order them in bulk from wholesalers.

Chen's attention to detail includes restaurant design and choosing new locations. He said he has rejected more than 20 locations for minor flaws including noise, poor air quality or fire safety issues. Interior designer Lin Chin-lien said he once spent more than a month with Chen before deciding on a final design.
"I've never met a restaurant owner able to consider every aspect, including profitability per square meter, aesthetic and details of how the service is conducted," Lin said.

While Chen continues to look for a second location in Taipei, he is also venturing out to set up new brands and sell different kinds of hot pots. Wu Cheng-he, head of Providence University's Department of Tourism in Taichung, said the expansion will be a test of Chen's management skills and whether his team is ready.

DOC.HEADLINE: MECO celebrates 112th anniversary of Philippines' founding
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 20:56:51 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei celebrated the 112th anniversary of the founding of the Philippines Friday in a cocktail reception with diplomats from the Philippines and Taiwan calling for deeper and closer relationships under the new Philippine administration.
Benigno Simeon C. Aquino will be sworn in as Philippine president on June 30.

Taiwan "is our sixth-largest trading partner and our fifth-largest source of foreign direct investments. It ranks fifth in tourist arrivals and is host to almost 90,000 Filipino workers, of which 65 percent work in the high-tech manufacturing industry, " said Antonio Basilio, managing director of the MECO, the Philippine authority in Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic ties.

Basilio told around 300 guests, including Taiwan diplomats, businesspeople and foreign representatives in Taiwan, that 21 memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on a wide range of areas have been signed by both sides in the last five years -- evidence of a strong friendship.

Taiwan is keen to forge a closer partnership with its closest neighbor to the south because the countries "share the same democratic values" and the economies of Taiwan and the Philippines complement each other well, said Shen Ssu-tsun, deputy minister of Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Basilio and Shen both said that warming cross-Taiwan Strait relations have had a positive impact on peace and stability in the region and created new dynamics that favor economic growth and integration in the region.
"This has also opened new pathways of friendship and cooperation between Taiwan and the Philippines," Basilio said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ships 200 tons of rice to Haiti
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 22:23:18 (By Sunrise Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two hundred tons of rice donated by Taiwan's government and a local non- government organization (NGO) were shipped to Haiti Friday to help people affected by an earthquake that devastated the Caribbean nation early this year.

Liu Chi-chun, president of Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) , said the Council of Agriculture (COA) agreed to donate 200 tons of rice from the government stock to Haiti at the request of his organization.
The TRMPC has also helped raise NT$1.5 million (US$46,875) to finance shipping costs from Taichung Port in central Taiwan to Haiti, Liu said.
"The rice, packed in 10 containers, was delivered earlier in the day after passing a quality examination by COA officials," Liu said.
Since Haiti was battered by a magnitude-7 earthquake in January, Taiwan has offered humanitarian aid, including cash and medical aid, to its Caribbean ally, Liu said.
Over the past months, TRMPC volunteers have traveled to Haiti on many occasions to offer medical and health care services, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA to help Taiwan create 260,000 jobs: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 22:49:36 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that an estimated 260,000 jobs are expected to be created in Taiwan after it signs a trade pact with China later this month.

Wu was rebutting media reports that said the trade deal will cause 150,000 local people to lose their jobs, a day after Taiwan and China finalized the early harvest lists for goods and services to enjoy preferential treatment under the trade pact.

According to the finalized lists, a total of 539 Taiwanese products and services will be given tariff cuts or improved market access under the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , more than double the 267 Chinese products and services included.

At a ceremony to mark the reopening of the Alishan Highway to large vehicles, Wu said Taiwan managed to place more items than expected on its early harvest list and predicted the trade accord would help boost Taiwan's employment.

Wu also said that most financial and economic scholars in Taiwan and abroad predicted Taiwan would benefit considerably from the ECFA even though it may negatively impact some local industries and services.

However, the government has devised measures and earmarked funds to help sectors that could be affected by the ECFA to deal with the challenges and strengthen their competitiveness through industrial transformation and upgrading, the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government awards foreign suppliers US$520m in contracts under GPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 22:51:38 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government gave foreign companies 273 business deals worth NT$16.73 billion (US$520 million) in its first 11 months as a member of the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA) , the Public Construction Commission reported Friday.

Among the foreign businesses, U.S. enterprises won contracts worth NT$7.07 billion, or 42.25 percent of the total, followed by European Union companies at NT$6.28 billion or 37.53 percent, and Japanese firms at NT$1.86 billion, the commission said.
Taiwan, which became a member of the GPA on July 15, 2009, is obligated to open part of its government procurements to international bidding by suppliers from other members, the commission said.
As of the end of May, a total of 1,905 government procurement deals worth NT$244.57 billion were open to domestic and international bidding, according to tallies compiled by the commission.
Foreign suppliers won 111 contracts directly because they faced no competition, the commission said.
The deals won by suppliers from other GPA members were mostly those that local suppliers aren't capable of handling, it said.

The contracts that foreign suppliers received primarily involved the procurement of products, including the purchase by Taipower of electricity generators and components worth NT$2.43 billion from German suppliers, and NT$2.27 billion in electric power equipment and parts from U.S. suppliers, according to the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court clears six former navy officers of corruption charge
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 23:11:59 (By Chen Yi-wei, Lai You-chia, An Chih-hsiang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Six former Navy officers who were charged with corruption in the country's 1991 purchase of six Lafayette-class missile frigates from France were found not guilty by the Taiwan District Court Friday.

After a trial of almost 10 years, the court said there was insufficient evidence to convict retired Vice Admirals Lei Hsueh-min, Yao Neng-chun, retired Rear Admiral Wang Chin-sheng, and three other middle-level staff officers responsible for the acquisition of the frigates of corruption.
Lei served as the chief of the Navy's Warship Management Office at the time while Yao served as the office's executive director.
They and the four others were indicted in July 5, 2001 for failing to check the price asked by French contractor Thomson-CSF (now known as Thales) for the six Lafayettes.

Because of their dereliction of duty, the indictment said, the cost of the deal increased sharply from US$2.45 billion when negotiations on the deal began in 1990 to US$2.8 billion when the contract was sealed in 1991.
The prosecutors said in the indictment that the French contractor overcharged Taiwan's government for the warships and paid at least US$160 million in kickbacks to brokers to secure the deal.
Lei, the most senior officer among the accused, said he was glad the court had cleared them of the charges even though it took almost 10 years and Yao had already passed away.

He urged the prosecutors not to appeal the verdict to spare the defendants the ordeal of another time-consuming trial, insisting that they were innocent and saying the indictment was not supported by evidence.
The original indictment was controversial within Taiwan's judicial ranks.

Incumbent Prosecutor General Huang Shyh-ming, who was the chief of the Taipei District Prosecutors Office in 2001, revealed at a Legislative Yuan hearing recently that he lost the job because he refused to bow to pressure from then Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa to indict Lei and the five others in the case.
It was Huang's successor, Shih Mao-lin, who approved the indictment.
Both Lu and Shih have retired and didn't respond to Huang's claims.
The case came to Taiwan's attention in August 1996 when a court in Geneva, Switzerland ordered Thomson-CSF to pay self-declared middleman Edmond Kwan 160 million francs in commission for the sale.
Taiwan's judicial authorities were drawn to the court ruling because the contract for the frigates explicitly forbid commissions to be paid on the sale.

However, Taipei's attempts to track down the allegedly massive kickbacks were stonewalled because the arms broker believed to have masterminded the sale, Andrew Wang, fled Taiwan in 1993 before investigators could question him.
When President Chen Shui-bian assumed office in 2000, he ordered the reopening of the probe, which resulted in the indictment of the six Navy officials.

Local prosecutors asked Swiss authorities in 2001 to freeze the US$520 million in Wang's bank account and indicted him and his five family members in the case in 2006, but his trial has never started because he refused to return to Taiwan to answer the charges.

Prosecutors in charge of the investigation of the case said they could not convince Swiss authorities to transfer Wang's funds back to Taiwan unless they were determined by a court to be illegally obtained gains.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP reiterates anti-ECFA stance on eve of rally
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 23:25:34 (By Lee Ming-Chung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) said it will not waver in its stance that it is too early to push for a trade deal with China and that the government cannot resolve misgivings about the pact, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Friday.
Tsai's comment came one day before the DPP stages a major rally in Taipei to voice its opposition to the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Many DPP heavyweights are expected to take part in the rally. Former President Lee Teng-hui will also address the protesters, but Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair and Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih will not attend.
Su suggesting that the party has been ambivalent about the signing the ECFA.
Tsai accused the government of stressing the pact's "early harvest" list, calling "it a strategy of shifting the focus."
She said the real issue with the ECFA was its long-term and structural problems, and she challenged the government to tell the people about the impact of the pact on Taiwan a decade from now.

She also voiced suspicions that the list, which includes 539 Taiwanese goods and 267 Chinese goods that will receive preferential treatment once the pact takes effect, has "many things that have been beautified and we've also seen places where China deliberately made concessions."
The DPP wants to ask why China is making the concessions and its political motives, she said.
Meanwhile, the party has prepared 100 "Taiwanese vuvuzelas" to distribute among the protesters.
DPP legislator Gao Jyh-peng bought 200 vuvuzelas, the noise-making trumpet of South African football fans, from abroad for use at the rally.
But he said the vuvuzela required a lot of skill to use, so Taipei City councilman Chen Chien-ming commissioned a southern Taiwan plant to make a Taiwanese version.
Nearly 1,000 policemen will be mobilized to maintain order.

Meanwhile, the ruling Kuomintang on Friday suspected that the DPP was using Saturday's rally as a facade and that the real purpose was to build momentum for the five special municipality elections on Nov. 27.

While Taipei is swarmed with protesters, President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih will travel to southern Taiwan to review the results of post-disaster construction after Typhoon Morakot last August.
In the meantime, officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Mainland Affairs Council and Council of Agriculture will host ECFA seminars in northern, central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government awards foreign suppliers US$520m in contracts under GPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/10 22:51:38 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government gave foreign companies 273 business deals worth NT$16.73 billion (US$520 million) in its first 11 months as a member of the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA) , the Public Construction Commission reported Friday.

Among the foreign businesses, U.S. enterprises won contracts worth NT$7.07 billion, or 42.25 percent of the total, followed by European Union companies at NT$6.28 billion or 37.53 percent, and Japanese firms at NT$1.86 billion, the commission said.
Taiwan, which became a member of the GPA on July 15, 2009, is obligated to open part of its government procurements to international bidding by suppliers from other members, the commission said.
As of the end of May, a total of 1,905 government procurement deals worth NT$244.57 billion were open to domestic and international bidding, according to tallies compiled by the commission.
Foreign suppliers won 111 contracts directly because they faced no competition, the commission said.
The deals won by suppliers from other GPA members were mostly those that local suppliers aren't capable of handling, it said.

The contracts that foreign suppliers received primarily involved the procurement of products, including the purchase by Taipower of electricity generators and components worth NT$2.43 billion from German suppliers, and NT$2.27 billion in electric power equipment and parts from U.S. suppliers, according to the commission.
